row.field: Viewing Messages from Renters

##Renter messages
In addition to renters having the option to call or email a venue directly, they also have the option to complete a short form and send you a message. You'll know up front if a potential renter is familiar with your venue, if their dates are flexible, etc. Making it easier for you respond.
## Renters see this form: ![contact space manager form](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=400 "contact space manager form")
## And a confirmation message: ![renter message confirmation](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=401 "renter message confirmation")
## You receive an email like this: ![renter message manager view](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=402 "renter message manager view")
## And can view your renter messages in your Dashboard: ![renter messages in dashboard](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=403 "renter messages in dashboard")
Taking a Listing Online (or Offline)

**Online Space Listings** appear publicly in the directory and in search results.
**Offline Space Listings** can only been seen by Organization Administrators and website administrators.
This is how you publish or unpublish rental listings, and does not relate to the status of the space itself.
![Take Space Online](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=396 "take space online")
Responding to a Review about your Space

Renters have the option to rate and review any space in the directory. If your space is reviewed, you will automatically receive an email notification and a notification posted on the dashboard.
If you are an Admin for the reviewed space, you may write a response to the user's review by navigating to the URL of the review from the notifications.
If you feel a review of your space is inappropriate, you can flag it for review by a site administrator. If the review is negative, but not inappropriate it may not be removed from the site.
From your dashboard you'll see a link under the review to **flag it for removal**. Once you flag the review, a site administrator will be notified. They will look over the review and either remove it or unflag at their discretion.
![Flag Review](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=404 "flag review")
Examples of inappropriate reviews include:
* Reviewer has conflict of interest * Review consists of second-hand experiences or hearsay * Review contains personal attacks, threats, or hate speech * Review is not relevant to the space (this includes commercial solicitations) * Review is plagiarized or includes copyrighted material without permission
How To Get Boosted In Search Results

Nothing beats a complete listing in terms of being matched to renters in search results. When details are missing, the listing won't appear in search results at all when a renter uses a relevant search filter.
However, **SpaceFinder does reward boosted search result ranking for venues who have opted into features that offer added convenience to renters.**
##Search ranking order:
1. Listings w/ Space Requests + Online Payment enabled 1. Listings w/ Space Requests + View Calendar 1. Listings w/ Space Requests 1. Listings w/ View Calendar 1. All other listings
Because of alphanumeric order, renters have an easier time discovering you if you remove articles like "The" from your organization name and venue listings. When renters search, they look for the name "Fantastic Studio Space" not "The Fantastic Studio Space."
A high page ranking is great for connecting with renters, but keep in mind keyword searches disrupt the page ranking logic. Being strategic about keywords used in your space description and equipment inventories will increase your matches to renter searches.
TIP: With the exception of Online payment, which a small fee is associated with, all of the other features that get you boosted search ranking are FREE!
### Related Articles - [3 Steps to Uploading Your Calendar](/site/knowledgebase/3-steps-to-uploading-your-calendar) - [Space Request Forms](/site/knowledgebase/space-request-forms-features-benefits) - [4 Steps to Accepting Payment Through SpaceFinder](/site/knowledgebase/4-steps-to-accepting-payment-through-spacefinder)
Tips for Creating a Listing that Stands Out

Creating a listing that catches a renter's eye and keeps them coming back means being as detailed as possible about what your venue has to offer them. SpaceFinder has features that not only help you do this, but that increase the visibility of your listing in the directory!
![Top Three Listings in Chicago Directory](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=495 "Top Three Listings in Chicago Directory")
** 1. List Each Space**
If have multiple spaces for rent and you created one listing for all your spaces (theatre, studio, meeting room, etc.), you saved a little time but you're missing out on renters understanding the unique aspects of each space you have available when they use the search filters. Free listings are unlimited, and the "clone" duplication feature saves you time. List each space!
**2. Enter Rental Rates**
One of the top search criteria used by renters is rental rate. If you haven’t entered rental rates (at least a minimum or average) for your space, your space won't appear when renters search by rate.
**3. Add Photos/Videos**
Renters consistently tell us that photos are one of their most valued features in a listing. Help renters imagine their event in your space. Upload photos of empty space as well as your space in use. Have a great video tour of your space? Add that too!
**4. Promote Empty Time Slots**
Uploading your booking calendar Makes it easier for new renters to discover you by promoting your up-to-date empty time slots. All it takes is uploading a link to the digital calendar you use to manage your rentals.
### Related Articles - [Creating Multiple Listing](/site/knowledgebase/using-clone-to-create-multiple-listings) - [3 Steps to Uploading Your Calendar](/site/knowledgebase/3-steps-to-uploading-your-calendar) - [Hourly Rates Forms](/site/knowledgebase/hourly-rates-forms)
Hourly Rates Forms

## What is the hourly rates form? **The hourly rates form is more than how you display the cost of renting your space,** it is how you organize the ‘inventory’ of what your space has to offer. We understand rental prices are determined by a number of factors and have created a flexible form that functions to connect your space to renters narrowing down their search by rental rate (often a top concern for renters). ## Where do I input this information? **You can access this page on the left side of your dashboard under the ‘Manage This Space’ column**. Make sure you have selected all the possible uses for your space in the ‘Space Usage’ tab first (such as Rehearsal, Special Event, etc.) as the Hourly Rates form allows you to enter a rate for each Space Usage selected. ![space usage affects the hourly rates forms](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=410 "space usage affects the hourly rates forms") ## How do I fill it out? **You will need a separate Hourly Rates form for each pricing scenario in your space**. If everything is $20/hr all day, every day for any type of usage than you’ll only need one form. This, however, is rarely the case. Many spaces have weekend rates or early bird specials, and if the cost is different it needs a new form. Also, the price might differ based on usage. It is common for rehearsal and audition rates to be different, so each type of usage will need a new form as well. If that is the case AND you have special weekend rates than you’ll need a form for weekend auditions, weekday auditions, weekend rehearsals, etc. ![a sample hourly rates form](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=411 "sample hourly rates form") ### Related Articles - [How do I show a range of rental rates?](/site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-show-a-range-of-rental-rates) - [What if the hourly rates form doesn't fit my pricing model?](/site/knowledgebase/what-if-the-hourly-rates-form-doesn-t-fit-my-pricing-model--)
What if the Hourly Rates Form Doesn't Fit My Pricing Model?

## What are my options if my pricing doesn't quite fit into the hourly rates form? We understand there are many different types of pricing models. At the same time rental rate is often the most important thing to a renter looking for space within their budget. Think strategically about how you want to communicate and be found by your rental rates. Remember if you don't enter any rate info in your listings forms, renters searching by rate will not find you. If you don't communicate at least a minimum rate renters are more likely to contact another venue they know they have the budget for.
## Some options to consider: * Enter minimum rates in the form** and clearly communicate additional details in the basic description. This will depend on the type of targeted renter you want to connect with, marketing goals, and volume of requests you get for your space.
* Enter maximum rates in the form and clearly communicate additional details in the basic description
* Upload a document with additional rental rate details
* List a range of rates in the basic description
How do I Show a Range of Rental Rates?

The hourly rates form is one of the most important parts of your listing. While listing rates is optional, without them you will not appear in rental searches by rate. Beyond giving renters a guideline of what your space will cost, hourly rates perform the following functions:
1. Rates are displayed on the listing. 2. They're used in searches by rate. 3. Rates are also used to display availability when uploading a calendar. Rates are defined by time periods because they display when your venue is open and closed. 4. The rates are also used to calculate the cost for rental requests and receipts. This is why more than one number in a form field is not accepted because the system wouldn't be able to calculate a total.
In order to achieve maximum flexibility while still giving renters a guideline, spaces can have multiple hourly rate forms.
Each rate form is defined by the following criteria:
* **Days** the space is available, and the rate applies. * **Hours** the rate is in effect. * **Uses** the rate is permitted for. * And the cost of the **rate** itself.
##Hourly Rate Examples We understand that venues have different cost models for their spaces, so the hourly rates form has been designed with flexibility in mind.
For our first example, we'll use a studio that has one hourly rate the entire time it's open.
![sample studio hourly rates](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=417 "sample studio hourly rates")
* The studio is available 7 days a week from 10am-10pm. * The rate is $15 per hour with no special member or non-profit rates. * The only available use for this space are small group or one on one uses.
In this case. We'll only need one hourly rate.
Displaying a Range of Rates
Now let's take a space with three different prices depending on the usage:
I have three different prices for the space depending on usage: Rehearsal, Class, Anything Else (auditions, performance, special event, etc.) Each of these uses is more expensive on the weekends when the space is in greater demand.
**The weekday rates per hour look like this:**
| **Weekday** | **Regular** | **Nonprofit** | |-------------|-------------|---------------| | Rehearsal | $15 | $10 | | Class | $25 | $15 | | Other | $40 | $35 |
**And the weekend rates per hour look like this:**
| **Weekend** | **Regular** | **Nonprofit** | |---------------|-------------|---------------| | Rehearsal | $20 | $10 | | Class | $30 | $20 | | Other | $50 | $40 |
Because there are 12 possible prices for renters I will need different rate schedules.
Here is a sample of what the weekday rehearsal form will look like:
![Weekday hourly rates form](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=418 "weekday hourly rates form")
**Note**: Only the weekday and rehearsal boxes are checked.The nonprofit rates are in the lower right corner.
For contrast, here is the weekend ‘other uses’ form. Notice that because they all have the same rental rate, all uses besides classes and rehearsals are checked off:
![Weekend hourly rates form](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=419 "weekend hourly rates form")
Once you have all six hourly rates forms filled out for the Dance Studio, renters will see a **range of rates** for each space usage.
![Range of rates displayed on a listing](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=420 "range of rates displayed on a listing")
Tips for Selecting Photos that Attract New Renters

One of the most useful things you can do to promote your rentals is to upload photos of your space. Whether you are using photos taken with your smart phone, or have professional photos, in order to attract new renters who've never been to your space before, photos are key. They're the first thing that prospective renters look at when considering a space. We've even polled renters about what they find helpful in their searches for space, and the majority agreed that having a visual of the space is super important.
As the venue account holder, you get to select one primary photo that stands out to renters looking at search results. (You'll be able to add as many photos as you'd like to your listing as well.) The images are slightly larger than a thumbnail and the primary photo should be choosen strategically:
**Primary photo winners:**
**Photos with high contrast or color** ![Project Gallery, Toronto](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=509 "Project Gallery, Toronto")
**Photos that show the space in use in a compelling way** ![Brooklyn Ballet Studio, Brooklyn, New York](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=507 "Brooklyn Ballet Studio, Brooklyn, New York")
**Photos that feature windows, or light sources** ![Green Space Studio, New York](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=508 "Green Space Studio, New York")
**Primary photo mistakes to avoid:**
- Dimly Lit/Dark Photos - Floor plans (these are great, but upload them as documents, rather than images) - Photos with logo or text (it doesn't read at thumbnail size) - Logos (these will be taken down by Site Administrators, renters want photos of the space) - Photo files that are so small the image is pixelated or blurry
Using "Clone" to Create Multiple Listings

If you have multiple spaces available for rent, make sure to create a listing for each one. Listing your entire inventory improves marketing visibility, search results, and SEO. There is no limit to the number of space listings you can publish.
To give you some helpful examples of facilities who have listed each unique space, check out:
[Kennedy Center listings on SpaceFinder DC](http://dc.spacefinder.org/spaces.html?instance_select=dc.spacefinder.org&q=%22+The+kennedy+center%22&rate=all&utf8=%E2%9C%93)
[Opera America: National Opera Center listings on SpaceFinder NYC](http://nyc.spacefinder.org/spaces.html?instance_select=nyc.spacefinder.org&q=%22national+opera+center%22&rate=all&utf8=%E2%9C%93)
**If you have spaces that are similar to one another, you can expedite this process by cloning your listings.** Cloning a listing creates a second space with nearly the exact same information as the original including possible uses, rates, amenities, and size. We recommend completing your listing before you Clone it. It's usually easier to change what's different than to re-enter what is the same.
Here's what information is _not_ cloned:
* Images * Documents * Hourly Rates
**Here's how you clone a listing:**
1. Create a Comprehensive Listing
Build one listing with as much pertinent information as possible. Include all possible uses for the space, a narrative description, rates, rental/cancellation policies, and a full list of available equipment and amenities.
![Add a Space from dashboard](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=500 "Add a Space")
2. Clone your listing
Once you've built a listing similar to your other spaces, go to your **Dashboard** and click **Space Listings**. You can then click **Clone **to make a copy.
![Clone a space from dashboard](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=501 "Clone a Listing")
* Click **Dashboard** * Choose **Space Listings** under the manage account menu * Select **clone** next to the space you want to copy * Do a victory dance.
All you need to do is change the space name and any other relevant information (square footage, new images, etc), take the space online, and you're all set! Then, when renters search through the directory, they'll see your listings together and be able to differentiate between the different types of spaces that you've got available to them.
![Multiple space listings for one organization in search results](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=495 "Multiple Space Listings for an Organization")
Automatic & Manual Updates to Calendar

**Once you have synced your calendar it will automatically publish your unbooked times to your listing calendar once a day.**
You can also **Manually Update** your calendar by going to the share my calendar page on your listing.
The time of day and how long it takes for the automatic refresh will vary based on how many calendars are being added to the system at any given moment. You can view when your calendar will next refresh and decide if a Manual Update is preferred.
The time it takes for a manual update to complete will also vary on how many calendars are being synced. It could be relatively instantaneous and it could take up to 30 minutes if it's a high traffic moment for users adding or updating calendars.
A little background on why this feature works in this way (if you're curious):
When developing a solution for connecting renters to space based on availability, we carefully weighed the pros and cons of integrating with venue calendars. The huge positive to integration is we can serve many different types of venues and staffing situations across the arts field and nationwide. If we required venues to all use the same calendar we would be able to more easily offer "real-time" calendar data but participation across the field would be greatly limited. We encourage feedback on the topic of calendar update timing and will continue to monitor this feature.
### ![Manual Update](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=425 "manual update")
Marketing Insight: How Renters Search and View Calendars
(coming soon)
3 Steps to Uploading Your Calendar

**1. Complete Hourly Rates Form** The hourly rates form reflects your hours of business.
**2. Upload Calendar** Once you have rates set, you'll need to upload your digital calendar(s) to the listing. No specifics of your activities will be visible, only what times are available. Many different calendars are compatible with our system, and it just takes a few minutes to set up.
**3. Publish Calendar** Once the calendar is uploaded, double check the availability is showing accurately (you may have to refresh the page) and check the "Publish To Listing" box.
**This is how a published calendar looks:**
![Calendar](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=423 "calendar")
**This is how a published calendar with online booking looks:**
![calendar with space requests](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=424 "calendar with space requests")
### Related Articles - [Share My Calendar Features and Benefits](/site/knowledgebase/share-my-calendar-features-and-benefits) - [Troubleshooting: Error Trying To Download This Feed](/site/knowledgebase/troubleshooting-error-trying-to-download-this-feed-)
Google: Finding Your Calendar Feed

**Google calendar offers calendar feeds so you can sync to devices (like your phone) and share with others via email.** This same calendar feed is what you will sync to your rentals listing.
##Confirm That Your Google Calendar is Public
1. Log in to your Google Account and select the calendar you want to share. 2. Select **Share This Calendar**.
![share this calendar detail](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=460 "share this calendar") 3. Confirm your Google Calendar is public. Select "Hide details" if you do not want to make the names and details of your calendar events public. ![Make Calendar Public](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=461 "Make Calendar Public")
##Copy Google Calendar Feed
1. In your Google account, find the calendar you want to share and click the dropdown menu. The button is a square with a downward pointing triangle when you move your mouse over it. 2. Select Calendar Settings. ![Calendar Settings](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=462 "calendar settings")
3. In the Calendar Address section, click the bright green ICAL button. A pop-up window with your calendar's public URL containing the .iCalendar feed will appear. Select and copy the entire URL. It will look something like this: https://www.google.com/calendar/ical/d473a6885d5e/basic.ics
![Google Calendar Address](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=463 "google calendar address")
##Upload your iCal Feed
1. On your listing's Share My Calendar Page, click the **Upload Your Calendar feed** button. ![Share my calendar on a SpaceFinder Listing](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=466 "share my calendar") 2. Paste that public iCal URL into the field. That URL should end with .ics 3. Click **Add Calendar **to upload the feed. It may take a couple of minutes for the feed to appear on the calendar preview.
![calendar upload page](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=467 "calendar upload page")
Google Calendar Settings - Public vs. Private

##Do I want a Private or Public Calendar? **A public Google Calendar is one that is searchable on the web.** For businesses or artists that want to promote their Calendar activities and have the general public be able to read event details, making your Google Calendar public is a good choice.
Even while making it public, you can choose the level of details that are shared. Hiding your details shows when you have blocked out time on your Calendar, but not what that time is being used for.
* Confirm your Google Calendar is public and set to "Hide details" (this is option is under Share this Calendar)
![make this calendar public](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=470 "make this calendar public")
**Private calendars are unsearchable and can only be shared through invitation.** Both private and public calendars can be synced to your SpaceFinder listing, but they do have different URLs.
* To share a Private Google Calendar make sure to select the Private Address iCal
![Goolge Calendar private address URL](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=471 "Google Calendar private address")
##All-Day Event Set-Up **Make Sure "all day" events on your calendar are marked as Public in the Event Detail Settings **
* All-day events won't show up in your calendar feed unless you specifically set the Privacy Setting for the Event as Public when you create the booking. Even if your general calendar privacy setting is set to Public.
* The "Default" Setting will not allow the all-day booking to show up in your calendar feed. You'll need to un-check that option when you set up your Event!
![all day events](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=472 "all day events")
Google Apps Calendar Settings

**Google Apps is a suite of Google tools for small business.** The Google Apps Calendar is very similar to Google Calendar but does have slightly different settings and options to be aware of when uploading a calendar to SpaceFinder.
* You can not share a Private version of the calendar outside of the domain you've connected to your Google Apps account. (That includes our website).
* To sync your Google Apps calendar with your rentals listing it must be a public calendar. You can, however select "Only free/busy information (hide event details)". You do not need to publish the public calendar in order to sync.
Details from Google's support forum on calendar sharing settings can be found here at [Google support.](http://support.google.com/a/bin/answer.py?hl=en&answer=60765 "Google Support Forum")
Outlook: Finding Your Calendar Feed

**Applies to: Microsoft Office Outlook 2007 and later.**
Microsoft Office offers a free service to Outlook users that enables you to sync your Outlook calendar to devices and publish your calendars online. This same functionality can be used to sync your Outlook calendar to your rentals listing.
## Before you share your Calendar * Register for Office Online by [creating a Windows Live ID account](https://signup.live.com/signup.aspx?lic=1). * [Publish your calendar(s) to Office Online](http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/outlook-help/publish-a-calendar-on-office-online-HA010080983.aspx?CTT=5&origin=HA010174355).
## Find Your Calendar Feed
1. Make sure the calendar is public.
![outlook share](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=477 "outlook share")
2. click on "ICS: Import into another calendar application."
![outlook ics link](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=478 "outlook ics")
3. Copy the .ics URL so you can paste it into your rental listings.
![Outlook iCalendar Feed](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=479 "Outlook iCalendar feed")
##Upload the calendar 1. Paste URL into the field provided. The URL should end with .ics
2. Click the "Add Calendar" button
![calendar upload page](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=467 "calendar upload page")
Yahoo: Finding Your Calendar Feed

### Yahoo calendar generates iCalendar feeds so you can sync to devices and share with others via email. This same iCalendar feed is what you will sync to your rentals listing.
## Step 1 - Create an iCalendar Feed
* Login to your Yahoo account * Under 'Calendars' on the left side of the page, Click the down-arrow button next to the appropriate calendar you want to sync * Select Share settings
![Yahoo Calendar Share Settings](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=475 "Yahoo Calendar Share Settings")
* Click 'iCalendar and Web Address' * Copy the url link above the 'reset' button.
![Yahoo Calendar URL](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=476 "Yahoo Calendar URL")
## Step 2 - Confirm Yahoo Calendar Access
* Confirm your Yahoo Calendar is set to 'Allow anyone to access this calendar'.
NOTE: This allows anyone you've shared the URL with to view your calendar info. It will not share your calendar info unless you share the URL specifically.
![Make Yahoo Calendar Publicly Accessible](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=474 "Make Yahoo Calendar Publicly Accessible")
## Step 3 - Paste Calendar Feed and "Add Calendar"
* Paste URL into the field provided. URL should end with .ics
* Click "Add Calendar" button
![New Calendar Add Field on SpaceFinder](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=473 "New Calendar Add Field on SpaceFinder")
MindBody: Finding Calendar Feed via Sync to Google

### MindBody offers a free Google Calendar Integration that enables you to sync your MindBody calendars to Google.
Whether you use the Google version of your calendar or not, this enables you to create an iCalendar feed and sync to your rentals listings. By using Google as a connector, your venue calender can automatically be synced to your rentals listing. Once you've set things up you don't ever need to manage the Google calendar. **There are some sync limitations from MindBody please pay attention to the options they provide.**
* [Create a Google Account](https://accounts.google.com/SignUp?continue=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com%2F&hl=en) with a Gmail address * [Sync your MindBody calendar(s) to Google Account](http://support.mindbodyonline.com/entries/21060322-google-calendar-integration) * [Copy Google calendar feed into space listing](/site/knowledgebase/google-finding-your-calendar-feed-)
Troubleshooting: Availability is Not Accurate on Calendar

**Here's a checklist to help you troubleshoot why your rental schedule and availability are not showing up accurately in your listing's calendar feed.** Remember when you are looking the calendar feed on your listing, you should only see your unbooked times as open blocks of time. ### Is the Hourly Rates Form on your listing correct? * The Hourly Rates Form combines your daily business hours along with your rates for specific types of rentals. The hours of business reflected in your hourly rates form should match your actual schedule.  * Example: If your Hourly Rates Form says you are open from 8am-4pm, but your space is really open from 10am-10pm, your calendar feed will show zero availability from 4pm on. That's a lot of rentals you could miss out on! ### Are all the online calendars you use to manage your rental schedule synced to your space listing? * Lot's of people use more than one calendar to manage a particular space. Maybe you have Nighttime Events and Meetings on a separate calendar, but both activities happen in the same space.  * You can sync as many calendars to one space listing as you need in order to make sure that all of your available/booked time for each use of a specific space is accounted for.  ### Do you have bookings on your calendar marked as tasks, communicate "available", etc.? * Only bookings scheduled as **Events** will show up in your calendar feed.  * If you've marked a rehearsal as a Task accidentally, it won't show up in the feed, and will look like available time to renters on your listing. ### Are events on your venue's online calendar marked as "all day" even if they are for a certain period of time? * You could be accidentally telling renters you are booked all day when you have an few hours free! ### Google Calendars: Are "all day" events on your venue's online calendar marked as Public in the Event Detail Settings? * We've found that even if your general calendar privacy setting is set to "Public" and your specific Event privacy settings are set to "Default" to the privacy settings of your calendar, all-day events won't show up in your calendar feed. See how to set up your All-Day Events in our [privacy settings article.](/site/knowledgebase/google-calendar-settings-public-vs-private) ### Does your online calendar have sync limitations? * Certain calendar software limit how far into the future they will sync event data, for example MindBody sync 30 days into the future. Some spaces who use Mindbody show their calendar in order to benefit from higher visibility, but provide renters with specific links in the listing for renters to click through and book space. ### Is your iCalendar feed refreshed? * Calendars refresh automatically once a day. You will see a countdown to your next refresh with the option to [manually refresh.](/site/knowledgebase/automatic-manual-updates-to-calendar)
Troubleshooting: 'Error Trying to Download this Feed'

**If you're trying to upload your Google calendar and you see this message:** *"There was an error trying to download this feed" * No need to worry, it's most likely because your Google calendar is set to *Private*, but you uploaded a *Public* version of the iCalendar feed. **This is an easy fix, follow the steps below**:
## 1. Go to your Google Calendar and select "Share This Calendar"
![Google Share This Calendar Option](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=468 "Google 'Share This Calendar' Option")
## 2. Select and copy the iCal under *Private* Address
![Goolge Calendar private address URL](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=471 "Google Calendar private address")
## 3. Go to SpaceFinder listing and select "Share My Calendar"
## 4. Select "Remove" and clear previous calendar causing error
## 5. Select "Upload calendar" and paste Private Address copied from Google
Remember, it's technically the same calendar, just with the corresponding privacy settings
## 6. Refresh page to preview uploaded calendar Confirm no error message
## 7. High five yourself, and publish calendar.
**Pro Tip:** If you enter the iCal URL into your web browser, it should download a file named **Basic.ics.** If the page takes you to a Google-Branded Error page, it means the feed is not public.
Exporting Space Request Data

**For venues who have enabled [Online Space Requests](/site/knowledgebase/space-request-forms-features-benefits), you also have the option to export the rentals data collected via those online forms.**
This is can be useful both when you want to export contact info for all of your renters, and even more so when you want to learn from your rental activity and make informed decisions.
## Common questions that an export of data can help answer:
- What usage of space is most popular (class, special event, etc.)? - What usage of space is bringing in the most money? - Who are the loyal return renters? - What are the most common reasons for a renter's space request being denied? - What are the most common reasons for a cancellation or a refund?
## To export Space Requests follow these steps:
1. Login to your SpaceFinder account 2. Go to your Dashboard 3. Select 'Space Requests' 4. Filter your report by date 5. Click 'View' to load the data 6. Click 'Export' 7. CSV file will be emailed to the email address you logged in with
## CSV file will include the following columns:
- By (who created the Space Request, an Admin or the Renter). - Renter's Organization - Renter Name - Renter's Email - Renter's Phone Number - Date/Time of Reservation - Created (Date Space Request was created) - Space Requested - Use of Space (rehearsal, performance, etc.) - Membership (renter answered 'yes' to being a member of your organization) - Request Status (can be Approved, Denied, or Cancelled) - Reason for canceling - Amount (total cost of the rental. if a partial refund has been processed the net total will show) - Payment Method (if credit card was used, the type of card and last four digits will be displayed. If "Other" is selected as a payment option by the Admin when creating a Space Request, whatever is entered will be displayed. For example "Cash", "Invoice #201", "workstudy", etc.)
### Related Articles - [Space Request Form Features & Benefits](/site/knowledgebase/space-request-forms-features-benefits)
Space Request Forms Features & Benefits

**Space requests are online forms submitted via SpaceFinder by a renter interested in booking your space. They are a free way to organize requests for bookings and provide the following benefits:**
## Streamline follow up with renter
By requiring renters to provide the info you need up front via a simple form, it makes it easier to quickly get back to a renter about their request. Renters receive automated email notifications when you approve their space request, ensuring you and the renter are on the same page with rental details, and cancellation policies.
## Boost your ranking in search results
Listings with space requests enabled display a "Book Online" button in search results and are rewarded boosted ranking in search results.
## Track what your space is being used for
To enable the Space Request form you are required to provide a rental rate for each different use of your space (performance, rehearsal, special event. etc.) By doing this you are empowering tracking of what your space is being used for. We provide a list view report of rentals by use, which can be sorted by date and exported for further analysis.
## Gain insight from your rentals data
Using online Space Requests allows you to organize and export important data about your renters. Info gathered from the form is stored in your account, so you can track your rental trends; for example: what types of rentals your space is most being used for.
## Collect and export renter contact info
Rental contact info is collected in the Space Request form and can be easily exported. This can come in handy when you have something relevant and exciting to share with renters for example offering loyal renters long term rental deals, or announcing a new membership model for discounted space.
## Streamline accepting payment
Taking payment upfront streamlines the interaction on the day of the rental. The renter will input their credit card information, but will NOT be charged until you approve the request. Early payment also means security for both you and your renter. The total is calculated based on your [Hourly Rates form](/site/knowledgebase/hourly-rates-forms), so make sure this information is complete.
*Note: Taking payment does NOT mean renters automatically book space. All requests must first be approved by the venue manager.*
## Help Fractured Atlas measure impact
Space Requests are optionally for a venue. If you decide you prefer a renter to call or email you, we do not put up a barrier for that option. However, thinking big picture for a moment, there is no way for us to measure when a renter calls or emails you. By turning Space Requests on you are not only making a savvy online business choice that makes you stand out from the competition, you are also helping us measure the impact of SpaceFinder as a subsidized service. We are able to track (and celebrate) the total dollar amount of rental requests submitted through Space Request forms.

Responding to Pending Space Requests

## Approving Space Requests
Space requests can be approved in 2 ways:
1\. Through the "Pending Space Request" on your Dashboard
2\. Through viewing the details of the request
### Details View
![Pending Reservations Details View](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=415 "Pending Reservations Details")
**When you approve a request the renter will receive an email confirmation. If you collect payment up front when you approve the request, the renter's credit card is charged.** Once the request is approved, you can still edit or cancel/refund up until the start time of the rental.
Reminder: Approving the request DOES NOT automatically add it to your calendar.
## Denying Space Requests
To deny a space request, select the option from the details view, and enter a reason for the renter. This will be emailed to the renter **as it is entered into the comment box.**
![Pending Reservation Rejection Details](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=416 "Pending Reservation Rejection Details")
## Expired Space Requests
Space requests that are never approved or denied expire when the rental date passes. No notification is sent to the renter.
Keeping Space Request Emails Out of the Spam Box

Email notifications such as pending space requests and renter confirmation receipts are sent from a "No Reply" email address that matches the website domain.
**Spacefinder LA sends email from noreply@spacefinderla.org**
**SpaceFinder Philly sends email from noreply@phillyspacefinder.com**
And so on...
Depending on settings and filters, those email notifications might end up in the SPAM folder. To ensure important SpaceFinder email notifications are delivered to the inbox - **add the 'noreply' email address to your address book or contact list.** This tells your email system we are an approved source to send you an email communication.
**If you have taken this step and are still not receiving email notifications,** please give us a call at 888.692.7878 ex.228 and we will help you out.
Member and Non-Profit Space Requests

**If you have entered both Member rates and Non Profits rates for your space, a renter will be prompted to check whether they are a member of your organization and if they are a non profit, when filling out a space request form.**
There is a chance a renter will check both member and non profit.
When this happens the space request calculates the renter's total cost using the the lowest rate of the two possible rates.
Securing Payment Details Before Day of Rental

Taking credit card payment information at the time of the rental request helps streamline the rental process for both you and the renter. No more hunting down payment information at the time of the rental.
## What the Renter Sees ##
1. The renter makes a space request.
![Contact Space Manager Form](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=400 "Contact Space Manager Form")
2. The renter then enters credit card payment information as the final step in submitting the request. The renter is reminded the card will NOT be charged unless the request is approved.
![Renter Payment Information](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=398 "Renter Payment Information")
## What the Venue Manager Sees ##
The venue manager receives an email notification with links to either approve or deny the request. The action can be taken from the email, or from the space request section on your Dashboard.
![List of Rentals to Approve or Deny](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=399 "List of Rentals to Approve or Deny")
If you follow decide to approve the rental request, press the "Approve Request button."
Approving a request causes the following:
* The renter's card is charged. * The renter receives and approval email. * The renter receives a reminder email 12 hours before the rental time.
If the rental is not a good fit you can deny the request by clicking "View Details" and "Deny."
Denying a request causes the following:
* The renter receives an email letting them know the request has been denied along with any custom text you send to the renter. * The credit card is NOT charged.
Processing Credit Cards in Person (and Over Phone)

## What is Charge Renter? Charge Renter is an easy way to process credit cards in person or over the phone using SpaceFinder. It is part of the suite of optional features included in Booking Engine. You do not have to be using online booking to use Charger Renter, this provides maximum flexibility in how you want to manage payment for rentals. ## What benefits does Charge Renter offer? Charger Renter is a streamlined way to process payment, [email receipts](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/rental-receipt-emails), keep a transaction history, and [send automated reminder emails to your rental customers](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/auto-reminder-emails-for-renters) and [process refunds](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/refunding-a-renter-s-credit-card-). ![enter image description here](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=562 "Booking Engine - Charge Renter Workflow") ## What are the fees to process credit cards? To keep SpaceFinder a free resource for renters and free for venues to list their spaces, there are some small fees associated with using online booking to collect rental payments.  - 1.5% of the rental amount goes to arts non-profit Fractured Atlas; these funds are split with our local partners to sustain SpaceFinder websites - 2.9 % + $.0.30 of the rental amount goes to credit card processing; this is the cost of secure online banking using our payment processor, Stripe. These are the only fees. There are no monthly payments. And, get ready for this... there are NO FEES FOR REFUNDS (which can really add up, especially if you have a pretty forgiving cancellation policy). ## What rental specifics features are there? **Charger Renter was created with venue rentals in mind.** When performing a transaction, you can input as much rental specific information as you need including who is using your space, what for, when, and for how long. You can also send automated email reminders for bookings taken over the phone. In addition, you may also use charge renter for rental related sales like piano tunings, equipment rentals, etc. by selecting the 'other' category under your planned activities. Because Charge Renter works independently from your listing, you have the freedom to offer flexible pricing, discounts, or additional costs as needed. ## Can I see my rental history? **A record of all transactions are kept in your dashboard searchable by date and renters name. ** Rental transactions include an overview of the renter, day of rental, amount paid, and payment type.  You can also access details of each rental and edit the information or issue whole/part refunds as necessary. Your list of transactions, in whole or part, is exportable into a basic CSV spreadsheet which you can use in other CRM (customer relationship management) systems. ![Rental History Export Button](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=393 "Past Rentals Report")
Rental Receipt Emails

### When you approve a renter's Space Request, the renter automatically receives a confirmation email with both a receipt for payment *and* rental details.
**If you are juggling a credit card payment system and emailing confirmations separately for renters, streamlining these together could save you time as well as reduce confusion among your busy renters.**
**Key aspects of receipts sent to renters:**
* Renter sees your venue name in the subject line of email
* Renter sees a custom message from you
* Renter can not reply directly to the receipt email, but your contact info is included in the confirmation
* Renter is reminded what to look for on their credit card statement
* Renter is reminded of your cancellation policy
* Renter is reminded of booking details and your location (with a link that opens in Google maps!)

Cancellations: Refunding a Renter's Credit Card

**In the case of a reservation cancellation, issuing a full or partial refund to a renter's credit card is at the sole discretion of the Space Manager.**
Issuing a refund will update the Space Request status to 'Cancel', send a cancellation/refund confirmation email to the renter, and a credit (full or partial) will be processed to the renter's credit card. Here are a few things to be aware of:
## No Refund Fees (Whoot!)
While many online payment systems charge you a fee to process a refund, Fractured Atlas has integrated SpaceFinder with a system that DOES NOT. We understand that cancellations and refunds are a just part of the reality of running a venue. You will not be charged any fees to refund a renter. Over the course of running a venue, this savings can really add up! [Click here to see more about fees](/site/knowledgebase/rental-transaction-fees).
## Credit Card Refund Limitations
Refunds made through SpaceFinder are only possible _before_ the rental date and time passes. After the rental date and time passes, venues are responsible for issuing refunds at their discretion and outside of SpaceFinder (by check, rental credit, other).
## How to Process a Refund/Cancellation
1. Open your Space Requests and click on the date of the transaction you want to refund.
![Rental Information to Refund](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=489 "Rental Information to Refund")
2. Select **Edit Request**.
![Edit Rental Request to Refund](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=488 "Edit Rental Request to Refund")
3. Click the **Refund** tab and choose the reason for the cancellation. Partial refunds may be performed by changing the refund amount.
![Refund Rental Transaction](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=490 "Refund Rental Transaction")
** This will complete the refund and trigger a refund confirmation email to the renter with the following information:**
Subject: Your reservation has been canceled
Your reservation at [space_name] on [reservation_date] from [starting_time] — [ending_time] has been canceled by the space's manager.
[reason_for_canceling]
If you did not request this cancellation please contact the space directly (details below).
Your credit card has been issued a refund of $X.00.
Refunds are issued by space managers according to the space's cancellation policy (listed below). If you feel that you are entitled to a refund (full or partial) that you did not receive, please contact the space directly.
[space_contact_info]
[space_cancellation_policy]
## Refund Tips
- The 'reason for canceling' is entered by the Space Manager and will be displayed both in the email to the renter _and_ on the transaction record for future reference. - [Credit Card Status](/site/knowledgebase/credit-card-status-answering-your-renter-s-questions-about-a-charge-or-refund-) will display as 'Refunded Fully' or 'Refunded Partially'. - If you cancel a reservation on the same day it was approved, no charge will show on the renter's card. (And therefore no refund will need to be processed.)
###Related Articles - [4 Steps to Accepting Payment Through SpaceFinder](/site/knowledgebase/4-steps-to-accepting-payment-through-spacefinder)
Credit Card Status: Answering your Renter's Questions about a Charge or Refund

### In order to give great customer service to your repeat renters, the Booking Engine provides easy access to the status of a credit card charge or refund.
'Credit Card Status' is displayed both in the list view of Space Requests as well as the Reservation detail page. Below are the options for credit card status and what they mean:
**Charged:** reservation was _approved_ and credit card charged
**Refunded Fully:** reservation was _cancelled_ and full rental fee is refunded to credit card
**Refunded Partially:** reservation was _cancelled_ and partial rental fee refunded to credit card
**Settled:** reservation was _approved_ and rental total (minus fees) has been transferred to venue bank account. Note: It takes a few days after being settled for bank account to record the transaction, this varies by bank.
### Credit Card Status will be blank when:
- Payment made is via a method _other_ than a credit card (cash, check, barter, etc.) - Reservation request was _denied_ (credit card was never charged) - Reservation request is _pending_ (has not been approved or denied yet) - Reservation request is _expired_ (was not approved or denied before requested rental date passed)
### Tips & Reminders
- Renter will see **your venue name** on their credit card - Reason for cancellation/refund is displayed in the transaction record - When searching for a rental transaction by name, it will be the name entered for the Renter (not always the same name as on the credit card) - When searching for a rental transaction by name, use exact spelling and punctuation
### Need additional help?
We understand your renters are important, and we want you to feel confidant using our system to provide your renters with a valuable service. If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to call on Fractured Atlas to help you. Call us at 888-692-7878 X228 or email us at spacefinder@fracturedatlas.org

Troubleshooting: Renter Can't Find Emailed Receipt

Confirmation and receipt for a rental transaction is triggered in Charge Renter by choosing the 'confirm' tab at the end of a transaction and clicking the 'Email Renter Confirmation' button.
If a renter believes they have not received a receipt by email, please check the following:
## 1\. Confirm renter email address is correct
**Confirm the email you have in the rental transaction is the correct one for the renter.** Sometimes simple things like name typos or switching a domain ending from .org to .com can cause an email to get sent to the wrong place.
## 2\. Remind renter the email doesn't come from venue directly
**Renters may not realize the receipt email comes from SpaceFinder **and may be looking for something from the venue email address. Each email notification states the name of a venue in the subject line.
## 3\. Did renter check email spam folder?
**Some spam filters are very sensitive and may have captured the email notification.** Have the renter check their spam folder for any email from the SpaceFinder website; it may have landed there instead of their inbox.
Booking Engine Features & Benefits

## 1\. Charge Renter
* **Take credit card payment online, over the phone and in person** * **Charge for rentals and other related services** * **Quickly email confirmation and receipt to renter** * **Easy refund/cancellation option** * **Low transaction fees**
![enter image description here](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=562 "Booking Engine - Charge Renter Workflow")
## 2\. Space Request Forms
* Reduce back and forth emails tracking down details from potential renters * Renters indicate whether they are flexible on requested dates/times * You can approve or deny any request from a renter (no space can be booked without your approval)
## **3\. Auto reminders to renters**
* Renters receive an automated email reminder 12 hrs in advance of their pending reservation * Email includes address, map, contact info and reminder of rental policies
## **4\. Higher Ranking**
* Listings that show availability and allow online space requests rank higher in search results than listings not offering this convenience to renters
## 5. Data Export
* Export rental transaction data * Export renter contact info

Rental Transaction Fees

## Rental Transaction Fees## Here is how the fees breakdown if you are accepting payment (online, over the phone and in person) thru SpaceFinder: - 1.5% of the rental amount goes to arts non-profit Fractured Atlas; these funds are split with our local partners to sustain SpaceFinder websites as a free resource for artists. - 2.9 % + $0.30 of the rental amount goes to payment processor Stipe; this is the cost of secure online banking transactions. **These are the only fees.** There are no monthly payments and no fees for refunds (that's right, we said "NO FEES FOR REFUNDS", which is huge for rentals business where cancellations are natural part of business, those refund fees can really add up). Rental revenue automatically deposits to your bank account on a 2-day rolling basis.  In deciding if processing payment through SpaceFinder's Booking Engine is right for your rentals business, ask yourself these questions: * Am I missing out on bookings because I only accept cash or check? * Am I spending too much administrative time processing and depositing cash and check? * Am I being asked for analysis of my rentals revenue, but it isn't all in one place where I can export it? * How much am I paying per year in refund fees with my current credit card processor? See below for how the math breaks down: ## Rental Example: ##
Rental Amount $100
Credit Card Processing $2.90+.30
SpaceFinder Fee $1.50
Rental Revenue $95.30
Fees Paid $4.70
## Refund Example: ##
Rental Amount $100
Refund Amount ($100)
Fees Paid $0

Auto Reminder Emails for Renters

**Renters receive auto reminder email 12 hours before their rental begins.**
Renters are juggling a million things and often renting multiple spaces. This friendly automated reminder not only helps keep them organized, but also acts as a reminder of your venue's policies.
The reminder includes the date and time of the rental, contact information, an interactive google map link for directions, and your venue's Rental/Cancellation Policies.
**Subject: Your reservation at [organization name] is coming up!**
![Auto Reminder Email on Mobile Phone](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=556 "Auto Reminder Email on Mobile Phone")
4 Steps to Accepting Payment through SpaceFinder

### Online booking is a great way to offer convenient payment options to renters and streamline your communications.
*Online booking is not a way to automatically book space.* A space request is just the first step in the rental process and developing a relationship with the renter. Renters must send a space request and are only charged after the request is approved by a venue manager.
To enable online booking complete the following steps for each listing:
**1. Complete Hourly Rates Form**
Each permitted use must have an hourly rate assigned to it in order for it be booked online. The hourly rates form also reflects your hours of business. More information on filling out this form can be found in the Hourly Rates Article.
**2. Upload Calendar**
(Optional, but encouraged)
Once you have rates set, you can upload your digital calendar to the listing. No specifics of your activities will be visible, only what times are available. Once the calendar is uploaded, double check the availability is showing accurately (you may have to refresh the page) and check the "Publish To Listing" box.
**3. Authorize Your Account to Accept Credit Cards**
To receive advanced payments for your rentals and accept credit cards in person or over the phone using Charge Renter, you need to authorize rental revenue to be deposited into your bank account.
**4. Enable Space Requests**
(Optional, but encouraged)
Select which space listing you want to enable Space Requests on. And select the parameters for a space request in the settings. For example you can control, how much lead-time is required, and the minimum length of a booking. Once you have successfully enabled space requests, renters will see the BOOK ONLINE button and your listing will be boosted to the top of search results.
### Related Articles - [Booking Engine Features & Benefits](/site/knowledgebase/booking-engine-features-benefits) - [Securing Payment Details Before Day of Rental](/site/knowledgebase/securing-payment-details-before-day-of-rental)
Connecting to Space Request Forms from Your Own Website

**Including rental information and workflows on your own website site can be tricky.** You are likely promoting a lot of things on your website such as events, programming, classes and fundraising campaigns. Rentals are often just an aspect of all the amazing things your organization is offering. It can difficult to build out the rental workflows you want on your website, and updating information or adding photos isn't always easy without website administrator help. **A practical solution is to integrate your SpaceFinder rentals listings into your own website**.
**By linking your SpaceFinder listing, you can easily direct potential renters to everything they need to know about booking your space.** Even if you already have information for your site available, it's easy to link directly to the Space Request Form so when a renter does contact you, they'll have already provided the information *you* need to rent your space.
## 1\. Link to your accounts "Rentals Homepage"
**The most straight forward method is to create a direct link on your website to your SpaceFinder listing. **Your Rentals Homepage displays a list of all your available spaces with a short description and photo. From there renters can click on an individual space to get more detailed information.
![Link from JACK Rentals page](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=413 "Link from JACK Rentals page")
## 2\. Link each space on your site to the corresponding listing
**If you have some rental info on your site, you can still link through to the calendar so renters can deeper details, like availability.**
Many spaces already include a list of their inventory on their site that includes basic information. From that list of spaces, it's easy to link directly to the detailed information about each space so renters have access to the nitty-gritty without it taking up room on your own webpage. This is a great way for renters to check out your calendar and see when the space they want is available.
![Link from Opera America Space Listings](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=414 "Link from Opera America Space Listings")
## 3\. If a calendar is already embedded on your website, link directly to a space request form.
**If you already have a calendar and information about the space on your site, you can direct renters to fill out the rental information you need.**
Instead of the usual email back and forth between renters and venue managers, you can use the Space Request form to make sure you get all the info about the rental you need right away. Using the Online Booking approval system, you can also receive payment upfront for the rental. You can also automate sending reminders about upcoming rental and copies of your rental/cancellation policy so you'll know they are informed.
![Link to Space Request form on SpaceFinder from Venue Calendar](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=412 "Link to Space Request form on SpaceFinder from Venue Calendar")

Tips for Finding Affordable Space

**We empathize with the challenge in finding affordable space.** It's a huge part of why Fractured Atlas maintains [SpaceFinder](http://spacefinder.org) as a subsidized service. It is also why we work with venues and encourage them to be transparent about their rates on SpaceFinder so you can search based on your hourly, weekly or monthly space budget. **Above and beyond searching by rate, here are some savvy ways to reduce your costs:**
![ElephantDollar](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=796 "ElephantDollar")
## Tips specific to finding affordable space using SpaceFinder:
### 1. Search by Square Footage or Capacity
Venues who choose NOT add their rates to their listings don't show up in your search results by rate. However most intimate spaces are often also the most affordable. If you search for space by 'Square Footage' or 'Capacity' this can be a good way to find more affordable spaces.
### 2. Use Keyword Search to find Alternative Spaces
All the world is a stage and Fractured Atlas is purposely inclusive of all sorts of spaces in SpaceFinder. Theatres, concert halls, museums, and dance studios are listed along with churches, libraries, cafes, rooftops, retail stores, comedy clubs, historic homes, community centers, and other places open to creative activity happening in their space. Sometimes being open to alternative spaces can save you money, sometimes not - but worth a look at what is out there. Using keyword search is a good way to quickly explore alternative spaces.
![KeywordGIF](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=795 "KeywordGIF")
### 3. Search by Alternative Payment (Barter, Work Study, FREE)
You can discover spaces willing to exchange something other than money for use of their space by using the SpaceFinder search filters for Barter, Work Study and FREE.
![Search by Rental Rate](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=553 "Search by Rental Rate - SpaceFinder")
![Free Space](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=554 "Free Space")
## Tips for finding affordable space beyond SpaceFinder
### 1. Qualify for Non-Profit Rates Many venues offer a lower rental rate to non-profits. Did you know fiscally sponsored projects are also eligible for non-profit rates? Venues are often willing to extend non-profit rates as long as you provide a letter from your fiscal sponsor confirming you are a charitable project.
If you are [fiscally sponsored](/site/fiscal/) by Fractured Atlas, we are happy to write venue letters so you can qualify for non-profit rental rates, please contact [support@fracturedatlas.org](mailto:support@fracturedatlas.org). If you are fiscally sponsored by an organization other than Fractured Atlas, see if they offer the same service, they likely do and it doesn't hurt to ask.
### 2. Ask venue about subsidized rates The cost to run a space is often higher than what artists can pay to use it. Certain funders have recognized this problem and stepped up with resources so a more affordable rate can be charged to artists. This is often referred to as a "subsidized" rental rate. Qualifications vary by venue - in some cases an application is required, and in others all that is required is your use of the space fall within certain parameters. Venues often have a limited number of subsidized hours each year, so be an informed consumer: inquire if a venue offers subsidized rates and how you can participate.
### 3. Offer Venue a Longer Commitment
Many venues are willing to consider a lower rate if a space will be rented consistently over a longer period of time. It never hurts to ask or negotiate.
### 4. Offer to Pay Venue Up Front
Sometimes being willing to pay up front helps a venue with cashflow in a way that is worth coming down on the rate a bit.
### 5. Don't Overpay on Event Insurance
Some venues require "proof of liability insurance" in order for you to rent their space. If you get insurance from a company that doesn't really understand the risks of a creative project, you could be overpaying.
Fractured Atlas helps creative projects with [liability insurance](/site/liability/). Our friendly staff are brokers who also come from artistic background, so we understand both worlds. *Learn more here: [When Venues Require Liability Insurance](/site/knowledgebase/when-a-venue-requires-liability-insurance)*
## Here's to securing space that fits your projects budget!

When a Venue Requires Liability Insurance

Working in a venue space carries unique, associated risks and exposures. To limit these risks, venues may require their renters to carry insurance:
**General liability insurance** covers damage to locations and injury to bystanders. This coverage is available on an annual and short-term basis, to fit your needs.
**Why do certain venues require it from renters?**
Venues will often require proof of insurance from renters to confirm that they have coverage in place. They may also ask to be listed as an Additional Insured entity for the risks and exposures related to your operations; this means that your insurance comes into play before any the venue carries.
**Why do some venues offer a master plan for their renters?**
Venues can offer a TULIP (Tenant/Users Liability Insurance Protection) plan, which allows you to be covered under the venue's insurance policy. This type of policy can keep your claims separate from the venue's, while making sure that everyone can be covered. Venues can offer to include you as insured under a TULIP policy for an additional fee or include the cost in the rental charges.
**What exactly does a Certificate of Insurance (COI) from cover?**
A Certificate of Insurance is the document that provides proof of insurance, listing the venue as either Certificate Holder or Additional Insured (if this was requested).
**Additional insurance help:**
[Fractured Atlas](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/about/): Fractured Atlas, the non-profit technology company that powers SpaceFinder, also helps the creative sector by offering affordable business insurance for the arts. In addition to being brokers for insurance, our friendly staff also come from artistic backgrounds, so they get both sides. Fractured Atlas has helped over 15,000 creative projects secure insurance. Depending on what else is involved in renting out your venue space, you may consider requiring other insurance types, which we can also help out with. For more info please visit our main [Insurance Program page](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/liability/).
**Note:**
Fractured Atlas can only secure insurance for groups based in the US with US tax IDs.
**Canadian-based insurance help:**
Many Canadian venues who require liability insurance work with their own preferred insurance providers, so start by asking a venue directly about options. Otherwise the Insurance Bureau of Canada is a general resource.
How does Online Booking Work?

##Is there a fee to book online? Nope. Renters do not pay an additional fee to book online through the website.
##Do I have to create a username and password? Nope. If you are interested in the features that come with creating an account (saved searches, etc.) we do encourage renters to create a username and password, however, it is not required for online booking.
##Will I start getting SPAM if I book online? Nope. We occasionally send relevant email updates when we have great feature releases worth letting you know about, but we don't turn on automated notifications based on online booking or try to endlessly "upsell" you.
##Who do I contact if I have a question about the rental? Always contact the Space Manager directly regarding questions about rental. In many cases a preferred method of contact will be indicated.
![contact space manager button](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=481 "contact space manager button")
##Can I book more than one space at a time? Not at this time. Currently the booking system creates a transaction for each individual date/time/space requested. This allows for flexible refund policies as well as nifty features like an automatic email reminders 12 hrs before your booking with details and a map.
##Why am I asked for my credit card with some spaces and not with others? Venues have the option to accept space requests with or without securing online payment up front. This varies from listing to listing.
##How far in advance do I need to book online? The default is 2 business days but venues have the option to increase or decrease the lead time for online booking. Some Space Managers are able to respond to within hours or same day and welcome last minute online bookings. Others (often because of staffing limitations) require more time. The lead time required to book online is communicated below the listing calendar.
![space requests 2 days in advance default](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=483 "the default is 2 days in advance")
##How is "Total Rental Cost" calculated for online booking? Date, time, space usage, and rental rates are all variables in calculating the total cost for online booking. Changing any of these variables may change your total cost.
For example: certain days of the week or times of day can be a lower rental rate. Read the listing carefully to fully understand your online booking and offline booking options.
##What should I expect after I complete my Space Request to book online? You'll receive an email with the details you submitted in your space request for reference.
Once the Space Manager approves or denies your request you'll receive an email confirmation. Depending on the type of rental the Space Manger might contact you directly for more information.
##What is the cancellation/refund policy? Cancellation, refund and booking policies are specific to each space. Before you complete an online booking request you are asked to review those policies and confirm you agree to them.
##When will my credit card be charged? When your Space Request is approved by the Space Manager.
##Can I use an international credit card for online booking? Yes. Many of our venues welcome renters from around the world, so we are happy to facilitate online booking for all. For the transaction to be approved, The card has to have a major carrier logo: American Express, Visa, MasterCard or Discover. Debit cards without a major credit card logo are not accepted.
##Where do I go if I have great ideas about how to make online booking better? We welcome feedback via spacefinder@fracturedatlas.org.
