What is a CRM, and why do I need one?

**CRM stands for Customer Relationship Management **(the C may also stand for Contact, Client, Constituent) and it is basically a database to help you see how you interact with your patrons, fans, volunteers, artists, and vendors. All Artful.ly users have free access to the CRM, which allows you to keep an organized list of your people including contact info, ticket purchases, and donations.
**A good CRM is an integral part of understanding your arts business. **It helps guide marketing, fundraising strategy, and business goals.
## The Artful.ly CRM Helps You:
* Track interactions with individual and organizations * Automatically note when they buy tickets or make donations * Keep track of a patron's involvement lifetime value to your organization * Make notes on [people and company records](/site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-create-a-new-people-record) * [Search](/site/knowledgebase/advanced-search-and-list-segments) by lifetime value * [Tag](/site/knowledgebase/how-can-i-use-tags) patrons * Record a [Heard Action](/site/knowledgebase/actions-the-action-feed) when you send a donor a thank you letter or email
## Example Person Record:
![](//cdn.thinglink.me/api/image/637754549121056770/1024/10/scaletowidth#tl-637754549121056770;1043138249')
## Related Articles:
* [What's it Cost?](/site/knowledgebase/what-s-it-cost-) * [Importing People](/site/knowledgebase/importing-people) * [Your Patrons: Who Are They and Why You Should Track Them in Artful.ly](/site/knowledgebase/who-are-my-patrons-and-why-should-i-track-them-in-artful-ly)
Getting Started With Artful.ly

**Welcome to Artful.ly!**
**Maybe you're wondering what to do next. Let us suggest jumping through some key questions**
1. **What is it like to create an event? **Start by [creating a test event](/site/knowledgebase/creating-an-event). Creating a test event is the best investment you can make in learning Artful.ly. It helps you get familiar with the interface in a safe environment to train on features like the [box office](/site/knowledgebase/box-office-sell-tickets-at-the-door "box office"). 2. **What's the difference between an event and a show? **Schedule a few shows for an event and edit them afterwards. Play around with publishing, unpublishing, adding and deleting shows and ticket types 3. **How do I charge for tickets?** Activate some kits. Head to **Account Administration** by clicking on your email in the upper-right corner. Click **Add** for any kits you'd like to activate. 4. **What do customers see when they buy tickets? **Try selling some tickets (Remember - your storefront is live: work with free tickets so your card is not charged.) through the [box office, Storefront and widget](/site/knowledgebase/four-sales-channels-explained). It's good to know what your customers will see when they buy their tickets in case they ever ask you questions. 5. **How can I collect donations on my own site? **[Install the Artful.ly widget.](/site/knowledgebase/what-is-the-widget-and-how-does-it-work "What Is The Widget and How Does It Work") With the widget installed your customers can donate right on your site, and the donations are automatically logged in Artful.ly.
As you sell tickets tickets to your test event you'll see their records populate in your [Artful.ly CRM](/site/knowledgebase/what-is-a-crm-and-why-do-i-need-one "What is a CRM and Why Do I Need One?"). When working with the CRM, it's a good idea to start with [people records](/site/knowledgebase/people-records-overview "People Records Overview") and move on to importing your other records such as donations and event attendance later.
1. **How do I fill up my CRM?** [Create some individual records](/site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-create-a-new-people-record "Create New People Records"). This will give you an idea of the types of information you can track. 2. **How can I do that in bulk?** [Import a list of contacts](/site/knowledgebase/importing-people "Importing People"). It's best to play around with importing people records first because those imports can be deleted. Mess around here before you start entering your previous donations or show records. Artful.ly allows for [3 types of imports](/site/knowledgebase/imports-demystified "Imports Demystified"): People Records, Donation History and Event Attendance. 3. **How can I learn more about them?** Once you have some records in your CRM, play around with [Advanced Search](/site/knowledgebase/advanced-search-and-list-segments "Advanced Search ") and create a List Segment or two. List segments are great for targeting specific types of patrons. 4. **How can I talk to my patrons?** [Set up MailChimp](/site/knowledgebase/what-is-mailchimp-and-why-should-i-use-it "What is MailChimp and Why Should I Use It"). With the MailChimp kit activated you can send beautifully designed emails to your patrons and those communications automatically log in your [Action Feed](/site/knowledgebase/actions-the-action-feed "Action Feed"). Take those list segments and reach out to your biggest fans.
This is just the tip of the iceberg. You can find more answers, articles, and how-to videos in the rest of our [Artful.ly Knowledge Base](/site/knowledgebase/topic/Artful.ly "Artful.ly Knowledge Base").
As a sponsored project, what can I do with Artful.ly?

##Artful.ly is business software for artists. You can use it to sell tickets to your events, take donations online, and keep track of your fans and patrons. We've built some special features just for fiscally sponsored projects. To access these, you will connect your Artful.ly account to your fiscal sponsorship. ([Learn how to do that here.](/site/knowledgebase/connect-your-sponsored-project-and-artful-ly-account))
##Build a Patron Database From Your Donor History. When you connect your Artful.ly account to your fiscally sponsored project, your donation records and contact information automatically synchronize to Artful.ly. In addition, any grants or donations to your project from institutional funders appear as Company Records in your database.
You can add notes about donations, details about donors, and see that information alongside ticket sales and communication records. This will help you stay in touch with your patrons, keep them updated on your events, and track your biggest supporters.
##Sell tickets Having control of ticket sales is an important step in growing your business. Artful.ly allows you to sell tickets for your events in advance and accept credit cards at minimal cost to you:
Online tickets include a $2 service fee paid by the patron, and credit card transactions include a merchant fee of 3.5%, which is automatically deducted from each sale.
The 7% fiscal sponsorship fee does not apply to ticket sales. To set up your paid ticketing kit, we need a completed [EFT form](https://www.artfullyhq.com/forms/artfully_etf_sign_up.pdf) emailed or faxed to us along with copy of a voided check.
**Please Note: **It is not currently possible for fiscally sponsored project to sell tax deductible or partially deductible tickets through Artful.ly (or any other ticketing platform). [Show your support for this feature in our Feature Request Forum here.](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/feature_request_view?id=271) In the meantime, you may use the giving levels on your sponsored project page to offer tickets as a perk to donors. Contact the fiscal sponsorship team for more details at support@fracturedatlas.org.
##Take Donations on Your Website The majority of funding for arts organizations comes from individual donations. As a sponsored project using Artful.ly, you can solicit tax-deductible donations for the purpose of your project without directing your patrons off your website.
To do this, you need either the [donation widget](/site/knowledgebase/what-is-the-widget-and-how-does-it-work) or [WordPress plugin](/site/knowledgebase/installing-using-the-wordpress-plugin) installed on your website. You'll need to know a bit of web programming to install the widget but what you'll get is a elegant way to receive donations. Donations received through Artful.ly will be automatically placed in your sponsored fund and kept separate from your ticket revenue, which gets sent directly to your bank account.
##You can also check out our webinar for sponsored projects using Artful.ly: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/dQpmvwMGcW8" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
**Related Articles:** - [What is a CRM and why do I need one?](/site/knowledgebase/what-is-a-crm-and-why-do-i-need-one)
- [Donations to Fractured Atlas Fiscally Sponsored Projects](/site/knowledgebase/donations-to-fiscally-sponsored-projects)
- [How do I connect my fiscally sponsored project to Artful.ly?](/site/knowledgebase/connect-your-sponsored-project-and-artful-ly-account)
As a sponsored project, can I sell tax-deductible tickets with Artful.ly?

**Short Answer:**
No.
**Long Answer:**
Donations to fiscally sponsored projects that come through Artful.ly are deposited in your sponsored fund and released to you when you submit a documented request. But with Artful.ly, ticket revenue goes directly to your bank account so we do not have the opportunity to oversee and approve the way you spend these funds. If we can't monitor how the funds are both collected and spent, than we can't give your patrons a tax-receipt.
This logic applies to memberships and passes too. The revenue for those also goes directly to your bank account so we can't issue tax-receipts for those sales either.
However, a patron may add a fully tax-deductible donation on top of a ticket purchase. Those donations go directly to your sponsored fund and are charged the 7% fiscal sponsorship fee.
We do plan to build features that allow sponsored projects to sell partially-deductible tickets, memberships, and passes. We just haven't gotten to that yet. If this is important to your organization, make your voice heard by [adding a vote for this in our feature request forum](https://artfully.zendesk.com/entries/21620351-Allow-fiscally-sponsored-projects-to-sell-tax-deductible-tickets-memberships-and-passes).
Five Steps to Producing a Successful Artful.ly Event

Here's a quick checklist of things to do and think about as you produce your event.
##1. Ticketing Set Up * **Activate the Paid Event Ticketing Kit.** If you want to charge for tickets, make sure we've activated it for you *before* you fill out the Event Details and Show information. It will save you from potentially having to backtrack and start over with your pricing information. [Here's how to do that if you need to](/site/knowledgebase/editing-ticket-information-for-existing-shows). * **Set your [capacity and ticket Availability](/site/knowledgebase/ticket-types-capacity).** Make sure you accurately set your capacity before publishing your event. Otherwise, your ticket availability might show up incorrectly (or not at all) on the Event Storefront where people buy tickets.
* **Add descriptions to your Ticket Types:** Use this to communicate important details about checking in at the event, purchase policies, event disclaimers, or specific price point perks to your patrons. Patrons will see this text in their [Order Confirmation emails](/site/knowledgebase/what-do-receipts-look-like).
##2. Event Promotion * **[Familiarize yourself with your Artful.ly storefronts](/site/knowledgebase/sell-tickets-via-central-storefront-and-event-storefront):** This is where people will go to find out more about your event and buy tickets. * **[Install The Artful.ly Widget](/site/knowledgebase/what-is-the-widget-and-how-does-it-work)** if you are interested in selling tickets from within your own site. * **Tell people about it!** Whether you use the Central Storefront link or link to a page on your website—put that link everywhere people will find it and buy tickets: Emails, social media, website, postcards, posters, text messages.... everywhere!
##3. Use the Box Office to Sell Tickets * **Grow your audience:** Get the names of people who show up at the last minute to buy tickets—[Use the Box Office!](/site/knowledgebase/box-office-sell-tickets-at-the-door)
**This is how you'll build your database of patrons. Its probably the most useful thing you can do to expand your network of support to the people you don't already know.**
* **Manage your internal sales and comps:** You can also sell tickets over the phone and issue comps for each show though the [Sales Console](/site/knowledgebase/sales-console-a-private-sales-channel-for-complex-orders) and for a particular show through the [Box Office](/site/knowledgebase/box-office-sell-tickets-at-the-door).
##4. Check Your Patrons In * **Use the Door List: **Each time you check the box next to a person's name a "Went" action will be logged on their record. This helps you track who actually showed up for future reference. If you just printed out the list, you can go back and do this after the event to make sure this information gets logged. * **The Door List App:** We've released an app to the iOS app store to help check in patrons right from an iPhone—[check it out!](/site/knowledgebase/the-artful-ly-app-door-list-for-your-iphone-or-ipod-touch)
##5. Post Event Follow Up * **Say thank you:** Since you've tracked all of your ticket sales, and checked people in from the Door List, you can now [Search and Segment](/site/knowledgebase/advanced-search-and-list-segments) all the people who came to say thanks and continue the relationship
* **Track patrons:** Using advanced search, you can [make tags and log notes](/site/knowledgebase/how-can-i-use-tags) on records of specific people who bought tickets. It might help you target your communication to them for your next production and future outreach * **Plan for your next event:** using that same list of people who attended your last event- you can quickly make sure that your audience gets invited to the next one.
Connect Your Sponsored Project & Artful.ly Account

**Link Artful.ly To Your Fractured Atlas Membership**
Linking Artful.ly to your fiscal sponsorship allows you to accept donations to your sponsored fund in addition to ticketing events. Connecting the account imports your donation history and donor records received through Fractured Atlas. Once this information is in your Artful.ly account you can manage your contacts and keep track of patrons.
1. Navigate to your **Account Administration** page.
![Account Administration](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=1 "Account Administration")
2. Find the section labeled Fractured Atlas and select **connect now**.
![Account Administration Detail](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=2 "Account Administration Detail")
3. Enter your Fractured Atlas username and password when "Connect to Fractured Atlas" appears.
![Connect to Fractured Atlas Modal](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=4 "Connect to Fractured Atlas Modal")
## Access To Donation History And Donor Records
* If your Sponsored Project is **active**, your donation history and donor information will sync with your Artful.ly account. This information is visible in your [Orders](/site/knowledgebase/transaction-history-sales-and-contributions). Donation information is synced once per hour, so any new donations processed by Fractured Atlas will reflect in your Artful.ly account. * Donor information will create[People Records](/site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-create-a-new-people-record). You can edit this information within Artful.ly for your records, and you can even export it. * Institutional giving imports as [Company Records.](/site/knowledgebase/company-records) This includes monetary gifts, grants, and in-kind donations from any organization. * If your project is **terminated, expired, **or** frozen**, your donation history and donor information will be imported into Artful.ly but you will have to re-activate your fiscally sponsored project to receive new donations through Artful.ly. Contact [support@fracturedatlas.org](mailto:support@fracturedatlas.org) with any fiscal sponsorship questions. * **Note: Any changes made through Artful.ly will not be reflected in your donation history on your My Fiscal Sponsorship page, nor will it effect any tax receipts issued. If you need to correct or change any information for tax purposes contact [support@fracturedatlas.org](mailto:support@fracturedatlas.org)**
## Accept Donations Through Artful.ly
* Donations made to sponsored projects using Artful.ly process through Fractured Atlas. Tax receipts are issued per the[ Fiscal Sponsorship Program guidelines](http://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/). Donations processed for Fiscally Sponsored Projects are still subject to the 7% administrative fee assessed for donations. Donations in Artful.ly can only be made by credit card. * You can receive donations either through an event Storefront or on your own website with a [widget](/site/knowledgebase/what-is-the-widget-and-how-does-it-work) for donations only or a combined event/donation widget. Embedding widgets on your site means your donors and patrons never have to leave your site to make those transactions! * Only **fully deductible donations** where no goods or services have been provided to the donor can be accepted through Artful.ly at this time. Partially deductible donations are planned for a [future update.](/site/knowledgebase/feature-development-roadmap "Feature Development Roadmap")
## Ticketing through Artful.ly
* All ticketing income is **earned revenue** because the funds go directly to your bank account. This revenue is not deductible through the Fiscal Sponsorship Program. * In order to opt into the Paid Ticketing Kit you'll need to send a copy of the completed the [EFT Form](https://www.artful.ly/forms/artfully_etf_sign_up.pdf) along with a copy of voided check to [support@artful.ly](mailto:support@artful.ly) or fax it to 815-366-8174. **Note: If you already have EFT information on file with Fractured Atlas for your project you will still need to submit a new form for Artful.ly. Our EFT service requires this.** * Once an Artful.ly admin approves your Paid Event Ticketing Kit, you'll receive a confirmation via email and will be able to set-up a paid event.
## Use Artful.ly to Deepen Relationships and Grow Your Arts Business!
Check out this article to help you get the most out of Artful.ly's patron management tools:
**[What is a CRM and why do I need one?](/site/knowledgebase/what-is-a-crm-and-why-do-i-need-one)**
Account Set Up

<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/dSVW4Uuro2s" width="425" height="350" frameborder="0"></iframe>
## 1. Create an Account
* To begin using Artful.ly you'll need to have a Fractured Atlas membership. If you are already a Fractured Atlas member, you may log in using your existing credentials, or if you don't have one, you can create a free Fractured Atlas membership using your email address. To use Artful.ly you only need a Community level membership. [Get your free membership here.](https://cas.fracturedatlas.org/signups/new?service=https://www.artful.ly/users/service).
## 2. Complete Your Organization Information
* Upon first signing up, you'll be asked to fill out information about your Organization. 'Organization' in this case can mean you as an individual artist, your production company, or the name of your fiscally sponsored project. Requested info includes a name and email for your organization, a website if you have one, and your primary artistic discipline. Don't worry, there is an 'Other' category.
## 3. Activate Paid Event Ticketing
* Every Artful.ly organization get access to the Free Event Ticketing kit to start so you can create a free event without any more set up. Or... * If you want to sell tickets for your events you will need to activate the Paid Event Ticketing Kit. Opt into this kit on the Organization Administration page. You will need to complete the [EFT Form](https://www.artful.ly/forms/artfully_etf_sign_up.pdf) attached below and return it to us along with a voided check. You can reach us at [support@artful.ly](mailto:support@ARTFUL.LY) or send it by fax at 815-366-8174 * If we have your EFT form and the voided check, we will approve your kit within one business day. * For more information about adding and managing events—[read up here!](/site/knowledgebase/creating-an-event) * It's important to keep your EFT info up to date. If your information is no longer accurate and we receive a returned settlement, there is a $10 fee per returned settlement.
## 4. Activate a Donation Kit
* If you're a registered 501(c)(3), you can opt into the **501(c)(3) Donations Kit** by sending us a copy of your IRS Determination letter and the [EFT form](https://www.artful.ly/forms/artfully_etf_sign_up.pdf). If you've activated the Paid Event Ticketing kit, we will only need the IRS Determination letter to approve your organization. Once we have your EFT form, the voided check, and IRS letter, then we will approve your kit within one business day. * If you're fiscally sponsored, you can easily link your project to your Artful.ly account and will be able to accept tax deductible donations from your donors. To do this, add your log-in details on the **Account Administration** page. You will still need to request the funds through your [My Fiscal Sponsorship page](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-release-funds), but you'll be able to access your donor histories and manage your donors' contact information in Artful.ly.
_Important note: Edits made to donor records on Artful.ly will not be reflected on the Fractured Atlas fiscal sponsorship side, and vice versa. If you need to change a donor's contact information for the tax receipt, or have a donation receipt reissued, be sure to contact [Fractured Atlas support](mailto:support@fracturedatlas.org). Read more about Artful.ly and fiscal sponsorship [here](https://staging.www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/connect-your-sponsored-project-and-artful-ly-account)_.

VIDEO: Getting Started & Account Set-Up

## This video shows you how to:  * Set up an account * Set up paid ticketing * Set up charity donations * Connect to your Fractured Atlas fiscally sponsored project * Adding Users to your Organization ## This video shows you how to:  * Set up an account * Set up paid ticketing * Set up charity donations * Connect to your Fractured Atlas fiscally sponsored project * Adding Users to your Organization
Who are my patrons and why should I track them in Artful.ly?

##Who are your patrons? **Patrons are your fans and supporters.** Their support comes from all directions: from attending your shows, giving you money, donating time, sharing your posts and tweets, talking about your work, pats on the back, etc. How do you keep track of it? Artful.ly can simplify and centralize that process so you can reach out and get to know the people who help make your work possible.
##Why should you track patrons in Artful.ly? **People who support you one way are often willing to give to you in other ways—if you ask. **If you know who came to your last show you'll already have a great list of people to invite to your next one. Or when you ask for a donation to support creating new work or ongoing projects. Or when you ask to spread the word to their friends. Since they are already familiar with you and your work, odds are they'll donate, continue to come to your shows, promote you in their social circles, etc.
**Think beyond family and friends.** Your good friends, and a few family members all came to your last show. Of course they did, they love you and think you're awesome. But what about all those people who showed up at the door. Who were they? Did you get their names? Do they love you too? Could they love you in time?
There's only one way to find out:
##Customer Relationship Management (CRM) Artful.ly's [CRM Tools](/site/knowledgebase/what-is-a-crm-and-why-do-i-need-one) take all of these people and allow you to track each interaction they have with your organization and art.
**Interactions Automatically Tracked by Artful.ly:** * [When fan buys a ticket online](/site/knowledgebase/sell-tickets-via-central-storefront-and-event-storefront) * When a supporter makes a donation online, both for [fiscally sponsored projects](/site/knowledgebase/connect-your-sponsored-project-and-artful-ly-account) and [501(c)(3) organizations](/site/knowledgebase/enabling-donations-for-501-c-3-nonprofits) * [When you sell a ticket to a fan at the door using Artful.ly's Box Office interface](/site/knowledgebase/box-office-sell-tickets-at-the-door) * When you sell a ticket over the phone using the [Sales Console](/site/knowledgebase/sales-console-a-private-sales-channel-for-complex-orders) * [When a fan receives an email sent from your synced MailChimp account](/site/knowledgebase/connecting-your-artful-ly-mailchimp-accountsy)
**Interactions You Can Log Manually in Artful.ly:** * [When you made a phone call, sent mail, sent an email, or sent/received other communications](/site/knowledgebase/actions-the-action-feed) * [Mailing address, email address, phone numbers, and birthdays](/site/knowledgebase/people-records-overview) * [Notes on individual fan's interests](/site/knowledgebase/notes-on-people-records) * [Volunteer hours](/site/knowledgebase/people-records-overview) * [Donations made offline (Only for 501(c)(3) organizations)](/site/knowledgebase/artful-ly-donation-management-tips)
**Information You Can Import:** * [Import people](/site/knowledgebase/importing-people) from other contact lists (email address books, paper mailing list sign-ups, website/blog subscriber lists, etc.) * [Import past event attendance](/site/knowledgebase/importing-events) (for events not ticketed through Artful.ly) * [Import donations (only for 501(c)(3) organizations)](/site/knowledgebase/importing-donations) (for donations not processed through Artful.ly)
If you import all of this information into your Artful.ly account—the next time these people make a donation, or attend an event, or do either of those for the first time, Artful.ly will track it automatically provided that they use the same email address listed in their [People Record](/site/knowledgebase/people-records-overview).
##Who should be in my CRM? 1. Lists from other email marketing tools 2. Past mailing lists for postcards or solicitation letters 3. Select contacts from your personal email account ([Here's how to get them from Gmail](/site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-get-my-gmail-contacts-into-artful-ly)) 4. Donors (for 501(c)(3) organizations)—[Importing Donations](/site/knowledgebase/importing-donations) 5. Post event attendanees—[Importing Events](/site/knowledgebase/importing-events) 6. Exports from past CRM or databases 7. Your press list (Tip: add a "Press" tag to their records) 8. Your donor prospect lists (Tip: tag them all with "Prospect") 9. Your vendors (Tip: tag them all with "Vendor") 10. Artists you work with regularly (Tip: tag them all with "Artist") 11. Board members (Tip: tag them all with "Board") 12. Volunteers (Tip: tag them all with "Volunteer")
Make sure you [format these lists properly so they import into Artful.ly nicely](/site/knowledgebase/importing-people).
##Related Topics * [What is a CRM and Why do I Need One?](/site/knowledgebase/what-is-a-crm-and-why-do-i-need-one) * [As a Fiscally Sponsored Project, What Can I Do With Artful.ly?](/site/knowledgebase/as-a-sponsored-project-what-can-i-do-with-artful-ly) * [Actions & The Action Feed](/site/knowledgebase/actions-the-action-feed) * [Tagging](/site/knowledgebase/how-can-i-use-tags)
Glossary of Artful.ly Terms

We know software vocabulary can be confusing, so we've created this glossary to clarify matters. If there is a word or phrase you think we should add, let us know in the comments section below! ## 501(c)(3) Donations Kit **The Charity Donation kit allows 501(c)3 organizations to accept credit card donations through Artful.ly.**  All credit card transactions processed through Artful.ly, including donations, are subject to a 3.5% credit card fee. Fractured Atlas Sponsored Projects use the **Sponsored Donations Kit**. ## Actions **Actions are any and all contact between your Organization and a patron.** Types of Actions include: ticket purchases (Get), donations (Give), communications (Hear). Every Artful.ly processed Action (ticket purchases and donations) is logged on that patron's People Record. You can also add Give and Hear Actions on an individual's People Record. ## Company **Companies are a type of People Record. There are five sub-types of Company Records--Business, Foundation, Government, Nonprofit, and Other.** You may assign contact info, actions, etc. to any Company record just as you would to an Individual record. ## Dashboard **Your Dashboard is the first page you see after you've signed in and your home base for account management.** It includes information about your Events, your Organization, and Recent Activity on your account. ## Events **Events are a "run" of Shows.** For example, if you are putting on a production of Hamlet for one week, the entire week would consist of the "Event." The performance that happens at 8PM on Thursday would be a Show. Please refer to the definition of "Show". ## Individual **Individuals are your ticket buyers, donors, patrons, customers, clients, etc.** Each individual record will include actions, contact info, etc. ## Kits **Kits are sets of features on the Artful.ly platform.** When you sign up, you automatically get the Free Event Ticketing kit and the People Management kit. You can opt into the Paid Event Ticketing kit, and either the 501(c)(3) Donations or the Sponsored Donation kits. ## Notes **Notes are pieces of information you can leave for reference on a People Record.** They are best used for recording observations about a patron, their preferences, or bits of prospect research. ## On Sale/ Off Sale **When you are managing tickets for a specific Show, you have the option to change the availability status of each Ticket Type.** If you "Put on sale" the tickets in that type are visible and patrons can buy them on the Storefront or widget. If you "Take off sale" the tickets in that type are visible but patrons who attempt to buy those those tickets will be told they are not available. On sale/ off sale status only applied to the Ticket Type status and is not the same as published or unpublished which applies to the whole Show. ## Paid Event Ticketing Kit **The Paid Event Ticketing kit allows you to charge for tickets online.** To activate this kit you need to provide us with some banking details so we can electronically transfer your money to you. When you sell paid tickets through Artful.ly, your ticket buyers pay a $2 fee per ticket. That's the only fee from us! When you receive payment for a Show, 3.5% will be deducted for the credit card processing company.  ## People Records **People records come in two types, Individual and Company.** Each individual has his or her own People Record. ## Publish/Unpublish **Publish is how you make tickets for a Show available for people to buy online.** When you first create a Show have the option to click "Save" or "Save and Publish."  If you save and publish, the Show will be visible to the public on your Storefront and the ticketing widget if you choose to use it. If you just save the Show it will default to unpublished status and will not be visible on either the Storefront or the widget. You can publish or unpublish a show at any time from the Shows overview page. ## Reports **Reports summarize how well a Show has done and what payments are owed to you.** You can also find importing and exporting features under the Reports tab on the top Artful.ly menu. ## Show **A Show is an individual instance of an Event**. A single performance, screening, showing, etc. For example, if you are putting on a production of Macbeth all week, the Event consists of the entire week. The Show, however, is what happens on Friday at 8PM. ## Settlements **Settlements are a kind of Report that details the fund transfers from Artful.ly to your bank account.** Transfers are made 2 business days after your show has occurred or after the donation has been made. You can view Settlements under the "Report" tab. ## Sponsored Donation Kit **The Sponsored Donation Kit gives Fractured Atlas Fiscally Sponsored Projects the ability to accept credit card donations through Artful.ly.** All donation rules and protocols for Fiscally Sponsored Projects apply. [Learn more about Artful.ly for Fiscally Sponsored Projects here](https://artfully.zendesk.com/entries/21293527-artful-ly-101-for-fractured-atlas-fiscally-sponsored-projects). ## Statements **Statements are a type of report that details the ticket sales and attendance for a single Show.** You can view Statements under the "Reports" tab. ## Storefront **A Storefront is a publicly viewable webpage that is automatically created for each of your Events**. Each Storefront has a unique URL that you can share with people so they can buy tickets for your Event. You can change the content of your Storefronts by editing the Details on your Event page. ## Ticket Type **A Ticket Type defines the price and features of each kind of ticket you want to offer to an Event**. Common Ticket Types include General Admission, Student Tickets, Balcony, VIP, etc. You can name a Ticket Type anything you want and set the price and capacity to meet your needs. Ticket Types can be set for an Event under the Event Details tab. You can also edit the Ticket Types offered at a specific Show under the Shows tab. ## Transactions **Transactions is  where you will find a list of all the Sales and a list of all the Contributions processed through Artful.ly for your organization.** You can search within either Sales or Contributions or both.  ## Vertical Bar A vertical bar is a typographical character also known as a "pipe character". On a conventional QWERTY keyboard, it is usually create with [Shift] + \ . When importing a CSV of People, you must use a vertical bar to separate multiple tags in the Tags column. ## Widget **A Widget is a tool that you can install on your own website through which your patrons can buy tickets and/or make donations to you through Artful.ly.** You can generate the css and javascript code for the Widget either under Events on the top menu or through the Share & Sell tab on your Event page.  Installing the widget requires basic programming knowledge.
I'm fiscally sponsored, where does my ticket money go?

* **Revenue from Artful.ly transfers directly to your bank account.** Because the money goes to you and not Fractured Atlas, ticket sales, memberships, and passes are not tax-deductible and do not count towards your grant eligibility requirement.
We plan to build features to sell tax-deductible tickets, memberships, and passes. If you want these features for your organization, please make sure to vote for it in our feature request forum: [Allow Fiscally Sponsored Projects to Sell Tax Deductible Tickets, Memberships, and Passes](/site/knowledgebase/feature_request_view?id=271).
* **Fully tax-deductible donations may be made in addition to a ticket sale**. Your patrons have the option to donate to your project at checkout. Those donations go directly to your sponsored fund just like any other donation.
Fiscally sponsored projects may also use the [Artful.ly Widget](/site/knowledgebase/what-is-the-widget-and-how-does-it-work) or [Wordpress Plugin](/site/knowledgebase/installing-using-the-wordpress-plugin) to take donations directly on their sites.
* **Funds from events ticketed through Artful.ly arrive in your bank account 7-10 business days after each show. **Artful.ly settles funds from ticket sales two business days after each show in your event, but your bank can take another 5-7 business to process those funds and post them your account.
What should I put for EIN?

## What is my EIN number?
**An EIN is a tax identification number used for business entities including non-profit organizations.** To set up the 501(c)(3) Donations Kit, you need to input your organization's EIN number in addition to submitting your IRS determination letter. EIN numbers are always nine digits and are usually listed on your IRS determination letter.
![Tax Information Boxes](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=8 "Tax Information Boxes")
**Fiscally Sponsored projects should NOT fill out this form.** Instead, you'll connect your account to your [Sponsored Fund.](/site/knowledgebase/connect-your-sponsored-project-and-artful-ly-account)
For-profit business entities cannot use the Charity Donations kit because they are ineligible to receive tax-deductible donations.
Can I use Artful.ly with other fiscal sponsors?

To process donations by credit card, your organization must be either a 501(c)(3) or fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas. We cannot process donations for other fiscal sponsors.
**However, these Artful.ly features are free and open to anyone:**
* [CRM](/site/knowledgebase/what-is-a-crm-and-why-do-i-need-one) * [Selling tickets](/site/knowledgebase/four-sales-channels-explained) * [Mailchimp Integration](/site/knowledgebase/what-is-mailchimp-and-why-should-i-use-it) * [Importing sales and/or attendance records from past events](/site/knowledgebase/importing-people) * [Importing donations](/site/knowledgebase/importing-donations)
Fractured Atlas's fiscal sponsorship program is also non-exclusive; it's fine with us if you want to be sponsored both by us and someone else. If you decide to pursue a second sponsorship, check with your sponsor about their policies. You might also ask your sponsor if they can send you donation records in a CSV. You can then import the information into Artful.ly and keep donations and ticket sales records all in one place.
You can find out more about Fractured Atlas Fiscal Sponsorship program [here](http://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/ "Fiscal Sponsorship").
How do I report bugs and other website problems?

**The best way to report a problem you're having with the website is to send us an email at [support@artful.ly](mailto:support@artful.ly). Be sure to include the following information:** * **Username** you used to log in * **Internet browser** you were using—Chrome, Safari, Firefox, Internet Explorer, etc. [(How to tell what browser type and version you are using.](http://www.whatbrowser.org/)) * **Version** of the browser you were using * **Action** you performed right before the error occurred * **Time** that error occurred * **URL** on the page that you found the error * **A screenshot** of the error page attached to your email. ([How to take a screenshot.](http://take-a-screenshot.org/))
Our support staff will be able to assist you faster if you're able to provide as much detail as possible in an email.
What's it cost?

**The basic functions of Artful.ly are free.** This includes online sales of free tickets and the CRM. All credit card transactions—except donations to Fractured Atlas Fiscally Sponsored Projects—are subject to a 3.5% credit card merchant fee. There is also a $2 service fee per online ticket sold that is passed on to the ticket buyer. There are no ticket fees attached to cash transactions through the Box Office interface.
## Artful.ly Pricing Breakdown##
| KIT | PRICING | |--------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------| | People Management Kit | FREE | | Free Ticketing Kit | FREE | | 501(c)(3) Donations Kit | 3.5% credit card fee. Requires proof of 501(c)(3) status. | | Sponsored Donations Kit | 7% administration fee. Requires Fractured Atlas fiscal sponsorship | | Paid Event Ticketing Kit | $2 per ticket. No $2 fee for cash or box office sales. 3.5% credit card fee.| | Memberships Kit | 5% fee on pass price, producer or patron can pay. 3.5% credit card fee | | Passes Kit | 5% fee on pass price, producer or patron can pay. 3.5% credit card fee |
## Some Examples
**A Ticket Sale:** A ticket to your production of Hamlet costs $15\. A ticket buyer uses her Visa to buy a ticket through Artful.ly and is charged $17\. We keep $2 of that. Visa charges 3.5% of the $15 - that's $.053\. In the end, you receive $14.47.
**A $0 Ticket Sale:** A ticket for your New Works Reading costs $0\. A ticket buyer does not have to give credit card info to reserve that ticket online. She is not charged anything--no $2 service fee. You will receive $0.
**A Mixed Ticket Sale:** You're charging $5 for Adult tickets and $0 for Child tickets. The patron buys one of each and pays $5 +$2 = $7\. You will receive $4.83.
**A Donation to a 501(c)(3):** A friend can't make it to your production of Hamlet but decides to make a $100 donation to your organization online. His MasterCard is charged $100\. There is a 3.5% processing fee on that transaction. You get $96.50.
**A Donation to a sponsored project:** Your biggest fan donates $100 to your project's campaign through Artful.ly. Her Visa is charged $100\. Fractured Atlas assess the standard fiscal sponsorship fee of 7%. Your fiscal sponsorship account is credited with $93\. There is no additional 3.5% credit card processing fee. You can learn more about fiscal sponsorship [here.](http://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/ "Fractured Atlas Fiscal Sponsorship")
**Related Articles** - [Pass Fees & Settlements](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/beta-pass-fees-settlements) - [Membership Fees & Settlements](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/beta-membership-fees-settlements) - [When and how do I get my money?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/when-and-how-do-i-get-my-money)
Do I have to sign a contract?

**There's no obligation to stick with Artful.ly.** If it's not working for you, you can export your data and leave, although we hope you'd first [give us feedback](/site/knowledgebase/feature_request_list?topic=Artful.ly) and a chance to make things right.
Can I use Artful.ly if I am not a 501(c)(3)?

**Artful.ly is open for use by absolutely anyone to organize patron information and sell tickets. ** If you want to use Artful.ly to take donations, you need to either be registered with the IRS as a 501(c)(3) charitable organization OR fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas.
Artful.ly cannot support donations to fiscally sponsored projects outside of the Fractured Atlas program. [Learn more about the Fractured Atlas's Fiscal Sponsorship Program here.](http://www.fracturedatlas.org/fiscal)
What are Artful.ly's time and technical requirements?

## How long does it generally take to learn Artful.ly and set up my account?##
Not long! Sign-up takes less than 5 minutes.
Submitting forms for electronic fund transfers takes about 10 minutes; we usually approve fund transfer set ups within one business day.
Importing a list of patrons from Excel or an old database might take 10 minutes or an hour depending on how many patrons you have.
Creating a new event for ticketing could take roughly 10 to 30 minutes, depending on the number of price points or ticket types you want to offer. Finally, putting the transaction widget on your site takes maybe 15 minutes if you're familiar with JavaScript.
## What are the technical requirements?##
Artful.ly only requires a computer and Internet connection.There's nothing to install. Artful.ly lives on the internet like Gmail or Facebook. As long as you have an Internet connection, you will have access to your patron data, ticket sales, and all Artful.ly functionality.
**Related Articles** - [Getting Started With Artful.ly](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/getting-started-with-artful-ly) - [Account Set Up](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/account-set-up)
Writing & Formatting Knowledge Base Articles (CC)

Writing and formatting articles for the public Knowledge Base and the Internal Knowledge Base work basically the same way... ### Article Titles - **Choose a question or a statement.** Compose article titles that are either: - A statement that uses [title case capitalization](http://titlecase.com) (eg. Feature Development Roadmap) - A question with standard sentence capitalization (eg. Do I have to sign a contract?) - **65 characters or less.** This keep titles to one line and makes browsing easier. - **Save the slugs!** The first time you save an article, the title will become part of the URL for that article. If you edit the article title, a new URL will be created, but the original URL will still exist and redirect to the new URL. Saving URL "slugs" like this helps prevent broken links. - **Two articles can have the same title,** an extra dash will just be added to the end of the second article's slug. Avoid giving the same name to two articles if possible though since it could confuse members. ### Content Tips - **Use Fractured Atlas voice and tone.** The [Fractured Atlas Brand Book](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1qs6ToC9NsAqV1ZN9ZLyS4WX7GWkRo40BMdbIF1fN9FE) details the appropriate voice and tone for customer communications. For Knowledge Base articles, the goal is to communicate process-based information to users who need help with a task. The audience is a combination of members and prospective members. The tone should be straightforward and simple. Users are looking to get something done. Use humor sparingly. - **Keep articles short.** Long articles are intimidating and confusing. Consider breaking one long article into two. (This article is very bad example of this principle.) On the other hand, browsing a bunch of articles that are just one sentence answers is annoying. Try to strike a balance and aim for a word count of about 100-500. - **Number steps.** Break processes down into discrete steps and number those steps. - **Explain the logic** behind a step if doing so clarifies the process. If it doesn't help, don't waste the reader's time. - **Use screenshots.** Not every step needs an image, but one per key step is helpful. ### Formatting Article Content Markdown is the text formatting syntax used in our KB. Many of the basic formatting styles can be applied with the nifty Markdown toolbar at the top of the Content editing field. If you're feeling fancy, dig into a Markdown cheat sheet like this one and learn some new tricks. Here are some basic formatting tips: - **Unordered lists** or bulleted lists should be used when the order of the items does not matter. To create a unordered list, highlight the text and click the toolbar icon with four rows. - **Ordered lists** or numbered lists should be used when the order of the items is important, such as describing steps of a process. To create a numbered list, highlight the text and click the toolbar icon with three rows. Do not manually number lists. - **Nested lists** are lists with multiple levels or tiers. To create them: - First create a basic list. - To indent a line, add two spaces before the dash to indent to the second level. - Additional levels are created by adding two more spaces before a dash. - Open this article in edit mode to see what the markdown looks like here. - **Quote** is a toolbar button for creating off-set block quotes. - **Code** is a tool bar button that allows you to display code without rendering it. You probably won't ever use this in public-facing articles, but there's an example of this for the em dash below. - **Em dash** can be created with this code: `—`This will not render properly in preview mode, but you'll see it once you save the article. - **Line breaks** often to not translate from the editing view to the published view. To ensure a line break, add two spaces after the final punctuation mark before your line break. - **Anchor links** may be possible in Markdown, but it would require some pretty involved HTML. You're welcome to experiment. - **Preview.** Make sure to check your formatting by clicking the "Preview" button, then flip back to continue editing. When you are done writing, double check the formatting from the public-facing side of the KB. ### Links - **Embed a link.** Highlight the relevant text, click the link button in the toolbar, and enter the URL address. - **Use relative links.** When linking to any page on www.fracturedatlas.org (including other KB articles, feature request threads, or images in the asset library) use relative links. To do this, omit all of the characters before the first slash. For example, if you want to link to the staff page, just enter "/site/bios/staff". This helps maintain fast and consistent navigation within our own site. - **Email address links** can be formatted like so: `[text you want someone to see](mailto:email@emailaddress.none)` - **Use HTML for links to open in a new tab.** When you want a link to open in a new tab, for example any page or download link (such as a hosted PDF file) outside of www.fracturedatlas.org, use this HTML formatting: `Create Birmingham` ### Arranging Articles - **Define one category per article.** This will determine where the article appears. (Eventually, we will be able to put articles in more than one category, but we need to change the way position ranking works before that will work well.) - **Organize articles with position numbers** within a category by defining a numerical position of each article. In the "Position" field, enter a digit. The articles with the smallest position numbers will appear at the top of the category and those with the largest at the bottom. If you don’t enter a position number, the article will default to the top of the list. - **Space position numbers by 10s**. Give yourself spaces to add space to add additional articles in the future by initially assigning positions in increments of ten. So your first article has position 10, your second is 20, third is 30, and so on. Then, when you want to insert an article that is second from the top, you can give it position 15 and save yourself the trouble of renumbering all the subsequent articles. You can have two articles in the same position but the order will be random so space them out. - **Ignore tags.** When viewing an article in agent browse mode, you may see a field for tags. We haven't set that up yet. Just ignore it for now. ### Publishing - **Publish.** When the article is all ready to go, check the box next to "Publish" on the top right the bottom and then click the "Save." Now the article will appear on the public-facing Knowledgebase. You can unpublish at any time. - **Draft.** Articles that do not have the publish box checked, are considered to be in a draft state. You can see "draft" tags on articles in the articles list view. ### Migrating Articles Into KB - **Converting HTML to Markdown is easy.** Try [this tool.](https://domchristie.github.io/to-markdown) - **Convert Word to Markdown is trickier.** We tried a couple options, but for now the best bet is to convert the Word text to plain text, paste that in to the KB, and reformat there. Sorry. - **Check it!** Be sure to glance over the Markdown code that you copy and paste from the converter. Sometimes the transition can add errors such as an extra line break, asterisk, span, or div. Just delete those. ### \#KBQ Still got questions? Chances are, if you have a question, someone else has the same question. Post them to Flowdock with the hashtag KBQ and we'll crowdsource an answer for you. ### Related Articles: - [Intro to the Fractured Atlas Knowledge Base](/admin/Knowledgebase/view_article?id=191) - [Adding Images to Knowledge Base Articles](/admin/Knowledgebase/view_article?id=441)
What is the Fractured Atlas Insurance Program?

Fractured Atlas is a nonprofit tech company that helps artists with the business aspect of their operations. Our Insurance Program allows our members to [apply](/site/knowledgebase/how-to-apply-for-a-quote) for, [purchase](/site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-purchase-the-policy), and maintain insurance coverage for various parts of these operations.
It is staffed with insurance experts who are also practicing artists, so we understand our members’ needs and can guide you through the process of finding a quote.
We work with a brokers' office and several insurance companies to get our members the best policies for their specific needs and, although we are not an insurance company, we do have a licensed insurance broker on staff.
Does Fractured Atlas provide Health Insurance?

We have discontinued our Health Insurance program and refer our members to their state exchange or [healthcare.gov](http://www.healthcare.gov). You may also compare different policies at [eHealth](http://www.ehealthinsurance.com).
We still do advocate for affordable healthcare and you may refer to our [pocket guide](http://www.arts-insurance.info/guides/the-artists-guide-to-health-insurance/pages/how-it-should-work) for some tips on what to look for when looking for health insurance.
Still have questions?

If you have more questions, please feel free to email us! That's always the fastest way to get an answer.
Shoot an email to support@fracturedatlas.org and we'll get back to you as soon as possible and definitely within one business day. You can also refer to our [pocket guides](http://www.arts-insurance.info/guides) for more information about insurance for artists, based on your artistic discipline.
[Contact us](/site/helpdesk/)
Who can apply for insurance through Fractured Atlas?

Our program was designed to service artists. If you're work is not arts-related, you have options besides Fractured Atlas, which will be a better fit for you.
If you are looking for insurance for arts-related activities, you may [sign up](/site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-sign-up-for-fractured-atlas-membership-so-that-i-can-apply-for-insurance) for Fractured Atlas membership at the free Community level and then [apply](/site/knowledgebase/how-to-apply-for-a-quote) for a quote.
If you decide to purchase a policy, you will need to sign up at one of our dues-paying levels. Don't forget to check out our other Programs and Services that you can take advantage of, as part of your membership:
- [SpaceFinder](/site/spacefinder)
- [Artful.ly](/site/artfully)
- [Fiscal Sponsorship](/site/fiscal/)
How to Apply for a Quote

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/24sOQL1WQqo" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
- In order to apply for an insurance quote, you'll need to **sign up** for a membership with Fractured Atlas. You can sign up for a free Community level membership in order to apply for a quote, but in order to purchase coverage through us, you'll need to upgrade to either a Professional level membership ($10/month) or an Organizational membership ($20/month).
![Image showing the Sign Up/ Log In page](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=527 "Sign Up/Log In")
- Once you've signed up for membership, you'll need to log in to the Fractured Atlas website and go to **Insurance for Artists and Orgs** from the Services menu, where you will be able to find insurance applications by artistic discipline.

How to Answer Application Questions

We need a lot of information to get you a quote, and it's important that it be correct.
For some questions, such as with regard to projected attendance, revenue or other upcoming activities, we'll need you to estimate to the best of your ability. With your answers, we will then provide the insurance carrier with the most accurate picture of your activity to ensure we're getting you the insurance coverage you need.
Some selected question fields on the application will have specific notes that help explain what we're looking for:
![enter image description here](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=552 "enter image title here")
If you still have questions, please feel free to [contact us](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/?contactus=1).
How much does applying for insurance cost?

Applying for an insurance quote is free. In order to apply for a quote, you will need to sign up for a membership with Fractured Atlas. You can sign up at the free Community level in order to apply for a quote.
However, if you choose to purchase insurance through our program, you will need to upgrade to a paid Fractured Atlas membership, either at the Professional level ($10 a month) or the Organizational level ($20 a month).
How long does it take to get a quote?

It depends. Once we receive your application, we can usually provide a quote in 3-5 business days. However, some quotes (like Errors and Omissions or Workers’ Compensation), may take more time. Other quotes, such as Equipment coverage and Volunteer Accident Insurance, are usually ready more quickly, in about 1-2 business days.
Rush Requests for Insurance Applications

If you need your quote sooner than the standard 3-5 business day turnaround, we can attempt to have your quote rushed within one business day.
If you want to request a rush, just send us an e-mail to support@fracturedatlas.org after you submit your application. We'll then check with the insurers we work with to see if a rush will be possible.
If we can have your quote rushed within one business day, we'll follow up with you and collect the additional $100 rush fee. If we are unable to rush your quote, we won't charge the fee and will send you the quote as soon as is possible. Either way, we'll let you know.
How much does an insurance policy cost?

Since Fractured Atlas staff members are not insurance underwriters and insurance premiums vary significantly between applications and types of insurance, we cannot provide estimates without members [applying](/site/knowledgebase/how-to-apply-for-a-quote) for a quote.
We can try our best to offer an estimate on the minimum premium based on the quotes we've seen in the past, but the actual quote could be substantially different since it would be based on the operations described in the application.

What should I look for in a quote?

You just received a quote. Congratulations! Now that you have a quote in hand, it's time to figure out whether or not it will meet your needs. When evaluating your quote, you'll want to ask these questions:
- **What is the premium to purchase this policy?** The premium is the total cost of your coverage, so of course you'll want to know what it is before making your purchase.
- **What are the limits of this policy?** A limit of insurance is the maximum amount your policy will pay out in the event of a claim. There are a few important types of limits to know: - *Per occurrence*- This is the maximum amount that your policy will pay out for any one event. - *General aggregate*- This is the maximum amount your policy will pay out throughout the entire policy term. - Note: it's common to see both per occurrence and general aggregate limits on liability insurance policies. For example, a common limit pairing is $1 million per occurrence and $2 million general aggregate.
- **Is there a deductible on this policy?** A deductible is an amount you must pay out of pocket before your insurance coverage can "kick in." For instance, you might have a $500 deductible on your equipment insurance policy, meaning that when you lose your $5,000 camera, you will need to pay for the first $500 before the insurance company can pay out the remaining $4,500 loss.
- **Does this policy include additional insured coverage?** Entities like the venues and organizations you work with will often require that you list them as additional insured on your policy. This means that they will be covered under your policy for the operations you conduct in relationship with them. When checking your quote, you'll want to see either that the policy lists the specific additional insureds you've requested, or that it includes *blanket additional insured coverage*—that is, coverage for an unlimited number of additional insureds.
- **What is the coverage territory on this policy?** Some policies are valid worldwide, others are valid anywhere in the United States, many are specific to the locations you've listed on your application, and some are even specific to the physical address listed on your application. Make sure you know where you need to be covered, and double check that the quote you receive will extend to to those locations.
**I've taken a good look at my quote, but I still have questions. Help!** Feel free to ask us any remaining questions about your quote by replying to the quote notification email. We'll get right back to you with answers.
What happens if you can't get me a quote?

Unfortunately, there are times when none of the carriers we work with are able to provide quotes. This happens for a number of reasons, but there are a few recurring themes: it is often difficult for carriers to insure music videos, aerial work, rap/hip-hop/heavy metal concerts, and other activities that they view as high-risk.
Please be assured that Fractured Atlas will do everything we can to find you a quote. We make a point to consult all available insurance carriers before we determine that a quote cannot be issued. In the event that we cannot provide a quote, however, we are also happy to refer you to a number of outside insurance resources, which may be able to help find the coverage you're looking for. Just ask, and we'll look into some alternative options.
