What's the binder fee?

The binder fee is a fee paid directly to Fractured Atlas in order to put your coverage in place. Paying your binder fee means that you are accepting the insurance quote that was issued to you. It is $100 or 10% of the premium for each policy (whichever is greater). Binder fees for renewals will be discounted.
It's our administrative fee for all of our policies that makes this program possible!
Glossary of Insurance Terms

**ACORD** A standards development organization for the insurance industry, ACORD creates the standard forms we use, including insurance certificates.
**Additional Insured** An entity that you add to your insurance policy that needs to be covered if they have an insurance claim that arises because of your activities. This is usually used when our members add venues or filming locations as Additional Insureds. You can add an entity as an Additional Insured by requesting a certificate for them.
**Additional Premium to Equal Policy Minimum** Underwriters use a rating process to determine your insurance premium. When that rate is below the absolute minimum premium that the insurer has established for that policy, “additional premium to equal policy minimum” will appear as a line item on your quote, bringing your rate up to the minimum premium.
**A.M. Best** An independent company that provides credit ratings of insurance companies. Their financial-strength ratings measure an insurance company’s ability to pay claims.
**Binder** A temporary contract of insurance, oral or written, offered by an insurer pending issuance of a permanent policy. It is usually written for a period of 30 days and remains in force until a permanent policy is either issued or denied.
**Binder Fee** A fee paid directly to Fractured Atlas in order to put your coverage in place. Paying your binder fee means that you are accepting the insurance quote that was issued to you.
**Broker** A broker represents the person or company seeking insurance (the insured).
**Business Personal Property** Items such as office furniture, phones, and fixtures that you use in your business.
**Cash Value** (Replacement Cost minus depreciation). Our equipment policy is Replacement Cost, which pays out more in the event of a claim.
**Certificate of Insurance (COI)** A document that evidences the existence of insurance coverage.
**Claim** A formal request to the insurance company asking for payment based on the terms of your insurance policy.
**Data/Negative Loss** This coverage will pay for physical loss or damage to negatives or digital data, covering expenses from hard drive recovery to the expenses incurred to re-shoot the lost or damaged material.
**Deductible** This is the amount of the claim that you will pay out of pocket before the insurance company starts paying.
**Employment Practices Liability** This coverage comes into play if someone files a lawsuit against you based on your employment practices, i.e., independent contractor vs. employee suits, gender discrimination, etc.
**Endorsement** A form added to an insurance policy that modifies the coverage in some way. These are produced by the insurance company itself, and typically take 2-10 business days to be processed.
**General Aggregate Limit** The highest dollar amount of insurance that the insurance company will pay out if you have multiple claims during a policy term (usually one year).
**General Liability** A policy that covers you if you injure other people or other people’s stuff.
**Hired and Non-Owned Auto Liability** Covers you when an auto that you lease, hire or borrow causes damage to someone or something else. It does not include damage to the auto itself.
**Hired Auto Physical Damage** Covers damage to the auto itself.
**Insured** You, if you have an insurance policy.
**Insurer** The insurance company that issues your policy.
**Limit** The most your insurance policy will pay for a specific type of claim.
**Loss Payee** The entity that is paid in the event of an equipment claim. If you are renting equipment from a rental house, they will ask to be added as Loss Payee, so that the insurance company will pay them directly if equipment rented to you is damaged.
**Medical Payments** “No fault” coverage for first aid and medical services. Sometimes referred to as “Good Neighbor” coverage, this coverage means that the policy will pay even if negligence isn’t established.
**Newly Acquired Equipment** A provision included on most equipment policies that covers you for equipment that any reasonable and prudent person would not have had time to add to their insurance policy between when they acquired it and when the loss occurred.
**Per Occurrence Limit** The highest dollar amount of insurance that the insurance company will pay out per claim. **Personal and Advertising Injury** An injury, other than bodily injury, arising out of oral or written publication of material (including advertising) that slanders or libels another’s goods, products, or services, or that infringes on copyright, title, or slogan.
**Policy** A contract between the insurer and insured, which determines the claims that the insurer is legally required to pay.
**Premium** The cost of the insurance policy, paid to the insurance company.
**Products and Completed Operations** This limit will cover you if a claim arises caused by a product that you sell that is no longer in your possession, or that happens after you have completed a job and left the premises. For instance, if you sell someone a sweater, and six months later they sue you, claiming that the sweater turned their skin green, this is the coverage that would come into play.
**Quote** An offer of insurance issued by an insurer. It will tell you how much premium your policy will cost.
**Quote Expiration Date** The last day you can purchase your insurance quote without having to reapply.
**Rental Reimbursement** This coverage will pay for you to rent replacement equipment when your equipment is damaged, resulting in an insurance claim. This is similar to when your car insurance will pay for a rental car while yours is in the shop.
**Replacement Cost** The amount of money it would cost to replace a damaged or destroyed item with one of like kind and quality at the time of loss. An equipment policy is either Replacement Cost or Actual
**Terrorism Risk Insurance Act (TRIA)** A federal law that has existed since 2002 that provides government backup for insurance claims that arise out of acts of terrorism. It allows you to purchase insurance that will still pay out if you have a claim as a result of a terrorist act.
**Umbrella** Provides coverage for higher limits than are generally available under basic liability policies, as well as for liability exposures either limited or excluded under basic liability policies.
**Workers Compensation Audit** Your premium is based on how much you pay out to employees. Every year, your policy will be audited by the insurance company, and you will receive a credit or charged extra premium, depending on how your audit compares to your payroll estimates at the beginning of the year.
**Your Tools** This coverage will pay for hand-held manual tools, like screwdrivers and hammers, valued at $1,000 or less.
Terms on Equipment and Property Quotes

**Data/Negative Loss** This coverage will pay for physical loss or damage to negatives or digital data, covering expenses from hard drive recovery to the expenses incurred to re-shoot the lost or damaged material.
**Newly Acquired Equipment** A provision included on most equipment policies that covers you for equipment that any reasonable and prudent person would not have had time to add to their insurance policy between when they acquired it and when the loss occurred.
**Rental Reimbursement** This coverage will pay for you to rent replacement equipment when your equipment is damaged, resulting in an insurance claim. This is similar to when your car insurance will pay for a rental car while yours is in the shop.
**Replacement Cost** The amount of money it would cost to replace a damaged or destroyed item with one of like kind and quality at the time of loss. An equipment policy is either Replacement Cost or Actual
**Cash Value** (Replacement Cost minus depreciation). Our equipment policy is Replacement Cost, which pays out more in the event of a claim.
**Your Tools** This coverage will pay for hand-held manual tools, like screwdrivers and hammers, valued at $1,000 or less.
Terms for Limits and Types of Coverage on Quotes

Quotes tend to include a lot of insurance jargon. What does it all mean? Here's what you need to know:
**Per Occurrence Limit** The highest dollar amount of insurance that the insurance company will pay out per claim.
**General Aggregate Limit** The highest dollar amount of insurance that the insurance company will pay out if you have multiple claims during a policy term (usually one year).
**Business Personal Property** Items such as office furniture, phones, and fixtures that you use in your business.
**Employment Practices Liability** This coverage comes into play if someone files a lawsuit against you based on your employment practices, i.e., independent contractor vs. employee suits, gender discrimination, etc.
**Hired & Non-Owned Auto Liability** Covers you when an auto that you lease, hire or borrow causes damage to someone or something else. This coverage does NOT include damage to the vehicle itself.
**Hired Auto Physical Damage** Covers damage to the auto itself.
**Medical Payments** “No fault” coverage for first aid and medical services. Sometimes referred to as “Good Neighbor” coverage, this coverage means that the policy will pay even if negligence isn’t established.
**Personal and Advertising Injury** An injury, other than bodily injury, arising out of oral or written publication of material (including advertising) that slanders or libels another’s goods, products, or services, or that infringes on copyright, title, or slogan.
**Products and Completed Operations** This limit will cover you if a claim arises caused by a product that you sell that is no longer in your possession, or that happens after you have completed a job and left the premises. For instance, if you sell someone a sweater, and six months later they sue you, claiming that the sweater turned their skin green, this is the coverage that would come into play.
I've purchased the policy. Is it active?

While you have paid for and bound your policy, the insurance company will have to bind the policy as well. This may entail the completion of "binder contingencies" depending on your quote. We will let you know if there are any binder contingencies as soon as we receive them.
Also, different insurers will require different methods of payment. Some will collect the premium directly and some will have us collect the full amount upon binding. This will be clarified upon checkout and we will provide instructions on how to pay for your policy.
What is an "Additional Insured?"

Additional insureds are entities covered for your specific operations based on their relationship with you. Sometimes venues or organizations ask to be included as additional insured and that's not a problem at all.
Our policies generally come with unlimited (or “blanket”) additional insureds. You can [request certificates](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/request-a-certificate) right through the Insurance section of your member account.
Request a Certificate

You may request certificates online through your member account.
- From the Insurance Action Center, select **Request a Certificate**.
![Image of where to find Request a Certificate](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=446 "Request a Certificate")
- Complete the Request a Certificate **form**.
![Image of the Certificate Request Form](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=447 "Certificate Request Form")
- You may select from the **frequently requested certificates** in the drop-down menu provided.
![Image of where to find drop-down menu for Frequently Requested Certificates](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=448 "Frequently Requested Certificates")
- If you need **special wording**, you may enter it in the provided field.
![Image of where to request Special Wording](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=449 "Special Wording")
Once the request is submitted, you should receive an email with your certificates attached within **one business day**.
Getting a Copy of Your Policy

Usually the insurance company will send you a paper copy of your policy 3-4 weeks after you purchase the coverage. For other policies, we'll upload a PDF of the policy to the Fractured Atlas website.
To upload the copy, log in to your account and select **My Insurance** under your Member Profile.
![Image showing where to find My Insurance under the Member Profile](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=438 "My Insurance under the Member Profile")
- Select the **View My Policies** tab under the Insurance Action Center.
![Image showing where to find Policies under the Insurance Action Center](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=435 "View My Policies under the Insurance Action Center")
- You can click on the **PDF icon** next to the policy number of an active policy to download a digital copy.
![Image showing where to download the PDF copy of the policy under the Policies page](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=436 "download the PDF copy of the policy")
Filing a Claim

To File a claim, please do the following:
- Select **File a Claim** in the Insurance Action Center.
![enter image description here](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=458 "enter image title here")
- fill out as much specific information about the claim in the provided description field. Once **submitted**, we will start the claim process the the claims adjuster.
![enter image description here](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=459 "enter image title here")
Can my premium be reduced?

We always make an effort to provide high-quality policies that meet the particular needs of each insurance applicant. This customization means that rates often vary substantially from one quote to the next, based on the specific operations outlined in each application. While high-quality coverage comes first, we also prioritize finding the most affordable policies that we can.
If you get a quote that seems high, feel free to ask us about it. While we cannot guarantee that the premium can be reduced, we can certainly try —and if nothing else, we'll be able to tell you what aspects of your application led to the high premium.
Annual General Liability Insurance

**What is annual general liability insurance?** It's a year-long policy that covers you against lawsuits that might be brought against you because of damage to rented spaces/locations, injury to spectators or innocent bystanders, etc.
**How much does it cost?** That depends on a lot of things, including what you do and where you are located. The minimum quote for annual general liability is $425, and it just goes up from there. Things that can make it more expensive are: location (some cities and states are more expensive than others because they're "more risky"), number of events, number of spectators, and total payroll.
**What is the territory?** US and Canada. For international operations, you will need a separate International Liability policy.
**Can I apply for International Liability Insurance?** Yes. Please include a detailed description of your international activities in your application and our broker will pursue an international quote.
**Is there a deductible?** Nope!
**What are the limits?** $1 million per occurrence; $2 or $3 million aggregate (that's the total that the insurance company will pay out) depending on the carrier; $1 million personal and advertising injury; $2 or $3 million products and completed operations depending on the carrier.
**What can be insured under these policies?** Almost anything, as long as it's arts-related.
[Apply for annual general liability.](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/liability/Gl)
Directors and Officers Insurance

**What is Directors' and Officers' Liability Insurance?** Directors' and officers' liability insurance (D&O) offers your individual directors (high-level staff of organizations) and officers (board members) the protection they need from personal liability and financial loss arising out of wrongful acts committed in their capacity as officers and/or directors. Example: If the executive director of an organization runs off with the company's money, this would cover the board members and other high-level staff if they were sued. One can also elect to include Employment Practices coverage as well, which covers things like sexual harassment, discrimination, and wrongful termination suits.
**How much does it cost?** The minimum premium is $650 and it goes up from there.
**Is there a deductible?** There is a $2500 deductible on certain claims.
**What are the limits?** The general aggregate on this insurance is $1,000,000.
**What can be insured?** Nonprofit arts organizations and fiscally sponsored projects
**What isn't insured?** For-profit arts organizations.
[Apply for Directors and Officers' Insurance.](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/liability/Do)
Event Insurance

**What is event liability insurance?** It's short-term liability insurance that covers you against claims related to damage to the venue and injury to spectators or innocent bystanders.
**Do event liability policies automatically provide workers' comp insurance?** No, that's a separate policy that has its own application.
**Do we need liquor liability?** Probably not, which is good because it's really expensive! The only time you need liquor liability coverage is if you are selling the alcohol and retaining the money that you make. If that's the case, you also need a liquor license (and we'll need a copy of it) and someone with your event needs to complete a specific online intervention training program (which we also need proof of). Event insurance already includes some liquor coverage that is everything you need if you're giving the alcohol away.
**Does this policy include performer coverage?** No. If you're doing an Equity showcase or have volunteer performers you'll need to get a volunteer accident policy, which is different coverage. If you have performers you are paying then you may want to look into a workers compensation policy.
**How much does it cost?** Every event is different, but the minimum is approximately $400 and as always, it can go up from there.
**Is there a deductible?** No, not on the liability insurance policies.
**What are the limits?** Generally, $3 million aggregate (the total that the insurance company will pay out); $1 million each occurrence; $1 million personal and advertising injury; $3 million products and completed operations. This can vary based on each policy, but these are the typical limits for the event insurance program.
**What can be insured under these policies?** All sorts of things, as long as they're artistic! We've done plays, musicals, dance, opera, music, gallery openings, film screenings, poetry readings, gala fundraisers, music festivals, the list goes on!
**What if my event is in lots of venues or is really long?** That's fine! But if you have lots of things going on throughout the year, you'll probably be better off with an annual policy.
**What isn't insured under these policies?** Events held in a private home, or anything that is not artistic. We can't do weddings.
[Apply for Event Liability Insurance.](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/liability/Event)
Film Production and Equipment Insurance

**What's film production insurance? What's equipment insurance?** Film production is an annual general liability policy that will cover you for your filmmaking activities (regardless of location, as long as you are in the US) for an entire year. Equipment insurance is a policy that will cover loss, damage, theft, etc. to your rented or owned equipment.
**How much does it cost?** They're always different, but the minimum cost of the film general liability is $500 and the equipment is $750. As always, it can just go up from there.
**Is there a deductible?** On the general liability, no! On the equipment, yes! It's usually $1000, but it's higher for some losses like by earthquake or hail.
**What are the limits?** $2 million general aggregate (the total that the insurance company will pay out); $1 million per occurrence; $1 million personal and advertising injury. The equipment insurance covers however much equipment value you request on the original application.
**What can be insured under these policies?** Film or video production! Just so you know, music videos are difficult and we can't do pornography.
[Apply for Film Production Insurance.](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/liability/Film)
Fire Performer Insurance

**Can you insure Canadian groups?** Not unless you have a US tax ID. Our program is only available to entities with a US tax ID (social security number or employer identification number).
**Do fire performance liability policies automatically provide workers' comp insurance?** Nope. That's a separate policy that has its own application.
**Does this policy include performer coverage?** No. If you have volunteer performers you'll need to get a volunteer accident policy, which is different coverage. If you have performers you are paying then you may want to look into a workers' compensation policy.
**How much does it cost?** They're always different, but most of our fire insurance quotes are in the $700-$1,300 range. Our staff can't guess what your quote will be, so we suggest signing up for membership and submitting a quote request. After we get back to you, usually within 3-5 business days, we would be more than happy to refund your membership dues if you choose not to purchase the coverage through us.
**Is there a deductible?** On the general liability, no.
**What are the limits?** $2 million general aggregate (the total that the insurance company will pay out); $1 million per occurrence; $1 million personal and advertising injury.
**What can be insured under these policies?** Fire performance!
[Apply for Fire Performer Insurance.](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/liability/Fire)
Public Art Insurance

**What is public art liability insurance?** It's liability coverage that protects you against claims for damage to a location or injury to a spectator or innocent bystander during fabrication, installation, and exhibition. Do note that this does not automatically include coverage for damage to the artwork itself, so you're covered if the art hurts someone but not if someone hurts the art. That's a separate policy.
**How much does it cost?** They start at $425 for the liability insurance and can go up from there.
**Is there a deductible?** For the liability policy, no! For the artwork, yes! It's $1000 unless the damage is due to earthquake, hail, or wind, and then it's $10,000.
**What are the limits?** $2 million general aggregate (the total that the insurance company will pay out); $1 million each occurrence; $1 million personal and advertising injury; $300,000 fire damage legal liability; $10,000 medical expense coverage per occurrence; and $1,000,000 for rented vehicles.
**What can be insured under these policies?** This insurance covers static works of visual art (sculptures, mainly) that are in areas accessible by the public.
**What isn't insured?** Performing arts. That's a separate policy.
[Apply for Public Art Insurance.](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/liability/PublicArt)
Volunteer Accident Insurance

**What is volunteer accident insurance?** Volunteer accident insurance provides annual insurance to cover accidental medical expenses for volunteer employees who are injured while on the job, as well as coverage for accidental death and dismemberment. This can be used to cover volunteer performers (including those in Equity Showcase performances and in films with unpaid SAG actors) or for any volunteer that is working under your auspices as an artist or arts organization. A volunteer is defined as someone who is an unpaid worker (or someone who is being paid via a stipend reimbursing them for their direct expenses) and who is not on payroll/salary.
**Can you obtain volunteer accident insurance for any state?** Absolutely. This policy covers volunteers in all states.
**How much does it cost?** We have a free quote estimator on our Volunteer Accident page.
**Is there a deductible?** Yes! Usually there's a $250 deductible.
**What are the limits?** Up to $500,000 (aggregate) of coverage per accident, with $50,000 in primary accident medical expense available immediately per volunteer per accident. For certain accidents, including those involving automobiles, the medical expense limit may differ. There is a $25,000 limit (principal sum) for Accidental Death and Dismemberment.
**What can be insured?** Any arts-related organization or artist with volunteer workers.
**What isn't insured?** Paid workers: you'll need a workers' compensation policy for that.
Injury due to aerialist activities cannot be covered under our Volunteer Accident program.
The policy also has standard exclusions, including the following: Owned Aircraft, Leased Aircraft, Operated Aircraft, Aircraft Pilot or Crew, Disease or Illness, Service in the Armed Forces, Specialized Aviation, Suicide or Intentional Injury, War. Please contact the Fractured Atlas staff for more details.
[Apply for Volunteer Accident Insurance.](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/liability/Volunteer)
Workers Compensation Insurance

**What is workers' compensation insurance?** It's coverage for paid employees in case they are injured on the job. Workers' comp pays medical bills before an individual's health insurance kicks in. Have volunteers? Check out our volunteer accident policy instead.
**Am I guaranteed to get a Workers’ Compensation quote?** Unfortunately, no. We're always willing to try to get you coverage, but it's been increasingly difficult to get quotes for performers without a relatively high payroll. We also can't get quotes for North Dakota, Ohio, Washington, West Virginia, and Wyoming. Because of state laws, workers' comp in those states has to be purchased through a state agency.
**How much does it cost?** It's always different! It depends on what state, how many employees, how much payroll, even what exactly you are doing. We can tell you that the minimum quote we've received so far, for an organization with very little payroll and just a few employees, is about $400.
[Apply for Workers' Compensation Insurance.](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/liability/Wc)
Renewing a Policy

To renew a policy, log in to your account and select **My Insurance** under your Member Profile.
![Image showing where to find My Insurance under the Member Profile](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=441 "My Insurance under the Member Profile")
- Select the **View My Policies** tab under the Insurance Action Center.
![Image showing where to find Policies under the Insurance Action Center](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=442 "View My Policies under the Insurance Action Center")
- Select **Renew Today!**

- Complete the renewal application and select **Submit**.
![Image of where to select Submit](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=444 "Submit on the renewal application")

Cancelling a Policy

**PLEASE NOTE**: Many policies are fully earned and no refund will be provided. Other policies will be refunded a pro-rated amount with additional fees included. The insurance company will decide the specific amount refunded for any policy once it is active.
- To Request a Cancellation, log in to your member account and select **My Insurance** on your member dashboard.
![Image showing how to select My Insurance on your member dashboard](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=438 "select My Insurance on your member dashboard")
- Select **View My Policies**
![enter image description here](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=435 "enter image title here")

![Image showing where to request a cancellation on the Policies page](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=440 "Where to request a cancellation on the Policies page")
Once requested, we will follow up with the **cancellation request form**. Only once you sign and date a cancellation request form and the insurer receives it can they proceed with a cancellation request.
Making Changes to Active Policies (Endorsements)

If you need to make a change to your policy, whether it is an address change or a change in the level of coverage, you will need to request an endorsement for the insurance company to update the policy itself. [Contact us](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/?contactus=1) with the specific requests.
Binder Contingencies

Quotes you receive may include binder contingencies, which are requirements and conditions the insurer will want confirmed prior to binding and making the policy active. These contingencies may be confirmation of a set of questions, proof of specific contracts or certificates, or completed applications and affidavits.
Any contingencies will be listed on the quote that you receive and we will be sure to let you know if any contingencies are needed for your policy to be active.
What type of Membership do I need to get insurance?

If you are looking for insurance for arts-related activities, you may [sign up](/site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-sign-up-for-fractured-atlas-membership-so-that-i-can-apply-for-insurance) for Fractured Atlas membership at the free Community level and then [apply](/site/knowledgebase/how-to-apply-for-a-quote) for a quote.
If you decide to purchase a policy, you will need to sign up at one of our dues-paying levels.
Note: If you need coverage for separate legal entities, you will need to maintain separate memberships.
Don't forget to check out our other Programs and Services that you can take advantage of, as part of your membership:
- [SpaceFinder](/site/spacefinder)
- [Artful.ly](/site/artfully)
- [Fiscal Sponsorship](/site/fiscal/)
How do I sign up for Fractured Atlas Membership, so that I can apply for insurance?

You can sign up for Fractured Atlas membership [here](/site/join). To [apply](/site/knowledgebase/how-to-apply-for-a-quote) for an insurance quote, you only need to sign up at the free Community level.
Alternately, if you are not a member, but would like to apply for insurance, you may select the type of [Insurance](/site/liability) you want and select "Apply Online." A pop-up window will ask you to sign up for membership, before you can submit the application.
Travel Accident Insurance

**What is it?** This insurance provides coverage for medical expenses and emergency medical evacuation while traveling outside of the United States. Please note that it does not include coverage for canceled or delayed flights or lost luggage: this is medical coverage only.
**How Much Does it Cost?** Travel accident insurance is based on the number of people traveling and the total length of the trip. Coverage starts at around $45 per week.
In addition to the premium, Fractured Atlas also charges an administrative binder fee ($100 or 10% of the premium, whichever is greater). This is the portion of your payment that stays with Fractured Atlas and pays to keep our program going. Binder fees are reduced for renewal polices.
**How Long Does it Take?** You can download the quote immediately after applying and can choose to purchase it online right then and there. You will then receive documentation with important phone numbers and coverage information from one of our staff members via email.
[Apply for Travel Accident Insurance.](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/liability/Travel)
Errors & Omissions (E&O) insurance

Members of Fractured Atlas can purchase Errors & Omissions (E&O) insurance to cover their professional operations.
The E&O insurance policy covers lawsuits regarding any act, error, omission, defamation, invasion of privacy, emotional distress, copyright/trademark infringement, or misappropriation. Insurance can be provided for three year periods by an A++ rated carrier.
**How Long Does it Take?** We try to get you a quote within a week, though it can take longer. If you like it, you can purchase the policy instantly online. You can then request certificates as proof of coverage through our website.
**How Much Does it Cost?** We're not an insurance company and we can't guarantee any particular rate. However, we can report that to date, members have consistently saved substantially compared to their prior coverage.
In addition to the premium, Fractured Atlas also charges an administrative binder fee ($100 or 10% of the premium, whichever is greater). This is the portion of your payment that stays with Fractured Atlas and pays to keep our program going. Binder fees are reduced for renewal polices.
[Apply for Errors & Omissions Insurance.](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/liability/RadioEo)
Filmmaker Errors & Omissions

Members of Fractured Atlas can purchase Errors & Omissions (E&O) insurance to cover their film, video, multimedia, performance, and other artistic work.
Insurance is available from an A++ rated carrier for three year policy periods. E&O insurance provides coverage for lawsuits arising from any act, error, omission, defamation, invasion of privacy, emotional distress, copyright/trademark infringement, or misappropriation that result from your artistic work.
**How Long Does it Take?** We try to get you a quote within a week, though it can take longer. If you prefer, you can purchase the policy instantly online. You can then request certificates as proof of coverage through our website.
**How Much Does it Cost?** We're not an insurance company and we can't guarantee any particular rate. However, we can report that to date, members have consistently saved substantially compared to their prior coverage.
In addition to the premium, Fractured Atlas also charges an administrative binder fee ($100 or 10% of the premium, whichever is greater). This is the portion of your payment that stays with Fractured Atlas and pays to keep our program going. Binder fees are reduced for renewal polices.
**What are Clearance Letters and Title Search Reports?** A **Title Search Report** is a document prepared by an attorney that confirms they found no conflict with the rights for the title of your work after their review. Separately, **Clearance Letters** provide the same confirmation for the content of your work after their review of your material. Insurance companies will require these documents in order for your policy to fully extend to the risk and exposure of your work.
[Apply for Film E&O.](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/liability/FilmEo)
Video: Creating Events

This video will walk you through creating your first Artful.ly event.
<iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/qr0jx9T04Uc" width="420" height="315" frameborder="0"></iframe>
Creating an Event

<iframe width="960" height="720" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/qr0jx9T04Uc" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
In Artful.ly, an "Event" is a run, and "Shows" are the individual instances of the performances or showings. To sell tickets to anything, you first need to create an event. To add a new event, follow these steps.
1. Under Events, select **New Event**. 2. Enter the the name of the event you are organizing and name of the venue where it is being held. Click **Create Event**. 3. You will then be directed through a series of pages to help you flesh out your "Event Details." Fill in each field based on what you want your patrons to know about your event, how to contact you, and your ticketing options. 4. The first Event Details page is called **About.** Fill in the the event name, event subtitle (if applicable), name of the producer, description, and contact information for your patrons. **Save & Next** 5. On the **Venue** page, complete information about the location of the Event. Here, you have the option to show or hide the Google map on your Storefront. Click **Save & Next**. 6. On the **Prices** page, set the overall **Capacity** for the event. Then, define your **Ticket Types**. Each Ticket Type includes a ticket type name, an optional description of that ticket, a price, and an option to limit the number of tickets of that type that you want to sell within the event capacity. Click **Save & Next**. (You will be able to adjust the capacity and ticket types available for each show later in the set up process.) See the screenshot below to better understand the relationship between Capacity and Ticket Types. 7. On the **Image** page, you can add an image that will appear on your Storefront and as a visual key for this event throughout your Artful.ly account. Click **Save & Next**. 8. On the **Messages** page, you have the option to create a question to ask your patrons during their checkout process. Often this field is used to ask patrons things like "Please tell us the names of your guests," "Do you have any special seating requests?" or "Would you prefer chicken or fish?" Click **Save & Next**.
![Ticket Type Prices and Limits](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=10 "ticket type prices and lmits")
## **Next Step: Create Shows** Now that you've set up information about the run of your event, you need to create "Shows" for each instance or performance of the event. [Learn how to set up shows here.](/site/knowledgebase/creating-shows-)
## Related Articles * [Creating Shows](/site/knowledgebase/creating-shows-) * [Editing Ticket Types and Availability](/site/knowledgebase/editing-ticket-types-prices)
VIDEO: Updating Ticket Prices and Availability

This video shows you how to:
- Update ticket prices and availability once your shows are published and on sale. - Put additional tickets on sale. - Take tickets off sale. - Change pricing for a specific number of tickets available for a certain show.
<iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/cwmJm5FBIh0?rel=0" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0"></iframe>
Creating Shows

## What are 'Events' and 'Shows'?
**In Artful.ly, an "event" is a run and "shows" are the individual instances of the performance or showings.** To sell tickets to anything, you first need to [create an event](/site/knowledgebase/creating-an-event). Once you've done that, you can add shows to your event.
## Show Set Up: Times, Dates, Capacity, and Prices To Add Shows: 1. Select the event for which you want to add an show. 2. Select **Shows** from the side menu. 3. Click on **Add shows**:
![Add New Show](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=17 "add new show")
##Add Show Times and Show Dates 1. **Show Time**:Select a start time.
2. **Show Dates**: Click on all the dates in Calendar that you have shows for the time you just selected.
**If your event has Shows at multiple times, repeat steps 4 and 5 until all the Show Times and Show Dates are accounted for in the Calendar.**
![Add Shows](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=20 "Add Shows")
##Capacity and Prices Whatever **Capacity** and **Ticket Types** you set up under **Event Details > Prices** will default to the individual Shows you set up. However, if you need to tweak capacity and price points per show—or add new Ticket Types for specific Shows—this is where you can do that.
* **Capacity**: sets how many overall tickets for Show you have available to sell. * **Ticket Types** : allow you to Name different types of tickets, set a variety of Price Points, Ticket Limits, and Availabilty. * **Name**:Appears to Patrons as the Type of Ticket they are purchasing. * **Ticket Type Limit**:The amount of Tickets available to sell at this Price Point for this Show. If it doesn't matter how many you sell at this price, **leave it blank.** This does not limit the amount of tickets one person can buy at a time. To do that you can use [Discount Codes](/site/knowledgebase/discount-codes) or sell this Ticket Type offline through the [Box Office](/site/knowledgebase/box-office-sell-tickets-at-the-door). * **Description**:Use this text to inform Patrons about what this type of Ticket means or includes. * **Storefront & Widgets**: Available for purchase online. * **Box Office**: Available to sell manually, over the phone, or in person.
![Ticket Capacity Details](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=21 "Ticket Capacity Details")
##Save and Publish
**Save** puts tickets on sale through the Box Office. **Save and Publish **puts tickets on sale both through the Box Office and to the public online.
**Your show will not be visible in the storefront unless you publish it.**
Important: If your ticket types are unique to different show times (not dates) go through steps 4-8 for each start time.
## Editing Show Details To Publish, Unpublish, or Duplicate shows:
1. Go to the **Shows** menu. 2. Click on **List.**
![List View Detail](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=19 "list view detail")
3. Click the gear button next to the show's time to publish, unpublish, put tickets on sale or take tickets off sale.
![List View Menu Detail](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=22 "List View Menu Detail")
## Changing Ticket Type Information, Capacity, or Availability 1. Repeat steps 1 and 2. 2. Click on the Show you want to edit—this will open up the **Show Details** page.
To go into more detail about editing Ticket Types and Availability once you've created your Shows, read [here](https://artfully.zendesk.com/entries/21653548--Editing-Ticket-Types-Prices-).
## Related Topics * [VIDEO: Updating Ticket Types and Availability](/site/knowledgebase/updating-ticket-prices-and-availability) * [Box Office: Sell Tickets at the Door](/site/knowledgebase/box-office-sell-tickets-at-the-door) * [ Discount Codes](/site/knowledgebase/discount-codes) * [Ticket Types and Capacity](/site/knowledgebase/ticket-types-capacity)
What is MailChimp and why should I use it?

MailChimp was built by some smart folks in Atlanta, Georgia, not by Fractured Atlas or Artful.ly. Here's why we really like them and why we think you will too.
## What is MailChimp?
MailChimp is a web-based email marketing service. It helps you design email newsletters, share them on social networks, integrate with services you already use, and track your results.
## Why do I need a special tool for email marketing?
Technically, you can send a newsletter or announcements about your upcoming shows via your personal email. Email providers like Gmail, Hotmail, and Outlook, however, are designed for one person to send one email to just a couple people at once--not a whole list of fans. That's a different kind of task achieved more efficiently, effectively, and professionally with a different tool. Here are a few reasons why an email marketing service like MailChimp is a better tool for this kind of task:
* **Approved bulk mailer.** Most email services and Internet service providers (ISP) limit the number of emails you can send at one time. This is to prevent spamming. With a tool like MailChimp, you can send an email to an unlimited number of recipients at one time. * **Greater deliverability.** Services like MailChimp work with ISPs and corporate domains to ensure your emails are recognized as safe and approved. If there is a problem with delivery, MailChimp will attempt to re-send the email and tell you why an email might be bouncing. * **Adherence** **to privacy laws.** Bulk mailers are required by law to include an unsubscribe link in every email. MailChimp and other email marketing services include this automatically and ask recipients why they are removing themselves from your list. * **Professional styling.** MailChimp offers a wide variety of customizable templates for designing polished emails. You can also build a template from scratch to use with MailChimp. * **Compatible with various email readers and devices.** MailChimp gives your recipients the option to read your emails in fully-styled HTML or text only. They can also click a link to read the email in a web browser instead of their email. Also, did you know that over 50% of emails are now opened up on mobile devices, and this number is only growing? MailChimp also provides you with tools to see how your email campaign looks on a smart phone and other mobile devices. * **Know if people are reading your emails.** If you send an email through your personal email, you have no idea who opened it. Email marketing tools give you all sorts of fun analytics on successful deliveries and open rates so you know your fans are listening.
## Other Cool Things MailChimp Does:
* **Divide your lists into groups.** Dividing your fan-base in sub-groups based on engagement, location, social stats and more, allows you to tailor your message to the people reading it. [Read more about grouping MailChimp lists here](http://mailchimp.com/features/segmentation-and-groups/). * **Install a sign-up form on your website.** Customize the fields you require and embed the HTML on your site. MailChimp also helps you easily send fans to your sign up form via URL, Twitter, Facebook, and QR code. [Read more about forms here.](http://mailchimp.com/features/custom-forms/) * **Click Maps.** Check out the screenshot below. It's from the MailChimp report the thank you letter Fractured Atlas sent to event attendees. I see the majority of readers clicked the Facebook album link. I can even dig deeper and see which of our newsletter subscribers clicked that link. This information tells me which stories appeal to whom and where I could improve my email next time. [Read more about click maps and other reporting here.](http://mailchimp.com/features/reports-overview/) * **[Browse the MailChimp Features Overview.](http://mailchimp.com/features/)**
![MailChimp Click Report](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=646 "MailChimp Click Report")
## How much does MailChimp cost?
MailChimp offers a variety of different plans. Read about it all on their [pricing page](http://mailchimp.com/pricing/), but here's our short version:
* **Forever Free.** As long as you've got fewer than 2,000 subscribers across all lists in your account, you can send up to 12,000 emails per month without paying a dime. So if you've got 1,999 subscribers you can email them all six times a month. (And really, only your mother wants to hear from you more than that.) They don't even ask for a credit card. * **Monthly Plans.** You can upgrade to a paid plan if you don't want limits on the number of emails you send a month. Unlimited email plans start at $10 for 500 subscribers and go up from there. * **Pay As You Go.** If you’re not a frequent sender, you can purchase credits that work like stamps for email. Buy them when you need them. Starting at $0.03 per email and decreasing in price as your volume increases.
Again, check out **[http://mailchimp.com/pricing/](http://mailchimp.com/pricing/). **
## Why MailChimp and not ConstantContact, Verticle Response, MadMimi, etc?
Because....
* ...we like MailChimp's clean, intuative interface and powerful tools. * ...their pricing is fair. * ...a lot of artists and arts groups use and like MailChimp already. (We use MailChimp ourselves for Artful.ly and Fractured Atlas enews) * ...they offer an API that makes it easy to integrate our tools with theirs. * ...they are friendly and nice to work with.
MailChimp was our first pick, but someday we may offer integration with other email marketing tools. Got one you really love that we should consider? Tell us in our [Feature Requests Forum.](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/feature_request_list?topic=Artful.ly)
## How do I sign up for a new MailChimp account?
Go to their website to get started: [http://mailchimp.com](http://mailchimp.com "MailChimp")

MailChimp has great user support resources. [Learn how to import lists to MailChimp here](http://kb.mailchimp.com/article/how-do-i-create-and-import-my-list) and browse the [MailChimp support knowledge base](http://kb.mailchimp.com/home/new?utm_expid=62798052-20&utm_referrer=http%3A%2F%2Fkb.mailchimp.com%2Farticle%2Fhow-do-i-create-and-import-my-list) for other tips and help.

Event & Show Sales Statements

## **What is a "statement?"** A statement report summarizes all of your ticket sales for an entire event or an individual show.  ## **Where do I find my statements?** You can access event and show statements from two different paths: 1. From the top menu bar, select **Reports**, then **Statements**, then choose the event. ![Event Statements List](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=799 "Event Statements List") 2. From a Show Details page, click **View Complete Settlement** as shown below. ![Statement Link](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=31 "Statement Link") 3. Then, either click on an individual show date, or select **Generate Report** to view the statement for the entire run of shows in the event. ![Generate Report Button For Event Statements](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=798 "Generate Report Button For Event Statements") ## What's on a statement? ### Revenue Overview  (In the screenshot at the bottom of this article, these numbers are in the gray box.) * **Tickets Sold** = Sum of the number of tickets sold. This number does not include comp tickets. * **Gross** = Total price paid for tickets sold for this show. * **CC Net** = Total revenue from credit card sales processed by Artful.ly minus the 3.5% processing fee. This total what Artful.ly owes you for the show. * **Settled** = Amount of money Artful.ly has paid you for the show. This will be $0 until until your [settlement](/site/knowledgebase/settlement-reports) has been initiated (2 business days after the show has played). After that, this value should be equal to the CC Net value. ### Breakdown by Payment Method For each method of payment—credit card, cash, comp--sales are broken out in the follow columns: * **Tickets** = Number of tickets purchased with the given payment method. * **Gross** = Total price of all tickets paid for with the given payment method. * **Processing** = Total fees paid to Artful.ly for credit card sales only. Equal to 3.5% of gross of credit card sales. * **Net** = Net revenue for given payment method. For credit card sales this is gross minus 3.5% processing. Should be equal to CC Net in the top bar.  ### Breakdown by Purchase Location Artful.ly tickets may be sold in a number of locations. This table helps you see where your sales are happening. * **Web** = Total number of tickets purchased via the Artful.ly Storefront, widget, and WordPress plugin. * **Box Office** = Total number of tickets purchased through the box office interface. * **Artful.ly** = Comp Tickets manually entered by you. * (The columns in this table are the same as the payment method columns defined above.) ### Breakdown by Discount If you have created any discount codes that can be used for this event or show they will be listed as rows in this table. Columns across the top are: * **Discount Code** = The name of the code. * **Type** = The promotion type associate with the code--either "X dollars off" or "buy one get one free". * **Tickets** = Total number of tickets purchased with this code. * **Discounted** = Total dollar value of discounts redeemed with this code. ### Slices = Data Visualization Clicking on the **Slices** button will show you a colored pie chart view for each set of breakdown criteria. This feature has some kinks in it but we thought we'd roll it out now so you can play around with it. :) ### Related Articles - [Transaction History: Sales & Contributions](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/transaction-history-sales-contributions) - [Settlement Reports](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/settlement-reports)
What is "open source" and why should I care?

When software is “open source”, that means it is free to download, including the underlying software code, and that anyone is allowed to modify it to suit their own needs. This is in contrast to most commercial software products, which cost money to license and which can’t be modified by the end user. Advocates of open source software (including us!) argue that it results in better quality code, increased reliability, greater flexibility, a lower total cost of ownership, and freedom from predatory vendor lock-in.
Artful.ly has been fully open source from day one, but we didn’t stop there. We’re aiming for radical transparency at all stages from design to distribution. Since the earliest requirement gathering phases, we’ve used community design sessions to hear from our colleagues in the arts community. The Artful.ly Open Source Edition code and documentation are free and publicly available, so anyone is free to build custom implementations, or to extend it with new modules or features.
This matters to Artful.ly because there’s a positive feedback loop between the two sister projects. As we (and others) continue to improve the Artful.ly Open Source Edition code base, those enhancements will be integrated into Artful.ly. Likewise, if we develop something really cool for Artful.ly, we’ll almost always incorporate it into the open source code.
Read more about the [Open Source Initiative](http://opensource.org/).
Ticket Types & Capacity

## Ticket Set-Up **Ticket Capacity** is the total number of seats in your venue, or rather, the maximum number of people you can sell tickets to.
With **Ticket Type Limits, **you can control how many tickets are available to sell at each price point. Every ticket sold will be subtracted from the remaining capacity amount so that you don't oversell your show.
![Prices and Ticket Capacities](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=692 "ticket type & capacity")
## An Example Let's say your theater has exactly 100 seats. Your town fire marshal loves to do surprise inspections, so you don't want to oversell. On the other hand, you've got actors to pay so you'd like to fill every seat. You set the total ticket capacity to 100.
You're offering four different ticket types—General Admission, Student, Senior, and VIP. You don't care what the distribution of GA, Student, and Senior tickets are so you don't put any limits on those. The VIP tickets come with a free puppy. You only have 10 puppies so you limit the number of VIP tickets to 10.
Now the hard cap is at 100 for the whole show; you can sell up to 10 VIP tickets; Students, Seniors, and General Admission folks all have a fair shot at a seat; and you haven't ticked-off the fire marshal. Take a bow.
![Multiple Ticket Types](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=34 "Multiple Ticket Types")
## Related Articles: * [Editing Ticket Types & Prices](/site/knowledgebase/editing-ticket-types-prices) * [Creating an Event](/site/knowledgebase/creating-an-event)
How are Artful.ly and Artful.ly Open Source Edition different?

**Artful.ly comes in two flavors...
1. Hosted Artful.ly 2. Artful.ly Open Source Edition
Here's how they compare:
**Hosted Artful.ly**
- Best for independent artists and small arts organizations. - You want a system that's ready to go. - The code is what powers the your experience but stays behind the scenes. - It lives on the cloud, so you can access it anywhere on the Internet. - Set up costs NOTHING! - Set up time is 10 minutes.
**Artful.ly Open Source Edition**
- Best for mid-sized arts organizations. - You want a system with a lot of customization. - The code is the framework of what you want to build. - It lives on the server of your choice. - Set up costs $$ because you'll need to hire a software developer, but the base code is free. - Set up time is a few months.
Artful.ly is one version of arts management software created with Artful.ly Open Source Edition, but there are many more possibilities. If you like to play with code, you can create a customized version of Artful.ly.
If you're interested in this, find out more information **[here.](https://www.artfullyhq.com/opensource "open source")**
Is Artful.ly PCI compliant?

Our practices are consistent with PCI compliance:
- No credit card data is stored in our application or database. - All sensitive payment information is transmitted over SSL encrypted connections. - Our systems are regularly reviewed for security vulnerabilities and we have never failed a test. - Servers are hosted remotely in secure data centers (Amazon EC2 via Heroku) and access is highly restricted.
Your Customers & Artful.ly

##Are you using my customers' information?
**We access only the information we need to settle your transactions and help you fix problems with your account**. We will never try to sell anything to your customers, and we cannot see your customers' credit card numbers—that information is managed by a third-party credit card processing vendor with bank-level security protection.
Since we’re a non-profit organization whose mission is to support the arts and cultural sector, we may use aggregate transaction data to conduct research for the benefit of the field, but anytime we do that it will be purged of personally identifying information.
Read the relatively brief fine print—[Privacy Policy](http://www.artful.ly/pages/privacy), [Terms of Use](http://www.artful.ly/pages/tou), and [User Agreement](http://www.artful.ly/pages/user_agreement).
## What support will you provide my customers?
**If a patron has technical trouble with Artful.ly (buying tickets, etc.), our support team is available to help sort it out.** For refunds, exchanges, or questions regarding your show or work, your patron should contact you first. After all, no one knows your work, your mission, and your patrons better than you!
Why did you build Artful.ly?

## Why did you build Artful.ly?
**We decided that we could build something better than the other ticketing and CRM tools already available.** Way back in 2011, many of Fractured Atlas's 35,000 member artists and arts groups weren't happy with their options. Over the years we've built several bits of software to manage our own business, and with our knowledge of arts and technology, Artful.ly was a natural next step.
Artful.ly was made to be different. It lets you sell tickets on your own site, it integrates sales and donations in one customer record, and it's more nimble and customizable than other systems. There are no licensing fees just to keep the system running and no contracts to sign.
And that's just the beginning. We engage with artists and arts organizations who use our software. We encourage both ticket-buyers and ticket-sellers to suggest new features, and we allow everyone to vote on features they like most. Fractured Atlas's goal is to help the artistic community, and Artful.ly is one step to fulfilling that goal.
Editing Ticket Types & Prices

<iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/cwmJm5FBIh0?rel=0" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0"></iframe>
##Q: I changed information on the Prices page but it's not changing my Storefront—why? **A:** Short answer: You probably updated the prices in your Event Details, but you have a show scheduled on the calendar with the old information.
Longer answer: Event Details functions like a template for any new show you create. If you've already created a Show(s) for your Event, changes to Ticket Types on the "Prices" page (price, description, or capacity) will not update existing Shows. New shows, however, will reflect the information in your updated Event Details.
You can either delete the Shows and then make changes to Ticket Types in **Event Details**, or change the Ticket Types for each **Show** separately.
![Edit Tickets Why and Where](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=36 "Edit Tickets Why and Where")
##Q: How do I add tickets for my show? **A**: Let's suppose your show is in such high demand that you added floor seating, thus increasing the overall capacity of the show.
1. Select the Show you are adding tickets to. 2. Add ticket to the overall **Capacity** for the show. 3. Add Tickets to the **Ticket Type **you want to update or create using the gear button as shown below. 4. Include any limitations to that particular **Ticket Type** if needed.
![Add Tickets](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=37 "Add Tickets")
##Q: How do I add a whole new Ticket Type to a show I've already created? **A** **Example**: You want to create some last minute buzz by adding a new discounted Ticket Type.
1. Open the shows menu and select **List**. 2. Select a date you want to add the ticket type to. ![select show date](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=644 "Select show date") 3. Select the **Add New Ticket Type** button. ![add new ticket type](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=645 "add new ticket type") 4. Name the Ticket Type, and add Description, Price, and Limits accordingly. 5. Depending on the type of ticket, you may choose to have it for sale only at the door or in advance. (You may need to scroll through the window to see the visibility options. 6. Save! This will automatically put the new tickets on sale for this show and make them available in your Storefront and Widget. 7. Repeat for each show in this event that you need to add new ticket types to.
![Add Ticket Types](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=694 "Add New Ticket Types")
Scroll though this menu and you'll find the ticket type visibility checkboxes, which change where the tickets will appear. - **Storefront & Widgets** This checkbox makes your tickets available for your fans to buy in the storefront or in a widget on your site. These are the self-service sales channels. - **Box Office & Sales Console** Check this to make the tickets sellable through your staff-managed sales channels. Think over-the-phone and door sales. - **Members** This applies only to organizations running the memberships kit. Checking this box makes a ticket visible in the member storefront. If you have a ticket type you want to be seen only by your members, check this box.
![Change Ticket Type Visibility](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=695 "Ticket Type Visibility Checkbox")
## Q: Why does the software work like this? **A:** Because it allows greater flexibility in your show pricing. Remember that an **Event** is the entire run of a production, while the **Show** is an individual occurrence of that production. In other words, an Event can happen over a week or month, but a Show happens on a specific day at a specific time.
When you start a new production, the **Ticket Types **you set in Event Details auto-populate for each Show you create for that Event. This is because we want to make your life easy.
BUT Shows will not automatically update with new information unless you update each Show separately. We designed it this way so that you can charge different prices for different Shows but not affect the prices of the entire Event. This allows you to, for example, charge different prices for the same section on weekends, or drop the price on a slow night without affecting the overall Event pricing.

Responding to New Feature Requests

Program directors are emailed when a new request is created.
1. Follow the link in the email and read the request in the admin-view. 2. Check to see if there are pre-existing requests that are similar. If so, merge the new request into the existing request. [Instructions for merging.](/admin/Knowledgebase/view_article?id=662) 3. If the new request is valid, click **Edit**. 4. Edit the title of the request so it is as clear as possible for future readers. 5. Make spelling corrections in the body of the request, but refrain from making other changes to the comment. 6. Under **Status**, select of these options: - Planned = Pretty definitely on the product roadmap. - Not Planned = Not never, but not something you see happening in the near future. - Done = Completed and released. 7. Click **Edit** to save your changes. You will be redirected to the admin view screen for the request. 8. Add a comment in the **Comments** section. You can format and add images just like in knowledge base articles. - For planned requests, give the requester some context of how this feature might be added. Avoid specifying a delivery estimate since those are rarely accurate. - For not planned requests, make sure to thank the requester for the idea. Encourage other readers to vote for the feature if you need to see more support before prioritizing its development. - For done features, tell the requester when it was released and link to any relevant knowledge base articles. *Use the full URL in these links because relative links will not work if the subscriber clicks on them in the notification email.* 9. Check the **Notify Subscribers** box and then the **Add Comment** button. This will published your comment to the public forum and send an email to any subscribers on the thread. Here's what the notification email looks like:
![feature request sample](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=699 "feature request sample")

Ask Fans a Question at Checkout

As part of creating a free or paid event, you have the option of asking your patrons a custom question during their checkout process. This can be a helpful feature when you want to know more about your ticket buyers. Patrons do not have to answer the question to complete checkout, but most will fill it out.
To create your question, select the appropriate event and choose the Messages tab. You can select the box that allows for a question during checkout and can type in your question under the 'Special Instructions' Caption.
![Ask a Question at Checkout](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=39 "Ask a Question at Checkout")
**Asking a final question can be helpful for all kinds of events from private RSVP's of free events to large scale performances.** Here are some examples of what you might ask during checkout:
* Which dinner option would you prefer: Chicken, Beef, or Vegan? * Where did you hear about this event? * Please provide the names for your guests. * List any questions you have for the panel. * What shows of ours have you seen before? * Who is your favorite Beatle?
**Your question will be listed under the 'special instructions' tab during check out.**
![Question at Checkout](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=41 "Question at Checkout")
This feature is currently available in the Artful.ly Storefront only; compatibility with the widget is coming soon.

Publish or Unpublish a Show

Sometimes you need to take a show off of public view and sometimes you'll need to put it back on display, whether it's to stop sales or a show, or maybe put a surprise show on sale. Either way, publishing and publishing a show is done from the same place.
## **To publish or unpublish a show**:
1. Go to your **Event Details**. 2. Click **List**.
![List View](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=42 "List View")
3. In **List View**, click the gear icon to publish or unpublish a show. Shows on a grey line are unpublished, and shows on a white line are published.
![Unpublish one or multiple shows](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=570 "Unpublish one or multiple shows")
## Related Articles * [How do I take tickets off sale?](/site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-take-tickets-off-sale) * [Refund, Exchange, or Return Tickets](/site/knowledgebase/refund-exchange-and-return-tickets) * [Cancel, Change the Time, or Reschedule a Show](https://staging.www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/cancel-change-the-time-or-reschedule-a-show)
Cancel, Change the Time, or Reschedule a Show

It's not ideal, but sometimes shows get cancelled or need to be rescheduled, and tickets may need to be exchanged or refunded.The important thing is to act as quickly as possible and inform your ticket buyers right away. You'll perform the same steps whether you need to cancel a show or just change the time. It's not possible to change the time of a show, but you can delete or unpublish the show and add a new one to the calendar.
## If you haven't sold any tickets, unpublish the show/s. This is the simplest solution. If no one bought tickets, then nothing needs to be returned. All you need to do is remove the show from the public view.
1. Select the Event. 2. From the left side menu, select **Shows**, then **List**. 3. In the table, find the show you want to cancel, click the "Unpublish" button.
![Unpublish Show](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=44 "Unpublish Show")
## If you have already sold tickets to the show, you can either:
1. Refund the tickets. 2. Or, exchange tickets for a different or rescheduled show. Note that if the show date has passed the tickets cannot be exchanged. We suggest comping people tickets to the other show if you move them to another night.
**Detailed information on how to refund and exchange tickets can be found here:**
* [Refund, Exchange, or Return Tickets](/site/knowledgebase/refund-exchange-and-return-tickets)
**Here are some more helpful tips to make sure your cancellation goes smoothly:** * Communicate with your ticket buyers ASAP. The sooner they know of a cancellation, the happier they will be. * If you are rescheduling, set up the new show as soon as you have a date so you can exchange tickets. * If you have sold tickets, tell your ticket buyers the show is cancelled and _provide refunds or exchanges before two business days after the show closes._ This is particularly important because if you don't refund tickets in time, the show settlement will be processed and you will have distribute refunds outside of Artful.ly (check reimbursements, etc). * Update your storefront links if you delete the entire event, and not just a showtime.
##Related Articles * [Refund, Exchange, or Return Tickets](/site/knowledgebase/refund-exchange-and-return-tickets) * [Publish or Unpublish a Show](site/knowledgebase/publish-or-unpublish-a-show)

Setting Up Free Events

If you are taking reservations for an event, registering guests, or simply not charging for tickets you should create a free event in Artful.ly. There is no cost to sell tickets to free events with Artful.ly. When you create a new account, the **Free Ticketing Kit** will be automatically activated for you. You don't need to set up a bank account with us--just get started!
## Create a New Event
1. Click on the **Sell** option at the top left corner of the page and select **New Event** from the drop down menu. 2. Enter the name of the event and the venue, then select **Create Event**. 3. This will take you to the **Event Overview** page, where you'll be walked through the steps of adding details about your event, the venue, and tickets.
![Little Apple Event](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=49 "Little Apple Event")
4. When you reach the **Event Details** section, you can add tickets under **Prices.** You'll see that the default ticket is already set to cost $0.00\. You can name it whatever you'd like: "RSVP," "Free Ticket," "Free Registration," etc.
![Little Apple Ticket](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=53 "Little Apple Ticket")
5. In the **Ticket Type Description**, you'll want to make it clear to your fans that the ticket is free. 6. Next, you need to add a show or shows. Go to the Add **Shows** section and click the **Add Shows** tab. 7. Under **Show Time**, set the start time of your show. 8. Under **Show Dates**, click on a day of the calendar to schedule a show at the time you set in the step above. 9. Add more shows to the calendar if you like. 10. When you're done, click **Save and Publish** at the bottom of the page and you're all set!
![Little Apple Shows](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=51 "Little Apple Shows")
## What Your Fans See
Once you have created and published your event, Artful.ly will automatically create a public Event Storefront. This page is where you can send fans to buy tickets. Here's an example of what an Event Storefront looks like with a free event:
![Little Apple Storefront](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=52 "Little Apple Storefront")
Fans can add tickets to their card and proceed to check out. When they check out, fans will see that they're completing an order for a $0.00 ticket.
![Little Apple Checkout](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=50 "Little Apple Checkout")
## Email Order Confirmation
Once your fan has checked out, he/she will receive a confirmation email for their order. This confirmation will include the event and ticket details.
![Little Apple Order Confirmation](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=54 "Little Apple Order Confirmation")

Deleting Shows

## Q: How do I delete a show?
**A: **You can delete a show if you have not sold any tickets to it.
1. Go to the **Shows Menu**. 2. Open up the show you want to delete from either the **Calendar** or **List** view of existing shows. 3. In the Show Details section at the top, click on the **Work With** button and choose **Delete**.
![delete_show](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=56 "Delete a Show Date")
**Note**: If you've already sold tickets to the show and want to hide tickets from public view, you can** Unpublish** the show instead so that no one else can purchase tickets online.

Deleting Events

## Q: How do I delete an event?
**A: You can delete an event only if you have not sold any tickets to any show within it**.(That includes free or comped tickets.) After you have sold a ticket, you can't delete the event. This is to prevent accidentally deleting an event that people have already bought tickets to and make sure the bookkeeping stays tidy.
As long as no tickets have been sold, a **Delete This Event** button will be available on the bottom of the **Event Overview **page. Click on the name of an event to reach its overview page. Or from in individual show you can click Event Overview on the left-hand side.
![delete_an_event](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=57 "Delete an Event")

Can I change the layout of my Artful.ly storefront?

*The short answer is no.* The content of the Storefront is completely in your control, but there is just one standard layout that includes the following information:
* The event name * The event subtitle * The name of the producer (usually your organization's name) * Show dates and times with a drop down ticket selector for each performance * An about section with your description of the event and the image you uploaded * The venue name, address, and a thumbnail Google map * Contact information for questions about tickets or the event itself
Here's an example of what a storefront looks like after you enter in all that information:
![Twelfth Night Storefront Example](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=620 "Storefront Example")
* If your event has more than five shows, the Storefront layout will shift from a bar per show to a calendar with your show dates in blue. This makes the view less cluttered.
* If you want to customize the page where your patrons buy tickets, you should use the [Artful.ly Widget](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/what-is-the-widget-and-how-does-it-work).

Adding Additional Tickets to a Show

## Add More Tickets To A Show:
1. Select an event. 2. Select a show date and time on the **Shows** side menu. 3. Click the Gear button below **Ticket Capacity.** 4. Choose **Add Tickets **from the drop down menu. This will allow you to add capacity to the number of tickets available for sale.
![work_with_add_tickets](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=59 "using the work with button to add tickets to a show")
