Taking "Yes" & "No" RSVPs

**Knowing who's not coming to an event can be just as important as knowing who is. This article suggests how to track all of your RSVP's so that you can:**
* Track who invitees who cannot attend * Follow-up with invitees who have not yet responded
## Step 1: Set Total Ticket Capacity
You can use Artful.ly to collect both "yes" and "no" responses to event invitations by creating "yes" and "no" ticket types. To do this, you will need to set a total capacity number that includes both "yes" and "no" responses. Set capacity to at least the number of invitations you will send and pad that with a few extras.
**Example**: If you have room for 45 people and invited 60, you should set capacity to 60 to allow for 60 total RSVP's.
![Event_Capacity](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=60 "set your event capacity")
## Step 2: Create Ticket Type for Attendees
Next, create a ticket type for the invitees who will attend, or a "yes" RSVP. You can name this ticket type whatever you like--we're just calling it "yes" to explain the idea here. Set the **Ticket Type Limit** to the real capacity of your venue.
![RSVP_yes_ticket_type](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=61 "RSVP yes ticket type")
## Step 3: Create Ticket Type for Declined Invitations
Create a ticket type for the guests who cannot attend. We are calling this the "RSVP No" for this example, but you can name this ticket type whatever you want. Just make sure to leave the **Ticket Type Limit **field blank for this ticket type. This will allow you to collect as many RSVPs as you could potentially get.
Use the Description field to clarify what the "RSVP No" ticket type means to your invitees. These invitees will still receive an order confirmation email which could be confusing without this text.
![RSVP_no_ticket_type](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=62 "rsvp no ticket type")
## Step 4: Get More Info at Checkout (optional)
If you'd like to automatically track reasons for not attending, try using the [Special Instructions](/site/knowledgebase/ask-fans-a-question-at-checkout) option to ask a question on the patron's checkout screen. You can also use this field to ask guests who are attending if they have special seating requests, or what the names of their guests are.
![cannot_attend_message](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=63 "cannot attend message")
## Step 5: Track Responses via Door List
On the **Show Details** page for each date of your event you'll be able to oversee how your RSVP's are coming in for each response.
![rsvp_tracking](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=65 "rsvp tracking")
* The number available will tell you how many RSVP's (both "yes" and "no" have yet to be claimed)
* The number sold from the "Yes" ticket type will tell you how many people have said "yes."
* The number sold from the "No" ticket type will tell you how many people have said "no."
## Organize Responses for Targeted Communication:
Use the Door List to quickly see who is not coming to your event and who is. You can download the list and organize the data in the spreadsheet by ticket type to see this organize this information more at a glance. You might then choose to send different follow up emails to the folks who can attend verses the ones who can't.
![Door_list](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=66 "door list")
![Door_list_csv](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=68 "door list csv")
* You can also compare this spreadsheet with your initial invitation list to quickly deduce who hasn't responded. Follow up with them too!
## Related Articles:
* [How do I ask patrons a question at checkout?](/site/knowledgebase/ask-patrons-a-question-at-checkout) * [Creating an Event](/site/knowledgebase/creating-an-event)
How can I set up pay-what-you-want ticketing?

Artful.ly does not yet offer specific features for Pay-What-You-Want ticketing. But there is a workaround.
##Pay-What-You-Want Workaround When creating an event in Artful.ly, you must set the overall capacity for your venue. Then you have the options to create an unlimited number of ticket types with different prices.
Depending on the general scale of your event, you can create a separate ticket type for each price point you'd like to offer as an option. So, if your venue holds 100 people and you'd like to offer tickets at a range of prices, select 100 as your capacity, then create individual ticket types for each price and leave the 'limit' blank. For instance, if you are hosting a small chamber music performance, you might offer tickets at $1, $2, $3, $5, $10, $15, $20, $25, or $50.
You can create multiple ticket types during event creation here:
![Creating Multiple Ticket Types](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=69 "creating multiple ticket types")
**Once you've created your ticket types, you can see the overview of everything you have to offer in the show details.**
There will also be an option to create even MORE ticket types if you so choose:
![pay_what_you_want_overview](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=70 "an overview of all the ticket types")
Note that tickets in the Storefront will display from most expensive on top to least expensive on bottom.
Here's an example of what the patrons will see in the Storefront:
![pay_what_you_want_storefront](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=71 "pay what you want storefront")

Print at Home Scannable Tickets Kit

## What does this kit do?
With the Scannable Tickets Kit enabled, when your patron buy tickets their order confirmation will come with a PDF file attachment that has images of each of the tickets in their order (see below). Patrons can print these tickets at home and take it to your show to be scanned with the [Artful.ly iOS app](/site/knowledgebase/the-artful-ly-app-scan-tickets-with-your-iphone-or-ipod-touch).
![ticket_example](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=72 "ticket example")
## What does this kit not do?
Currently, Artful.ly does not offer the following features...
* Bulk printing a batch of tickets and hand them out in a will call scenario. * Allowing a ticket buyer to send his ticket to Passbook or open in a dedicated app.
If these features are a priority for you, please tell us in the [Feature Request Forum](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/feature_request_list?topic=Artful.ly).
## Activating The Scannable Ticking Kit
It is recommended you activate this kit for a show that you have not sold tickets for, yet. Turning on the kit in the middle of a run could cause confusion when patrons arrive at the door--those who bought tickets before you turned the kit on would not have printed tickets and those who bought tickets after you turned the kit on would have printed tickets. You don't need any more nuttiness just before a performance.
To turn on the kit:
1. Navigate to your **Account Administration** page by navigating to the top menu and clicking on your email address. 2. Under **Kits**, click the **Add** button next to **Scannable Tickets**.
![add scannable tickets kit](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=74 "scannable tickets kit add button") 3. Click the green **Activate Scannable Tickets** button.

Sales Channels Explained

There are five channels through which tickets may be sold in Artful.ly. Some channels are public where your fans can buy tickets directly, and some are private and only accessible to you and the approved users on your account.
1. Event Storefront (public) 2. Event Widget/WordPress Plugin (public) 4. Event Box Office (private) 5. Sales Console (private)
You can use all of these or just a couple. No matter what channels you use, all tickets come from the same pool so you don't need to allocate a certain number of tickets to a given channel.
##Event Storefront
**The storefront is a public facing URL that you can share with your patrons, it displays upcoming shows.** Patrons can select the show they'd like to attend and check out using a credit card.
1. To find the event storefront, either select **Event Overview** or **Share & Sell** from the side menu on an event page.
![Storefront Links](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=75 "storefront link")
2. Select **Storefront** to view the URL. You can use this URL in your ticket promotion materials or link to it from your site or other promotion outlets.
![Winters_Tale_Storefront_Sales_Channel](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=76 "storefront")
## Event Widget
**The Artful.ly widget enables you to take donations and sell tickets directly from your own website.** A sleek shopping cart will appear on your web page when someone clicks “Buy” or “Donate.” Using the widget requires a certain level of coding knowledge.If you aren't familiar with web programming, save yourself some trouble and use the storefront.
For instructions on how to set up the Artful.ly Widget, [see this article.](/site/knowledgebase/what-is-the-widget-and-how-does-it-work)
![Widget_generator](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=78 "widget generator")
## WordPress Plugin
**The event plugin works on websites that use WordPress as a content management system.** Like the widget, the Artful.ly plugin enables patrons to donate and purchase tickets directly from your website. If your site is hosted on wordpress.com and not on a domain you own, you cannot use this plugin.
[Click here](/site/knowledgebase/installing-using-the-wordpress-plugin "Installing & Using the WordPress Plugin") to learn more about the plugin and view installation instructions.
![plugin](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=79 "plugin")
## Event Box Office
**The Box Office is a private sales channel you and your staff can use to sell tickets at the door or over the phone.** It also provides easy access to your Door List to check in patrons as they arrive. There are no ticket fees applied to Box Office sales. You only pay the credit card processing fee if you sell tickets via card.
Check out [this article](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/box-office-sell-tickets-at-the-door "Box Office: Sell Tickets at the Door") for more information about the Box Office and selling tickets at the door.
![gettingtoboxoffice](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=80 "getting to the Box Office")
## Sales Console
**The Sales Console is another private sales channel that you and your staff can use to build orders for your patrons.** This is ideal for orders that involve more than just tickets. You combine tickets, discounts, memberships, passes, and donations and process the whole order in one transaction.
For more information about selling tickets with the sales console, [review this article](/site/knowledgebase/sales-console-a-private-sales-channel-for-complex-orders).
![sales console](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=82 "sales console")

Troubleshooting: Why can't I sell tickets?

## Make sure your shows are published. Go to **Shows** and then **List**. Unpublished shows will be on a grey line and published shows will be on a white line. To publish a show, click on the gear to work with it and click **Publish.**
![Listviewcapture](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=83 "list view")
## Make sure the shows are scheduled on the calendar. If no shows apper when you check in the **List**. Go to **Shows** and click **Add Shows**. Make sure you pick the time you want (the default time is 8:00pm). Then click **Save & Publish**.
![calendar](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=84 "add shows to calendar")
## Make sure you have ticket types. By default, Artful.ly will have a "General Admission" ticket type. The ticket type names can be changed and more ticket types can be added in **Event Details** under **Prices**. You can see more about this in [Setting Up an Event](/site/knowledgebase/creating-an-event "Setting Up an Event").
## Make sure your event has a capacity.
In your **Event Details** under **Prices** you need to set the capacity of your venue. This puts a limit on the number of tickets you can sell so you don't oversell and keep the fire marshal happy.
![ticket capacity](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=85 "ticket capacity")
## Are your tickets visible in the Storefront, Widget, or Box Office?
Sometimes you may need to set up a ticket type that you need to keep private. You can choose which ticket types are visible in the public **Storefront** and which are only visible in the private **Box Office** with the check boxes for your ticket types.
![ticketvisibility1](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=87 "ticketvisibility")
## Have you requested the Paid Event Ticketing Kit?
It takes approximately 1-2 business days to activate a Paid Event Ticketing Kit. To request the kit, have your Organization Administrator go to the **Account Administration Page** and press **Add** for the kit you want to use.
![paid event checkbox](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=88 "if you see a checkbox on your account, you have the paid event ticketing kit")
## Are you in the correct Storefront?
Check the Share and Sell Menu and select **Storefront**.
![findyourstorefront](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=89 "findyourstorefront")
Or you can use the Central Storefront in the Account Administration page. Your Central Storefront shows all the events you currently have scheduled.
![accountadmin](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=90 "account admin")
## Is your Wordpress Plugin installed with the correct shortcodes?
See: [Installing and Using the WordPress Plugin](/site/knowledgebase/installing-using-the-wordpress-plugin "Installing and Using the WordPress Plugin").
## Is your Widget pointed to the right Event?
See: [What is a Widget and How Does it Work?](/site/knowledgebase/what-is-the-widget-and-how-does-it-work)
Or See: [Troubleshooting Widgets](/site/knowledgebase/troubleshooting-widgets "Troubleshooting Widgets").
Promoting Your Event With the Artful.ly Storefront Link

Anywhere you are promoting your event online--Facebook Event Page, Twitter post, video trailer, email message, etc.--you can add your **Artful.ly Storefront** URL so fans can click through to RSVP or purchase tickets.
## Where do I find my Storefront URL?
1. Open up your Event from your dashboard or the Sell Menu. 2. Click on **Share and Sell** tab in the side menu. 3. Click **Storefront** in the side menu. 4. Click on the blue link in the center of the page--it looks something like this: artful.ly/store/events/..." 5. This will bring you to your publicly viewable Storefront page. 6. Copy/paste the entire URL address link from your browser and put it into whatever online promotional tool you are using. 7. If you want a shorter or custom URL, try a link-shortening tool like [bit.ly](http://www.bit.ly).

* [Selling Tickets](/site/knowledgebase/four-sales-channels-explained) * [Sell Tickets Through The Central Storefront & Event Storefront](/site/knowledgebase/sell-tickets-via-central-storefront-and-event-storefront) * [Troubleshooting: Why can't I sell tickets?](/site/knowledgebase/troubleshooting-why-can-t-i-sell-tickets)
Sell Tickets via Central Storefront & Event Storefront

## Central Storefront
If you have multiple events running simultaneously, you can share your **Central Storefront** with your patrons. This storefront that displays every upcoming event you have scheduled. You can find the link under** Account Administration **in the upper-right corner of the page. By default the URL is your Organization Name, but you can customize it using the **Edit** button on the left side of the page.
![account admin5](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=91 "account admin")
If you have multiple events running in the same time period, you can share your **Central Storefront** with your patrons. Any events with upcoming shows scheduled will be visible here. Your Central Storefront link includes your organization's name, so it's also good for printed materials.
![Central Storefront View](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=513 "central storefront")
Clicking a **Buy Tickets** button will take you to that event's storefront.
## Event Storefront
If you want to promote just one event at a time, find the link in your event's **Share and Sell** menu.
![Event Storefront Link](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=514 "event storefront link")
That link will send patrons directly to that specific event's storefront.
![Event Storefront Detail](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=515)+

Resetting Your Password

If you've forgotten your password, or need to change it, go to the Fractured Atlas website and press the "Log in" button as you normally would. When the login modal pops up, click on "Reset Password," then enter your email address. This will send you a temporary password.
![Reset password button](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=601 "Reset password button")
Once you've logged in, you can change your Artful.ly password on your Fractured Atlas membership page.
1. In Artful.ly, click on your username in the upper right hand corner. 2. Select **My Membership** from the dropdown menu.
![Select My Membership to view Account](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=560 "Select My Membership to view Account")
3. Go to the **Password** section, enter your old/temporary password, and enter your new password.
![Change Password in Fractured Atlas](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=561 "Change Password in Fractured Atlas")
Still having trouble logging in? Don't worry! Email us at [Support@Artful.ly](mailto:support@artful.ly).
Transaction History: Sales & Contributions

The Orders section of your Artful.ly account tracks every order processed by Artful.ly, which can be viewed and downloaded for further use.
Each order includes:
* **Order ID** number of the transaction * **Person** who placed the order * **Order Date ** * **Method** of payment * **Event and Show ** * **Amount** and **Quantity Details** of entire purchase
In the **Orders** menu, located in the top navigation bar of your dashboard, you'll see that you can either view transaction history in three ways:
* **Sales:** Orders for free and paid ticketing events. * **Contributions:** Donations processed through Artful.ly either with the 501(c)(3) Donations Kit or in connection to a Fractured Atlas sponsored fund. * **Search:** Looks back in time for each transaction, regardless of type. You can search by **Patron Name, Event,** or **Order Number**.
## **Example: How to Find Sales Transactions and Download the Results:**
1. Click the **From** or **To** field and the calendar will appear. 2. Adjust the calendar month using the arrows on either side of the calendar heading. **This only changes the calendar not the Date field!** 3. Select a **Date box** on the calendar to set the time range, which updates the **Date field**. 4. Select All Events or click the drop down arrow to choose a specific **Event**. 5. Select the **Search** button and wait for the results to load. 6. Select **Download** and a CSV file will download to your computer.
![Transaction History](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=102 "Transaction History")
## To View Details
* To access the Order details, select the **Order ID** number from the list * To look up the **Person Record**, select the name listed under the **Person** heading * To go directly to the **Event Details Page,** select its name from under the **Event** heading

Settlement Reports

## What is a settlement?
**A settlement** is the money Artful.ly owes you for each show or donation.
Each show has one settlement that includes all money you made from credit card sales minus the 3.5% processing fee. Two business days after your show, Artful.ly sends the settlement to the automated clearing house. From there, it takes another few days for them to process the payment and send it to your bank account.
Each donation has its own settlement. Artful.ly sends donation settlements two business days after the donation is made. From there it takes a few days for the automated clearing house to get it to your bank account.
It is important to keep your bank account info up to date. If the EFT information is no longer accurate and a transaction is returned, there will be a $10 fee per returned settlement.
Note: To generate revenue breakdowns for each show, view [Statement Reports](/site/knowledgebase/show-sales-statements)
## Where do I find my settlements report?
1. Select **Reports **from the top navigation bar 2. Choose **Settlements** 3. From there, you can view either previously **Sent** or **Upcoming** settlements by toggling between them.
Here's an example of a settlement report:
![Settlements](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=794 "Settlements")
From the **Show Details** page, you can also view the estimated settlement date and amount.
![Settlement estimate on show details page](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=831 "Settlement estimate on show details page")
## What do the columns on the report mean?
**ID:** This is uniquely identifies the settlement within Artful.ly. Click on this and you'll see a list of all the orders included in the settlement.
**Item:** This will be either an Event Name, Donation, Membership, or Pass.
**Detail:** These column contains either the show date, or the name of the membership type or pass type. This column is blank for donation settlements. Because memberships and passes have the option of having the service fee paid either by the producer or by the patron, we've included one example of each here.
**Date:** This is the day Artful.ly released the settlement. From this date, it will take the automated clearing house system another 3-5 business days for the funds to reflect in your bank account.
**Gross:** Total amount of credit card sales for this show or the total amount of the donation.
**Realized:** Total amount received by Artful.ly from patrons for this show. This number should always equal the gross figure.
**Net:** Total amount owed to you for credit card sales after the 3.5% processing fee is deducted.
## Wait, so when do I get my money?
Funds usually end up in your bank account 7-10 business days after each show closes.
**Example:** Your show played on the evening of Wednesday the 1st. Artful.ly will send the settlement the following Monday the 6th. (Wednesday night = Thursday day in bank-think, so Friday and Monday are the two business days.) You should see the deposit to your bank account anytime between Wednesday the 8th and Friday 10th.
**Bank Holidays** slow the EFT process down. That's why we recommend planning for the entire 7-10 business day window.
Discount Code Reporting

To get a proper notion of how effective and popular your discounts are, you can access a discounts report. It is found under **Reports** in the top menu bar.
## How do I search discounts?
There are three ways to search discounts:
* By all discounts * By an individual discount * By a range of dates
Note: If you have used the same code for multiple events, the report will show you all applicable events.
![Discount Codes List](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=104 "Discount Codes List")
## What's in the report?
**The report gives you an overview for each discount type and specifics on the individual transactions.** This includes the number of discounts and a break down by the patron and event. It also shows you the original income potential for the tickets, what they earned instead, and the difference. If you would like to export this information you may do so using the 'Download CSV' button.
![Discount Code Report](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=105 "Discount Code Report") ## Can I get specific discount info for a particular show?
**Discount reports by show are available in each show's complete statement.** You can access this by selecting "Reports" from the top menu bar, then "Statements", select an event, then select a show. (Or access the same statement report from a show's details page.) This statement will shows you which discounts were used for the chosen show, how many were claimed, and the final price after the discount for each ticket.
![Discount Code Show Statement](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=106 "Discount Code Show Statement")
### Related Articles - [Discount Codes](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/discount-codes)
Adding Users & Managing User Permissions

Artful.ly has four different user permission levels to help you manage who has access to sensitive information and sales features within your organization's account. There can only be one Organization Administrator per account, but you can add an unlimited amount of users at the other levels.
### 1. Organization Administrator: full access to the account
* Can view, add, and edit everything * Can add other users and set user permission levels * Can edit connected bank account
### 2. Manager: advanced access for supervisors
* Can view, add, and edit any record, report, event, show, membership, pass, or discount * Can make sales * Can refund or exchange orders * Can add and configure kits * Cannot add or edit users, permissions, or bank account
### 3. General Associate: standard access for most staff
* Can view, add, and edit most records or reports * Can import * Cannot export * Cannot add or edit events, shows, memberships, passes, or discounts * Cannot make sales
### 4. Box Office Associate: limited access for junior staff or volunteers
* Can make sales * Can view and edit only the contact information on people records * Cannot import or export data * Cannot refund or exchange orders
## Adding New Users
As an Organization Administrator, once you've logged into your account, you can add users from your **Account Administration** page.
1. Navigate to **Account Administration** by clicking the Admin link in the upper right hand corner of the header bar. 2. From there, click on the **Users** tab. 3. Click on **Invite User.**
![Account Administration page with user tab selected](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=120 "users tab") 4. Enter the person's email address and select the permission level. 5. Choose whether or not you'd like them to receive the [Daily Sales Report](/site/knowledgebase/daily-sales-report), then select **Invite.** 6. Choose whether or not you'd like them to be notified when your organization receives a donation through Artful.ly.
![modal to add user to your organization](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=598 "add user modal")
The new user will receive an email inviting him/her to your organization's account. He/she will need to follow the directions in that email to create a Fractured Atlas membership & password in order to log into the account. For access to Artful.ly, a user only needs a free, Community membership.
## Editing & Removing Existing Users
To edit an existing user's permission levels or email subscriptions:
1. Go to the **Users** section of your **Account Administration** page 2. Select **Edit** to open the modal and edit the permission level or subscription to the Daily Sales Email. 3. To delete a user, select **Remove.** 4. If a user has not accepted the invitation and no longer has it in her inbox, you can resend the invitation from this same section by clicking the **Resend Invite** link below their email address.
![edit or remove users from permission page](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=748 "edit permission level")
## Changing The Organization Administrator
To change the Organization Administrator, email the Artful.ly Support Team at support@artful.ly. The email should come from your organization's current org admin and it should include the full name and email address of the new org admin. These requests normally take 1-2 business days to fulfill, and both the original and the new org admin will be notified once the change has been made.
### Related Articles
* [Daily Sales Report](/site/knowledgebase/daily-sales-report) * [Resetting Your Password](/site/knowledgebase/resetting-your-password-)
When and how do I get my money?

When you set up paid event ticketing or donations, you send us information to set up [electronic fund transfers](https://www.artful.ly/forms/artfully_etf_sign_up.pdf) (EFT). This allows us to send money directly to your bank account. We send the money for different things at different times:
- **Ticket Revenue.** Artful.ly initiates the settlement two business days after each show takes place. (That way, you don't have to wait for the whole run to be over.) - **Donations to 501(c)(3) Nonprofits.** Settlements initiate two business days after the contribution is made. - **Donations for Fiscally Sponsored Projects.** These are sent to your sponsored fund and released when requested as just like any other donation to a sponsored project as described [here.](/site/knowledgebase/when-and-how-do-i-get-my-project-s-funds.) - **Passes and Memberships.** Settlements initiate two business days after a pass or membership is sold.
From there the money moves through the electronic payment processing system which sends it to your bank account. Typically, you can expect the funds to be deposited in your bank account **7-10 business days after a show date passes or a donation is made.**
## Viewing Past and Upcoming Settlements
To view settlements, go to the **Reports** menu and click on **Settlements**. Toggle between **Sent** and **Upcoming** to view past and pending settlements to your account. When viewing past settlements, use the "Work with..." button to download a CSV.
![Upcoming Settlements](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=794 "Upcoming Settlements")
Within the settlements table you'll find the following columns for:
- **ID** The order numbers will be hyperlinked to take you to the Order Details page for that transaction. - **Item** This will either be the name of the event a ticket was purchased for, a donation, or membership or pass sale. - **Detail** This will detail either the show date, pass type, or membership type. - **Date** The date the settlement was initiated. It will most likely take your bank 3-5 days to process the funds from the date the settlement was initiated. - **Gross** The total amount of funds in the settlement before any service or credit card transaction fees are removed. - **Realized** If you have passes and/or memberships set up with the producer paying the service fee, this column shows revenue after service fees for memberships or passes have been deducted. - **Net** The final amount settled to your organization. For memberships and passes, this will be the revenue after the credit card processing fees are deducted from the realized column.
**Note: Artful.ly does not send you deposit notifications. Check your bank's online statement to see if they have posted the funds to your account.** Bank holidays can sometimes delay when a settlement reaches you, so be mindful of shows that happen right before a 3 day weekend. Also, banks can occasionally delay a deposit if it's larger than average for your bank account; it's rare, but can sometimes prolong the settlement period.
### Related Articles
- [Can my Artful.ly ticket revenue go to my sponsored fund?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/can-my-artful-ly-ticket-revenue-go-to-my-fiscally-sponsored-fund) - [Settlement Reports](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/settlement-reports) - [Why are my settlements off by a few cents?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/why-are-my-settlements-off-by-a-few-cents-)
Daily Sales Report

**Every morning, Artful.ly sends you an email summarizing the all your sales and donations from the previous day.**
These emails are sent to the person listed as the Organization Administrator on your account, and whomever the Organization Administrator has listed as a recipient.
The email includes all ticket sales, exchanges, refunds, and donations the day before. You won't receive a Daily Sales Emails for days with no activity. To see the full order details of each transaction, you can click on an order number.
Additionally, Artful.ly will send the Organization Administrator a notification when your organization receives a donation; the Organization Administrator can turn this email on for other users on the account.
_Note: Dollar amounts listed are gross sales and do not include the 3.5% credit card fees. _
**Receiving a daily sales email is entirely optional.** The Organization Administrator may opt out of receiving these emails by visiting the link at the bottom of the email and adjusting your settings. This can be done for every user on the account. On the Account Administration page, the Organization Administrator can edit who does or does not receive the email by selecting "Edit" next to each user.
![Daily Sales](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=816 "Daily Sales")
## Editing Daily Sales Report Recipients
1. When logged into your Organization Administrator account, navigate to your **Account Administration** page.
![Account Administration](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=112 "Account Administration")
2. Click on the **Edit** Button.
![Account Administration Users](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=115 "Account Administration Users")
3. Choose whether or not you'd like the user to receive the Daily Sales Report or be notified when your organization receives a donation via Artful.ly.
![Edit User](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=598 "Edit User")

User Calls: General New User Consultation

## 1) LEARN ABOUT THEM
## Ask for description of the organization:
* Name * Discipline/s * Location/s * Self-presenting or presented by others? * Do they have their own venue? * How many performances (shows) do they have per year? * How many tickets do they sell per performance (show)? * Are their tickets assigned seating or general admission?
## Gather info on their current systems:
* Ticketing * Online Donations * Donor Management * Email Marketing * Website Content Management System (CMS)
## What other services are they considering?
* Other ticketing software? * Other donor management software?
## 2) TELL THEM ABOUT ARTFUL.LY
## Current Features
* Ticketing overview * Donations overview * CRM overview * MailChimp overview
## Upcoming Features
* Memberships * Passes * Relationships * Householding * Printable tickets * iOS ticket scanner
## Pricing
* No fees for sign-up or user accounts * No license fees * We only make money when you do.
* Tickets = $2/ticket, patron pays. 3.5% credit card fee. * Donations = Just 3.5% credit card fee. * Memberships = 5% fee per membership. 3.5% credit card fee.
## How It's Made
* We build what users tell us to. * As a nonprofit, we want to keep prices as low as possible for our services. Grant funding pays for the initial development so we don't have to charge fees as high as for profit companies to re-coup those costs.
## 3) MISCELLANY
* Questions about Artful.ly? * Features they want that we don't have yet...
* Is it part of ATC scope of work? Then it's coming soon. * Is it a feature request we've heard before? Then talk about how we prioritize features with lots of votes. * Is it something we have a workaround for? Then tell them about that.
* Outline next steps for them--set up account, organize import data, test it out with a demo account, etc.
## 4) SEND FOLLOW UP EMAIL
* For any feature requests, vote on their behalf and subscribe them to that thread. * Link to relevant articles. * If applicable, create an account on Demo for them and send them login credentials.
User Calls: Passes Beta Orientation

I've been scheduling these calls over Join.Me, and hosting the audio over SpacePhone.
## Questions to Ask
* How did they hear about us? (If they're new.) * Do they currently have a subscription program? How do they run it? * What systems are they using now? * How many shows does the organization present a year? * What is their subscriber base like?
## Create a Pass and Make a Show Pass Eligible
* Create a pass. I use Lorem ipsum as the placeholder text. * Detail each field in the pass creation process. * Explain the 5% service fee + 3.5 percent credit card processing fee. With the producer paying you get a nice round price but lower net revenue, and for the patron paying the service fee is added, but the net revenue is higher. (For these demos, I've set the passes and memberships to have the patron pay.) * After creating the pass show how a show is made pass-eligible. * If the org is an FSP, mention that passes are non-deductible. We want to build them, but it's going to in a later version of Artful.ly.
## Member Storefront
* Go to Account Administration and talk about customizing the member storefront. * Show the Central Member Storefront, but also show how to access the storefronts for individual pass types. You can find these under Sell and Passes. Click the button labeled **Store Link **with a shopping cart next to it. * Purchase the pass in the storefront. If Selena is around she may be able to forward you the emails, but don't count on having the confirmation emails as an example. Use the Use Pass Now button from the confirmation page. * Purchase a ticket to show you made pass-eligible.
## Show Back End Changes Part 1 - Patron Records
* Go to a passholder patron record and talk about the new Member identifiers. * Click on the passholder tag to go show the pass history. * Show how to send a reminder email and show the pass. * Click the checkbox next to the pass and talk about the work with options.
## Demo Sales Console
* At this point I usually navigate to the Sales Console and begin talking about the various tiles. * Conduct one regular transaction on the sales console. * Mention that for pass sales we are not charging the 5% service fee during the beta, but the 3.5% still applies. Passes and pass-eligible tickets for the same person can't be sold during the same transaction. * Instead, show the producer sell-to to apply a pass code to an order. Demo selling to a passholder and applying the pass code. * Open Advanced Search and search by pass types.
## Conclude
You've gone over:
* Creating passes * Making shows pass-eligible * Customizing the Pass Storefront * Sales Console * Changes to People Records * Advanced Search
Send the org copies of the knowledge base articles on passes.
User Calls: Membership Beta Orientation

I've been scheduling these calls over Fuze, and I have a meeting created specifically for these calls. It's labeled Passes and Memberships Beta Conversations. Login info is in the Admin only article on hosting webinars.
## Questions to Ask
* How did they hear about us? (If they're new.) * Do they currently have a membership constituency? How do they run it? * What systems are they using now? * What do they offer their members? * Are the purely membership based, or is this a membership that runs alongside general ticket sales?
## Create a Membership and a Member Event
* Explain the difference between rolling and seasonal memberships (If they've been doing memberships already they'll probably know immediately when they see both options.) * Show how to set up a membership. I use Lorem ipsum as the placeholder text. * Detail each field in the membership creation process. * Explain the 5% service fee + 3.5 percent credit card processing fee. With the producer paying you get a nice round price but lower net revenue, and for the patron paying the service fee is added, but the net revenue is higher. (For these demos, I've set the passes and memberships to have the patron pay.) * After creating the membership show the difference between making a member-only event, and member-only ticket types. * If the org is an FSP, mention that the memberships are non-deductible. We want to build them, but it's going to in a later version of Artful.ly.
## Member Storefront
* Go to Account Administration and talk about customizing the member storefront. * Show the Central Member Storefront, but also show how to access the storefronts for individual membership types. You can find these under Sell and Memberships. Click the button labeled **Store Link **with a shopping cart next to it. * Purchase the membership. If Selena is around she may be able to forward you the emails, but don't count on having the confirmation emails as an example. If you're using Backyard Ensemble you can log in with Sally Fields (people get a good chuckle out of her name) Email: Sfields@example.com Password: password * I try to have a member event with Sally's membership Demo Rolling Membership attached to it. * Purchase a member ticket. * This is the point where it's good to talk about how the organization is going to advertise the membership and how their patrons will be directed to the storefront. Since this is often a behavioral change for their patrons, I recommend linking to the member sign in page from their own website alongside any links to general admission ticket sales. They should probably also do this with email marketing, too. A good example of this is [Boom Arts](http://www.boomarts.org/#current-projects).
## Show Back End Changes Part 1 - Patron Records
* Go to a member's patron record and talk about the new Member identifiers. * Click on the member tag to go show the Member history. * Show how to send a member password reset. * Click the checkbox next to the membership and talk about the work with options.
## Demo Sales Console
* At this point I usually navigate to the Sales Console and begin talking about the various tiles. * Conduct one regular transaction on the sales console. * Mention that for membership sales we are not charging the 5% service fee during the beta, but the 3.5% still applies. Memberships and member tickets for the same person can't be sold during the same transaction. * Instead, show them the sell-to feature. Demo selling to a member and adding a member ticket to the cart.
## Back End Changes Part 2 - Advanced Search and Comping Memberships
* Open advanced search and show membership specific search parameters * Talk about searching by Current Lapsed and Past memberships * Show how to save a list segment * Discuss exporting lists of members * Show how to use an advanced search to comp memberships in bulk. This is especially important for organizations looking to move their existing membership constituency to Artful.ly. Show how you can set a different expiration date and customized message.
## Conclude
You've gone over:
* Creating memberships * Making member shows and tickets * Customizing Member Storefront * Sales Console * Member Login * Changes to People Records * Advanced Search * Comping Memberships
Enjoy yourself and take your time. This is a complex set of features. I'd budget a bit over an hour the first time you do it.
User Calls: Security Talking Points

1. We do not store credit card numbers, even encrypted. These are all stored in our credit card processor's electronic vault. Our servers keep only the last 4 digits and an internal identifier that can be used to re-bill subscription fees or recurring donations. Even that information is only stored as needed (i.e. not in the case of a one-time donation or ticket purchase). No one on staff has the ability to access full credit card numbers. 2. Passwords are stored in an encrypted format using the most current encryption algorithms, as recommended by security experts. If someone were to steal our entire database, it would still be nearly impossible to crack individual passwords. That said, many people use passwords that are inherently insecure, and there's not a lot we can do about that. - Always use passwords that are at least 8 digits long (10 is better) and contain a mix of lowercase letters, uppercase letters, numbers, and symbols. - Don't use the same password on every website. - Never share your login credentials with anyone. 3. Social security and tax id numbers are stored in an encrypted format that would be nearly impossible to crack if the database were compromised. 4. Our office is essentially paperless. No sensitive information is stored on site.

Triaging Widget Install Issues

If a user is having trouble installing a widget...
1. **Deploy the "problem with widget install" macro and get:** 1. URL of install page 2. CMS they're using (If its wordpress- see below) 3. Artful.ly org name 2. **For ticketing widget, check that they have Paid Event Ticketing kit activated and published show/s.** 3. **For donation-only widget, check that they have a donation kit activated.** 4. **Check for errors in Inspector.** 1. Using Chrome, go to their website. 2. Right click and select "Inspect element." 3. On the inspector toolbar, select "Console." 4. Check for errors. 5. If error says something about "artfully.js" >> Assign ticket to Gary with above info. 6. If error exists but doesn't says "artfully.js" >> Tell user error may be conflicting with Artful.ly widget and they should resolve it. 5. **Check jquery.** 1. Using Chrome, go to their website. 2. Right click and select "View page source" 3. Ctrl+F and search for "jquery" 4. If jquery appears in multiple lines >> Tell user to delete pasted code and start again. This time, they should generate widget again but select "Yes" so jquery is not included in javascript snippet. Re-install new snippet. 5. If jquery appears nowhere >> Tell user to delete pasted code and start again. This time, they should generate widget again but select "No or I don't know" so jquery is included in javascript snippet. Re-install new snippet. 6. If jquery appears in only one line >> This is not the source of the problem. Assign ticket to Gary with above info. 6. **If error is not coming from Artful.ly and they use Wordpress** 1. If the website is hosted by WP (URL ends w / wordpress.com) the widget will not work. 2. If website is not hosted by WP prompt producer to check and make sure that the custom CMS theme they are using supports enough widgets to include Artful.ly. This may be a good reference to point people towards so that they can troubleshoot on their own: [http://codex.wordpress.org/WordPress_Widgets](http://codex.wordpress.org/WordPress_Widgets) 7. **If problem persists, deploy "passing on to Gary for troubleshooting" macro and assign ticket to Gary with above info.**
Checking SendGrid for Sent Emails

A producer wants to know if his patron was sent an email order confirmation...
1. Get patron's email address. 2. [Log into Heroku](https://id.heroku.com/login) 3. [Navigate to dashboard](https://dashboard.heroku.com/apps) 4. Click "artfully" app. 5. Scroll down to "SendGrid" and click it. 6. On the top nav bar, click "Email Activity" 7. Search for patron's email address.
* Note: Times may be one hour off. As of 2/19/14, SendGrid times were in Central timezone.
Turning on Beta Kits

When beta testing a new kit, we will push the code to Production but make it invisible to users. This prevents them from seeing or turning on the kit without talking to us.
To turn on a beta kit...
1. Make sure Selena is okay with giving the org this kit. 2. Log in to Artful.ly as an admin. 3. Find the org. 4. Log in as the Org Admin. 5. Navigate to their Account Administration page. 6. Click the Add button next to the appropriate kit. (You can see this because you're an admin but the user cannot see the beta kits.) 7. Log out of the Org Admin's account. 8. From the admin panel, navigate back to their org page. 9. If the kit requires a bank account, make sure that is added. 10. Click the approve button. 11. Send the user appropriate notification.
Turning on Kits

Yay! Kits!
1. Start with two windows open--Zen Desk (ZD) and [Artful.ly admin panel](https://www.artfullyhq.com/admin.) (AAP). 2. Merge any auto-alert tickets pertaining to the organization's kit set up into one ticket. 3. On AAP, find and open org overview. 4. On AAP, are there any pending kits? 1. No. Then send them a ZD message telling them how to opt into kits. 2. Yes. Paid Event Ticketing kit. Go to step 5. 3. Yes. Charity Donation Kit. Go to step 5. 5. For either Paid Event Ticketing or Charity Donation kit, do we have a completed EFT form AND voided check? 1. No. Use the macro called "documentation need to approve kits." 2. Yes. Save to "Q:\Programs and Services\Artful.ly\EFT Forms & Voided Checks" with constant naming convention. 6. For Charity Donation Kit only, do we have their IRS letter? 1. No. Use the macro called "documentation need to approve kits." 2. Yes. Save to "Q:\Programs and Services\Artful.ly\IRS Determination Letters" with constant naming convention. 7. On AAP, fill in bank account fields. 1. Copy all information you can from check, not form. (People screw up copying their own account info.) 2. The routing number is always 9 digits long**.** On checks, it's located between the two colon-like marks. 3. The account number can be any length.
![check](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=123 "check")
8. Double-check the bank account fields. 9. Triple-check the bank account fields. 10. Click "Approve" button next to appropriate kits. 11. On ZD, tell user kits are now activated. Use the macro called "EFT and Kit Confirmation" and edit appropriately. 1. Fill in full routing number. 2. Give only last four digits of account number 3. Specify kit or kits you are approving 4. Change the paragraph about donations to reflect whether org is fiscally sponsored or 501(c)(3). 12. Send email and close ticket.

Admin adds. | Required | -- | -- | | Passes | Beta. Admin adds. | Required | -- | -- | | Relationships | No one. Waiting for beta. | -- | -- | -- | | Campaigns | No one. Chargebacks

This article describes how admins should follow up with chargeback notifications.
1. Finance Team receives notification of chargeback from BrainTree or directly from a credit card company. 2. Finance Team forwards the notification with due date and other related information to support@artful.ly, which goes into the FA HD. 3. Selena or a PA assigns the ticket to Alessandra (Or, whomever is handling CB's at the time.) 4. PA tracks down the charge either with the name of the patron or the Braintree Transaction ID provided in the email that the finance team receives. (Oftentimes, the latter is what's easiest for finding the charge, since frequently the name on the credit card does not match the name of the person who placed the order.) 5. PA creates new FA HD ticket to email patron with boilerplate message. 6. PA logs into the Producer's Artful.ly account and re-sends the order confirmation receipt along with their message regarding the dispute. 7. PA responds to finance team confirming that they have reached out to the patron. 8. PA logs the CB in the Google doc [here.](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Tf5ANcxZz752IHb48TFW5_z0WApaICAcoRSCdptLvUI/edit#gid=0) (If you do not have access to this document to edit it, please request editing privileges from someone on the finance team.) 9. If customer has not gotten back to their email within 48 hours, PA calls the patron. 10. If patron replies via email: create a PDF of the email thread and send it in original ticket from the finance team. If the patron replies on the phone, request that they respond to your email with a written confirmation that they understand what the charge was for. 11. Finance Team sends the appropriate documentation to the bank, documents status of the CB in the Google Doc. 12. Every month or so, Finance Team will update the Google Doc with the outcome of the dispute.
Answering Tickets

Before you write a reply, ask yourself these questions:
1. Who's asking the question? - Current user or prospective user? - 501(c)(3) or fiscally sponsored project? 2. What's the real question? - Have we corresponded with them before? 3. What's the larger need? - What are our business goals here? - Are they likely to run into another issue right after this? - Can we teach them to help themselves in the future?
What documents are needed to request a letter?

We typically need to review the following documents:
**The I-129:** This is the Visa application form provided by USCIS.
**The petitioner's letter:** This is the letter by the petitioner for the applicant written to USCIS which confirms the operations the artist will complete while in the United States.
**3-4 support letters:** These are references to confirm the extraordinary ability of the applicant.
**The artist's C.V.:** This is the resume which may include a list of previous experience, accomplishments, training, and awards.
Discount Codes

<iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/oqwMqLoqbKA?rel=0" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0"></iframe>
**Creating custom discounts for individual tickets, **buy-one-get-one**, and group rates is easy with Artful.ly.** You can create unlimited discounts for any event and limit a code to specific show dates and/or ticket types. Discount codes can be applied to tickets sold online through event Storefronts, the Box Office and Sales Console, and on your site with a ticketing widget or WordPress plugin.
## Step 1: Add a discount code to your event.
**Open one of your events. Find "Discounts" under "Share & Sell."**
![Discount_Menu](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=124 "Discounts live in the share and sell menu")
## Step 2: Create Discount Code Name
**This is what patrons will type in to receive the discount.** The code must be 4-15 characters long and may include numbers but not spaces.
## Step 3: Choose the Show/s and Ticket Type/s
**Choose the shows for which the code can be used.** The default will allow patrons to use the code for any show in the event's run. Next, choose which of your ticket types are available for discount. You may include all ticket types or specify the discount for only a certain section or price.
![Sample Discount](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=125 "discount sample")
## Step 4: Choose Promotion Type
**You can create three types of promotions--set price deduction, buy one get one free, and group discount. **
* **X dollars off each ticket"** will subtract a set dollar amount off of each valid ticket in the patron's cart. Set the minimum purchase to 1. * **"Buy one get one free"** will charge the full value for one ticket and $0 for the second. Set the minimum purchase to 2\. This code will also work as a 'buy two get two free' and 'buy three get three free' etc. Please note that the $2 service fee still applies to all tickets in the order. For example, if a patron buys two $10 tickets and uses a two-for-one discount code, she will pay $10 + $2 for the first ticket and $0 + $2 for the second for a total of $14. * **Group discounts** can be created by raising the minimum purchase number. You may create either a set dollar amount off each ticket or a buy one get one free promotion and limit it to order of certain minimum number of tickets. For example, if your group discount only kicks in at 10 tickets and a patron tries to use it with a purchase of just 8 tickets, the discount will not work.
Note: Pricing can be done in dollar and cents, so be careful when inputting your discount price._
Step 5: Limit Total Tickets Sold with Discount
Choose how many tickets can be with sold with this code. The default is to offer unlimited discounted tickets to an event. You may want to change this setting and set a maximum number of discounted tickets if the discount is very large or you are concerned about selling out. Be aware that each ticket sold with a buy one get one free code count against this total amount. So if you limit the discount to 20 tickets, that will be 10 tickets paid at full price, and 10 tickets free.
![Discount_Inventory](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=126 "discount_inventory")
## More Tips:
* You can use the same code word for multiple events (eg. "DanceFriend") but you'll need to set up the terms of the code in each event. This allows you to make "DanceFriend" worth $5 for tickets at one event and $15 at a different event. * Once you create a discount, a summary list of discounts will be created on the Discounts page. You may delete codes that have not been redeemed. Once a code has been used, you cannot delete it (this would mess up the sales accounting). To turn off a code, simply click on the code name in the summary discounts list, and uncheck the box labeled "Discount is active and can be used now". You can see which codes are active and inactive on the summary discounts list.
![Discount Code List](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=127 "discount code list")
* You can explore how your patrons are using discounts in a **Show Statement** report or the **Discounts** report. Access these under **'Reports'** on the top menu bar.
## Related Articles * [Discount Code Reporting](/site/knowledgebase/discount-code-reporting)
Intro to the Fractured Atlas Knowledge Base (CC)

### What is it?
The Fractured Atlas Knowledge Base is an online library of articles and videos that describe how to use our software tools and services. It is organized into two collections--the public Knowledge Base (KB) and the Internal Knowledge Base (IKB) which can only be seen by staff.
The purpose of the public Knowledge Base is to teach our members how to navigate our tools and give them a place to answer their own questions 24-7. The purpose of the Internal Knowledge Base is focused on sharing tips for using internal tools, procedures for job-based tasks, and onboarding materials for new staff. Our hope is that the Knowledge Base will reduce customer service volume, increase customer satisfaction, streamline staff onboarding, and increase cross-department understanding.
### How is it organized?
The public KB and the IKB are organized with a similar hierarchy...
1. **Topics** = Programs or major areas. Only Adam and Shawn have permission to add new topics in either knowledge base. - **Public KB Topics** - Artful.ly - Fiscal Sponsorship - Insurance - SpaceFinder - Membership - Visa Letters - Arts Entrepreneurship Awards - Other - **IKB Topics** - Who Is Fractured Atlas? - Members & Database - Programs - Additional Services - External Communication - How We Work - Operations - Learning at Fractured Atlas 2. **Categories** = Sections within a topic - [Browse all categories in this agent view](admin/Knowledgebase/category_list). - Edit or delete categories from that list. - [All agents can add categories here.](/admin/Knowledgebase/category_form) 3. **Articles** = Instructions or answers about a specific aspect of a program, service, or application - [Browse all articles in this agent view](/admin/Knowledgebase). You can filter by topic and category or search by keyword. - Edit or delete articles from that list. - [All agents can add articles here.](/admin/Knowledgebase/article_form)
### How do I use it?
All staff members have permission to write new articles or edit existing ones. Generally, you should talk to your supervisor before adding an article to the public Knowledge Base. Read these articles to learn how to create new articles...
- [Writing & Formatting Knowledge Base Articles (CC)](/admin/Knowledgebase/view_article?id=84) - [Adding Images to Knowledge Base Articles](/admin/Knowledgebase/view_article?id=441)
Can my Artful.ly ticket revenue go to my fiscally sponsored fund?

No, because donations and income from ticket sales are treated differently. Ticket sales are **earned** revenue, but your sponsored fund is for **contributed** revenue (donations). If you have an active fiscally sponsored project with Fractured Atlas, any donations you receive through Artful.ly are processed as contributed income per the terms of the sponsorship program. Income from ticketing is earned income which does not fall under the sponsorship program.
When you opt into the Paid Event Ticketing Kit, you need to submit your electronic funds transfer information so that we can send your ticketing revenue to your bank account. This can be the same bank account you use for fund releases from your sponsored fund. You can use your personal checking account to receive your ticketing revenue, but it's advisable to keep your company's revenues separate from your personal money. If you have a business bank account set up, you can send us an **[Artful.ly EFT form](https://www.artful.ly/forms/artfully_etf_sign_up.pdf)** and a copy of a voided check, and we'll set you up with the **Paid Event Ticketing Kit**.
### Looking for a deal on business checking accounts?
It doesn't matter where you set up your company bank account, but TD Bank does offer Fractured Atlas members a deal on new checking accounts: [https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/specialoffers/120](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/specialoffers/120).
###Related Articles - [Donations to Fiscally Sponsored Projects](/site/knowledgebase/donations-to-fiscally-sponsored-projects)

If you want to accept donations with Artful.ly to your Fractured Atlas sponsored fund, don't make your organization name Fractured Atlas.

Add a Photo to Your Artful.ly Account With Gravatar

**I want to turn that blank head into a picture. Where do I go?**
![Demo Bust](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=130 "Demo Bust")
Artful.ly uses Gravatar for profile photos.
**To add an image:**
Go to [Gravatar](http://en.gravatar.com/ "Gravatar") and create an account. Be sure to use the same email address as your Artful.ly user account. Gravatar only knows who you are through email addresses.
Once you create your account and upload an image, that photo will populate on any Gravatar-supported sites where your account uses that email address.
If you want to learn more about Gravatar, you can find more information in their [Knowledge Base](http://en.gravatar.com/support/).
Why are my settlements off by a few cents?

When you look through your Artful.ly settlements, it might seem like there's a discrepancy of a few cents.
This is because the 3.5% credit card processing fee is deducted and rounded off from each ticket, donation, or membership as it is sold rather than a 3.5% charge applied to a whole settlement. For certain dollar amounts, these rounding differences will appear as a discrepancy of a few cents.
**For Example**:
**You have a show where the tickets cost $55.**
3.5% of a $55 ticket = $1.925, but that gets rounded to $1.93.
$55 gross - $1.93 = $53.07 Net
**Now say you've sold 5 tickets...**
If you multiply the whole settlement gross by the credit card percentage, you'll get...
$275 * 3.5% = $9.625, rounded to $9.63
$275 - $9.63 = $265.37 Net
**The correct math is:**
($55 - $1.93) * 5 = $265.35 Net
### Related Articles - [Settlement Reports](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/settlement-reports)
Exporting Data

Artful.ly makes it easy to export your contacts, sales, and donations to an external CSV for use in other programs.
1\. Under Reports, select **Imports/Exports**.
![Imports and Exports](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=132 "Imports and Exports")
2\. Choose what kind of data you want to export:
* **Export People:** name, email, and contact information including social media information * **Export Donations:** name, email, amount, and non-deductible portion * **Export Sales: **name, email, event title, and amount
![Export](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=131 "Export")
3. Selecting the appropriate button will automatically download a CSV to your computer.
## Related Articles
* [Importing People](/site/knowledgebase/importing-people) * [Importing Events](/site/knowledgebase/importing-events) * [Importing Donations](/site/knowledgebase/importing-donations)
How do I format an import without Excel?

Artful.ly gives you a downloadable CSV template, this means "Comma Separated Values," and is a file format that's universally accepted by most spreadsheet applications. This can be filled in with your fans' emails, addresses, event attendance, past donations, and more. Then, the template can be imported into Artful.ly, which will create People records for each of individuals or companies on your list.
In order to format your file correctly for importing, you need to be able to view and edit the CSV file in a spreadsheet program such as Microsoft Excel. If you have Excel on your computer, it will probably be the default program for reading CSV files.
## I don't have Excel...
If you don't have Excel software in your computer, don't worry. There are plenty of other tools you can use to format a CSV file for your import, such as:
* [Google Drive](http://www.google.com/drive/apps.html#product=sheets) (free!) * [Open Office](http://www.openoffice.org) * [Numbers (for Macs)](http://www.apple.com/iwork/numbers) * [A list of all sorts of spreadsheet software on Wikipedia (that also includes Microsoft Office for PC and Mac)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_spreadsheet_software)
Pretty much any spreadsheet tool will let you read and edit a CSV file. And when you're done adding all your contacts, remember to save your spreadsheet as a CSV file type so Artful.ly can read it when you import it.

Privacy Policy

# Privacy Policy
Protecting the information you share with us is very important to us, and we respect your privacy. This Privacy Policy is meant to explain how we use and protect the information you share with us. This Privacy Policy applies to all users of this web site or our services, and to any information provided to us.
We reserve the right to change, modify, add, or remove provisions of this Privacy Policy. Changes to this Privacy Policy will be posted on this site. We encourage you to check back from time to time to ensure continuing familiarity with the most current version of our Privacy Policy. Please read this Privacy Policy carefully. Your use of this web site constitutes your acceptance to be bound by this Privacy Policy without limitation, qualification or change. If at any time you do not accept all the terms and conditions contained herein, you must immediately discontinue use of this web site.
### Information Collection
We collect information from users of this web site at several different points on this web site. When you opt to use many of the services on our web site, you must first set up an account, which requires you to submit contact information (i.e., email and mailing address), demographic information, and certain unique identifiers. We only ask for such information as is necessary for the provision of member services, and we use it in the provision of those services.
In the event you make a transaction through the web site, we may collect your credit card number or other payment account number, billing address and other information related to such purchase (collectively, "Payment Information") from you. The Payment Information is transmitted via secure, encrypted processes. We do not store credit card numbers any longer than is necessary to process transactions and provide related support. Our third-party credit card processing vendors may store credit card numbers indefinitely, and are responsible for ensuring the security of such storage.
We will use the Payment Information that you provide to bill you for and fulfill your transaction. By providing your Payment Information, you are authorizing us to give that information to third parties as necessary to confirm and fulfill your order (for example, to process your credit card or payment account number and to send you products you have ordered).
### Traffic Analysis
When you visit pages on this web site, our web server records your page views. This is an extremely common practice, and is necessary for us to design the best, most usable web site possible.
### Information Use
Information submitted by users of this web site either in the sign up process or when using one of the "premium" features of the web site will be used:
* to assist us in the provision of services; * to contact users with important updates about this web site or the services it provides; and * in the aggregate, as a means for us to understand more about our community and its needs.
This web site uses "cookies" exclusively to aid the login process. A cookie is a piece of data stored on the user's computer tied to information about the user. The cookies used by this web site contain very minimal information used only to identify and authenticate members. No sensitive identifying information is stored by cookies.
Like most standard web site servers, we use log files. This includes internet protocol (IP) addresses, browser type, internet service provider (ISP), referring/exit pages, platform type, date/time stamp, and number of clicks to analyze trends, administer the site, track users movement in the aggregate, and gather broad demographic information for aggregate use. These types of files are not linked to sensitive identifying information.
### Third Party Information Use
We do not share individual demographic information with any advertisers or other outside companies.
Though we make every effort to preserve user privacy, we may need to disclose demographic or other identifying information collected on our web site when required by law when we have a good-faith belief that such action is necessary to comply with a current judicial proceeding, a court order or legal process served on our web site.
In the event that we go through a business transition, such as a merger, being acquired by another company, or selling a portion of our assets, users’ information will be, in most instances, part of the assets transferred.
### Links
This web site contains links to other sites. We are not responsible for the privacy practices of such other web sites. We encourage our users to be aware when they leave our web site and to read the privacy statements of each and every web site that collects identifying information. This privacy statement applies solely to information collected by this web site.
### Notification of Changes
If we decide to change our privacy policy, we will post those changes to this privacy statement so our users are always aware of what information we collect, how we use it, and under what circumstances, if any, we disclose it.
Order Details

Every order made through any sales channel will create Order Details. This is where you'll go:
- Make and read notes on orders - Perform returns, refunds, and exchanges - Audit the history of an order - Resend email receipts and print hard copies
Here's an example of what the order details page can look like:
![A very complex order details page featuring different inventory types, exchanges, and internal notes](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=835 "complex order details")
## Notes on Orders Order Details pages have two places where you can read notes on an order: **Special Instructions** and **Internal Notes**. If you ask a question at checkout using Special Instructions, they'll appear in yellow. You can add your own notes to an order during a transaction in the Box Office or Sales Console, or on the Order Details page. Your Internal Notes appear in blue.
More information on adding Internal Notes and Special instructions can be found in this article: [Internal Notes & Special Instructions on Orders](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/internal-notes-special-instructions-on-orders)
## Refunds, Returns, & Exchanges You'll also open Order Details if you need to refund, return, and exchange tickets, donations, memberships, or passes. Each of these inventory types gets their own table on the page.
You can take action on multiple items in a table by ticking the checkboxes next to what you want to refund, return, or exchange, and use the gear button above the table. To refund, return, or exchange one item in a table, click the gear icon on that inventory item's line.
![Refund, Return, or Exchange Multiple Tickets](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=840 "refund, return, or exchange multiple tickets")
Once something has been returned, refunded, or exchanged, it will create a separate order we call a child order. The original (or parent) order will list everything in the original order, and the child order will list the changes. This information, along with the links to the child orders can be found in the grey box on the right hand side of the order details page.
For a more detailed look at how to perform refunds, check out [Refunds, Exchanges, and Returns](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/refunds-exchanges-returns).
Additionally, the user account of the staff member who created the order will appear in the **Created By** line. For this reason, it's good to have user accounts for each of your staff members. You can find out more on adding administrators to your account in this article: [Adding Users & Managing User Permissions](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/adding-users-managing-user-permissions-).
## Resending & Printing Receipts If one of your supporters lost her receipt and needs a new copy emailed to her, you can quickly do that from the **Work With** button on the upper right hand corner of the page.
There's also the option to print a receipt, and if your organization is using the [Print at Home Scannable Tickets Kit](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/print-at-home-scannable-tickets-kit) you can print a customer's barcoded tickets.
![Order details Work With button](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=839 "Work With order details")
**Related Articles:**
- [How do I ask patrons a question at checkout?](/site/knowledgebase/ask-patrons-a-question-at-checkout) - [Notes on People Records](/site/knowledgebase/notes-on-people-records) - [Internal Notes & Special Instructions on Orders](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/internal-notes-special-instructions-on-orders) - [Adding Users & Managing User Permissions](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/adding-users-managing-user-permissions-) - [Refunds, Exchanges, and Returns](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/refunds-exchanges-returns) - [Print at Home Scannable Tickets Kit](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/print-at-home-scannable-tickets-kit)
When does my storefront stop displaying a show?

Your Storefront is open to sell tickets up to one hour after your show begins. After about an hour, the storefront stops displaying the show so that patrons can't buy tickets from home too long after the curtain rises.
If you'd like to remove the show from your storefront sooner, you can unpublish the show or take tickets off sale at any time. These actions can be done on the **Show Details** page. This puts you in control of exactly when or where the patron will see it.
![taking tickets off sale in show details](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=137 "take tickets off sale")
On the other hand, producers can sell tickets via the box office up to two business days after each show. Credit card sales should not be made after this time period because the show settlement will have already been sent and thus it will be impossible to settle the funds.
## Related Articles * [Box Office: Sell Tickets at the Door](/site/knowledgebase/box-office-sell-tickets-at-the-door) * [Publish or Unpublish a Show](/site/knowledgebase/publish-or-unpublish-a-show) * [Cancel, Change the Time, or Reschedule a Show](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/cancel-change-the-time-or-reschedule-a-show)
What do receipts look like?

## What do receipts look like?
Like this!
![an example order confirmation email](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=691 "order confirmation email")
## Artful.ly receipts include the following information:
* Receipts are referred to as **"Order Confirmations"** * They remind patrons that the charge on their credit card statement will appear as **"Artful.ly"** * **Order number:** This is corresponds to the **Order ID** number you see in Transaction records * **Purchase date** * **Order total:** The total value of tickets and/or donations * **Payment method**: This will either be credit card, cash, or comp. The credit card type and number is not provided * **Service fee:** The total fee for the entire order.[Here's a reminder about Artful.ly Fees and when they appear to the Patron](/site/knowledgebase/what-s-it-cost-) * **Venue location** * **Contact email and phone number** (If you provided one) * **Itemized list** featuring: - Each ticket type purchased - Ticket Type description - Receipt details—great for things like telling people where to park and other details that don't need to be included in the ticket type description. - Price - Donation amount (if applicable)
## Where do receipts come from?
They are automatically emailed to the patron from support@artful.ly immediately following the transaction.
**For Charity Donations:** The receipt is only to document the transaction. You will need to send any additional tax-related documentation (such as information about partially deductible donations) separately.
**For Donations to **Fractured Atlas** Fiscally Sponsored Projects: **Receipts will be emailed separately from Fractured Atlas (support@fracturedatlas.org) and will serve as the patron's receipt for tax purposes**.** If the donation is made in addition to a ticket purchase, the patron will receive two separate receipts simultaneously.[Here's more information about Fiscal Sponsorship Donations.](/site/knowledgebase/donations-to-fiscally-sponsored-projects)
## Who do patrons contact if they need a new receipt or have questions about their order?
You!
[Here's how to resend a receipt](/site/knowledgebase/resending-receipts).
