Sales Console: A Private Sales Channel for Complex Orders

## Sales Console v. Box Office
The Sales Console is a private sales channel for producers to manage more complex orders outside of the Box Office. From the Sales Console you can sell tickets to multiple events, sell passes or memberships (if those kits are activated), apply discount codes, and even take donations. It's also an avenue to process ticket sales for passholders and members. Keep in mind that credit card swipers are currently only supported in the Box Office.
Depending on the situation, choose the appropriate sales interface:
* Sales Console for complex orders with multiple items * Box Office for simple ticket sales for just one show when speed is the priority
Sales made through the Sales Console will...
* Send the customer a receipt * Create a record for a new customer, or add the information to an existing record * Log the appropriate Bought or Gave Actions on the customer's record
## Using The Sales Console
The Sales Console can be found under the **Sell** menu
![Navigate to Sales Console](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=138 "Navigate to Sales Console")
## Sales Console Tiles
![Sales Console Tiles](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=142 "Sales Console Tiles")
The look of your sales console will vary depending on your organization and which kits are enabled. You may see the following tiles:
* **Tickets**: Regular and member tickets are added through this tile. * **Donations**: Organizations with the 501(c)(3) Donations Kit enabled can process donations outside of the storefront or widget. * **Memberships**: Allows organizations with the Memberships Kit to sell memberships directly to patrons. * **Passes**: Allows organizations with the Passes Kit to sell passes directly to patrons. * **Apply Pass Or Discount Code**: This tile is used to apply a patron's passcode, as well as any discount codes you've created for events.
Click on these tiles and select various options to build an order. You'll see a list of all the items in the order on the right under **Order Summary.**
## Selling Through The Sales Console
1. Click on the tickets tile and select the event you want to sell tickets to. **Note**: in order to sell tickets through the sales console, the tickets must also be available in the Storefront and Widget. 2. Select the show. 3. Add tickets to the cart.
![Add Tickets](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=146 "Add Tickets")
4. If your patron wants to add a donation, you can use the donation tile to add a donation to an order, or you can also apply a Discount or Pass code to the order.
![Donation or Discount](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=147 "Donation or Discount")
5. When the order is built, click the green Check Out tile. The interface for checking out an order will feel similar to the Box Office. You can sell items through the Sales Console via cash, credit, or check—or you can comp an order. Comp sales willl not generate an email receipt to the patron unless you check the box to send a confirmation email; the checkbox is above the checkout button.
![Add Payment Information](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=141 "Add Payment Information")
## Sell to an Existing Customer
If the customer you're selling to is already in your Artful.ly records, you can help keep your database tidy by using the **Sell To** feature.
1. Navigate to the patron's record. 2. Click the **Work With** button and select **Sell to**.
![Sell To Existing Customer](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=143 "Sell To Existing Customer")
3. Build the order in the Sales Console. 4. When you go to check out, the customer's contact information will already be filled into the buyer info fields.
![Check Out](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=144 "Check Out")
## Sales Console Fees
* Tickets purchased via credit card are not charged the $2 service fee, but the 3.5% credit card fee still applies. * There are no charges for logging sales via check, cash, or comp.

Beta: Membership v. Passes

## Do I want memberships or passes?
## Short Answer
Probably passes. They're simpler.
## Long Answer
![Memberships vs. Passes](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=150 "Memberships vs. Passes")
## Can I have both?
Of course. Just make sure your business rules around each are clear with your staff and obvious to your patrons.
### Related Articles:
* [Memberships Overview](/site/knowledgebase/beta-memberships-overview) * [How Patrons Become Members](/site/knowledgebase/beta-how-patrons-become-members) * [Passes Overview and Activation](/site/knowledgebase/beta-passes-overview-and-activation) * [How Patrons Buy Passes and Apply Pass Codes](/site/knowledgebase/beta-how-patrons-buy-passes-and-apply-pass-codes)
Beta: Memberships Overview

The membership kit is currently in beta. Please email support@artful.ly if you're interested in becoming a beta tester.
## Defining "Membership"
Membership, Subscription, Season Supporter, Friend of the Theater—memberships can mean something completely different depending on the organization. For Artful.ly, we've designed two membership paradigms to cover a variety of business strategies.
Artful.ly membership features allow you to:
* Create and sell multiple membership types (or levels) with different names, price points, and benefits * Sell member-only ticket types with special member pricing * Make events or shows only visible to logged in members * Sell tickets to members before they go on sale to the general public * Offer special membership renewal pricing
## Two Flavors of Membership
To accommodate a wide range of business rules, we've structured memberships into two flexible types:
**Season**: Members sign up and receive benefits for your theatrical season, a calendar year, or some other term with a fixed end date. Sign-ups and renewals are focused at a certain time of year.
**Rolling**: Members sign up and receive benefits for a number of months or years from their sign-up date. Members can start at any time and renewal takes place whenever an individual's membership expires.
## Tickets to Multiple Shows
Memberships might not be the right solution for every organization. Patrons can also buy tickets to multiple shows though **Passes**. To learn more about the differences, take a look at our article [Memberships v Passes](https://artfully.zendesk.com/entries/79532407-Beta-Membership-v-Passes).
## Tax Deductibility for 501(c)(3) Organizations
Organizations that have their own 501(c)(3) status can issue tax receipts for memberships based on their own business rules.
## Tax Deductibility for Fractured Atlas Fiscally Sponsored Projects
Fractured Atlas fiscally sponsored projects may sell memberships, but the purchase is not tax deductible for your fans. The funds from membership sales are deposited directly into your organization's bank account, rather than your sponsored fund. Membership revenue does not count for your grant-eligibility requirement.
Patrons do have the option to add a tax-deductible donation on top of a membership purchase, and sponsored projects may also use the Donation Widget or Wordpress Plugin.
However, we plan to build features to do this soon. If you would like these features for your organization, please vote for it in our Feature Request forum: [Allow fiscally sponsored projects to sell tax-deductible tickets, memberships, and passes](https://artfully.zendesk.com/entries/21620351-Allow-fiscally-sponsored-projects-to-sell-tax-deductible-tickets-memberships-and-passes).

Resending Receipts

Except for comp sales, order confirmations are sent automatically sent to your supporters for all transactions as long as an email address was collected during checkout. You can resend a receipt from an Order Details page, which you can reach in two ways:
## Orders Reports: 1. Select the inventory item category from the **Orders** Menu. 2. Use the date selectors to narrow down the date range if the order isn't super recent. 3. Click on the **Order ID** number under the order column to reach the order details page. ![Order ID in an orders report](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=823 "orders report order id")
## The Action Feed in a People Record:
1. From the menu bar, select **People**, and then Search. 2. Type in their email or name in the field provided and hit the **Search** button. 3. Click on the person's name to open the record. 4. Find the order under the **Action Feed.** 5. Click on the bought action you need to work with and select **View Order Details**. ![View Order Details from individual Action Feed](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=824 "action feed")
On the Order Details page. 1. Click the **Work With** button on the top left side of the screen. 2. Select **Send Receipt** from the dropdown menu.
**Note:** The new order confirmation email will be sent to the primary email address on file in the purchaser's people record. So, if you are resending a receipt because a patron mistyped her email address, make sure you correct the address on her people record before resending the receipt.
![use the work with button and click resend receipt](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=821 "work with button resend receipt")

How do I take tickets off sale?

There are a lot of ways to take tickets off sale in Artful.ly which range from changing who can see a ticket type, modifying your show's capacity and ticket inventory, or unpublishing the show entirely. We'll detail all of the options here.
## Adjusting Visibility For Individual Ticket Types- Taking Tickets On or Off Sale in the Storefront
Taking the tickets out of the storefront will make those ticket types no longer visible. This can be useful if you want a ticket type available at the door, but not for advance sales.
* **The edit menu **allows for changes to the ticket name, price, and description. You can also choose where tickets are visible for purchase.
* If, for instance, you do NOT want a ticket type available to patrons online, and only want to sell tickets at the box office, **uncheck Storefront and Widgets**. This is also useful if you want to end ticket sales early for a particular ticket type. * **You can also limit the number of tickets available for that type**. If there is no limit besides the capacity of the venue, leave the box blank.
![Editing an individual ticket type using the work with button](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=162 "edit a ticket type")
![editing ticket type visibility modal](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=163 "ticket type modal")
## Option 2: Adjusting the Ticket Capacity of a Show
* The capacity reflects overall availability in your venue for all ticket types. * Ticket types reflect different price points for certain patrons or limited availability of special tickets (like rush tickets).
For example, you have 100 seats in your venue and they are available to any mix of students, seniors, or the general public. You can set your capacity at 100\. Those 100 seats can be filled by any combination of students, seniors, and the general public, so you would set all those ticket types to UNLIMITED. You also offer a special rush deal for the first 10 people who say 'pumpernickel' at the door, so you would limit that ticket type to 10.
## Unpublish a Show or Take Tickets on and Off Sale: List View
If you need to take tickets on or off sale, it's easy adjust your ticket capacity from the list view.
* Go to **Shows** and select **List.** * Click on the **Gear **to perform an action on a show. * Select **Put on Sale **or **Take off Sale** to adjust your show's capacity. Taking tickets off sale removes them from the available ticket pool. This can be useful if you want to hold back some tickets for door sales. Just remember to put them back on sale when you're ready to begin those sales.
![Using the work with button on list view can take a batch of tickets on or off sale](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=164 "list view take tickets on or off sale")
**Then it's just a matter of choosing the number of tickets to adjust.**
![put tickets on sale modal](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=165 "put tickets on sale modal")
It's also possible to unpublish one or several shows at once from the List view to ensure that they are not publicly viewable. To do so, select **Work with...** and click on **Unpublish**.
![Publish or unpublish a show in list view](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=609 "Publish or unpublish a show in list view")
## **Changing Ticket Capacity: Show Page**
**When you first create an event you will set a capacity. From there you can increase the capacity or take tickets on or off sale**.
* First, select a **Show**. * Select the gear button under **Ticket Capacity**. * A dropdown menu will appear with options to **Put On Sale**, ****Take Off Sale****, or **Add Tickets**.
![work with take off sale on show view](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=167 "work with take off sale on show")
**From there you can choose how many tickets you would like to remove from sale**.
![take off sale modal](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=168 "take off sale modal")

Refunds, Exchanges & Returns

## What's the difference between a Refund, Exchange, and Return?
**Refund**: Refunds full price of ticket to the patron. This applies to paid and free tickets.
**Exchange**: Swaps original ticket for another. Use this when the tickets have equal value.
**Return**: Returns a ticket to inventory. This is for Comp tickets.
## When can I issue Refunds or Exchanges? **Cash/Check:** Exchanges and refunds can be made immediately following the purchase and up to two days after the show.
**Credit Card:** Exchanges can be made immediately after the purchase. Refunds cannot be made until at least one business day after the purchase was made. Exchanges may be made up until showtime, and refunds can be made until two days after the show.
Donations are held for two days before they are issued for settlement, and they can be refunded before the settlement is issued. If a refund needs to happen after the two day period has passed, the producer is responsible for issuing the refund to the patron.
## Refunding a Ticket, Membership, Pass, or Donation: 1. Select **Orders** and then the appropriate inventory item from the top menu bar. 2. If the purchase wasn't made recently, use the date selectors to narrow the date range. 3. When you've located the purchase you are looking for, click on the **Order ID** number to go to the Order Details. 4. On the Order Details, you can refund a single ticket by clicking the gear icon next to each item, or use the checkbox above the table to refund all of the tickets in an order. Tickets, donations, memberships, and passes must be refunded separately. 5. Select **Refund**, and you will be prompted to either issue a refund and return the ticket to the show's inventory (back on sale), or issue the refund and keep the ticket out of the pool of available tickets. 6. Credit Card refunds will show up on the patron's card statement within 3-5 business days.
![The orders for ticket sales page](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=169 "orders ticket sales")
## Exchanging Tickets of Equal Value:
1. Go through steps 1-4 above. 2. Select **Exchange,** and you will be prompted to select an event to which you'd like to exchange the ticket for, a show date, and ticket types. 3. A list of individual tickets will pop up based on the number of tickets that are available at that ticket type for the show. Select one, than select the **Exchange** ticket button at the bottom of the page. ![exchanging tickets view](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=830 "exchange tickets")
## Exchanging a Ticket for Another at a Different Price Partial payments or refunds aren't currently possible in Artful.ly. If patron wants to exchange tickets for new ones at a different price point, you must:
1. Refund the original ticket(s). 2. Have the patron purchase the new ticket(s).
## Returning a Ticket (for comp tickets only):
1. Comped tickets can be returned. This puts the free ticket back on sale. 2. Repeat steps 1-4 under Refunds above. 3. Instead of an option to refund you'll see a button labeled return. Select that and the ticket will be put back in your pool of available tickets.

Comp Tickets

**All complementary tickets are issued through the Box Office or Sales Console.** Basically, "comp" is a payment type you can use to give any ticket to a specific individual. For each show you need to comp tickets to, either:
1. Go to that show's detail page. Select **Shows **in the side menu, then select the date and time from your show list.
2. Select **Box Office** and [execute a box office sale](/site/knowledgebase/box-office-sell-tickets-at-the-door) using "Comp" as the payment method.
OR
1. Build an order in the [Sales Console](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/sales-console-a-private-sales-channel-for-complex-orders) and use "comp" as the payment method.
Comp sales will not automatically send confirmation emails. If you'd like to send a confirmation email with the comp, be sure to check the box for it right before the checkout button.
![Checkbox to send confirmation for comp order](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=806)
In general it's a good idea to send email confirmations with comp orders. If you have a situation where that would be weird, though, you can leave it blank. It's especially a good idea to send confirmation emails if your organization has the scannable tickets kit turned on.
If you didn't send a confirmation email with the comp order you can [resend the receipt](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/resending-receipts).
Group Sales

**There are a number of ways to organize group sales depending on the organization of your event.** Patrons are currently limited to 10 tickets at once through the storefront or 20 tickets in a single order through the box office. With that in mind, here are some ways to organize group sales for your event.
## Using Discount Codes for Groups
**Group discounts are easy to offer by creating a discount code and raising the minimum purchase number.** For example: if your group discount kicks in at 10 tickets and a patron tries to use it with a purchase of 8 tickets, the discount will not work. You can also create tiered discounts by offering multiple codes that work at different ticket amounts, for instance $2 off each ticket for groups of 5 or more, or $3 off each ticket for a group of 10.
**You can also use discount codes for a specific group larger than 10** by giving the discount code to the organization and having individuals purchase their tickets using the code. To prevent unwarranted sharing of the code, you may limit the number of times the code may be used.
![group discount codes](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=171 "group discount codes")
##Using the Sales Console or Box Office Over the Phone
**Unless you are openly advertising group rates, many will be negotiated over the phone or email.** To sell a group rate over the phone, create a special ticket type for the requested show with the appropriate price and limit the number to match the amount of tickets you'll need to sell. Then, using either the sales console the box office, you can sell these tickets using the patrons credit card number up to 20 tickets at a time. Groups larger than 20 will require multiple transactions.
Please Note: When creating the ticket type for the show, make sure the ticket is available in the box office but not the Storefront. [Read more about hiding a ticket type from the Storefront here](/site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-take-tickets-off-sale).
![box office group sale](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=172 "box office group sale")
## Buy-Out Events and Performances for Large Groups
If a patron wants an exclusive event or performance for a very large group (birthday parties, corporate outings, etc.), **i**t may be simplest to create a special event or show for them with its own ticket type. Create a ticket type with one (presumably fairly expensive) ticket. If you would still like to collective RSVP information for the attendees, create a free ticket type in conjunction and share the storefront URL with that group exclusively.

Importing Events

## How do I Import Events? **Artful.ly makes importing your ticketing and event history easy.** Import old attendance records or sales from other ticketing portals by following these steps:
1. Go to **Reports**
2. Select** Imports/Exports**
![select reports and imports and exports](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=173 "imports and exports")
3. Click **Import Events** 4. Under the heading "Template" download an empty CSV file with appropriate headers for your specific data (see below). **Important: Your files must be in CSV (comma separated-values) format in order to upload.** [Learn how to save an Excel file as a CSV here.](http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/excel-help/import-or-export-text-txt-or-csv-files-HP010099725.aspx) 5. Copy/paste the data from your old spreadsheet into the appropriate columns. Make sure to include all required fields as described under "Format". ![Import Events](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=174 "Import Events") 6. **Event and Venue Name are mandatory fields.** If you don't have that data filled in, the import won't work. For every patron or attendee, you must include either a first name, a last name, or an email address. 7. When your CSV is ready, select **Choose File **under the header "Upload" and retrieve the file from your computer. Once you see the file name appear, you can select **Import**. It may take a few minutes for your contacts to be imported. 8. Once it has been processed (and there are no errors) you must **approve** the import. Depending on the size of the file, it may take a few minutes. ![approve import](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=175 "approve import")
## Importing Tips * **Make sure your column headers match those in the blank CSV.** If your CSV is not organized properly or the information is in the wrong place (email in the wrong column, for instance), you will receive an error message. We recommend you delete the file and adjust the spreadsheet appropriately before uploading it again. * **Observe usable values and date formatting. **Make sure you use the right terms (for example: CASH or CREDIT CARD in Payment Methods) when filling out your spreadsheet. Also, observe the specific formatting for dates so your data isn't confused. You can make this a default setting in Excel (right click on the column > Format Cells > Date). * **Tidy up your data in the CSV before you import it.** It's much easier to fix typos and formatting in a spreadsheet rather than doing it record-by-record in the app. * Make sure you import your event in one CSV. This ensures the cleanest import of the event.
**If you have a yearly event, it's best to label each event with the year it occurred.** If several years' attendance of a yearly event is imported at once then each year will be imported as a show. It will be much cleaner for your accounting if you label these events as "Annual Gala 2014," "Annual Gala 2013," and so on.
## Can I delete an import? Unfortunately, it is not yet possible to delete a whole event import. Please exercise a great deal of caution before importing an event and make sure you double check your work.

VIDEO: Importing People
Actions & the Action Feed

**The Action Feed lists all interactions a patron has with your organization. **To help producers think holistically about the patron experience, we've framed all Actions from the point of view of the patron--What tickets did Jane Doe get? What donations did she give? What communication did she hear? etc. If you see all of these interactions in one place, then you can start to see correlations between the Tuesday eblast and the Wednesday ticket sales.
##Action Types: * **Bought Actions** record ticket purchases. They are automatically created when a patron buys tickets through any Artful.ly [sales channel](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/sales-channels-explained). Bought actions are also created when you [import an event](/site/knowledgebase/importing-events). Bought actions cannot manually be added. * **Gave Actions** record donations. Gave actions are automatically logged if the donation is made through Artful.ly, or you've linked your account to your fiscally sponsored project. 501(c)(3) organizations may manually log donations you receive via cash or check and donations received through other credit card processors. Fiscally sponsored projects should log their donations through their My Fiscal Sponsorship Page. * **Heard Actions** record emails, eblasts, phone calls, and other communications your organization sent to a patron. Heard actions are what that person heard from you and your team. If you have activated the [MailChimp kit](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/what-is-mailchimp-and-why-should-i-use-it), Heard actions will be logged for all people who receive your MailChimp campaigns. You can also manually add Heard actions. * **Helped Actions** record volunteer activity; all are manually logged. * **Said Actions** record communications from a patron such as emails and phone calls. Said actions are the opposite of heard actions; it's what the fan told you. These are manually logged. * **Went Actions** record events a fan attended. Use these for events you didn't ticket or where a ticket purchase might vary from actual attendance. Went actions are automatically logged if you check off people from a show's door list. Otherwise, you can manually log Went actions post-event.
![action feed detail view](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=176 "action feed")
## Manually Adding an Action 1. From a people record, select the **Add** button next to "Action Feed" ![adding an action on a people record](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=771 "add action") 2. Select the relevant **Action Type** from the buttons 3. Adjust the **Date** 4. Complete additional fields accordingly to record action details 5. For Said and Heard action types, select a communication method subtype 6. **Save** your action.
After you log an action, you can also see who created it by clicking on the action and selecting "Edit". The creator will be listed in the edit box.
##Bulk Adding Actions You can add the same action to multiple people's records at the same time via Advanced Search:
1. From the top menu, select **People**, then **Advanced Search** 2. Set search criteria. 3. Click **Search**. 4. To the right of the search returns, click the **Work with...** button, then select **Log action**. 5. Proceed as you would manually entering an action for one person.
OR, bulk add actions via List Segments:
1. From the top menu, select **People**, then **List Segments**. 2. Choose a list segment. 3. To the left of the names in your segment, click the** Work with...** button, then select **Log action**. 4. Proceed as you would manually entering an action for one person.
![work with button on list segment](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=178 "work with button on list segment")
## Starring Actions The Action Feed is automatically sorted from most recent actions down to the oldest. The list of actions could get pretty long and a push an important action down below where you and your team might ordinarily look. For important actions, click the gray star to the left of the action date. This will turn the star yellow. Refresh your browser and you'll see all the starred action filter to the top of the Action Feed.
![starring actions](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=179 "starring actions")
By the way, you can also star important notes. Only the first three starred notes will show up on the front of a patron's record, but the rest will appear when you click the "X more notes" link.

How do I create a new people record?

## Creating a New People Record
1. Select **People** from the top navigation bar. 2. Select **New Contact.** 3. Select either **Person** or **Company.** 4. For People Records, enter a **First Name, Last Name,** and/or an** Email Address.** Then hit **Save.** 5. For Company Records, choose the **Company Type**, then enter the **Company Name** and **Contact Email** you use. 6. Press Save.
As you start to type a name for a new record, Artful.ly will suggest similar existing records. This is to help you avoid duplicates in your database. If you see a record already exists for an individual or company, just abandon the form and click on the right name in the blue panel to go to that record.
![Artful.ly showing existing people records](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=180 "existing people")
### To Add and Edit Information
Select the **Work With** button and select **Edit Person's Info**
![the work with button on the patron record activated](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=181 "work with on a patron record")
Once there, you can update their name, nickname/preferred name, address, contact information, and birthday. It's possible to add up to three addresses per record, you can label them as: Work, Home, or Other, and then set a preferred address.
![edit people record](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=603 "edit people record")
### To Search for a Person Record
You can search do a simple search for a person's name, nickname, listing name, or email address. With an advanced search, you can also search by location using the zipcode.
To view more information about searching for individual people records, check out [this article.](/site/knowledgebase/advanced-search-and-list-segments)
### Importing Multiple People Records
You can also create multiple People Records in one fell swoop by [importing a CSV.](/site/knowledgebase/importing-people)

Revenue Meter

The Revenue Meter shows the total number and value of a person's purchases and donations to your organization. Depending on what kinds of things your organization sells through Artful.ly, this may include tickets, memberships, passes, and donations.
From a person's record, you can filter his or her spending history by time period or item type.
## Search By Time Period
Click on **Lifetime.**
* Search by Lifetime: Returns the value of every single purchase or donation a patron has made. * Search by Year: Option to search the last three years. * Search by Date Range: Enter the dates in the form displayed to search for purchases/donations during that period.
![lifetime value dropdown](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=183 "lifetime value dropdown")
##Search By Item Purchased
Click on **Total.**
* Total: All tickets, donations, memberships, and passes. * Tickets, Donations, Memberships, Passes: Depending on what kits you have turned on, different items will be listed below "Total". The number of items is listed after each type. Select one type to see how much this individual spent on a particular item in the given time period.
As you select different types of items, you will see sections of the ring darken. The darker area represents the revenue from the select item type relative to total revenue.
![total in dropdown](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=184 "total dropdown")
On the right side of the meter, the blue dots provide a visual aid to understanding a individual's value relative to others in your database. This display changes to reflect the item type and time period you have selected. Mouse over the dots to see how this individual's spending with your organization compares to your average patron.
![right side of the meter displays the patron's monetary contributions relative to other patrons](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=185 "comparing this patron to the average patron in the CRM")
### Related Articles
* [People Records Overview](/site/knowledgebase/people-records-overview) * [Advanced Search and List Segments](/site/knowledgebase/advanced-search-and-list-segments)
Beta: Sales Console for Memberships

If you're just starting with the Sales Console we recommend beginning with this article: [Sales Console: A Private Sales Channel for Complex Orders.](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/sales-console-a-private-sales-channel-for-complex-orders)
**Note**: It's currently not possible to purchase a membership and use it to buy member tickets in the same order. The same applies to selling passes and applying the pass code in the same order. These must be done over two transactions: one to sell the pass or membership, and the next one to buy tickets. If this is important to your organization, please let us know in the [feature request forum](https://artfully.zendesk.com/forums/318163-Feature-Requests).
## Sales Console Fees Structure for Memberships
* **Memberships and passes** sold via credit card are charged the 5% service fee plus the 3.5% credit card processing fee. The 5% service fee will be added to the order total if you designated that when setting up the membership or pass type.
* BETA USERS: We are not charging the 5% service charge for sales via Sale Console during the beta period.
## Selling Memberships Through the Sales Console
1. Navigate to the Sales Console through the **Sell** menu or select **Sell To** on a people record. 2. Select the **Memberships** tile and then select the membership type.
![Sales Console Memberships](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=186 "Sales Console Memberships") 3. Select the green **Check Out** tile. After you sell the membership you can then use the **Sell to** function in the **Work With** button on the patron's record to sell member tickets to the patron.
## Selling Member Tickets Through the Sales Console
1. Search for an individual's **People Record**.
2. Click **Work With** and select **Sell To**.
![Grace Lawson Sell To](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=187 "Grace Lawson Sell To")
3. Build the order for the patron and select the member tickets. Since you're selling to a member, the tickets will be available. Note that the tickets must also be available in the Storefront and Widgets in order to be sold through the Sales Console.
![Sales Console](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=190 "Sales Console")
4. Add any other items to the order and click the green **Check Ou**t tile and select the proper payment method. 5. Since you're using the Sell To function, the patron's contact information will automatically be filled into the buyer info fields.This helps to keep your database clean and organized.
![Sales Console Checkout](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=193 "Sales Console Checkout")
### Related Articles - [Sales Console: A Private Sales Channel for Complex Orders](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/sales-console-a-private-sales-channel-for-complex-orders)
Beta: Configure Your Membership Storefront

Once you activate your Membership Kit, you should customize the language and images that appear on your Membership Storefront. This is where you can talk about your membership program and make a sales pitch for why your fans should join.
1. Go to your **Account Administration** page.
2. On your Membership Kit click **Configure**. ![Configure Membership Kit](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=194 "Configure Membership Kit")
3. Here you can add text and use the rich formatting tools to adjust text size, add emphasis, and even add images to your Membership Storefront. There's also a checkbox at the bottom to show or hide the membership storefront. This is useful if you only sell memberships during a certain part of the year.
![Configure Membership Storefront](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=678 "Configure Membership Storefront")
4. As you make changes to the marketing material in each text box, it's useful to have another window with your **Membership Storefront** open so you can see the results of your edits. As you save changes from configuring the storefront, you can refresh the view of the storefront to see the results. Here's an example of the Membership Storefront developing...
![Member Storefront Results](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=195 "Member Storefront Results")
Once your patrons purchase a membership and login to the storefront, they will see a list of member only events.
![Member Storefront View](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=196 "Member Storefront View")
### Related Articles
* [Create a Membership Type](/site/knowledgebase/beta-create-a-membership-type) * [How Patrons Become Members](/site/knowledgebase/beta-how-patrons-become-members)
Beta: Create a Membership Type

## To Make a Membership Type:
1. Navigate to the **Sell** menu and select **Membership.**
![Sell Memberships](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=198 "Sell Memberships") 2. There are two types of memberships available: **Season** and **Rolling.**
![Membership Type](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=200 "Membership Type")
* If your programming is only for part of the year or has a fixed beginning and end date, it's probably best to choose a **Seasonal** membership. * If your programming is year-round, it's probably better to choose a **Rolling** membership.
## Basic Membership Details
Setting up a Membership is similar to setting up a ticket type, so if you've ticketed a show with Artful.ly, the workflow should feel familiar.
1. **Membership Name:** This could just be "Membership," or it could be a creative name specific to your organization. If you sell multiple types of membership you'll want to make sure each type has a different name. For example, if you have "Bronze," "Silver," or "Gold" memberships, you would have three membership types each with a different name.
2. **Description:** Describe the benefits a patron gets by purchasing this membership. Similar to a ticket type description, this is where you communicate the nitty-gritty details.
![Edit Description](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=201 "Edit Description")
3. **Membership Start and End Date (Seasonal Only):** This is where you define a season for a seasonal membership by choosing a start date and an end date. This is the range of time the membership will be valid for. ![Membership Dates](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=202 "Membership Dates")
4. **(Or) Membership Duration (Rolling Only):** If you're setting up a rolling membership, you'll define the length of the membership, as opposed to the date range of the season. Most organizations will probably choose one year.
![Duration Dropdown](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=199 "Duration Dropdown")
## Pricing
1. **Set the membership price**: Enter the cost of the membership. 2. **Add renewal price**: If you select to offer a renewal price, the patron will have the option to re-up at a discounted rate when their membership expires. 3. **Choose who pays the fee**: You have the option to have the patron pay the service fee, or fold the cost into the membership price. For a detailed breakdown, check out our [membership fees article.](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/beta-membership-fees-settlements)
![Membership Pricing](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=204 "Membership Pricing")
## Storefront Copy
* **Thanks Message:** The thanks message appears on your patron's browser after he or she has purchased a membership. * **Email Message:** After purchasing a membership, your patron is sent an email confirmation message with further instructions. You can customize this to include details about how to use their membership benefits or thank them once again.
![Storefront Copy](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=203 "Storefront Copy")
## Sales
1. **Sales Start:** Select the date when people can first buy a membership. This is useful if you're creating your membership type before it goes on sale. 2. **Sales End: ** This is the last day a patron could buy a membership. An end date is especially important for organizations that sell memberships for a season that runs for part of the year. 3. **Show on Storefront:** Checking this box publishes the membership type to your membership storefront. In most cases, you'll want to have this box checked, but if you have a private membership type, you can leave the box unchecked. This is similar to publishing and unpublishing a show. 4. **Limit Per Transaction:** This limit is how many memberships a patron can buy in one transaction. In most cases, you'll want to leave this option at one. Here are two sample scenarios for setting a limit:
* When a membership equals one seat per play, an organization may want to allow a single patron to purchase multiple memberships for him and his family members. * If your organization does not limit how many tickets a member can buy at a discount, you'll want to leave the limit per transaction at one: One Patron - One Membership.
![Sales Definition](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=205 "Sales Definition")
Once your membership type is saved it will be available in your Organization's **Membership Storefront. **You can reach the membership storefront from the link on the membership type creation page, or by going to your Central Storefront and clicking **Become a Member.**
### Related Articles
* [How Patrons Become Members](/site/knowledgebase/beta-how-patrons-become-members) * [Configure Your Membership Storefront](/site/knowledgebase/beta-configure-your-membership-storefront)
Taking a Down-Payment for a Longer Rental

Renters sometimes need an entire space for larger blocks of time, sometimes whole days or weekends in a row. If you get a rental request that might require a down payment:
1. Call the renter and find out what she'll need during the rental period. Let's say this rental will cost 500 dollars and our venue requires a 50% down payment.
2. If the renter agrees to the down payment, you can process that through Charge Renter, which is accessible through your dashboard.
In this case, we'll process a 250 dollar payment and add an Internal Note that it will be a down payment. When you charge the card, the renter will receive a confirmation of the charge.
3. Block out the times of the rental in your calendar to prevent double-booking. It's also good to put a reminder to collect the rest of the fee for the rental.
4. The remaining $250 can then be collected in another Charge Renter Transaction on the day of the show to complete payment for the rental.

Exporting Space Rental Payment History

For venues who have enabled [Online Space Requests](/site/knowledgebase/space-request-forms-features-benefits), you also have the option to export the payment information when a renter's card is charged or refunded, and when those funds are settled to your bank account.
## To export Space Requests
1. Login to your SpaceFinder account 2. Go to your Dashboard 3. Select 'Payments' 4. Filter your report by date 5. Click 'View' to load the data 6. Click 'Export' 7. A CSV will be emailed to the email address you logged in with ![a view of the payments screen with an arrow pointing to the export button](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=851 "export payments")
The CSV is split into two sections.
## Payments
The first table details when funds are submitted for settlement to your bank account, and for how much.
This table has the following columns:
- **Date** When the payment initiated - **Bank Account** The payment was settled to - **Amount** The total number of funds in the settlement - **Link** A link to see all of the transactions within the settlement and a breakdown of the gross total before merchant and service fees
## Transactions
We also include all of the transactions for the date range you specified. These are the individual credit card charges and refunds.
The table includes:
- **Date** The day of the transaction (this is when the card was charged, not necessarily when the rental happened - **Customer** The name of the renter - **Space** Which space within your organization the customer rented - **Amount** How much the rental cost - **Type** Either a purchase or a refund - **Link** A link to the transaction record
## Related Articles - [Space Request Form Features & Benefits](/site/knowledgebase/space-request-forms-features-benefits) - [Exporting Space Request History](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/exporting-space-request-data)

Resolving a Renter's Dispute of Credit Card Charge

Every now and then, a renter might not recognize the charge on their bank statement for their rental at your venue. This can sometimes leads to a charge dispute action with the bank. Understanding how our payment processor handles chargebacks will help you resolve the dispute as quickly as possible.
Organizations are contacted directly when a customer disputes a charge.
**Note: Stripe charges a $15 fee per chargeback. (Fee is in the currency in which the funds were received.) The fee is refunded if the issuing bank decides in the organization's favor.**
1. Stripe receives a notification of the disputed charge, sends organization automated email with the details. 2. Stripe deducts disputed amount and fee from account. 3. Organization responds to chargeback from their Stripe dashboard ("Disputes" section of their account.) 4. Org enters evidence that the charge is legitimate and selects "Respond to dispute" from their dashboard. 5. Stripe submits evidence to customer's credit card company, updates you afterwards. 6. Fee is refunded if the org wins the dispute.
For more details, Stripe outlines this process in the following two support articles:
- [Disputes/Chargebacks](https://stripe.com/help/disputes)
- [How does Stripe handle chargebacks?](https://support.stripe.com/questions/how-does-stripe-handle-chargebacks)
Here's an example of the automated email an organization would receive in the event of a chargeback:
Subject Line: "You have a disputed charge for $70.00 (ch_XxXXXXxXXXXxXxXxXXXXxXxx)"
Sender: support@stripe.com
Body of message:
"We're sorry to report that one of your customers has disputed a $360.00 charge (made on June 15, 2014) with his or her credit card company. Your customer is claiming that they did not receive the product or service they paid for.
When one of your customers disputes a charge, we're notified by his or her bank -- which automatically refunds the transaction -- and pass on as much information to you as we receive. Since the payment has been returned to your customer, we'll deduct this amount and the dispute fee from your account within the next day.
The good news is that you still have a chance to resolve the dispute and receive the amount and fee back. You can respond to the dispute through your dashboard; your customer's bank then makes the ultimate decision about how to resolve the dispute. If the dispute is resolved in your favor by your customer's bank or credit card company, we'll return both the disputed amount and the fee.
Disputes are handled by your customer's bank, so we don't have any information about how specifically this payment will be reviewed. However, we do want you to have as good a chance as possible in responding to these disputes. We've put together detailed documentation that can be very helpful in understanding and responding to disputes:
https://stripe.com/help/disputes
You can also read a bit about how we recommend responding to this specific type of dispute:
https://support.stripe.com/questions/dispute-product-not-received-evidence
You can view all of the details about the disputed payment and respond to the dispute right from your dashboard:
https://dashboard.stripe.com/payments/ch_XXXXxXxXxXXXXX
We realize how frustrating this can be. You can find answers to most questions at https://support.stripe.com/, and we'll be here to help you with any step along the way.
Yours,
The Stripe Team"
Who can apply for a visa letter?
Artists, attorneys representing the artist or organizations assisting in the submission of a visa application may submit a request for a letter of consultation from Fractured Atlas.
How to Request an Artist Visa Letter

### Instructions to request a letter:
- **Log in** and visit International Artist Visas under Programs and Services:
![Image showing where to select International Artist Visas under Programs and Services on the Fractured Atlas Home Page](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=431 "Where to find International Artist Visas under Programs and Services")
- **Select** "request a letter of consultation online":
![Image showing where to request a Visa Letter on the International Artist Visa page](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=433 "where to request a Visa Letter on the International Artist Visa page")
- **Complete** the information on the request form:
![Image showing Visa Letter Request Form](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=374 "Visa Letter Request Form")
- **Upload** the supporting documents and proceed to **pay** the $200 Fee:
![Image showing where to upload documents and pay on the Visa Letter Request Form](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=434 "where to upload documents and pay on the Visa Letter Request Form")
You will then receive an email confirmation that your request has been made. We will email a **PDF copy** of the requested letter once it is complete.
International Artist Visas Through Fractured Atlas

Getting a visa to work as an artist in the United States is a time-consuming and frustrating process. Government bureaucracy and red tape are a hassle, especially when you're only going to be working in the country for a short time.
As part of this lengthy process, artists applying for these visas often need letters of consultation/no objection that vouch for their artistic excellence. These can be hard to get if you're not already in a union or other professional association (and sometimes even if you are). Fractured Atlas can help.
If you're working on an O or P Visa application — whether as an immigration attorney, an employer/petitioner, or a visiting artist/group of artists — we can review your materials and write a letter of consultation/no objection for the application. We can help ALL artists and creative professionals with this process. With thousands of members across the country (and internationally), our membership represents every discipline (including, among others, the performing, visual, literary, design, and media arts).
We charge $200 for all letters. If USCIS requests further evidence after their initial review (which usually means a more specific letter of consultation), we charge $100 for the second letter.
Fractured Atlas is considered a "peer group" by USCIS. We are not a management or labor organization. Please check your visa application requirements to determine if you can use a peer group letter as your primary letter, or if you can only use a peer group letter as a supplement to a letter from a union or labor organization.
We can help make this process quick, easy, inexpensive, and efficient. Relevant visa application documents can be submitted online. We'll do an immediate review and send our letter of consultation within one business day.
Note that you'll need to be a member of Fractured Atlas to submit the request. If you're not already a member, you can join online for free in just a few minutes.
Can Fractured Atlas assist with completing the full visa application?

Outside of providing letters of no objection as a peer group for artists, Fractured Atlas is not staffed with immigration attorneys and can't offer advice about the actual visa application/process.
If you have questions about getting a visa, check out [www.artistsfromabroad.org](http://www.artistsfromabroad.org/) or contact one of the immigration attorneys listed on our [Special Offers](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/specialoffers/) page. [Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts](http://www.vlany.org/) may also be able to assist you with referrals for legal assistance. We are happy to provide further immigration attorney referrals upon request.
Fractured Atlas writes letters for what type of Visa applications?

If you're working on an O or P Visa application — whether as an immigration attorney, an employer/petitioner, or a visiting artist/group of artists — we can review your materials and write a letter of consultation/no objection for the application.
We can help artists and creative professionals in numerous disciplines with this process. With thousands of members across the country (and internationally), our membership represents almost every discipline (including, among others, the performing, visual, literary, design, and media arts).
What is a "peer group" and how is it different from a labor organization?

USCIS notices certain organizations within the field of the arts as peer groups who can provide letters of non-objection for certain Visa applications.
Fractured Atlas writes letters as a peer group, not a labor organization. If a visa application requires a labor organization letter instead, we could not fulfill this requirement and would need to be provided by a separate organization.
Visa Letter Rush Requests

If you would like to make a rush request, we will attempt to provide a letter within 1 business day. If the rush is successful, there will be an additional $150 fee. You may include the rush request in the submitted request.
How long will it take to get a letter once a request is submitted?

All requests will be honored within 3-5 business days. You may request a rush and we will attempt to provide a letter in one business day. If we're able to meet that timeline, there will be an additional $150 rush fee (for a total of $350) for the letter.

![the edit button is located under work with in people records](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=206)
Once there, you can update the patron's name, nickname, listing name, maiden name, address, image, contact information, mark a patron as deceased, and record someone's birthday.

For instructions on uploading an image to a record, read [this article.](/site/knowledgebase/adding-images-to-records) Any uploaded image will trump the person's existing Gravatar, if they've got one.
### To Search for a Patron Record
You can search do a simple search for a person's name or email address. With an advanced search, you can also search by location using the zipcode and a variety of other criteria. * [People Records Overview](/site/knowledgebase/people-records-overview) * [Actions & The Action Feed](/site/knowledgebase/actions-the-action-feed) * [Create Segmented Lists of People](/site/knowledgebase/advanced-search-and-list-segments) * [Merging People Records](/site/knowledgebase/merging-people-records) * [Notes on People Records](/site/knowledgebase/notes-on-people-records)
Company Records

Company records are how you keep track of your relationship with different businesses, government organizations, institutional funders, etc. They function similarly to individual people records with a couple of small differences.
## Company Types
**Company records come in five different flavors.** You will select a type when the record is first created, but it is changeable at any time.
The types are:
* Business * Foundation * Government * Non-Profit * Other
![creating_company records](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=210)
If you want to segment your company contacts further, try using tags. [Read how here.](/site/knowledgebase/how-can-i-use-tags)
## Companies in Search
**You can include companies in your advanced search filters.** Under "Type" you can choose Individual or Company. Leaving it blank will include both in search results. If you select company, and additional filter will show up for "Company Type".
## Converting an Individual to a Company record
**You may have some older records that are marked as individuals but are actually companies.** Making the change is easy:
1. Select the person record in question. 2. Click **Work With**. 3. Choose the option **Convert to Company** at the bottom of the modal. 4. Select the **Company Type**. 5. Include the company's name, this will overwrite the previous name you had.
![Convert_to_Company.png](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=208)
## Importing Companies
**You can import company records into Artful.ly just like individual people records.** You can also import companies and individuals in the same spreadsheet. Just make sure to specify what type of record is in each row.For a detailed description of how to import people records visit our article: [Importing People](/site/knowledgebase/importing-people).
Note: Fractured Atlas Fiscally Sponsored Projects will automatically have any institutional funders imported as a Company Record when they [connect their Artful.ly and Fractured Atlas accounts.](/site/knowledgebase/connect-your-sponsored-project-and-artful-ly-account)
## Best Practices
**Company records are quite useful when keeping track of institutional giving and business interactions. **Examples include:
* An institution which you are applying for a grant * Businesses that give you matching gifts * Organizations that make significant in-kind donations * Vendors or contractors with whom you do business
## Upcoming Company Features
**We are still expanding the level of detail in People records.** Coming features include:
* Defining relationships between individuals and companies * Householding couples and families
###Related Articles - [People Records Overview](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/people-records-overview) - [Importing People](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/importing-people) (Includes details about importing Company Records as well.)
Importing People

## How do I import patron information? Artful.ly makes creating many People records at once easy. Just collect your patron data in a spreadsheet and follow these steps:  1. Go to **Reports** 2. Select **Imports/Exports** ![reports and imports and exports are in the top menu bar](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=211 "imports and exports") 3. Click **Import People** 4. Under the heading "Template" download an empty CSV with appropriate headers for your specific data (see below). **Important: Your files must be in CSV (comma separated-values) format in order to upload. [Learn how to save an Excel file as a CSV here.](http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/excel-help/import-or-export-text-txt-or-csv-files-HP010099725.aspx)** 5. Copy/paste the data from your old spreadsheet into the appropriate columns. Make sure to include all required fields as described under "Format". ![Import Steps.png](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=212 "Import steps") 6.  **First Name, Last Name, and Email—you must have at least one of those fields for each person you are trying to import**. If you don't have a first name, last name, or email for each row, the import won't work. All the other columns are optional. Note: Importing Company records requires that you include a TYPE (one of the 5 listed above) and COMPANY NAME or EMAIL instead. 7. When your CSV is ready, select **Choose File** under the header "Upload" and retrieve the file from your computer. Once you see the file name appear, you can select **Import**. It may take a few minutes for your contacts to be imported. 8. Once it has been processed (and there are no errors) you must click **Approve** next to the import. Depending on the size of the file, it may take a few minutes. ![Once the import is in, you click the approve button](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=213 "click the approve button to finalize the import") 9. If any of the email addresses in your import match email addresses already in your database, then the imported information will be added to the existing record. In other words, we will merge the records for you. If any of the information in the pre-existing record conflicts with the information in the import, the existing data will win out over the new data.  ## Importing Tips * ****Make sure your column headers exactly match those in the blank CSV.**** For example, if your CSV has a column called just "Company" instead of "Company Name" then your file will not import properly.  * **Observe usable values and date formatting. **Make sure you use the right terms ("Work", ""Home", "Cell", or "Fax" for phone numbers types for instance) when filling out your spreadsheet.  * **Tidy up your data in the CSV before you import it.** It's much easier to fix typos and formatting in a spreadsheet rather than doing it record-by-record in the app. * **Artful.ly matches records based on email addresses.** Therefore, if you already have patron with the email jsmith@example.com in your account and import donation attributed to jsmith@example.com, that donation will be added to the existing record. If there is no jsmith@example.com in your account, then a new record will be created for this person. * Up to three addresses for one person can be added during an import. On the template they're labeled Address A, Address B, and Address C. ## Can I delete an import?  Yes. You can recall all the People records created by an import.  Here's how: 1. Go to **Reports** 2. Select **Import/Export** 3. Under the **Import History** section, click on the name of the imported file you want to recall 4. Click the **Recall This Import** button ![recall people imports](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=215 "recall people import") Note: Recalling an import only works for People imports--not Event or Donation imports. ## How do I get my data out of another system?  To get your data into Artful.ly you may need to get it out of another database. We're not experts on _every_ database in the world, but here are some tips for exporting from some common systems: * [Save an Excel file as a CSV](http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/excel-help/import-or-export-text-txt-or-csv-files-HP010099725.aspx) * [Export data from Access](http://office.microsoft.com/en-us/access-help/export-data-to-excel-HA101819737.aspx?CTT=1) * [Save a FileMaker file as an Excel file](http://www.filemaker.com/11help/html/import_export.16.3.html) * [Export Gmail contacts as Outlook CSV ](https://support.google.com/mail/answer/24911?hl=en) ## Related Articles * [How do I format an import without Excel?](/site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-format-an-import-without-excel) * [How do I get my Gmail contacts into Artful.ly?](/site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-get-my-gmail-contacts-into-artful-ly) * [Importing Donations](/site/knowledgebase/importing-donations) * [Importing Events](/site/knowledgebase/importing-events) * [Exporting Data](/site/knowledgebase/exporting-data)
Imports Demystified

All imports require that you first download the Artful.ly CSV template, then plug your data into the provided fields. This article will help demystify how to arrange patron, event, and donation information into the correct format within these fields, so that your imports are successful.
**Important Note:** you cannot add additional fields to the template. Any information you want to include in an import that does not correspond with a provided field can be entered as a [Tag](/site/knowledgebase/how-can-i-use-tags).
## Required Field Formats
* Red highlighted cells are required information.
#### **People Imports (Individual records) **
![required fields for people imports](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=216 "required columns are highlighted in red")
#### **People Imports (Company records) **
![required fields for company records](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=217 "required for company records")
#### **Event Imports**
#### ![Event Import](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=219 "event imports")
**Important note:** Show Dates w/o a time stamp will show up as 8pm in the Person Record. If you aren't using Excel, the date column can also be formatted like this: 2012/04/18.
#### Donation Imports
#### **![required fields for donation imports](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=220 "donation imports")**
* Don't add $ or any other currency symbols to the Amount column- it will cause the import to fail.
## The Tag Field
As mentioned above, **Tags** will allow you to attach significant information about a person that enables you to group them into a particular category. If you want to attach more then one label to a person, you can format tag fields like this:
![tag imports](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=221 "tags")
## Tips
- Don't use an Excel program? Try converting the CSV template file into a Google Doc Spreadsheet. Take a quick look at this [short video](http://screencast.com/t/mHxGh8HflZE8).
- Artful.ly doesn't check for formatting on phone numbers, so you can have phone numbers in your import template in various formats.
For example: - 8888888888 - 888.888.8888 - (888) 888-8888 - etc.

Advanced Search & List Segments

Artful.ly's Advanced Search features are designed for you to learn more about your audience.
Our search model is built on stringing together sentences of search criteria that you're looking for, kind of like word problems, but instead of having to calculate when two trains leaving from different cities will crash into one another, you can find information that's useful to your organization, like:
![Example Advanced Search](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=775 "Example Advanced Search")
- People who went to your shows between a specific date range. - Who have an email address - Have purchased tickets for a specific show - And volunteered to help your organization between a date range.
There's a lot more you can search for, and the best way to learn is to play around with your own CRM data to see what you can find, so here are some tips to help you get started. We're excited to see what you can come up with and what you find.
## Match Results to Any or All
One of the first things you'll want to consider when building a new search is how you want the search to run. For starters, you need to define how you want people to match up to your search. There are two options:
- *Any* searches cast a wide net. When you do one of these searches, results will come back if anyone in your CRM fits even just one of your conditions. So if you have a search for 4 different sentences, anyone who fits at lease one of your terms will be in the results. - *All* searches are laser-focused. Here the results will only include people who fit all of your search conditions. If you search for 4 different conditions and perform an all search, only people who meet all 4 will be returned.
## Search Conditions
Once you have your match criteria set, you get to start building your search; we refer to the blocks of your searches as conditions. A full list of conditions is found in this article [Advanced Search Conditions Glossary]()
Different kits give you different conditions to search with. MailChimp, memberships, passes, relationships, fundraising campaigns add have their own specific search filters that appear when those kits are added to your account. This keeps your conditions list uncluttered and relevant to your organization's activities.
## Double, Triple, or even Quadruple Negative! Sure, you can search for people who have done things, but oftentimes it's just as useful to know those who *have not* done something. For those moments, you can make your search conditions negative. For example, you could build a search for people who:
- *Went* your gala. (you would use the date the event happened in your search condition) and - *Did not buy* a ticket to your first show of the season So you can send them a customized email letting them know tickets are available.
Nearly every condition has negative search option, so you can use them in combination to find just who you're looking for. ![An example of a search built with all negative conditions](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=772 "a search for opportunities")
## I've searched for something, now what?
After you've admired how clever your search is, you'll probably want to take some action on it. For that you'll use the **Work With** button on the right hand side of your search results.
![An expanded view of the items in the work with button in Advanced Search](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=773 "work with button in advanced search")
The options are:
- **Tag All** This adds a tag to everyone in your search results. Learn more in [How can I use tags?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/how-can-i-use-tags) - **Log Action** This adds a bulk action to everyone in your search results. More can be found in [Actions & the Action Feed](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/actions-the-action-feed) - **Create List Segment** Lets you save a search. List segments deserve a little more explanation, so we'll cover them in the next section. - **Export to CSV** Lets you export a copy of your people records as a comma separated value file so you can work with it in another application. - **Comp Memberships** If you have the memberships kit, this allows you to comp memberships in bulk. There's more on that in [Comp Memberships](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/beta-comp-memberships) - **Subscribe to MailChimp list** Adds people to your MailChimp Lists. Read more about how this works in [Adding people to MailChimp lists or groups.](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/adding-people-to-mailchimp-lists-or-groups) - **Subscribe to MailChimp list group** Same as above, but for groups within lists.
## What is a list segment? You might be wondering what we mean by a list segment. In essence, list segments are dynamic saved searches that you can return to at a later time.
For example, if you create a list segment for everyone who has a VIP tag and donated more than $150 since January of 2015, you'll be able to save that search; and as more people donate and get tagged as a VIP, that list segment will grow to reflect the new people who meet your conditions the next time you return to it.
Once you've created a list segment, you can return to it in the people menu at the top of Artful.ly.
![An expanded people menu with an arrow pointing to list segments](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=774 "list segments")
## What if the search filter I want isn't here? Let us know! The best place to do that is in a [Feature Request](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/feature_request_list?topic=Artful.ly). Let us know what you want to see and how it would be useful to you!
### Related Articles - [How can I use tags?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/how-can-i-use-tags) - [Exporting Data](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/exporting-data) - [Adding people to MailChimp lists or groups.](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/adding-people-to-mailchimp-lists-or-groups) - [Actions & the Action Feed](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/actions-the-action-feed) - [Advanced Search Conditions Glossary](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/advanced-search-conditions-glossary)
How can I use tags?

Tags are custom identifiers you can attach to a People Record. Where they really shine is when you use the same tag to identify a unique group of people. People with the same tag can be easily found with advanced search and monitored via list segments. This can help you target your communication or track donor groups.
## What makes a good tag?
Tags are best used for classifications that are unique to your organization and/or that individual or company. Only letters, number, or dashes allowed in tags. Some examples include:
* "Board-Member" * "VIP" * "Artist" * Discipline Interests (e.g. "Dance", "Theater", "Opera", "Film") * Custom Company Classifications (e.g. "Theater-Company", "Gallery", "Producer", "Presenter", "Vendor")
You do not need to create tags for things like state or "2012-Gala-Ticket" since location and event are both advanced search filters of their own.
## Creating a Tag
1. Open **People** from the top menu bar 2. Select **Search** (if the Person Record already exists), or **New Contact** 3. Type in the name of the tag in the field provided. Remember--use only letters, numbers, and dashes. 4. Select the **Add Tag** button
Note: When viewing a Person Record, you can click on a tag in order to view the entire list of people in your database who have that tag. ![people record](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=226 "people record")
## Tag a Bunch of People At Once
Using [Advanced Search](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/advanced-search-list-segments), you can give the same tag to a group of people with one click.
1. Open **Advanced Search** from the People drop down menu in the top navigation bar 2. Build your search using the search conditions. 3. Click the **Work With** button 4. Select **Tag All** from the drop down menu that appears 5. Type the name of your new tag in the pop-up field that appear
![Advanced Searches being used to tag all search results from the work with button](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=728 "tag all")
## Edit or Delete a Tag
Tags can be edited or deleted from the Tags List.
1. Go to the **People** section and select **Tags List** from the drop down menu. 2. Click on the Tag name to view the list of patrons who are tagged in that segment. 3. Click on **Edit** to change the name of the tag. This will update every person's record who has that tag. 4. Click on **Delete** to remove the tag. This will delete the tag from every person's record who has that tag. 5. To delete only one tag from an individual Person Record, view the record, hover over the tag, and click on the red X.
![tags list](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=228 "tags list")
