Installing & Using the WordPress Plugin

## What's a WordPress Plugin? Plugins are little bits of code that you can insert into websites built with WordPress CMS. They can do all sorts of things to extend the functionality of your site. Our Artful.ly plugin allows you to sell tickets and/or take donations on your WordPress site. It does the same thing our widgets do but is specially designed to work on WordPress sites.
## **Where This Plugin Will and Won't Work** **Our plugin works on websites that use WordPress as a content management system but are hosted through a paid host. If your site is hosted on wordpress.com you cannot use this plugin.** The WordPress.com commercial hosting service does not allow users to install JavaScript so our plugin and widget cannot be used on theses sites. Link to the [Artful.ly Storefront](/site/knowledgebase/sell-tickets-via-central-storefront-and-event-storefront) from your site instead.
Confused? Read more...
Basically, there are two WordPress products:
1. WordPress CMS, a content management system 2. WordPress.com, a blog host
WordPress CMS is web software that allows you to create a website and manage the content on it. To use WordPress, you need to first find a webhost such as Bluehost, DreamHost, or Laughing Squid. That's where your website lives. Then you install WordPress on your hosted site and start designing it and filling it with content. This is when you can install an Artful.ly plugin. Learn more about WordPress CMS at [www.wordpress.org](http://www.wordpress.org/).
If you do not need the flexibility of a full web host, WordPress offers free blogs on WordPress.com. Blogs hosted on WordPress.com do not support plugins of any kind so you cannot install Artful.ly ticketing or donation tools on those sites. WordPress.com hosted blogs usually have URL that includes "wordpress.com". Learn more about WordPress hosted blogs at [www.wordpress.com](http://www.wordpress.com/).
Because WordPress.com hosted blogs are limited, most organizations pay for site hosting and just use the CMS. This allows for great flexibility in design, custom URLs, and access to features like plugins. If you're reading this, I suspect your organization is planning to do this, too, and you should have no problems using the Artful.ly plugins.
## Installing the Plugin 1. Login to your WordPress site as an administrator. 2. On the left-hand dashboard menu, click "Plugins." 3. Click "Add New." 4. In the search box, search for "Artful.ly." 5. Under "Artful.ly Widget" click "Install Now.” 6. After WordPress tells you the plugin was successfully installed, click "Activate Plugin."
## Current Version = 1.1 The current WordPress plugin version is 1.1. If you are not running this version, please upgrade now (see directions below).
## Using the Plugin to Sell Tickets 1. Log into your Artful.ly account. 2. Make sure you have activated the **[Paid Ticketing Kit](/site/knowledgebase/video-getting-started-account-set-up).** 3. Create an event and publish tickets for that event. 4. Select **Share & Sell **from the side menu on your event, then choose** WordPress Plugin**. 5. Copy the **Event ID** number on this page. (You can also find your event ID number at the end of the URL on your event set up pages it looks like this "https://www.artful.ly/events/60". The number 60 is ID number for that event.). 6. In WordPress, on the page where you want ticket information to be displayed, insert **[art-event id="eventID"]** and replace “eventID” with the ID number you copied from Artful.ly.
![get the shortcode from the share and sell menu on your event](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=325 "shortcode")
## Using the Plugin to Take Donations
1. Log into your Artful.ly account . 2. Activate a donation kit. If you are a 501(c)(3), add the **501(c)(3) Donation Kit**. If you are fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, **[connect to Fractured Atlas](/site/knowledgebase/connect-your-sponsored-project-and-artful-ly-account)** to activate your Sponsored Donation Kit. 3. On your Artful.ly Account Administration page, copy your **Organization ID** number. You'll also see this ID number listed on the **Wordpress Plugin** page in the **Share & Sell** menu for each Event. 4. In WordPress, on the page where you the want the donation field to be displayed, insert **[art-donation id="organizationID"]** and replace “organizationID” with the number you copied.
![account administration](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=326 "account administration")
## Updating Your Plugin (Version 1.1) We make improvements to the WP plugin as needed. If you have having problems with a plugin, please make sure you are running the latest version which is 1.1 (as of October 2015). To update your plugin:
1. Login to your WordPress admin dashboard. 2. Go to "Plugins." 3. Below the Artful.ly plugin, there should be an alert that says version 1.1 is available, click the "Upgrade" link there. 4. If you don't see an alert for the Artful.ly plugin, navigate to another page of your admin panel then go back to the Plugin page--that should force the alert to appear. Proceed with the upgrade. 5. After you upgrade the plugin to version 1.1, it will take WordPress approximately 10 minutes to clear it's cache and then anywhere you have Artful.ly short codes displayed should update accordingly.
![plugin](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=327 "plugin")
## Rate It! Help us spread the word about this plugin by rating it in the WordPress Plugin Directory. If you don't already have a WordPress.org account, you'll need to create one. Making one just takes a second, will give you access to additional WordPress support, and help you connect with other WordPress users. [Rate the plugin here](http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/artfully-widget/) and thanks!
How do I change the way my plugin looks?

*A little preemptive warning:* We aren't WordPress developers or designers. That's a different brand of geekdom. We have picked up a few tips that we'll share, but if you need helping building a site you need to hire someone who specializes in WordPress.
## First: Update Your Artful.ly Plugin! 1. For best performance, make sure you are running the latest version of the Artful.ly plugin. 2. Log in to your WordPress admin dashboard. 3. Select "Plugins" from the side menu. 4. Find "Artful.ly Widget." 5. If there is an update notice below that, click "update now." 6. This will update all the Artful.ly elements on your site, no need to update or change the individual short codes you've placed on your pages.
## Editing Plugin Appearance The Artful.ly plugin doesn't come with any set styles—it just picks up the style from the theme you have chosen for your WordPress site. To edit the appearance of Artful.ly plugin elements like the ticket headers, ticket selector, or donation field, you need to edit your WordPress theme.
Editing a WordPress theme is best left to an experienced WordPress designer. But, if you're the brave type and want to teach yourself, [check out these instructions from WordPress](http://en.support.wordpress.com/custom-design/editing-css/).
## How do I change the font size of the event name? 1. Select "Appearance" from the side menu. 2. Select "Editor." 3. Scroll to the bottom of all the style code. 4. Insert this snippet **#artfully-event h1 {font-size: 24px;}** 5. Change the number of the font size to whatever size you need—14px, 20px, 32px, etc. 6. Click "Update File." 7. Check the page where you have a short code for an event installed—the font size of the event name should reflect your styling changes.
## How do I make the bullets go away? Many WordPress themes insert bullets by the show dates like this...
![bullets.png](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=328 "bullets")
Often, you can make these bullets go away by making a little change to the theme's style sheet. Crack open the CSS editor, then add this code snippet:
`li.performance { background: none; }`
If that doesn't work you can try adding this to your custom CSS section or the main CSS file for your theme. `ul.performances > li { list-style: none !important; }`
`ul.ticket-types > li {list-style: none !important; }`
That should clear it up.
### Related Articles:
* [Installing & Using the WordPress Plugin](/site/knowledgebase/installing-using-the-wordpress-plugin)
Troubleshooting Widgets

To install any Artful.ly widget, **you must have a firm understanding of your site's markup language and the ability to add HTML, CSS, and JavaScript**. If you don't know HTML from a hat tree, we suggest you call your friendly website developer or use the automatically generated Artful.ly Storefronts to start selling tickets now.
Because the widget is code that you install on your site, sometimes adding this new element unearths other latent errors in the site's code. Unfortunately, we cannot help you debug other developers' programming, so it's best if you work with someone who knows and can access your whole site.
## Troubleshooting Tips: * **For donation widgets, do you have a donation kit activated?** You, or your organization administrator, can see what kits you have turned by clicking on your email users name, then selecting "Account Administration" from the dropdown. You need to either have the 501(c)(3) Donations Kit activated, or have connected your Artful.ly account to an active Fractured Atlas Fiscally Sponsored project. Connecting a project will automatically turn on the Sponsored Donation Kit.
* **For ticket widgets, do you have the Paid Event Ticketing Kit activated?** You, or your organization administrator, can see what kits you have turned by clicking on your email users name, then selecting "Account Administration" from the dropdown. The Paid Event Ticketing Kit will have a check next to it if it is activated.
* **For ticket widgets, make sure you have a PUBLISHED show.** Your ticketing widget may be properly installed, but if you don't have a show created and published for that event patrons will not be able to select tickets in the widget. * **Got a self-hosted WordPress site?** Use our WordPress plugin instead of the regular widget. It's faster, smoother, and easier to install. [Learn how here.](/site/knowledgebase/installing-using-the-wordpress-plugin) * **Got a WordPress.com site?** This commercial hosting service does not allow users to install JavaScript so widgets won't work. These sites also do not support plugins so the WordPress plugin won't work either. Use an Artful.ly Storefront to sell tickets instead or upgrade to a paid WordPress site to allow for plugin functionality. * **Check different browsers.** Are you seeing the same problem in Firefox, Safari, Chrome, and Internet Explorer? If the error is limited to one browser, you may have found a bug. Let us know via support@artful.ly. * **Is your browser up to date?** The most current version of an Internet browser will give you the best idea of your site's operation. Read about how to check what version your browser is and if it's up-to-date [here](http://www.webdevelopersnotes.com/how-do-i/check-browser-version.php). * **Did you paste in both the header script and the div script?** The widget is comprised of two chunks of code. You need to install the JavaScript bit in header of your page AND the display code where you want the actual ticket selector or donation field to appear. * **Is jQuery installed multiple times?** jQuery is needed to run the widget but if it is installed more than once on your site, it may cause a conflict. * **Check for code errors.** We like to open the problem page in a Chrome browser to look for errors. Do that, then right click on the page. Select 'Inspect element.' On the toolbar, select 'Console.' If there is an error with the page code, it will be indicated there. If the error includes the word "Artful.ly," please let us know. If the error mentions some other bit of code, your website developer can help you figure out what needs to be done to resolve the issue. * **Are you running the latest version of the widget code? **We are currently on version 3 of the widget. To see what version of the widget code you are running, look in the head tag for the phrase "artfully-v3".
Here's an example of **old widget code**. It just says "artfully.js"
![old widget code](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=329 "old widget code")
Here's an example of **current widget code**. It says "artfully-v3.js"
![current widget code](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=330 "current widget code")
**Still not working?**
* Use your Event Storefront to sell tickets * For 501(c)(3)s, use your Donation Storefront to take donations. * For Fractured Atlas Fiscally Sponsored projects, use your project page to take donations.

Name, billing address, valid expiration date, and csv code can be whatever you want.

Testing Your Widget

**You should test the Artful.ly widget on your site before you publicize your event and/or your fundraising efforts.** Testing allows you to confirm that everything is working smoothly on your site, and to get a feel for your patrons' purchase experience.
## How to Perform Test Transactions 1. Make a purchase with your credit card. 2. Wait 24 hours, then [refund](/site/knowledgebase/refund-exchange-return-tickets) the transaction (the card needs to be processed fully before a refund can be issued).
**You can only refund a transaction through Artful.ly before the money is settled.** After that, you'd have to cut yourself a check, which is a lot of hassle for a little testing! To test donations, you may as well give yourself a $.01 gift so that you don't have to worry about charging your card any real amount of money.
**Donations** are settled two business days from when the donation is made.
**Ticket sales** for each show, are settled two business days after that show or performance of an event.
## Demo Widgets: If you'd like to see how the widget works before you install it for real on your own website, we have installed Artful.ly widgets on these fake sites for you to explore. These two pages use the same event and same widget JavaScript and CSS from Artful.ly but the web site designer has styled them very differently so you can see the possibilities.
You can go through the whole checkout process in these widgets by using this dummy credit card number: 4111111111111111. Name, billing address, valid expiration date, and csv code can be whatever you want.
* [Demo 1](https://www.artful.ly/widget-demo-1) * [Demo 2](https://www.artful.ly/widget-demo-2)
Beta: Passes Overview & Activation

**Deciding Between Memberships and Passes?** Take a look at our article [Memberships v Passes](/site/knowledgebase/beta-membership-v-passes).
## Define "Passes" Passes are for selling a set of tickets to multiple events and shows. This is useful for events like festivals, season passes, concert or lecture series, or two-part shows. When a customer buys a pass, the patron receives a pass code that functions similar to a discount code for an event.
To apply the pass to tickets, the patron enters the code during checkout and the eligible tickets become $0.
![pass code entry](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=331 "pass code entry")
## Kit Activation The Passes Kit is currently only available to beta testers. If you would like to beta test these features please have your Organization Administrator email us at support@artful.ly and we will set up a time to go over the kit with you.
### Related Articles * [Memberships v. Passes](/site/knowledgebase/beta-membership-v-passes) * [Creating Passes](/site/knowledgebase/beta-creating-passes) * [How Patrons Buy Passes and Apply Pass Codes](/site/knowledgebase/beta-how-patrons-buy-passes-and-apply-pass-codes) * [Pass Fees and Settlements](/site/knowledgebase/beta-pass-fees-and-settlements)
Beta: Creating Passes

Creating Passes is a two-step process. First you create the pass, and then you select which shows are eligible.
## Add a New Pass 1. In the top menu bar click **Sell **and **Passes.**
![sell menu passes](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=332 "sell passes")
2. On your Passes overview page select **Add New Pass**. This will take you to the page where you add all of your pass details.
![add new pass type](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=333 "add new pass type")
## Basics 1. **Name**: The first thing you'll do is give your pass a name. This can be as simple as "Season Pass" or it can be unique to your organization. 2. **Description**: Here is where you'll tell potential passholders exactly what the pass entitles them to. 3. **Pass Start and End Date**: Next you'll define the date range for which the pass is valid. A passholder will be able to use his/her pass for shows within this time frame.
![pass basics](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=334 "pass basics")
## Pricing 1. **Number of Tickets**: How many tickets is the pass valid for? If you are running a show with multiple events, it's a good best practice to make this number equal to your number of events. 2. **Price**: How much the pass costs. 3. **Who Pays The Fee? **You have the option to pass the service fee on to the patron or roll it into the pass price. In both cases you, the producer, will pay the credit card processing fee. For more information, check out our article on [Pass Fees](/site/knowledgebase/beta-pass-fees-and-settlements) ![passes pricing options](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=335 "passes pricing options")
## Storefront Copy The messages a patron sees after purchasing a pass are customizable:
1. **Thanks Message**: This field lets you add custom text to the **Order** **Confirmation Thanks** page that appears after a customer purchases a pass. 2. **Email Message**:This field adds custom text to the **Pass Details Email**.
![pass storefront copy](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=336 "pass storefront copy")
## Sales 1. Sales Start and End 2. Show on Storefront: Checking this box makes the pass visible in your Passes Storefront; it's akin to publishing or unpublishing a show from the storefront. 3. Finally you'll click **Save** to finalize the pass so you can select which events and shows the pass applies to.
![pass sales start and end](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=337 "pass sales start and end")
## Related Articles * [Making Shows Pass-Eligible](/site/knowledgebase/beta-making-shows-pass-eligible)
Beta: Making Shows Pass-Eligible

In order for patrons to use their pass on an event, the event must be made eligible for passes to be used. As the producer, you define how the pass may be used.
## Adding Pass Eligibility 1. Open an **Event** you would like to make eligible for passholders. 2. Select **Share &Sell** and **Passes**. This will prompt you to add a pass to this event.
![share and sell passes](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=338 "share and sell passes")
3. Select a **Pass Type** you want to apply to the event.
4. Decide whether or not the pass is active immediately or not. If the box is left unchecked, you'll have to navigate back and check the box when you would like patrons to use pass codes for that event.
5. **Ticket Limit per Pass**: This is the number of tickets the pass may be used for in one transaction. In most cases, you'll probably want this to be one, but you can change the limit based on your pass business rules.
6. **Allowed Ticket Types**: This menu lets you select which ticket types the pass is eligible for. For example, if you have a more expensive VIP ticket type and a VIP Pass, you could make the VIP Pass eligible for the VIP ticket type.
7. **Excluded Shows**: You also have the option to exclude individual shows for the event in case you have special performances that you do not want to allow passes for.
8. Finally, **Save** the changes.
![add a pass details](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=339 "add a pass details")
## Adding Multiple Passes to an Event
To add additional passes to an event:
1. Navigate back to **Share & Sell** and **Passes**. 2. Click the **Add** button.
![add additional passes](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=340)
### Related Articles - [Creating Shows](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/creating-shows-) - [How Patrons Buy and Apply Passcodes](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/beta-how-patrons-buy-passes-apply-pass-codes)
Beta: How Patrons Buy Passes & Apply Pass Codes

With the Passes Kit activated, your patrons can buy passes through the Passes Storefront. This page can be found at the top of your Artful.ly Storefront under the label **Buy Passes**.
1. Patrons purchase passes much in the same way they purchase tickets to a show. They'll simply click on the type of pass they'd like, select a quantity, and add it to their cart.
![pass storefront](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=342)
2. Upon checkout, the patron receives an email with their pass code, and a link to start using the pass right away.
![bette smith confirmation](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=343 "pass confirmation")
3. The patron then adds tickets to the cart and applies the pass code like a discount code, which makes the ticket price zero dollars.
![pass code entry](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=344 "pass code entry")
### Related Articles * [Retrieve a Patron's Passcode](/site/knowledgebase/beta-retrieve-a-patron-s-passcode) * [Configure Your Passes Storefront](/site/knowledgebase/beta-configure-your-passes-storefront)
Beta: Change Membership Expiration

To change the expiration date of a membership:
1. Open the patron's record. 2. Click on either the **membership badge icon** or the **member tag** to open the patron's membership details view. 3. Use the check boxes to select which membership/s you want to edit.
![Work With Change Expiration](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=346 "Work With Change Expiration") 4. Select **Work With** and **Change Expiration**.
![Work With Change Expiration](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=347 "Work With Change Expiration") 5. Choose the new expiration date on the calendar.
![Change Expiration on Calendar](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=345 "Change Expiration on Calendar") 6. Click **Change Expiration** button.
Beta: Reset Member Passwords

We get it. People have a lot of passwords and it's easy to lose track of them. Luckily it's easy to send a password reset link to your members.
1. Navigate to that member's People Record and click either the **Membership ID, Member Tag,** or the **Work With** button. Each will take you to the Member History page.
![Member History Pathways](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=350 "Member History Pathways")
2. On the Member History page, click on the red **Reset Password** button. An email with a temporary password will be sent to the person. Keep in mind the temporary password will eventually expire, so it's best to send one when you have a member on the phone with you, or when you know they will be checking their email soon. Sending a follow up email after sending a temporary password is also a good idea.
![Reset Password Button](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=348 "Reset Password Button")
**Members can reset their own passwords at: [https://www.artful.ly/members/password/new](https://www.artful.ly/members/password/new)**
## Resetting Member Passwords When Emails are Incorrect
When resetting your member's password, it's a good idea to check to see if the member's email address is spelled correctly. Sometimes patrons make a typo when purchasing their memberships, which sets the member login to the misspelled email address. When this happens, if you try to reset the member's password, she'll never get the email.
Luckily there's an easy fix:
1. Open the Member's record. Click **Work With** and **Edit Info**.
![Member Record Work With](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=349 "Member Record Work With") 2. Correct the email address and click OK. 3. Click **Work With **again, select **View Memberships** and click the red Password Reset Button. 4. Click the **Reset Password** button and make sure the email address that appears in the blue bubble at the top of the page is spelled correctly.
![Password Email Sent Confirmation](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=351 "Password Email Sent Confirmation")
### Related Articles
* [What Happens If Patrons Mistype Their Email Addresses?](/site/knowledgebase/what-happens-if-patrons-mistype-their-email-addresses) * [How Patrons Buy Member Tickets](/site/knowledgebase/beta-how-members-buy-member-tickets) * [Sales Console For Memberships](/site/knowledgebase/sales-console-for-memberships)
Beta: Sales Console for Passes

If this is your first time using the sales console, we recommend beginning by reading this article: [Sales Console: a Private Sales Channel for Complex Orders](/site/knowledgebase/sales-console-a-private-sales-channel-for-complex-orders).
## Sales Console Fees Structure * **Memberships and Passes** sold via credit card are charged the 5% service fee plus the 3.5% credit card processing fee. The 5% service fee will be added to the order total if you designated that when setting up the membership or pass type.
* BETA USERS: We are not charging the 5% service charge for sales via Sale Console during the beta period._
## Selling Passes Through the Sales Console 1. Navigate to the Sales Console through either the **Sell** menu or the **Sell to** option on a people record if the patron is already in your Artful.ly CRM.
2. Click on the **Passes** tile and select which pass the patron wants to purchase.
3. Click the green **Check Out** tile to sell the pass.
## Use a Pass Code Through the Sales Console
1. Open the passholder's **People Record**. 2. Click on the **Passholder** tag. This will take you to the patron's **Pass History**.
![click on the Passholder Tag to get to pass history](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=360 "passholder tag")
3. Select **View Passcodes **and copy the pass code.
![view passcodes](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=361 "view passcode") 4. Click **View Record** to return to the people record.
![view record takes you back to the patron record](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=364 "view record") 5. Click **Work With** and select **Sell To** to be taken to the sales console.
![sell to is found under the work with button](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=362 "sell to") 6. Add the desired tickets to the cart and use the **Apply Pass or Discount Code** to apply the pass that you copied from their record. The code will redeem and zero out the ticket cost.
![pass codes can be applied in the sales console](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=363 "pass codes can be applied in the sales console")
7. Select the green **Check Out **tile to confirm the patron's order.
## Related Articles:
* [Sales Console: a Private Sales Channel for Complex Orders](https://artfully.zendesk.com/entries/53290425-Sales-Console-a-Private-Sales-Channel-for-Complex-Orders) * [Sales Channels](https://artfully.zendesk.com/entries/78854357-Sales-Channels) * [Sales Console for Memberships](https://artfully.zendesk.com/entries/53292325-Sales-Console-for-Memberships)
Beta: Refunding Passes

Passes may be refunded up to two full business days after a pass is purchased. This window gives organizations the opportunity to perform refunds, if they allow them.
After two business days the funds are settled to the organization, and the organization then becomes responsible for issuing refunds via check or other payment process.
## Refunding a Pass
1. Navigate to **Orders** and **Search All** and click on the order you need to refund. 2. Check the box for the pass that needs to be refunded and click **Refund**.
![a pass being refunded from order details](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=826 "refunding from order details") 3. You'll be taken to a page to confirm that this is the order you want to refund. You have a choice to send an email to the patron confirming the refund. In most cases you'll want to leave the box checked so the patron has a receipt for the return.
![pass refund confirmation](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=827 "pass refund confirmation")
###Related Articles - [Refund, Exchange, and Return Tickets](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/refund-exchange-return-tickets)
Beta: See Individual's Pass Usage & Make Edits

When looking at a passholder's patron record, you may want to see how many passes that patron has purchased over the years, and how the pass translated to event attendance.
## Navigating to Pass History You can surface this information in what we call the **Pass History** page. You can get to it by clicking on the **Passholder** tag or the **Work With** button on the patron's record.
![pass history pathways](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=368 "pass history")
## Reading Patron Pass History When viewing your patron's pass history you can see:
* The types of passes a patron has purchased * The purchase date * Start and end dates * Number of tickets in the pass * How many of those tickets have been purchased with the pass
By clicking on a checkbox next to a pass, use the **Work With** button to:
* Change the pass expiration date * Send the patron an email reminder containing her pass code
![pass history detail](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=369 "pass history detail")
### Related Articles - [Pass Usage Report](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/pass-usage-report)
Beta: Retrieve a Patron's Passcode

Sometimes a patron might lose a pass code and need your help retrieving it.
## To Retreive a Patron's Passcode 1. Search for the individual's **People Record**. 2. Click on the **Passholder** tag. This will take you to the patron's **Pass History**.
![passholder tag](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=370 "passholder tag")
3. Select **View Passcodes** and retrieve the code from the record.
![view passcodes](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=371 "view passcodes") 4. You can then resend the patron's pass code in an email, or you can use this in conjunction with **Work With** button and **Sell To** to sell a patron a ticket through the **Sales Console**.
### Related Articles: - [Sales Console](/site/knowledgebase/beta-sales-console-for-passes) - [See Individual Patron Pass Usage & Edit Individual Patron's Passes](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/see-individual-patron-pass-usage-edit-individual-patron-s-passes)
Beta: Configure Your Passes Storefront

Once you activate your Passes Kit, you should customize the language and images that appear on your Passes Storefront. This public page is where you can talk about your passes and make a sales pitch for why your fans should become passholders.
1. Go to your **Account Administration** page.
2. On your Passes Kit, click **Configure**.
![Configure Passes link](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=376 "configure passes storefront link")
3. Here you can add text and use the rich formatting tools to adjust text size, add emphasis, and even choose to show or hide the Passes Storefront. The
![storefront marketing copy text fields](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=679 "storefront text fields")
4. As you make changes to the marketing material in each text box, it's useful to have another window with your **Passes Storefront** open so you can see the results of your edits. As you save changes from configuring the storefront, you can refresh the view of the storefront to see the results. Here's an example of the Passes Storefront developing...
![passes storefront example](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=378 "example passes storefront")
### Related Articles * [How Patrons Buy Passes and Apply Pass Codes](/site/knowledgebase/beta-how-patrons-buy-passes-and-apply-pass-codes)
Beta: Pass Fees & Settlements

When creating a new pass, the producer decides who pays the 5% service charge by selecting one of two options under **Who Pays The Fee?**
**Patron Pays**: Here the patron pays the 5% charge as a service fee added at checkout. With this option, the revenue is greater for your organization.
**Producer Pays**: Here the 5% service fee is deducted from the price of the pass before we send you the money for the sale. With this option the patron sees a nice round amount, but your revenue is lower. Of course, you can also choose this option and increase the price of the pass to cover the fee.
| | **When Producer Pays Fee** | **When Patron Pays Fee** | |-------------------|---------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------| | Patron Pays | $50 flat | $50 +5% service fee= **$52.50** | | Producer Receives | $50-5% service fee= 47.45 -3.5% credit card fee= **$45.79** | $50-3.5% credit card fee= **$48.25**|
## Passes Settlements Settlements for pass revenue initiate two days after a pass is purchased.
## Passes Refunds Refunds can be processed within Artful.ly during the two day period before the funds are settled. Once the settlement is has been deposited into your bank account, any refunds are at your discretion and must be sent outside the Artful.ly system eg. via check.
### Related Articles - [Settlement Reports](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/settlement-reports)
Beta: Pass Usage Report

It's possible to see the pass usage for individual patrons in their pass histories, but sometimes you'll want a higher-level view of the pass usage for your whole patron base. We call it the Pass Usage report. To find it, navigate to **Reports** in the top menu bar and select **Pass Usage.** A copy of your pass report can also be downloaded as a CSV.
![pass usage](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=379 "pass usage")
On this page you can search by pass type and order date range to find when tickets are being claimed through your passes. In the report, you'll find an at-a-glance view of:
* The number of passes sold * The number of tickets sold from passes * How many tickets remain on those passes
Using the drop down menu, you can find information on a specific type of pass, and/or a specific date range.
**Within each row you'll be able to find**:
* Which pass type was used * Order number and date * Passholder name * Event name * Number of tickets in the order * Original ticket price * Gross sales
![individual pass usage](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=380 "individual pass usage")
In the bottom portion of the report, you'll find more information about the individual orders where passes were used. Usually you'll be looking at the usage report for multiple patrons, but for the above example, it's easiest if we look at one usage for one patron's orders. In the example, we can see Leslie has purchased one pass valid for six tickets. She has used the pass to purchase four tickets over two orders, and there are now two tickets left on her pass.
### Related Articles
* [See Individual Patron Pass Usgae & Edit Individual Patron's Passes](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/see-individual-patron-pass-usage-edit-individual-patron-s-passes) * [Sales Console for Passes](/site/knowledgebase/beta-sales-console-for-passes)
Beta: Printing Membership Cards

Once you have sold some memberships, you may want to print membership cards to distribute to your members. Here's how:
1. From top menu, select **Orders**, then**Memberships.**
![Membership Orders Menu](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=354 "Membership Orders Menu")
2. Choose a date range of membership orders.
![Membership Orders Date Range](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=353 "Membership Orders Date Range")
3. Choose a membership type or all types and click **Search**.
![Select Membership Type From Menu](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=355 "Select Membership Type From Menu")
4. Click **Work With** and select **Print Member Cards_;_** this will generate a PDF.
![Work With Menu to Print Member Cards](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=352 "Work With Menu to Print Member Cards")
**We suggest performing a small test print to make sure your printer aligns the PDF with the card perforations**. In our tests, it seemed to work best when we did not use the "scale to fit" setting on the printer.
Membership cards are formatted to print 3.375 x 2.125". This is the size of a standard credit card. We've formatted bulk card printing to work with [Blanks USA Synthetic Cards](http://www.blanksusa.com/products/integrated-cards/synthetic-cards "Blanks USA Synthetic Cards") which available in packs of 60, 300, or 600, and are also available from Staples and other office supply stores. These synthetic cards are durable, tear-resistant, and compatible with laser and ink jet printers.
You can print one side with your company logo or design using templates available on Blank USA's website, then print the reverse side with the member information and QR code generated by Artful.ly.
As an alternative, you can print on standard card stock and then cut the cards afterward.
Beta: Scanning Membership Cards

## Membership Cards When patrons buy a membership, they are also sent a membership card as an email attachment. If a member brings a membership card to a show, the card may be scanned by the [Artful.ly iOS app](/site/knowledgebase/the-artful-ly-app-scan-tickets-with-your-iphone-or-ipod-touch). When the card is scanned one of three things will happen: 1. If the member has purchased a ticket to the show, the app can scan the membership card and check in the patron. 2. If the member has not purchased a ticket to the show, but member ticket types are **$0 tickets**, then the app will sell the member a free ticket and check in the patron. 3. If the patron does not have a ticket, but presents the card to an event where tickets are paid, then the app will give an error message. Organizations that use member cards may want to add language referencing the card in the email customization fields when setting up a membership type. ### Related Articles - [Printing Membership Cards](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/beta-printing-membership-cards) - [How Members Buy Member Tickets](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/beta-how-members-buy-member-tickets)
Beta: Membership Fees & Settlements

## Membership Fees
Selling a membership through Artful.ly has a 5% service fee plus a 3.5% credit card processing fee. These fees apply whether the patron purchases the tickets through your Member Storefront or the Sales Console. There are no fees for memberships paid via cash, check, or comp.
As a producer, you have the option to have the patron pay the service fee on top of the membership price, or you can pay the service fee out of your sales revenue.
Let's consider an example with a $50 membership:
![Membership Fee Structure, When producer pays the fee and when the patron pays the fee](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=381 "Membership Fee Structure")
## Membership Settlements
Settlements for membership revenue initiate two days after a membership is purchased.
## Membership Refunds
Refunds can be processed within Artful.ly during the two day period before the funds are settled. Once the settlement is issued, any refunds are at your discretion and need to be send outside the Artful.ly system eg. via check.
## Fees on Member Tickets
The $2 service fee applies to paid member ticket types. If the member ticket is $0, there is no additional service fee.
## Related Articles
* [Membership Reporting](/site/knowledgebase/beta-membership-reporting)
Beta: Importing Past Memberships

It's possible to import your historical membership history. The import process is similar to bringing in your ticket or donation history.
1. Go to **Reports** in the top menu bar and select **Imports/Exports**. 2. Select **Import Memberships**.
![Import Memberships Button](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=382 "Import Memberships Button")
3. Download the Artful.ly membership import template CSV.
![Download CSV Template Link](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=384 "Download CSV Template")
## Building Your CSV
As you begin to copy your content into the CSV template, keep in mind that email addresses are required for every membership you import or sell. Because an email address is required, the following fields are optional, but highly encouraged:
* First names * Last names * Company names
The rest of the required columns correspond to the fields required to create a membership type to sell in your storefront:
* **Membership Name -** However you refer to your membership.This is unique to each membership type you create.
* **Membership Type -** This will be either **Seasonal** or **Rolling**. Seasonal memberships have a fixed start and end date, and membership drives typically happen over a specific portion of the year. Rolling memberships are valid for a certain amount of months or years beginning from when the membership is purchased.
* **Start Date** - Required for both seasonal and rolling memberships. The date the membership begins for patrons. Dates must be in one of the following formats: if you're using Excel, the format should be **DD-MMM-YY HH:MMpm**. If you're editing the file in another program, it's a good rule-of-thumb to format the date as **YYYY/MM/DD HH:MMpm**. Specific order times are optional.
* **End Date -** Only for seasonal memberships.The date the membership ends.
* **Duration** - Rolling Memberships only. This will be a number that corresponds to what you define in the period column. For example, if you have a 6 month membership you would put "6" in the duration column, and "months" in the period column.
* **Period** - Rolling Memberships only. This is how you measure how long a rolling membership is—either in **months** or **years**.
* **Price Paid** - How much does your membership cost? Make sure you just put dollars and cents with no "$" or other symbols.
* **Payment Method **- You can enter Cash, Credit Card, Check, Comp, Other, or Unknown.
## Other Optional Fields
* **Order Date - **This is optional. The order date must be in one of the following formats. If you're using Excel, format your dates as **DD-MMM-YY HH:MMpm.** If you're editing the file in another program, it's a good rule-of-thumb to format the date as **YYYY/MM/DD HH:MMpm**. The time of the order is optional.
* ****Every Other Field -**** Any other column header that works on people imports can be done with a membership import, like Twitter handles, tags, and birthdays.
## Uploading Your CSV
1. Once you have your CSV filled out with all of the content double-checked, select **Choose File** and **Import **to begin the process.
![Upload Import File](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=386 "Upload Import File") 2. Once you upload the file, you'll be taken to a page to review the membership types you're importing. New membership types will be in the box in the upper portion of the page, and if you're importing memberships to an existing membership type, those will appear below the new membership types.
![Membership Import Data Review](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=383 "Membership Import Data Review") 3. To approve the membership import, you'll first need to preview the data for any existing or previous memberships you have. Once you've previewed the content and double-checked to make sure it's correct, you'll then be able to approve the import as the last step.
** Note: Membership imports cannot be recalled once you have approved them.**
## **Related Articles**
* [Importing People](/site/knowledgebase/importing-people) * [Importing Events](/site/knowledgebase/importing-events) * [Importing Donations](/site/knowledgebase/importing-donations) * [Imports Demystified](/site/knowledgebase/imports-demystified)
Beta: Membership Lists & Searching for Members

Once you've sold some memberships, you'll want a way to report on them. There are several ways to track your memberships.
## Advanced Search Filters
Turning on the Membership Kit gives you and new set of criteria to use in Advanced Search.
* **Starts**: Searches for memberships that begin within a specific date range. * **Ends**: Searches for memberships ending within a specific date range. * **Status**: Finds members who are Current, Lapsed, Past, or Non-Members. ![The membership status search condition in Advanced Search](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=776 "membership status search")
* Current members have valid memberships as of the date of the search. * Lapsed members are members whose memberships have expired within the past year. * Past members have not had a valid membership in the past year but they had one more than a year ago. * Non-Members are people who have never been members of your organization.
* **Type**: Finds people with a specific membership type. ![Advanced Search for Membership Criteria](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=777 "Membership Advanced Search")
## Searching for Membership Types
Membership type is an available condition in Advanced Search. You can search for all membership types or for specific ones. ![Membership Type Search](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=777 "Membership Type Search")
## Membership Sales Stats
In the **Sell** menu under **Memberships** you can see an at-a-glance view of how many of each membership type you have sold. Typically, the number of Memberships Sold will equal the number of members, unless members are allowed to purchase more than one membership per person.
![Membership Sales Stats](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=388 "Membership Sales Stats")
## Membership Sales by Order
Under **Orders**, and **Membership **you'll find a list of membership sales. Here you can search by the date of sale as well as the membership type. You can also export your membership orders reports as CSVs.
![Membership Orders List by Date Range](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=387 "Membership Orders List")
### Related Articles - [Advanced Search and List Segments](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/advanced-search-list-segments)
Are there certain reasons I could not apply for a grant?

In certain situations, our projects may not be able to apply for a grant. Below are some of the reasons why a project would not be allowed to apply for a grant with Fractured Atlas as their fiscal sponsor:
- A particular funder does not accept fiscally sponsored applications (like the National Endowment for the Arts) - Fractured Atlas may be applying to a particular funder for our own programming (although it is rare that our applications conflict with our projects' since we operate very different programs) - A funder may only accept one application per organization and your application would prevent other projects from applying (we usually don't allow our projects to apply to sources that restrict the number of applications) - A foundation is simply out of the realistic scope of an emerging artist/organization and it would be inappropriate for Fractured Atlas to allow that application to be submitted - A project has not met the [Fractured Atlas grant eligibility requirement](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/grant-eligibility-requirement) - A project does not meet the required guidelines that a funder publishes
In all cases, we strive to be as helpful and as accommodating as possible regarding grant applications and we aim to work with projects to apply to as many funding sources as possible.
Are there any eligibility requirements to become a member?

Nope! We only ask that you care about the arts, as we are an arts and technology organization. It really wouldn't make sense for those outside of the arts to use our programs, as they're all geared toward artists. That being said, this doesn't mean that you have to be a full-time artist. You might just enjoy painting or acting in your spare time. It doesn't matter to us! We're not going to check your qualifications.
How do I sign up?

Click the [Join Today](/site/join/) tab at the top of our website and choose Sign Up For Membership. You will need to provide your email address and other contact information. You will also be prompted to create a username and password for your account. If you are signing up for a paid membership, billing information is required.
Once you sign up online, you'll be able to immediately log in to the website and begin using our services.
Applying for Grants: How does it work?

All grant proposals and LOIs **must be reviewed by a Fractured Atlas staff member prior to submission** to the funder. Before we can issue any materials, we’ll first need to review and approve your application materials. **We require 10 business days to review all grant materials.**
Once you have identified an appropriate source, you should email the following documents and information to begin the application process on our end:
- The application deadline, full contact information for the funding source, and link to the funding source website (if available) - Any and all application forms & cover letters (or the LOI) - The completed narrative sections & projected budgets - A list of any and all required supplemental documents (Board of Directors, Audited Financials, etc.) - Your “ask” amount along with the funding source’s average or typical grant amount
We need to keep this information on file since we are legally the applicant of record and must be available to answer any questions if contacted by the funder about your proposal.
Once we have reviewed everything and you have made any necessary changes, we will send the documents required from Fractured Atlas in order to complete the application as a PDF. These materials could include any or all of the following:
- Endorsement letter – this certifies that you are fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas and provides our contact information in case the funder needs to get in touch with our staff for any reason. - IRS Letter of Determination – this is what certifies Fractured Atlas as a tax exempt, charitable organization and is typically required for grant applications. - Audited Financial Statement - Form 990 - Board of Directors - Organization Budget
Related Articles
- [Grant Eligibility Requirement](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/grant-eligibility-requirement) - [Is there specific text that I need to include in my proposals?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/is-there-specific-text-that-i-need-to-include-in-my-proposals)
When can I start soliciting donations?

Fiscally sponsored projects are not permitted to begin soliciting or accepting donations through Fractured Atlas until the date that the Board of Directors approves their application to the program. We will not be able to issue tax receipts for any donations a project solicits or receives before approval by our Board.
For any donations solicited or received prior to the Board's approval, the project should accept them directly and Fractured Atlas will not be able to issue tax receipt to these donors. Fiscal sponsorship applicants are not permitted to use Fractured Atlas's name when soliciting contributions prior to approval by our Board.
Related Articles:
- [How long does it take to get fiscal sponsorship?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/how-long-does-it-take-to-get-fiscal-sponsorship) - [How do I know if a donation is eligible for a tax receipt?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-know-if-a-donation-is-eligible-for-a-tax-receipt)
I was told I get free membership through another organization.

That's great, you must be a member of one of our many [Open Arts Network Partners](/site/oan/). Please contact the other organization for a special sign-up link. Using the website link provided to you, you can sign up for and receive one free year of Professional membership and then a 50% discounted membership dues rate after the free year is up. If you have a problem retrieving this information, please [contact](/site/helpdesk) our office.
What is an EIN and do I need one to apply for sponsorship?

An EIN stands for employer identification number. EINs are issued by the IRS as a way to track the income related to business activities. It is like a social security number for a business rather than an individual. An EIN is not required to apply for fiscal sponsorship. If you plan to incorporate your business, you may want to consider getting an EIN since that is the first step toward forming a company. Getting an EIN is not enough to open a business bank account as was once the case. Before you get one, we suggest you contact an attorney or an accountant.
Can I change my project name after I get sponsored?

If your board-approved activities stay the same, we can absolutely change the name of your fiscal sponsorship. Please contact us with your new fiscal sponsorship title and we’ll ask you to confirm in writing that the approved activities will remain the same.
I'm not a member. Can I use any of Fractured Atlas's services?

You can browse the copious amounts of information about our programs and services on our website, but you cannot use our services without becoming a member. We offer a free basic level of membership (Community Membership), which allows you access to a select portion of our programs and services, including Artful.ly, SpaceFinder, special offers and discounts from a myriad of industry professionals and vendors, the calendar of member news and events, and connection to Fractured Atlas through various social networks and the Fractured Atlas blog.
Can I change the legal entity responsible for the fund?

Yes, we can change the legal entity associated with your fiscal sponsorship. Please [email](/site/helpdesk) us the name of the new entity along with the tax ID and the name of the legal signatory for the entity. We’ll put together an amendment to our grant agreement which the legal signatories for the new and former entities will sign before we can change the entity we have on file.
How do I know I am a member of Fractured Atlas?

Once you successfully sign up for membership with us, you will be sent a Welcome to Fractured Atlas! email. If you do not receive this message from us shortly after you sign up, please check any spam or junk folders for the email. If you still do not see the welcome message, please contact our office.
Can I have multiple projects fiscally sponsored?

Each Fractured Atlas membership can only have one fiscal sponsorship. If you’d like fiscal sponsorship for more than one project, you’ll need to submit an application for all of your artistic activities or you’ll need to have more than one Fractured Atlas membership, each with its own fiscal sponsorship.
Will I receive fiscal sponsorship and insurance once I'm a member?

Once you become a paid member, you will have immediate access to the fiscal sponsorship application and insurance quote applications. Please consult the Program and Services menu, for more information on our Fiscal Sponsorship and Insurance programs. Signing up for membership does not automatically grant you fiscal sponsorship or insurance.
I am a Professional member and want insurance for my company.

If you work with, or are a part of, a company/organization that needs insurance, you can feel free to register as a Professional Member and apply on the company's behalf. You do not need to upgrade to an Organizational Membership unless multiple people from your group need to administer the insurance and/or your Fractured Atlas membership. If someone else besides yourself will be contacting Fractured Atlas in regards to the insurance, then you will need to upgrade to an Organizational Membership and add that person as a user. This is done for your security and safety -- you don't want us giving out your insurance information to someone not associated with your membership!
Can I have your employee identification number (EIN)?

A Fractured Atlas staff member can authorize use of Fractured Atlas’s EIN on a case by case basis. These instances include, but are not limited to:
- Applying for a grant - Soliciting non-cash donations - Soliciting monetary donations
**What if my situation does not fall into one of the above categories?**
Please contact us if your individual situation does not fall into one of the above categories. We’ll work with you to figure out whether or not it is appropriate to use our EIN for your specific situation.
**How do I obtain permission to use your EIN?**
Please contact us to seek permission to use our EIN. Remember, our EIN is kind of like our Social Security Number, so we’ll need to know:
- Who is asking for it? What is his/her/the business’s address? - Why is it needed/how will it be used? - Is there an application involved? - Is there a contract involved? - When is it needed?
We’ll issue a letter containing our EIN unless there is a different format required. This business-style letter will be emailed to you as a PDF which you can then pass along to the person/entity requesting it.
**How long will it take for you to send Fractured Atlas’s EIN?**
It really depends on the situation. It could take us 1 business day if it is for a simple donation that does not require an application or anything else, or it could take us 10 business days if it is for a grant in which case we’ll need to review and approve the grant application. In all cases, please let us know when you need the EIN and we’ll try to email it to you by that date. Please do leave a few days for back and forth in case any questions arise about your situation.
**Note:** The Fractured Atlas staff reserves the right to deny permission for use of Fractured Atlas’s EIN. Using Fractured Atlas’s EIN in any situation without written permission for that situation is a prohibited activity of our program and is grounds for termination of your fiscal sponsorship.
Why would my application be denied?

An application for fiscal sponsorship will be denied if it does not fall within one of our three major criteria for approval. Specifically, the project will be denied if its artistic component is not clearly defined, if it does not provide a public benefit, or it seems to be commercial in nature or for personal gain. Our staff will be in touch before the applications go to our board if we have any concerns regarding your application. If you fail to address these concerns in the time allowed, your application may be denied, but we will usually offer the chance to apply again the following month.
Related Articles: - [What percentage of fiscal sponsorship applications do you approve?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/what-percentage-of-fiscal-sponsorship-applications-do-you-approve) - [Can an international artist apply for fiscal sponsorship?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/can-an-international-artist-apply-for-fiscal-sponsorship) - [What is the difference between a non-profit and a for-profit project?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/what-is-the-difference-between-a-non-profit-and-a-for-profit-project)
I live outside of New York City. Can I use your services?

Of course! We're a national organization for artists across the country. Naturally, many of our members reside in and around New York City, but we have hundreds of members in all 50 states (and in foreign countries!). We pride ourselves on the fact that all of our services can be used by artists nationwide. Now and then, we will pilot/test a program in a specific city or area with the hope of expanding it nationwide should it prove to be effective. If you ever notice us testing a program and would like more information or would like us to bring it to your own area, feel free to [contact us](/site/helpdesk) about it!
How do I file a tax return for the money you disbursed to me?

The way you file a tax return for the funds released to you depends on a lot of factors, including the type of legal entity responsible for the funds. We strongly suggest that you work with [an accountant or a tax professional](/site/fiscal/page/accounting_resources) to file your taxes and to address any concerns you have about your tax responsibilities.
I live outside of the United States. Can I use your services?

You are more than welcome to join -- we definitely have a number of members residing outside the U.S. However, we can't guarantee that you'll be able to use all of our services (insurance and fiscal sponsorship, for example, which may require U.S. tax ID numbers and/or U.S. addresses). We definitely do encourage you to be a part of a [very large](/site/about/membership) artist community. And there are certainly services that you may find useful!
How long does it take to get fiscal sponsorship?

Applications are accepted on an ongoing basis and the monthly deadline is the last day of each month at 11:59pm Eastern Time. Our Board reviews applications at the beginning of the following month and we issue approvals no later than the 15th of the following month. For example, if you submit your application in January, it will be reviewed at the beginning of February and you’ll be notified of approval by February 15th.
Related Articles: - [Why would my application be denied?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/why-would-my-application-be-denied) - [How long does my fiscal sponsorship stay active?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/how-long-does-my-fiscal-sponsorship-stay-active)
What do you mean by a "legal entity" associated with the fund?

Our fiscal sponsorship program is structured as a grantor-grantee relationship. This means that all funds that are released from Fractured Atlas for the purposes of the project are considered a grant. The grantor is Fractured Atlas and the grantee is the legal entity of the project. The IRS requires that a grantee reports all grant income on their taxes. This means that all funds released through our fiscal sponsorship program are considered taxable income according to the IRS. The legal entity is the individual or business entity responsible for reporting the income we disburse to the IRS.
What if the grant application is online?

**The bad news:** Online applications often create problems for sponsored applicants for two reasons: there is no way to distinguish the project from the sponsor and many systems only allow one application per organization. Since Fractured Atlas’s program aims to be as inclusive as possible, we cannot allow one project to apply at the expense of the other artists we serve.
**The good news:** There are a few funders who have built their online applications to accept multiple applications for sponsored projects under the primary account for the sponsoring organization. In cases like this, you are certainly allowed to apply using Fractured Atlas as your fiscal sponsor.
Many online applications (especially for corporate funders) require a tax ID in order to access the application. This means that Fractured Atlas staff must set up the account for you. In some cases, we may have to complete the application for you, and will send you your portion of the application to complete. Most of these applications can be handled within the one hour time allotment, but please note that there may be fees for applications that take more than one hour of cumulative staff time.
What if the grant does not require a fiscal sponsor?

We’ll only need to be included in the grant application process if the grant requires 501(c)3 status or a fiscal sponsor. If they award grants to non-501(c)3s, then you’re welcome to apply directly. In these cases, you should not mention Fractured Atlas in the application and grant payments should be made payable to you or your company directly. You’ll then manage these funds outside of your fiscal sponsorship.
Does Fractured Atlas help me raise money for my work?

Through fiscal sponsorship, Fractured Atlas extends many of the benefits of our 501(c)(3) status to artists and arts organizations. You can apply for sponsorship for your work, or "project," and if approved by our Board of Directors, you will be able to solicit tax-deductible donations from individuals, corporate sponsors, and grantmakers, all of which would be otherwise available only to nonprofits.
It is the responsibility of each fiscally sponsored project to raise its own money. We do, however, provide educational resources to our projects to aid them in their fundraising efforts. We offer fundraising templates to use in outreach efforts, and our staff is always available to answer your questions. Our fiscal sponsorship team also presents webinars covering topics related to fundraising and we offer a free one-hour consultation on fundraising to our projects each year.
For active fiscally sponsored projects, you can access our fundraising templates on your My Fiscal Sponsorship page on our site.
![enter image description here](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=590 "enter image title here")
Related Articles:
- [Will you raise money for me?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/will-you-raise-money-for-me) - [Will you provide me with a list of donors?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/will-you-provide-me-with-a-list-of-donors) - [Will you provide me with a list of grant funders?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/will-you-provide-me-with-a-list-of-grant-funders)
What if I want to change my sponsored project?

If you want to become fiscally sponsored for a brand new project, we can “expire” your original fiscal sponsorship which would allow you to submit an application for the new project on our website. If you’re seeking to become fiscally sponsored for expanded or edited activities related to your original project, we’ll have you submit an “expansion” application to be reviewed by our Board of Directors.
In order to do this, our fiscal sponsorship staff will need to set your current fiscal sponsorship status to “pending,” which will allow you access to your original application where you can make the necessary edits or additions. While your fiscal sponsorship is pending, you will not be able to release funds and we will not be able to process donations for the purposes of your fiscal sponsorship. Please [contact us](/site/helpdesk) in order to start this process.
When and how do I get my project's funds?

**We transfer funds to your bank account via electronic fund transfer (EFT).** Visit the My Fiscal Sponsorship page to set up electronic fund transfer.
![A screenshot of the My Fiscal Sponsorship page with an arrow to EFT sign up.](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=496 "My Fiscal Sponsorship Page Screenshot")
From there, you'll need to complete our [EFT Sign Up Form](/site/fiscal/EFT_Sign_Up.pdf) and you'll need to send us a voided check. Your bank account must be in the United States in order to receive electronic fund transfers from Fractured Atlas.
*Please also note that we cannot accept temporary or starter checks* and that the check must include your account and routing numbers as well as confirmation of the account holder name and address.
![Image showcasing starter checks with the "no" symbol](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=585 "No Starter Checks")
If you do not have a check to void, we'll require a bank-issued document complete with contact information instead. A copy of a checking statement with address and account number should suffice. We can accept a letter from the bank with the account number, routing number, account holder name, and address as well.
After you've sent your EFT information to Fractured Atlas and received confirmation from us that it's been set up, you can request funds from the [fund release request form.](/site/fiscal/fund_release) Request and releases can be made seven (7) days after the donations are received. Electronic fund releases take one (1) to three (3) business days to show up in your bank account once approved by Fractured Atlas.
Related Articles:
- [Why are the funds released taxable income for me?](/site/knowledgebase/why-are-the-funds-released-taxable-income-for-me) - [How long does it take to get money out of my fund?](/site/knowledgebase/how-long-does-it-take-to-get-money-out-of-my-fund) - [How long do I have to wait until my funds are available?](/site/knowledgebase/how-long-do-i-have-to-wait-until-my-funds-are-available) - [How do I file a tax return for the money you disbursed to me?](/site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-file-a-tax-return-for-the-money-you-disbursed-to-me)
What questions are in the fiscal sponsorship application?

Our application is fairly straightforward and asks the following questions:
1. Name of Legal Entity Responsible [What do you mean by *legal entity*?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/what-do-you-mean-by-a-legal-entity-associated-with-the-fund) 1. Type of Legal Entity Responsible (choose one): Individual/Sole Proprietorship, Informal Group with an EIN, Corporation, Limited Liability Company, General/Limited Partnership [Should I form an LLC or incorporate?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/should-i-form-an-llc-or-incorporate) 1. Social Security Number or Employee Identification Number for the Legal Entity [What is an Employee Identification Number?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/what-is-an-ein-and-do-i-need-one-to-apply-for-sponsorship) 1. Project Title 1. Project Discipline (Dance, Film/Video/Media, Music, Literary Arts, Theatre, Visual Arts) 1. Is the project Temporary or Ongoing? 1. Project Description (For temporary sponsorship you would describe a single project; for ongoing sponsorship give a general description of the kind of work you create, your mission statement, or various projects you plan to fund) 1. Describe the Public Benefit of the work that you do. (For what audience is your project intended?) 1. Online Profile Text (All sponsored projects are profiled on our website - this should be a general description of you as an artist or of your group. You will be able to update this section later at your discretion) 1. Project Website and Social Media Links (Facebook or Twitter) 1. Online Profile Image or Video 1. Summary of Artist Qualifications/Group History 1. Budget and Fundraising Goals [Need help with your budget?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/should-my-budget-be-projections-or-based-on-the-last-year) 1. Prospective Fundraising Sources (You can answer this question as broadly as you'd like.)
Related Articles: - [How long does it take to get fiscal sponsorship?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/how-long-does-it-take-to-get-fiscal-sponsorship) - [Why would my application be denied?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/why-would-my-application-be-denied) - [Should I apply for project or ongoing activities?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/should-i-apply-for-project-or-ongoing-activities)
What is included in my membership?

You can use any and all of our programs and services (which is basically everything on our website) with any paid membership. If you signed up for a free Community Membership, you will have access to [Artful.ly](/site/artfully), FracturedU, [SpaceFinder](/site/spacefinder), the [calendar of events](/site/events/), and [special offers](/site/specialoffers/). Please keep in mind that to use some services, you need to submit a separate application once you've signed up for membership.
If you sign up through an [Open Arts Network partner](/site/oan/), you will receive one free year of professional membership and a 50% discount thereafter.
Grant Eligibility Requirement

You must first raise $1,000 for your project from individual sources other than yourself and immediate family before you’ll be eligible to submit a letter of inquiry or a proposal to a funder. Earned revenue does not count towards this requirement.
We implemented this policy to protect the integrity of the fiscal sponsorship program and to maximize your chances of being funded when you do submit grant applications. It may seem unpleasant, but this rule exists for a couple of important reasons:
- Best practices dictate that you should wait to approach institutional funders until after you’ve established a base of individual support. - Funders have consistently told us that they don’t want to receive grant applications from projects that have no committed base of support for the activity.
Ultimately, by meeting the $1,000 eligibility requirement, you are improving your chances of being funded. Having committed funds on your project budget shows that you are experienced with handling funds, and that your project is already on its way to being successfully funded.
**What if I raised funds before I was fiscally sponsored?**
If you can provide proof that you have been awarded a grant or received donations within the last two years for the same project, you may be exempt from this requirement. Examples of proof include:
- Award letters from the funder - Donation award letters from your donors - Links to a previous crowdfunding campaign
Is there specific text that I need to include in my proposals?

As with individual solicitations, we aim to make letters of inquiry (LOIs) and grant application approvals as easy as possible by providing Standard Text to use in your LOIs and grant applications. You may include it in your cover letter or within the narrative at your discretion, but it needs to appear somewhere in your LOI or application. Here’s the text to use for Foundations, Corporations, and Government Agencies:
> “[PROJECT NAME] is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Fractured Atlas will receive grants for the charitable purposes of [PROJECT NAME], provide oversight to ensure that grant funds are used in accordance with grant agreements, and provide reports as required by the grantor. Contributions for the charitable purposes of [PROJECT NAME] must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax deductible to the extent permitted by law.”
How much time do you need to review my grant application?

Grant application materials (including LOIs) must be submitted for review at least 10 business days before the application deadline. This time allows our staff to prepare the documents you need and provides you with time to make any changes before the application is approved. We prefer to accept application materials via email, but fax is also acceptable. Please send these documents to support@fracturedatlas.org or fax to 212-277-8025.
Please keep in mind that if we do not receive the materials to review 10 business days before the application deadline, we do reserve the right to charge a $75 rush fee.
Are there any fees related to applying for grants?

There are generally no fees related to applying for grants if you plan ahead and manage your deadlines well. However, in some situations the following fees may apply:
- Rush fee: if you need a response in fewer than 10 business days, we must charge a $75 rush fee. Paying the rush fee guarantees a response within 1 business day. - Grant administration fee: We allocate each LOI and grant application with one hour of staff time to review it and provide what is needed for final submission. If more than one hour of a Fractured Atlas staff member’s time is required to help you submit a grant or administer the award and reports, we will need to charge you for the time required at a rate of $50/hr. You will be notified of this before we do anything in cases where it is applicable.
**Note:** Fractured Atlas reserves the right to deny the submission of LOIs or grant applications at any time. To protect the integrity of the program and to ensure that funders have a positive experience with Fractured Atlas projects, we try only to submit sponsored proposals that are appropriate and well presented.
