Share My Calendar Features and Benefits

**Share My Calendar is a free, smart, and easy way to promote your venues unbooked rental times.** ## This is how a published calendar looks: ![Calendar](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=423 "calendar")

Depending on calendar software (Google, Yahoo, Outlook, etc.) there are different steps to generating the iCalendar feeds used to upload to Share My Calendar, however the whole process only takes about 2-3 minutes and these are all the benefits you will reap:

## Attract new renters

Renters searching by availability are matched to your listing when your calendar shows space as available. This is a great way for new renters to discover your space.

## Promote last minute openings

Calendars uploaded to SpaceFinder refresh automatically once day. Many venues post last minute openings of availability on social media, pretty hit or miss in terms of effective marketing, Share My Calendar is a way to automatically connect with renters actively looking for space, including any last minute openings, on a daily basis. Once a day your update inventory is released into the SpaceFinder marketplace.

## Boost your ranking in search results

Listings with calendars provide renters the convenience of viewing availability and are therefore rewarded with a boost in search results.

## Display unbooked times, not booking details Renters only see colored blocks of time on your calendar as Available or Not Available. No details of your booking are displayed in the calendar. This makes it easy to maintain privacy around who else has booked your space, while also marketing your unbooked times. ## Combine more than one calendar

If you use multiple calendars to keep track of different types of activities in your space (i.e. classes, events, rehearsals) you can combine as many icalendar feeds as needed to reflect availability in a space.

## Say "sorry" less, and "yes" more By displaying availability you reduce time spend saying "sorry, I don't have space at that date and time", and increase your time spent saying "yes, that time is open for booking" to renters who are matched to you based on availability. ### Related Articles - [3 Steps to Uploading Your Calendar](/site/knowledgebase/3-steps-to-uploading-your-calendar) - [Google: Finding Your Calendar Feed](/site/knowledgebase/google-finding-your-calendar-feed-)

Resettling Funds in Artful.ly

When you receive notice that a user's settlement has failed...
**There is a $10.00 fee charged to the producer for us to resettle the funds.**
1. Verify the bank account information on file. If it matches the most recent EFT form and check that the user sent in, we'll need to request updated bank documents and deduct the $10.00 fee. 2. If the information we have on file is not correct and was entered incorrectly by an admin, then we do **not** need to deduct the fee.
**Follow up email to the producer should include:**
- Notification that we received notice from the bank saying that the settlements failed. - Request for updated EFT documents. (If applicable) - Explanation of $10.00 fee for resettlements. (If applicable) - Details for each settlement that was resettled. (Show, Show date, Total net amount settled)
**To initiate the resettlement:**
1. View the user's organization in Artful.ly Admin. 2. Hover over the failed settlement and select the "Resettle" button. 3. The system will ask whether or not you would like to deduct the $10.00 fee.
![Pop-up asking whether or not to charge fee to producer](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=557 "Pop-up asking whether or not to charge fee to producer")
4. Select **Create New Settlement**
Admin will confirm that the settlement has successfully been initiated.
![Settlement Success Confirmation Note on Screen](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=558 "Settlement Success Confirmation Note on Screen")
Once you have completed the settlements, the producer will be able to view it when they are logged into Artful.ly in the **Reports > Settlements** section.
![User view of resettled funds in Reports](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=559 "User view of resettled funds in Reports")
Troubleshooting Log In Problems

If you're receiving a call to troubleshoot logging in over the phone, try to find out what is happening first. Here are some things to look out for:
- Is the member receiving any sort of error message? If there is an incorrect email/password error, check for any multiple member records. Do you see multiple email addresses for different accounts? If the member is resetting the password on their own, the temporary password might be going to the correct email address, but for a different account. If the member does not want to change the email address on file for the account OR if they have only one account with us, feel free to reset the password for the specific account they're trying to log in to. Remind the member to log in using their username instead of email address. If the member says they don't require the other accounts (e.g. they have multiple older Community memberships), you can offer to merge the accounts. You can do so by going to the Membership tab in HD → Merge Members. You will have a form with the option to enter the two accounts you wish to merge.
- Is the member saying they have not received the login reminder email (reset password) from us? Ask them to kindly check any spam/junk folders in case it got filed away automatically. It shouldn't take more than a few minutes for them to receive it in their inbox. If you have reset their password recently, you can also check to see if their email bounced back for any reason. You can check this by going to the Helpdesk tab in HD → Bounced Emails. You can enter the email address you want to check in the search bar on the right hand side of the page. If you see that the email bounced back, you can check for the reason. If the member's email address is correct and they're inbox is not over quota, try clicking the "Whitelist?" link located right next to their email address in the search results. Then reset the password again to see if they receive it now.
- A general rule of thumb is to take note of the browser and browser version the member is using. We say that our website works best on up-to-date versions of Chrome, Firefox, and Safari. Our website does not display correctly on Internet Explorer, so kindly advise the member to use a different browser if they use IE to access our website. If they're not using IE, guide the member to clear their browser history and trying again. Also, opening up a new page or an Incognito window in Chrome might be a quick fix.
- Is the user's browser zoomed in? Sometimes this will bump the member bar out of view.
- If for some reason, you need to get the member logged out and they're unable to, send them the logout link: [www.fracturedatlas.org/site/members/logout](http://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/members/logout)
What is the difference between Customer ID and Member ID?

- every customer record has a (customer) ID - customers with memberships have member records that have their own (member) IDs - customers with donor/prospect records have donor records that have their own (donor) IDs - members have 1-n users, and each user has his/her own user record, with a (user) ID
Connecting Your Artful.ly & MailChimp Accounts

## What does integrating Artful.ly with MailChimp do for me?
Connecting your Artful.ly and MailChimp accounts will allow the two programs to share patron contact information. Specifically, the integration will:
* Copy your MailChimp subscribers into Artful.ly * Add new MailChimp subscribers to Artful.ly on a rolling basis * Display which MailChimp lists and groups an individual is subscribed to on his/her Artful.ly record * Allow you to add an individual to a MailChimp list directly from his/her Artful.ly people record * Indicate if an individual unsubscribes from a MailChimp list or if campaign email to them bounces * Log an action on an individual's record when you send him or her a MailChimp campaign * Log an action on an individual's record when he or she opens your MailChimp email * Ask your patrons to opt-in to your mailing list when they checkout on your Storefront, at the Box Office, or through the Sales Console * Use Advanced Search filters to find people who are or are not subscribed to specific MailChimp lists and groups * Define a list segment using Artful.ly Advanced Search filters and add the whole segment to a MailChimp list or group
## How do I set up this integration? This is a multi-step process, but thankfully you only have to do it once!
**Step 1: Get Your MailChimp API Key****
1. If you don't have a MailChimp account already, [create one](http://mailchimp.com/) and set up at least one list. 2. [Log in to your MailChimp account](https://login.mailchimp.com). 3. Navigate to [this page](http://admin.mailchimp.com/account/api). 4. Scroll down, click the **Create A Key** button. A new row will be added the the Your API Keys table. 5. Copy the string of letters and numbers that make up the **API Key**.
![getting the MailChimp Key](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=563 "getting the key")
** Step 2: Enable the MailChimp Kit in Artful.ly**
1. Log in to Artful.ly and navigate to your **Account Administration** page. 2. Click on the **Kits** tab. 3. Click the **Add** button next to the MailChimp tile. 4. Click the **Activate MailChimp** button. 5. Paste your MailChimp API key into the field and click **Set API Key** button.
**Step 3: Configure Your MailChimp Kit Settings in Artful.ly**
1. On the top right, select one or more lists from the **"Which MailChimp lists would you like to sync?"** area. 2. Below that, select the one list you want fans to join when they check out. 3. Below that, you can customize the text your fans see when they are asked to join your list at checkout. 4. Click **Save**. Depending on the size of your MailChimp lists, importing and creating Artful.ly records for everyone may take some time.
![sweet list](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=631 "sweet list")
The groups and lists that an individual is subscribed to will show up on their people record:
![Groups and lists on people record](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=635 "Groups and lists on people record")
## Related Articles: * [What is MailChimp and why do I need it?](/site/knowledgebase/what-is-mailchimp-and-why-should-i-use-it) * [Adding People to MailChimp Lists or Groups](/site/knowledgebase/adding-people-to-mailchimp-lists-or-groups) * [Our Favorite MailChimp Resources](/site/knowledgebase/our-favorite-mailchimp-resources)
Beta: Reporting on Relationships and Households

Artful.ly can help you find potential household pairings among your existing contacts. There are two ways you can search for existing households in your database:
1. **Advanced Search**: find existing relationships to create list segments, tag records, export information, and more.
2. **Exports**: create a spreadsheet of people in your database to work with the information outside of Artful.ly.
## Search & Report with Households
Once you turn on the Relationships Kit, you will automatically get a few more filters in your Advanced Search options.
1. Under the **People** tab, click on **Advanced Search** 2. Click on the **Relationships** tab. 3. Select your desired relationship type and perform the search. 4. Press the **Work with...** button at the top of the page to perform various actions on the search results.
![Advanced Search by Relationship Type](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=828 "Advanced Search by Relationship Type")
## Exporting Household Information
A people export will include a Household column so that you can search for members of specific households in your spreadsheet.
1. Under the **Reports** menu, select **Import/Export** 2. Select **Export People** to download a CSV file of your patron database. 3. Use sort and filter functions in your spreadsheet application to find individuals who are part of Households.
![Export people](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=829 "Export people")
### Related Articles - [Creating Households](/site/knowledgebase/beta-creating-households) - [Tracking Relationships Between Patrons](/site/knowledgebase/beta-tracking-relationships-between-patrons)
Beta: Cancel or Refund a Membership

You may run into a situation where you need to end a membership before it expires.
1. Open a Patron Record and click on either the **Membership ID Number** or **Member Tag**. This will open the patron's Membership History.
![David_Richard_People_Record.PNG](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=565 "David Richard People Record") 2. Check the box on the Membership you wish to cancel.
![Check_Membership.PNG](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=566 "check membership") 3. Select **Work With** and **Cancel Membership**.
![Work_With_Manage_Membership_Cancel_Membership.png](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=567 "work with manage membership cancel membership")
4. You will then need to Confirm the cancellation. A refund will be possible if the funds from the purchase have not settled. Membership revenue settlements issue two full business days after the membership is sold. If the funds have settled, your organization may issue refunds through your own internal refund procedures.
![Cancel_Membership_Refund.PNG](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=569 "cancel membership")
![Work_With_Cancel_Membership.PNG](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=568 "work with cancel membership")
## Refund Memberships
A membership may also be canceled and refunded just like you would a ticket. This may be done so long as the funds from the purchase have not settled. If the funds have settled to your bank account, your organization is responsible for refunding the customer based on your organization's refund procedures.
Go to the top menu bar and select **Orders** and **Memberships**. Or find the order from a patron's record. Click on the order to view the order details.
To refund from the order:
1. Navigate to **Orders** at the top menu bar and click **Memberships**. Or find the order on a patron record and view the order details. 2. Check the box for the order you need to refund.
Different Methods of Paying for Your Policy

Depending on the insurer, some policies will be fully due upon binding, and some are invoiced or collected at a later time directly by the carrier. The specific payment amount will be itemized at checkout.
Payment plans will sometimes be available (usually for policies above $2,000), but this will depend upon the insurer.
For all policies, the binder fee will be collected through your Fractured Atlas member account at checkout.
Beta: Tracking Relationships Between Patrons

## The Relationship Kit
*This kit is currently only available to beta testers. If you would like to beta test these features, please have your Organization Administrator email us at support@artful.ly and we will reach out to you about activating the kit.*
After we activate the kit, new functionally will now be added to your organization, and you will be able to:
- Define a relationship between any two records (spouse, friend, primary contact, etc.) - See the relationship on both records - Use Advanced Search to find people who have a certain relationship type on their record - Create a household that allows you to see the attributes of two or more individual records together - Find potential households with the Suggested Households report
## Defining the Relationship
Relationships can be created between any two records in your database—both individuals and companies.
1. Make sure both sides of the relationship have a record. If you just have one half of the relationship, go to the **People** menu and select **New Contact** add the other individual or company.
2. Open one record click the **Work With** button and click **Edit Info**.
![Work With Button Edit Info](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=573 "Work With")
3. Click **Relationships** in the side bar.
![Relationships Button](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=574 "edit info")
4. Select a relationship type (see list below)
5. Start typing the name of the other individual or company. Select that record and **Save**.
The relationship will now appear on both patron records. Relationships appear on the left-hand side of any record.
If a relationship is really significant, you can click the **star** next to it. Starred relationships stay at the top of the list.
![starred relationship](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=575 "starred relationship")
## Relationship Types
When you create a relationship on one record, a reciprocal relationship is created on the associated record. Some relationships are between two people, and other relationships are between an individual and a company. These are the various types of relationships you can log:
| Relationship Type | Reciprocal Relationship | |------------------------|-------------------------| | affiliated with | affiliated with | | alumnus/alumna of | has alumnus/alumna | | assistant to | assisted by | | assisted by | assistant to | | child of | parent of | | colleague of | colleague of | | did employ | was employed by | | donated to | received donation from | | employed by | employs | | employs | employed by | | friend of | friend of | | has alumnus/alumna | alumnus/alumna of | | has board member | on the board of | | on board of | has board member | | parent of | child of | | primarily contacted by | primary contact for | | primary contact for | primarily contacted by | | prospect of | solicitor of | | received donation from | donated to | | relative of | relative of | | represented by | representative of | | representative of | represented by | | sibling of | sibling of | | solicitor of | prospect of | | spouse of | spouse of | | was employed by | did employ |
The relationship types list is fixed to allow for optimal performance. If the relationship type you need isn't on the list, you might try "affiliated with." However, if customizing relationship types is a priority for your organization, please vote for this functionality in our [Feature Request Forum](https://artfully.zendesk.com/forums/318163-Feature-Requests).
## Search by Relationship Type
Sometimes it will be useful to see all the records that have a single type of relationship.
1. Go to **People** and click **Advanced Search**. 2. Choose **Relationships** in the side menu. 3. Select the relationship type you want to see in the dropdown menu.
This is great if you want to, say, send a mailing to all of the parents in your network. To find the parents, you would do a search for everyone with the "parent of" relationship type.
![parent search](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=779 "parent search")
## Relationship Tips
* Never go to bed angry. (For real.) * When you define a "spouse" relationship between two individuals, Artful.ly will suggest they be joined in a household. Read more about that [here.](/site/knowledgebase/beta-creating-households) * When you define an "employed by/employs" relationship between an individual and a company, and the individual does *not* have a company listed on her record, then Artful.ly will automatically fill in the company name on her record. * Some relationships can only be made between a person and a company. When creating a relationship between a person and a company, it's easiest to create the relationship from the company record. When you start from the company, you only see the relationships that can be made between a company and another record. * You can view all the relationships an individual or company has right on their record. This is useful for seeing the details of who one person knows and how she knows them. For example, if you have a board member with a number of prospective donors assigned to her, you can go directly to her record and see who she is assigned to solicit.
![All Relationships viewed on a people record](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=576 "all relationships on a people record")
## Related Topics
* [People Records Overview](/site/knowledgebase/people-records-overview) * [Creating Households](/site/knowledgebase/beta-creating-households)
Beta: Creating Households

*This functionality is part of The Relationships Kit and is currently only available to beta testers. If you would like to beta test these features, please have your Organization Administrator email us at support@artful.ly and we will reach out to you about activating the kit.*
After we activate the kit, new functionally will now be added to your organization, and you will be able to:
- Define a relationship between any two records (spouse, friend, primary contact, etc.) - See the relationship on both records - Use Advanced Search to find people who have a certain relationship type on their record - Create a household that allows you to see the attributes of two or more individual records together - Find potential households with the Suggested Households report
## What is Householding?
Householding associates two or more individuals into a "decision making unit." Most commonly, this refers to spouses who live together and make financial decisions together. A household may also include children or other relatives. The rules of who and what constitutes a household are up to you.
When you do choose to join two individual records in a household:
* Both individuals keep their own individual record. * A new household "view" is created that combines the actions, notes, and tags of the household members. * You define the household name and address. * Any future transactions still take placed at the individual level, but can also be seen at the household level. * You can use Advanced Search filters to define what record types you want to see—just individuals, just companies, just households, or all record types.
## How to Create a Household
1. Identify two individuals you want to household. (If you only have a record for one partner, create a record for the second before creating the household.) 2. Navigate to one individual's record. 3. Click **Work With**. 4. Select **Edit So-And-So's Info**
![Courtney_Household.png](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=578)
5. Select **Households**. 6. Click **Add to New Household**. 7. Enter a name for the household. 8. Add any remaining of the household members. 9. Click **Save**.
![Hollinor-Wellington.PNG](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=579)
## Viewing Households
Once a household is established, you see all the members on the people records in the household.
1. Clicking the **View** link on a record will take you to the Household Record. Here you'll see all of the activity in the household aggregated in one place.
![Courtney Household](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=578 "Courtney Household")
2. On the household record, you can see notes, actions, ticket sales, donations, and lifetime household value. This information is compiled from each member of the household's record.
![Michaels-Wendell Household](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=579 "michaels-wendell")
If you click **Edit Household** you'll find a few more aspects of the household that can be edited:
* **Basics** lets you rename the household. * **Address** lets you update the address information. You can use the Populate From dropdown menu if you already have the household address on a patron record. * **Overwrite member addresses** checkbox applies the address to every member of the household.
![Edit Household Info](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=582)
* **Add Individual** lets you add additional members to a household. Note: Each record can only be a part of one household. * **Delete** eliminates the household, but not the people records.
## Suggested Households
Artful.ly detects individuals you may want to join into households. These are suggested based on the following criteria: - **Address**: Address Line 1 and the first five digits of the zip code match - **Relationship**: Type is "spouse"
To view suggested households,
1. From the top navigation bar, click **People** and select **Suggested Households.** 2. If you want to create a household, click **Join**. 3. If you know the individuals are not members of the same household, you can click **Ignore** and the suggestion should not appear again.
![Suggested household example](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=630 "Suggested household example")
We recommend you review the suggested households for your organization at least once a month.
## Related Topics
- [Tracking Relationships Between People](site/knowledgebase/beta-tracking-relationships-between-patrons) - [People Records Overview](/site/knowledgebase/people-records-overview) - [How do I create a new people record?](/site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-create-a-new-people-record)
Artful.ly Theory of Change (CC)

The Artful.ly program aspires to fulfill the Fractured Atlas mission with the following activities, outcomes, and impacts.
## Activities
- Build and maintain tools for arts administration - Practice community-driven design - Continually develop and improve the software - Take advantage of new technologies - Keep prices low - Make it easy to try - Prioritize open access - Provide open-source edition of tool - Provide open access to users' own data - Educate users about using data for marketing and fundraising
## Outcomes
- User feedback is reflected in Artful.ly design - Artful.ly users contribute to betterment of the tools - Artful.ly users can afford sophisticated tools designed for them - Artful.ly users are better able to execute administrative functions - Artful.ly users have better subjective experience of administration - OSE users create custom editions of the software - Artful.ly users are better able to align business tools with their values - Artful.ly users avoid vendor lock-in and control over their own data - Artful.ly users fell more ownership of their data - Current and potential users have more trust in Artful.ly and Fractured Atlas - Artful.ly users can employ data about their fans - Artful.ly users improve brand perception and user experience of their fans - Better user experience and brand equity improve marketing and fundraising results
## Impacts
- Artful.ly users are able to spend their time and money more cost effectively - Artful.ly users feel more ownership of their creative business identities - Artful.ly users are able to maximize value from their fans
![Artfully Theory of Change](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=754 "Artfully Theory of Change")
Creating Demo Accounts for Users

## When is it appropriate to give a user a demo account?
We don't want to hand out demo accounts to just anyone. Doing so can create unnecessary friction in user acquisition. The prospective user may be confused by the idea of a demo account or expect that we will be able to transfer their data from demo to production.
On the other hand, some prospective users may be hesitant to try Artful.ly at all without a preview. These will often be larger or more established organizations with a lot of data to move and set expectations. These organizations are also usually worth more to us so spending extra effort to reel them in with demo account pays off.
Use your judgement to determine when a demo account will be helpful and be prepared to spend extra time with these prospects.
## How do I create a demo account?
1. Start on the [Fractured Atlas Staging site](https://staging.www.fracturedatlas.org/). 2. Sign up for a new membership. 3. Note the email and password you used to create this account. 4. Go to [Artful.ly Demo site](https://artfully-demo.herokuapp.com/signups/collect_info) 5. Create a new org. 6. Name the account org after the real organization you're working with and signal that it's a test or demo account. This is to prevent Artful.ly staff from using this account for screencasts/shots and the remind the user that they are not in production mode. For example, if you are creating a demo account for the folks at Keen Company, name their Artful.ly demo org something like "Keen Test Account" or "Keen Demo Account". - Emails are not live in Demo but use safe fake emails just in case. - Make the password something easy to relay, like "password". - Make the timezone whatever timezone the prospective user is in. 7. Click "Create My Artful.ly Account" 8. Navigate to "Account Administration" page. 9. Add the appropriate kits (probably just donation and ticketing kits). 10. Log out of user account. 11. Log into [Demo Admin Panel](https://artfully-demo.herokuapp.com/admins/sign_in). 12. Find the org account you just created. 13. Add a fake bank account and approve the kits. 14. Tell prospective user that their account is ready to go (see below).
## What do tell the user about their demo account?
1. Use the "Demo account set up" macro. 2. Point out any features or articles you know the prospective user is interested in.
Converting a Ticket Order Into a Donation

**(Note: This is only possible for nonprofit organizations with the [501(C)(3) Donations kit](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/enabling-donations-for-501-c-3-nonprofits) activated.)**
If a fan is unable to make your event, but wants to donate the money from his or her original ticket order, you can convert the ticket order into a donation.
1. View the patron's people record and click on the **order details.**
![Patron people record with order details](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=597 "Patron people record with order details")
2. On the **Order Details** page, select one or all of the tickets to be converted, click on the asterisks above all of the tickets, and select **Convert**.
![Convert tickets on order details page](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=836 "Convert tickets on order details page")
3. Click on **Confirm Convert** to complete the conversion.
![Confirm conversion of order](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=837 "Confirm conversion of order")
The conversion will appear in the Action Feed on the patron's record:
![Ticket conversion on action feed](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=838 "Ticket conversion on action feed")
**Please note that tickets can only be converted until the day of the show.**
### Related Articles - [Donations & Donation Reports](/site/knowledgebase/donations-donation-reports)
Searching for Artful.ly Orders

Sometimes people get confused. They don't read their emails, see 'Artful.ly' on a credit card statement, or have no idea what that's all about. Lucky for us, there are easy ways to find their orders and remind them which show they saw or organization they supported.
### Ask for this information:
- **Name** on the credit card (Or the names of anybody who has access to the credit card: husband/wife, children, other family, etc.) - **Date** of the charge (Keep in mind that sometimes the date posted on their CC statement may be a day or two before/after what we have in our records.) - **Amount** of the charge - What is listed as the description or merchant name on the statement? (If this says "Fractured Atlas" rather than "Artful.ly" you will not find the order in Artful.ly. Try looking in the Fractured Atlas admin panel for a fiscal sponsorship donation or membership dues.)
###Finding an order in Artful.ly
1. Log into [Artful.ly Admin](artful.ly/admin) 2. Use the Find an Order field by typing a first and/or last name, order number.
![Order Search Field](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=599 "Order Search Field")
### Still can't find it?
If there is confusion about who purchased the tickets, which credit card was used, or what event the customer saw - you'll have to search through the database a little more meticulously. You still need at least SOME of the information above, like the day of the charge on the statement and the amount. Oftentimes, the order is usually under a different person's name.
1. Go to https://www.artful.ly/admin/orders/artfully 2. Scroll through listings based on date. As you progress through the orders you can adjust the URL slug to change the page number where it says "Page=". 3. For order details, click on the order number.
![Order Details Page](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=600 "Order Details Page")
If all else fails and you cannot find the order in Artful.ly admin, request the **last four digits of the credit card** and speak with someone on the finance team who can look it up by date/CC number.
### Congratulations, you found the order!
Resending a Receipt: 1. Open the order details. 2. Click Copy Receipt. This will send a copy of the confirmation email to YOU (to whatever email you used to log into the Artful.ly admin panel). From your email, you can send the receipt or a screenshot of it to the patron or organization as necessary.

Merging & Terminating Member Records

_Merging member records is an ongoing part of database hygiene that all Fractured Atlas staffers contribute to. It's a critical chore that ensures we all have easy access to the most holistic view of a members experience across the organization._
Merging is an action that can not be undone, and there are certain scenarios where multiple memberships for an individual is correct, so best practice is to 'Measure Twice, Cut Once'. Below are guidelines for merging (and the occasional rare termination) of a member record.
![Measure Twice Cut Once](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=757 "Measure Twice Cut Once")
### Common Scenarios for Merging - Member is also has a separate donor record under the same contact info - Member created multiple accounts with different emails but one is definitively most recent
### You Should Probably Merge Two Memberships When... - The contact info on both records is identical - The two records are not for two different fiscally sponsored projects - The two records do not carry insurance for separate legal entities
### You Should Probably Leave It Alone When... - There are two fiscally sponsored projects - There are two separate legal entities being insured - There record was created for invoicing purposes only (i.e. a Customer record/not a membership record, created by Jillian - double check!)
### What Happens When You Merge Two Records? - This stuff is combined: - Customer service history - Member payment history - Member donation history - Insurance coverage history - This stuff gets ditched: - The "loser" record's name, email, address, phone numbers
TIP: If you are unsure which info should be overwritten, take a quick screen cap of both records BEFORE the merge, so you can reference and update a certain fields if need be. Example: When the loser record has the most recent physical address, but an out of date email.
### How to merge
Tip: If you are trying to merge an individual that has more than 2 memberships, open each member record in a new tab to compare in order to determine the 'winning' record.
1. In the Fractured Atlas Admin panel - Go to 'Membership' 2. Select 'Merge Members' 3. In field for 'Customer # 1' start typing the member name or email, auto suggest will provide some options, select the member and you will see a preview of the contact info 4. Do the same for 'Customer #2'
### What do you see just before merging?
- The first record you select (Customer #1) will be the 'winner' record and the second one (Customer #2) will be the 'loser' record
![Merge Example](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=756 "enter image title here")
### You Should Probably Terminate a Membership When... - This action is very rare, in most scenarios is a merge is preferred. Exceptions include:
- Test membership records - Member specifically requests termination of membership while fully understanding downgrading, opting out of communications or merging as alternatives to termination. - You know that the individual no longer works at the associated organization, the email uses the domain of that organization, AND you have no way of personally contacting or finding that person to update info on their member record with new contact info. (Example: venues that have closed and membership records with staff emails with first name/last name that is "Rentals Manager" or a pass thru email 'booking@examplevenue.com').
### More Tips
- Clarify with the member what overall details should remain on the record if you are unsure, this can often become a great touchpoint with a member on what is new with them (or us).
- The old member record that was merged will continue to show up in customer quick-search at first, just give it a spell and the search will update to reflect your merge changes.

# The Greater Environments
Greater Environments have some consistency about them. The code running on these environments is intentional. The databases are semi-static. These environemtns are not reset unless absolutely necessary.
### Production
Don't ever do anything to production
http://artful.ly/ Credentials: production credentials
### Staging
Staging is an exact replica of production and is used to test production pushes as well as test production bugs. Production-ready changes should be pushed to staging and tested there before being pushed to production.
Staging should not be different from production for any significant length of time.
Do not ever push to Staging
http://artfully-staging.herokuapp.com/ Credentials: production credentials
Basic auth is enabled on staging sometimes username: fracturedatlas password: frenchpress Password is subject to change at any time
### Demo
Demo is a first class environment used for: widget demos, PA demos.
Master is pushed to demo after production
http://artfully-demo.herokuapp.com
# The Lesser Environments
Lesser Environments are used to show features in progress so that the business may provide feedback to the developers. These environments, while providing consistency during feature development, may be reset/rebuilt from time to time.
None of these environments should be considered secure. Do not upload sensitive material, password, bank information, etc..

Unless otherwise noted, all passwords on dev are "password"

2015 August Staff Meeting Minutes

**Thursday, August 6th, 2015**

Our Playbook (CC)

### VISION
Our vision is what we want the future to look like. This is our notion of a better world. It’s our big idea. It’s bigger than what we can realistically achieve as one single organization and will require decades of collaborative effort. It is the ultimate intended impact of our work.
>We envision an agile and resilient cultural ecosystem with a diversity of artistic voices and broad support for cultural activity.
### CORE PURPOSE
This is the grand and aspirational reason for our specific work and the existence of our organization. It is not necessarily unique, but it is why we get up in the morning. It is how we want to contribute to a better world.
>Fractured Atlas exists to maximize humanity’s creative and expressive potential.
### MISSION
This is what we do—the how and why. We may share a common vision with other organizations, but this is our unique slice of the pie.
>Fractured Atlas empowers artists, arts organizations, and other cultural sector stakeholders by eliminating practical barriers to artistic expression, so as to foster a more agile and resilient cultural ecosystem.
### CORE BEHAVIORAL VALUES
These values describe how we behave with one another and with our various constituents. We believe we are better at these things than the majority of organizations and they uniquely define us.
> We... > >**Embrace Challenge.** We seek out challenging problems and relish opportunities to venture into unexplored territory. We are entrepreneurial and comfortable with high-risk, high-impact efforts. #EmbraceChallenge > >**Make It Happen.** We are agile, creative problem solvers with a pragmatic focus on concrete results. We do what needs to be done and do it well every day. #MakeItHappen > >**Seek Continuous Improvement.** We are curious, unafraid of change, and excited by opportunities to better our services, our systems, and ourselves. Innovations and good ideas may be incremental or radical, and they can come from any corner of the organization at any time. #SeekImprovement > >**Be Excellent to Each Other.** We invest our time in quality work and giving customers and colleagues alike our respect, recognition, and support. #BeExcellent
### GUIDING PRINCIPLES
These values may not be as quirky as our Core Values, but these are important commitments we make to our members and customers.
> **Level Playing Field.** Artistic success should be achieved through talent and hard work, and not hindered by other barriers. > > **Diversity of Voices.** We believe that society benefits from a diversity of individual voices in the arts. > > **Non-Curatorial.** We leave it to others to judge artistic quality. > > **Fair Price.** We believe that people will typically pay for services that are of value to them, and that this provides useful feedback to us as a service provider. > > **Scale.** We can reach more artists and offer lower prices when we leverage technology and operate at scale. > > **Transparency.** Intentionally sharing our processes and outcomes fosters learning and accountability.
### OBJECTIVES
These are the goals we must achieve to fulfill our mission. Objectives guide our efforts as individuals and as an organization, and we measure our progress against our objectives regularly to assess how effective our work is.
> We aim to help… > > Artists and arts organizations reduce frustration > > Artists and arts organizations raise and earn more money > > Artists and arts organizations save money and time > > Artists and arts organizations meet legal and contractual requirements for opportunities > > Artists and arts organizations feel in control of their creative and business identities > > Leaders make more favorable decisions on behalf of the cultural ecosystem
For a deeper understanding of our activities, outcomes, intended impacts, and the logic that connects them, please refer to the Fractured Atlas Theory of Change.
### STAKEHOLDERS
These are the constituents and groups we work with to achieve our objectives and mission. Generally, those at the center of the diagram have the greater stake in the success of our organization. That said, our environment is dynamic and our relationship to each individual stakeholder is somewhat fluid and contextual.
There are people in each of those concentric rings who are "true believers" and they have been carrying the Fractured Atlas banner for years. And there are others who, despite a significant transactional relationship, don't give us much thought at all and wouldn't hesitate to move their business to someone else if a lower price were available.
The important thing to understand is that we have a very complex constituency and the decisions we make should be considered relative to how they might impact any of these stakeholders.
![stakeholdermap](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=607 "map of stakeholders")
### POSITIONING
Positioning is essentially our plan for success. It is comprised of “Strategic Anchors,” a collection of intentional decisions made to give ourselves the best chance to thrive and differentiate ourselves from competitors. These statements are not used publicly.
> To succeed, we will... > > Cultivate a diverse portfolio of activities and revenue streams > > Aggregate and share knowledge and ideas > > Attract and develop a lean, highly productive staff > > Invent and leverage technology
### PERSONALITY
If Fractured Atlas were a character in a play, this is how he or she would be described. Our personality is our voice, our style, and our attitude. It should be expressed throughout our communications and distinguish us from our peers. Channel these attributes when writing or speaking on behalf of Fractured Atlas.
> Fractured Atlas is… > > Professional but not corporate > > Friendly but not sappy > > Cheeky but not snarky > > Smart but not inaccessible > > Authoritative but not autocratic > > Practical but not heartless > > Tipsy but not trashed > > Helpful but not your mother

Fractured Atlas Theory of Change (CC)

### What is a theory of change?
Put simply, a theory of change is a visual depiction of strategy. For more on theories of change and logic models, please see [this blog post](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/blog/2012/06/28/in-defense-of-logic-models/) from 2012. (You can skip down to “What the Hell Is a Logic Model, Anyway?”)
Fractured Atlas's theory of change describes the strategic pillars of the organization's *mission*. Fractured Atlas is a hybrid organization drawing from both nonprofit and for-profit paradigms. In some cases the organization's business objectives (earned revenue, etc.) are served by achieving mission goals and vice versa, but not always.
## Fractured Atlas Theory of Change [![FA TOC](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=752 "FA TOC")](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/fa-toc.png)
(Click image to view larger.)
## How to Use the Theory of Change
- **Let it help you decide what to measure.** What information is most important for your program to have? Are there any assumptions underlying your program’s success that seem especially vulnerable or uncertain? Does the theory of change show that certain objectives have to be met before any others are possible? If so, you might want to focus measurement or tracking efforts on those objectives or assumptions. - **Use it as an onboarding tool.** Walking through a theory of change can be a great way to get up to speed quickly on the “big picture” of Fractured Atlas as an organization, and not just the details that you need to focus on day to day. A theory of change can be particularly effective at helping you understand how your work fits into a larger plan. - **Use it in grant applications.** Many funders are accustomed to working with theories of change and logic models, and including one with a proposal can communicate that we speak their language and have thought seriously about how a program works. Depending on the situation, you might even be able to frame language in the proposal around it, for example to argue that the grant would support progress towards a specific, mission-critical outcome. - **Learn from the theories of change of programs other than your own.** How well does your perception of how the other programs at Fractured Atlas work and what they’re each trying to accomplish match up with reality? Do the staff for those programs think about their goals or activities differently than you? Are there any concepts or measures they’ve come up with that you want to steal?
The most up-to-date version of Fractured Atlas's overall theory of change as well as theories of change for each program area can be found in the "Theories of Change" folder in the top level of the shared files system.

Membership Overview

**Types of Membership**
There are three different types of memberships: Community, Professional, and Organization.
The free Community level of membership provides access to benefits like free insurance quotes, the member calendar, SpaceFinder, Artful.ly, and special offers/discounts. SpaceFinder helps artists and arts organization find spaces in their neighborhood to either hold events, rehearse, and so on. Artful.ly offers artists a way to sell tickets and manage/communicate with their donors.
Professional membership has all the benefits at the Community level plus access to our full insurance program and access to apply for our fiscal sponsorship program. Since we are such a large member organization, we are able to offer our member good rates on insurance policies. Our fiscal sponsorship program helps artists fundraise for their works by incentivizing individual donations, obtain nonprofit rates, and more.
Organization membership provides all the benefits at the Professional level for up to three authorized users.
**Why do we have memberships?**
We have different memberships for the varying needs of the artist community. The membership dues is revenue generated by Fractured Atlas that goes towards sustaining the programs and services that we offer. The dues goes toward paying support staff, general administrative costs, software maintenance, and development.
**How many members do we have?**
We currently have about 50,000 members. There are live stats posted on our website (www.fracturedatlas.org/site/about/membership), but a more specific breakdown can be found under the Membership tab > Membership Stats.
**How much money do we make from membership dues and how is that revenue used in our org?**

Reporting Bugs (CC)

### Is it a bug? Sometimes users will report things they don't like or features that are missing as bugs. While we do care about these kinds of issues, they are not bugs. A bug is a bug when it: - Produces an error message - Does not complete the action as expected (e.g., after submitting a form the changes are not saved) - It is just broken (e.g., blank pages, odd behavior, errant calculations) ###How to write bug report Before writing a bug report make sure that we are really dealing with a bug. The best way to do this is to find a way to reproduce it. Understanding the conditions that cause a bug will help expedite getting it fixed. Once you have determined that we are likely dealing with a bug it is time to report it. When reporting a bug you will want to provide as much detail as possible. Always include the following details: - Who (the user and type of user) - What (what happened, what did they see, what did they do) - When (yes, when it happened can be helpful as it allows developers to look through error logs) In addition to the basics you should provide any other details including screenshots or screencasts. ### Where to report a bug If it is a not a bug that needs immediate attention you have a couple options for reporting bugs. If you have access to the Pivotal tracker for the piece of software that is having an issue you should create a bug story. If you do not have access to the appropriate tracker or are just unsure you can email bug@fracturedatlas.org. ### What if it's on fire?!? In the event that something needs to be addressed immediately you should post a message in Flowdock asking for help, using the @team tag will help to get everyone's attention.

Web hosting and FTP * Hello world! Intro to programming with Ruby
### Intro to Databases
There are many types of databases. For the purposes of this document we're speaking of Relational databases (RDBMS)
**What it is**
A place to store the data associated with your application and your users. A software program, just like Outlook, Word or Firefox.
**What it is not**
A web application. HighRise, Basecamp, Popplet, Foursquare, etc... are not databases. They are web applications. They use databases to store the data that you enter.
**What is so special about a database?**
ACID compliance Atomicity - When you do a set of somethings, they should all work, otherwise don't do any of them Consistency - When you do something, tidy up after yourself so that things are ready for the next task Isolation - When you do something, don't interfere with others who may be doing something else Durability - When you do something, it better be there in the morning.
**Brands of databases**
- MySQL - Postgres - Oracle 9i, 10g
**So what does your data look like?**
Data is stored in rows in tables Table stores one type of thing: employees Columns are the information that describe the thing: First name, last name, age, email address, company Rows store information on one specific thing: An employee named Jim Smith The table employees will have many rows, each containing information on one employee
**Further Reading**
A Short History of Databases: http://math.hws.edu/vaughn/cpsc/343/2003/history.html Database fundamentals clas at Penn State: http://www.personal.psu.edu/glh10/ist110/topic/topic07/topic07_01.html SQL tester: http://www.w3schools.com/sql/sql_tryit.asp MySQL: The most popular open source database http://www.mysql.com/
###Intro to SQL
SQL stands for Structured Query Language. It is pronounced "Sequel" or "S.Q.L." SQL is the language that you use to talk to your database. An SQL statement issued to a database is called a "query"
**Basic SQL syntax**
**Putting Data Into the DB**
INSERT INTO (table) VALUES (column delimited list of values) for example...
INSERT INTO employees VALUES 'Gary','Moore','33'
**Updating Data in the DB**
UPDATE (which table) VALUES (the values that you want to change) WHERE (the criteria for updating)
**Getting Data From the DB**
SELECT (the columns that you want) FROM (the table that holds the data we want) WHERE (the following conditions are met) for example, if you want to list all employees who are over the age of 30.
SELECT first_name, last_name, age FROM employees WHERE age > 30 If you want all the columns, use *
SELECT * FROM employees WHERE age > 30 Use AND to chain WHERE clauses
SELECT * FROM employees WHERE age > 30 AND age < 40 For partial matches, use the % character as a wildcard
SELECT first_name, last_name, age FROM employees WHERE last_name LIKE 'Smith%'
### Intro to Internet
The Internet (with a capital I) is a global system of connected computers that serve data to each other.
**ARPANET**
Advanced Research Projects Agency Network - The first successful iteration of what would become the Internet. Developed in the late 60's by really smart people with financing and direction from the Department of Defense. Created, in part, to serve academic documents between universities but of course served many other needs.
Two principal technological innovations baked into ARPANET that were critical to it's success:
Packet switching redundancy, surviving network links failing
**IP Adddresses and DNS**
IP Address = a numerical label assigned to devices connected to the Internet. IPv4 (current and most common) is in the format NNN.NNN.NNN.NNN
DNS = Domain name service. The computer responsible for translating a domain name (yahoo.com) into an IP address NNN.NNN.NNN.NNN. YOur internet service provider provides this service. It is a distributed, fault-tolerant service that has o central authority.
**Further Reading**
The 100 oldest registered .com names - http://www.jottings.com/100-oldest-dot-com-domains.htm Internet Pulse - http://internetpulse.net/
Decision Analysis (CC)

### Decision Analysis Training: An Introduction
Decisions, decisions! We make them every day, but how much thought do we really put into them on a regular basis? Research on human judgment and cognition tells us that the answer is usually “not much.” For this reason, improving the decision-making process is one of the highest-leverage capacity-building activities an organization can undertake.
As part of the Core Curriculum, Fractured Atlas gives its staff members an introduction to the innovative techniques Fractured Atlas has used since 2013 to analyze decisions and place them in context. These workshops happen with a small group 2-3 times a year and last 3.5 hours.
### Curriculum and Learning Objectives
Fractured Atlas believes that research and data collection should be relentlessly tied to decisions that matter. This introductory workshop explores how decisions shape organizational strategy and tactics, covering the following topics along the way:
- **What defines a “good decision”** - **Decision-making and uncertainty** - **The role of measurement and prediction in decision-making** - **Why measurement is easier than you think** - **Better estimates through calibrated probability assessment** - **When sh!t gets serious: building quantitative decision models** - **A generalized method for analyzing and making any decision**
### Additional Resources
Fractured Atlas offers an advanced workshop series that covers quantitative decision modeling in more depth. This training is optional and happens on an ad hoc basis whenever there is enough demand to support it.
*[How to Measure Anything](http://www.amazon.com/How-Measure-Anything-Intangibles-Business/dp/1452654204)* by Douglas Hubbard (core text) *[The Signal and the Noise](http://www.amazon.com/The-Signal-Noise-Predictions-Fail-but/dp/0143125087)* by Nate Silver *[Thinking, Fast and Slow](http://www.amazon.com/Thinking-Fast-Slow-Daniel-Kahneman/dp/0374533555)* by Daniel Kahneman

Staff Professional Development Recommendations

Each fiscal year Fractured Atlas staff are given a professional development allowance. Below is a list of options staff have found helpful: ### In-Person Classes * [National Arts Strategies](http://www.artstrategies.org/) * [Coactive Coaching Fundamentals](http://www.thecoaches.com/coach-training/core-courses/co-active-coaching-fundamentals) * Continuing Education courses at Baruch and NYU. Baruch costs less and was a better experience, but NYU has several one-day courses if you can't commit to multiple weeks. Recommended class at Baruch: Negotiation & Conflict Management. * [Support Center for Nonprofit Management](http://www.supportcenteronline.org): Affordable, thoughtful, and surprisingly relevant offerings for NPOs of all stripes. They cover everything from strategic planning, to reading financial statements, to board development. They also do a great "Meet the Grantmakers" series. * Introduction to Not-for-profit Accounting and Governmental Reporting at NYU School of Continuing and Professional Studies. One semester, meets about 8 times and goes over incorporation, Form 1023, boards, basic accounting principals and financial reports. Recommended. * [General Assembly](http://generalassemb.ly)--Design/biz/tech school * [Big Duck](http://www.bigducknyc.com/resources/workshops)--Marketing/branding firm specializing in nonprofits. Lots of one-off workshops * [Support Center](http://supportcenteronline.force.com/EventCalendar)--A variety of nonprofit management workshops and panels * [Foundation Center](http://www.grantspace.org/Classroom)--Workshops and courses in non-profit management, grant writing, etc. * [Design Gym](http://www.thedesigngym.com/)--Classes and workshops on creativity, collaboration, and innovation. Topics include: Design Thinking, Facilitation Skills, User Experience Design, Design Research, etc. ### Online Classes * [Harvard Business Review ManageMentor Series](http://hbr.org/harvardmanagementor) * [MIT OpenCourseWare](http://ocw.mit.edu/index.htm) * [Open Yale Courses](http://oyc.yale.edu/courses) * [Khan Academy](http://www.khanacademy.org/) * [Foundation Center](http://foundationcenter.org/getstarted/training/online/) for webinars and self-paced online classes * [Lynda](http://www.lynda.com/) online courses with topic ranging from coding to photography to marketing
### Meetups * [Arts Culture and Technology Meetup](http://www.meetup.com/Arts-Culture-and-Technology/) ~ Lisa Niedermeyer ### Coaching * Coactive Coaching ~ Lisa Niedermeyer * Capes Coaching, an OAN partner, which will sometimes offer us free sessions. * [Dewey Schott](http://www.dewey-schott.com) * Diane Lennard, public speaking coach (dlennard@stern.nyu.edu). Ian and Dianne worked with her. She's super helpful, charges $300 per session. ### Professional Organizations * Arts and Business Council of NY - Arts Leadership Institute * Woodhull Institute - Young Women's Ethical Leadership Retreat ### Conferences * NAMP - National Arts Marketing Conference. Great information on marketing and fundraising for the arts. * Fundraising Day in NYC - Usually in June. It's not specific to the arts, but there are basic fundraising workshops throughout the day. ### Hack-a-thons * DataDives produced by [DataKind](http://www.datakind.org/) - Data analysts, data visualization artists, developers, project managers, marketers and more volunteer to work with on social impact projects over a weekend of beer and pizza ~ Lisa Niedermeyer * [Comedy Hack Day](http://www.comedyhackday.org) produced by Cultivated Whit - Developers, comedians and often playwrights come together to make apps, hilarity ensues ~ Lisa Niedermeyer * Startup Weekend - build a start up business in 72 hours, finale is a pitch to investors - great experience for people who think they could be interested in product or project management but have yet to have the opportunity to experience leading a team with tangible deadline and outcome - plus it is great fun ~ Lisa Niedermeyer ### NOT RECOMMENDED * Arts Reach Conference - Snore! Pretty out of date. Not worth your time or money. * Games for Change - not worth it!

Fractured Atlas Glossary (CC)

Jargon sucks. Avoid using it externally.
But sometimes we _need_ to use it internally. Here are some of the uncommon words, abbreviations, and acronyms we use at Fractured Atlas and how they relate to organization specifically.
Feel free to add terms.
- **Affiliate** = - **Agile** = - **Additional Insured (AI)** = An entity that you add to your insurance policy that needs to be covered if they have an insurance claim that arises because of your activities. This is usually used when our members add venues or filming locations as Additional Insureds. You can add an entity as an Additional Insured by requesting a certificate for them. - **Amazon Hosted Data Center** = - **API** = - **Artsopolis** = A software platform primarily for cultural event calendars. - **ATHENA** = Stands for Advanced Technology Hub and Extensible Nexus for the Arts. Artful.ly's name before rebranding. - **Authorize.net** = - **Background Job** = A piece of software that runs outside of a user request. Required by tasks that could take longer than a normal web request (1-5 secs). - **beta** = Before releasing major new software features, we often try to run a "beta testing phase" with a limited set of users. This helps surface bugs and refine the features before making the changes for all users. - **Binder** = A temporary contract of insurance, oral or written, offered by an insurer pending issuance of a permanent policy. It is usually written for a period of 30 days and remains in force until a permanent policy is either issued or denied. - **Binder Fee** = A fee paid directly to Fractured Atlas in order to put your coverage in place. Paying your binder fee means that you are accepting the insurance quote that was issued to you. - **Braintree** = A merchant account vendor Fractured Atlas uses to process credit card payments for certain programs. - **cascade** = Shorthand for "cascading communication." This idea comes from Patrick Lencioni's book _The Advantage_. Members our leadership team leave each of their meetings having agreed on a common set of messages that they will communicate to their respective staffs within 24-48 hours after the meeting. What is important is that messages are being communicated consistently and quickly in a personal way. Staff members have the opportunity to ask their supervisors questions immediately and in person. - **Certificate of Insurance (COI)** = A document that evidences the existence of insurance coverage. - **CopyCopter** = A third party software used to update copy (as in text and links) within a web application. - **CRUD** = Create. Read. Update. Delete. It's an acronym that boils down the basic functions of most pieces of software. - **Deployed** = This means the code or feature being referenced has been pushed to a server for viewing. Servers can be in *staging* or *production*. - **EOB** = End of Business Day (often used for clarity on deadlines) - **Future of Music Coalition** = - **General Liability** = A policy that covers you if you injure other people or other people’s stuff. - **GNU General Public License** = - **GUI** = Stands for Graphical User Interface. It's what you're using to read this article right now. Instead of entering complex lines of code in a command line prompt, you can click on folders and icons that represent what you want to do. - **Instance** = Each SpaceFinder web application is referred to internally as an 'instance'. We do not use this term externally. - **Local Leader** = A title used in the SpaceFinder program when referring to local partner organizations we have written agreements with. - **MDP** = These are the initials for our broker Maury, Donnelly, and Parr. We work exclusively with MDP who broker all policies for Fractured Atlas. - **MVP** = Yep we have both MDP and MVP. MVP stands for Minimal Viable Product. It is used as short hand for getting the foundation of an idea shipped (often crudely and quickly) so it can be tested and refined. - **OAN** = Open Arts Network. Fractured Atlas program allowing other member orgs to pass on our benefits to their membdernally. - **Open Source** = - **Pareto Principle** = (also known as the 80–20 rule) states that, for many events, roughly 80% of the effects come from 20% of the causes. - **Parkinson's Law** = Work expands so as to fill the time available for its completion. - **PEBKAC** = A user error is an error made by the human user of a complex system, usually a computer system, in interacting with it. Although the term is sometimes used by Human Computer Interaction practitioners, the more formal human error term is used in the context of human reliability. User Error and related phrases such as PEBKAC ("Problem Exists Between Keyboard And Chair") - **PHP** = The original programming language used to build software at Fractured Atlas. Some systems are still written using PHP but most are written in *Ruby*. - **Production** = An environment for an application that is public facing. This is the "live" environment for an application. - **QA testing** = - **Rake Task**= Same as *script*, but sometimes run on a schedule (eg, settlements running every evening). - **Reseller** = A dormant module of Artful.ly. Designed to allow individuals or organizations to promote and resell tickets on behalf of Artful.ly producers. Producers would choose which tickets and how many they offer to a reseller. Resellers can choose whether or not to accept and resell those tickets and if they add a fee for their service. This kit is not complete and we currently do not offer it to members. - **RESTful**= While REST stands for Representational State Transfer, which is an architectural style for networked hypermedia applications, it is primarily used to build Web services that are lightweight, maintainable, and scalable. A service based on REST is called a RESTful service. Fractured Atlas built our own tool called [RESTful Metrics](http://www.restfulmetrics.com/) to track and report stats from our SpaceFinder platform. - **roadmap** = - **Ruby** = The programming language used to build most software at Fractured Atlas. Some systems still use *PHP*. - **Ruby-on-Rails** = - **SaaS** = - **Script**= A one time piece of software written to address a specific issue. Usually one off. - **Service-Oriented Architecture** = - **SOPA** = Stop Online Piracy Act, House bill, allow the U.S. Department of Justice and copyright owners to seek court orders targeting websites they accuse of infringing copyright. - **Staging** = An environment for an application that allows stakeholders to test and verify software functionality. This is not "live" like *production*. - **Theory of Change** = - **Terrorism Risk Insurance Act (TRIA)** = A federal law that has existed since 2002 that provides government backup for insurance claims that arise out of acts of terrorism. It allows you to purchase insurance that will still pay out if you have a claim as a result of a terrorist act. - **WFH** = Working From Home

Visa Letter Basics (CC)

We write "letters of consultation" for O & P Visa applicants. These are also known as "advisory letters" or "advisory opinions" or "no objection letters." We can work with artists directly or with their immigration attorneys to complete these letters.
We have been doing these since 2008 and, to the best of our knowledge, none have been denied a visa due to our letter. We have completed these for artists and creative professionals of all types, including, but not limited to those involved with: theater (actors, directors, administrators), film/TV (actors, filmmakers/directors, designers, public liaisons for documentaries), visual art (painters, sculptors, photographers), fashion (designers, photographers, hair/makeup), design (architects, graphic designers), dance (dancers, choreographers), music (musicians, DJs, bands/orchestras, booking agents), radio (on-air personalities), literary (journalists, writers, editors), and more.
The basics on our service are:
- We only need the I-129, petitioner's letter, the artist's resume (if not already included in the petitioner's letter), and 3-4 support letters. If we have questions and need further information, we can generally find it through Google or we can request further documentation. The documents can be emailed (to support@fracturedatlas.org) or faxed (212-277-8025) to us. Once we have them, we can get our letter back within 3-5 business days (sometimes 1 business day with an additional $100 rush request).
- We will email our letter to as a PDF. If it also needs to be mailed, we can do that, but there has never been a problem with our emailed letters, as they can be printed out and included in the package.
- We charge $200 per letter. If USCIS requests further evidence after their initial review (which usually means a more specific letter of consultation), we charge $100 for the second letter ($50 for paying members or Associate Members). We accept credit/debit card (over the phone), check, or money order for payment. If the payment is coming from the attorney, we can send the letter before payment is received. If it's coming from the artist-applicant themselves, we must receive payment before we send the letter. We can invoice any party if necessary.
- We are considered a "peer group" by USCIS. We are not a management or labor organization.
- We have a Special Offers section which attorneys can post to if they would like to offer discounted or pro bono legal service to our members.
- If someone wants more information about the actual process of obtaining a visa, they should be directed to [www.artistsfromabroad.org](http://www.artistsfromabroad.org) and should be urged to contact an immigration attorney. If anyone asks if we can serve as their visa sponsor/petitioner, we cannot, as we are unable to be responsible for their employment while they are in the U.S. It should be suggested that they contact an arts organization or artist that they have done business with in the past (or will be doing business with).
**CA Address**:
U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services California Service Center P.O. Box 10129 Laguna Niguel, CA 92607-1012
**VT Address**:
U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services Vermont Service Center 75 Lower Welden St. St. Albans, VT 05479
Visa Letters- Request Review Guidelines

1) We will consider issuing letters of support for the following types of visas:
- O1B classification for aliens of extraordinary ability in the arts - O2 classification for personnel accompanying an O1B alien - P1B classification for internationally renowned performing groups and essential support personnel; and, for individual foreign artists performing as a member of a U.S. based internationally renowned performing group - P2 classification for reciprocal exchange program - P3 classification for culturally unique performers or groups, teachers and coaches, and essential support personnel.
2) The following documents must be submitted in order for us to write a letter:
- The I129 - The petitioner's letter - 3 to 4 support letters (if necessary) - The artist's C.V.
3) The application should show the following:
- Any awards or honors won by the artist - A list of companies or cities in which the artist has performed / exhibited - Roles the artist has performed (if applicable) - Any recordings, television appearances or other areas in which the artist is in demand - Support materials such as CD covers, programs, advertisements, etc. which establishes the group or artist. - Information regarding training, particularly for young artists - Statement as to why this particular artist is crucial to the company's production (e.g., a lighting designer who works exclusively with your stage director) - Critical reviews documenting recent public performances by the artist. If reviews are unavailable, evidence of how the artist is regarded in the press or by colleagues or employers. (If the reviews are foreign, include translations) - An itinerary of all events, including dates, names and addresses of the establishments, venues or locations where services will be performed, deal memos or contracts.
4) Eligibility Criteria
Must meet this criterion:
- Do we serve artists working in this vein with our programs and services?
5) Evaluation Criteria
Candidate must meet at least 5 of the following criteria to show extraordinary ability or distinction:
- Are the letters of recommendation from reputable sources? - Is the project in the United States at a notable venue? - Is the project in partnership with a notable artist or producer? - Are the letters of recommendation compelling? - Does the candidate unequivocally possess extraordinary ability in their field? - Are there news articles/reviews in the application that attest to the career accomplishments of the candidate? - Has the candidate been recognized nationally or internationally for their work? (awards, etc.)
6) Internal Review
- Before sending the letter to the requester, letters must be additionally be reviewed by the Program Director, and receive her approval. The Program Director shall be provided with a summary of the evaluation made with respect to each candidate. Particularly controversial or borderline candidates shall be flagged. The Program Director will review visa requests once per week. - All requests will be honored in 3-5 business days. If a 1 day turnaround is required, we will charge an additional $150 (for a total of $350) for the letter. - If the Program Director is unavailable for secondary review, the letters may be reviewed by the Program Specialist in her stead. - Any particularly controversial or borderline requests should be reviewed by the Executive Director before issuing.

Fiscal Sponsorship Basics (CC)

As part of Core Curriculum, Dianne will meet with new employees and discuss the following:
1. Definition of F.S. - Our definition Fiscal Sponsorship is a fundraising tool that enables artists and arts organizations to use some of the benefits of Fractured Atlas's non-profit status to fundraise. This means they can get access to tax deductible donations and grants that are typically only available to nonprofit 501(c)(3) organizations.
- Different models There are many models of fiscal sponsorship. Fractured Atlas operates what is referred to as a Model C or grantor-grantee relationship. Each project has a grant agreement with Fractured Atlas. - History of F.S. (external & internal) - Why it exists - Our business model - Legal & IRS overview - oversight - Theory of change - National Network of Fiscal Sponsors 2. Who uses the program - Examples of two projects - Where they come from - How they find us - How they use the program (temp vs ongoing) 3. The application process - Online app - Eligibility (tax ID, criteria, membership, U.S. address) - Staff and board review process 4. How it works - Contract and program manual - Text reviews - Donations and grants - Fund releases - Annual reports - Guidance/education - Admin fees 5. More resources - Program manual and contract - Webinars - KB - Reading: 6 Ways to Do It Right 6. Member access - Login access to dummy account 7. Future of the program - Microphilanthropy - why, when, how - Board presentation

1. History/Evolution of the FA Insurance Program 2. The Health Insurance program legacy - why we got in - why we got out 3. The structure of our program - MDP - insurance companies - why use FA? 4. What is insurance? - general concepts - Why artists choose to purchase insurance - Insurance as financial security - types of insurance we sell - Commercial Lines - types of insurance we don’t sell - Personal Lines - Health Insurance - Personal Car Insurance 5. Member experience - Map the member experience - application - staff communication - purchase - certificates - claims - endorsements - renewal - Our customer service philosophy
SpaceFinder Basics (CC)

# SpaceFinder 101 (Core Curriculum)
### 1. Assigned Reading (30 minutes)
- [SpaceFinder.org](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/spacefinder) - [Help for Renters](http://la.spacefinder.org/pages/help-for-renters) - [Help for Venues](http://chicago.spacefinder.org/pages/help-for-venues) - [SpaceFinder 2014 Year in Review](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/blog/2015/01/07/spacefinder-2014-year-in-review/) - [SpaceFinder Expands to Massachusetts](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/blog/2014/11/14/spacefinder-expands-to-massachusetts/)
### Extra Credit Reading:
- [Press Coverage Highlights](https://spacefinder.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/203707834-Coverage-Highlights)
### 2. DEMO: Schedule SpaceFinder product overview w/Program Associate (30 minutes) *Note: Assigned Reading should be completed*
Program Associate will sit with you and demo the SpaceFinder service both from the artists perspective and the venue perspective.
