Feature Request Forum Basics (CC)

The [Fractured Atlas Feature Request Forum](/site/knowledgebase/feature_request_list) is an invaluable component of our software's community-driven design. Each program and major service area has a page/forum for feature requests (Artful.ly, Fiscal Sponsorship, Insurance, SpaceFinder, Membership, Visa Letters, Arts Entrepreneurship Awards, Other). ### How New Feature Requests Are Created: If someone suggests an idea that we haven't heard before, we'll add it to the feature request forum so other users can vote on it to show their support. If the request already exists, she'll add a vote to the original request, and sometimes a comment. - A member suggests a new feature through the forum. - An admin suggests as him/herself. - Admin creates on behalf of a member by [logging in as the member](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/admin/Knowledgebase/view_article?id=442), navigating to the feature request forum, and suggesting a new feature. Regardless of who puts the request in the forum, they all get created the same way—by clicking the suggest an idea link in the feature request forum. ![Feature Request Forum with an arrow pointing to the suggest an idea link](http://fracturedatlas.org/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=760 "suggest an idea") Comments can also be added to feature requests in these same three ways, but they all go through the comment field at the bottom of the request. ![Add a commment box on a feature request](http://fracturedatlas.org/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=761 "add a comment") When a new request is added to a forum, the program director receives an email alert. Read this article for instructions on [how to respond to and administer new requests](/admin/Knowledgebase/view_article?id=147). ### How Votes Are Added to a Feature Request: - A member votes on a request - An admin adds a vote as him/herself. - An admin adds on behalf of a member (typically from a customer email) by logging in as the member and voting on the request. - A guest adds a vote. Votes may be cast both the main page of the feature request forum, or when viewing a request in detail. ![a view of the feature request forum with an arrow pointing to the vote button](http://fracturedatlas.org/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=762 "vote") or After adding a feature request or vote on a member's behalf, you should let the member know in an email with a link to the request. Here is an example of some of the boilerplate used when the Artful.ly team responds to a feature request: >Thanks for your interest in Artful.ly and for your suggestion. >This is not a current feature, but we might be able to add it. I've subscribed you a relevant thread in our public Feature Request Forum and voted for this feature on your behalf: <> ><> I have posted this idea to our public Feature Request Forum on your behalf: <> >Please feel free to add comments to this idea or suggest other ideas. If we have questions orsend updates, we will post to this request thread and you will receive an email notification. >As much as possible, we prioritize the features requests with the most votes. >Thanks again for your feedback! Let us know if you have any other questions. ## Related Articles - [Logging in as a member](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/admin/Knowledgebase/view_article?id=442)

Changing Membership Status & Level

**Upgrading** Members can upgrade their membership at any time. They can go to My Stuff → Upgrade Membership. Alternatively, you can upgrade the member by going to the Membership tab in their record and selecting the requested level under the Type dropdown menu. Click Save button to finalize changes. It's also best to confirm that there's a next billing date for the member and that the dues were charged.
_Upgrading to Organization:_ Provide steps for adding users (logging into account → My Stuff → Manage Users → entering user info and clicking "Add User"
**Downgrading** _Downgrading from Organization to Professional: _ This membership level change will leave only one user on the account (the Master User). Make sure that the master user on the account is requesting this change. If not, the master user can send an email to support to confirm that the other authorized user should be made the master user. After they do this, you can promote the other user to Master User and make the membership change (Membership tab in record → Type menu → Select Professional in menu → Click Save button.)
_Downgrading to Community: _ We want to keep our members as part of our community - encourage switching to the Community level if the member does not wish to pay dues or use all our programs and services for the time being. Follow same check procedure as terminating.
**Terminating**
If a member is requesting to cancel their membership, please check for the following:
>_Fiscal Sponsorship tab_: Is the member actively fiscally sponsored by us? If so, check for any fund balance and fund releases. Let the member know that downgrading or canceling their membership will automatically end their fiscal sponsorship with us. If they're okay with that, have them request any remaining funds online and/or make sure to file their Annual Report if they haven't already.
>_Insurance tab_: Check for any open applications (where a staff member is assigned to it) and/or any Active policies. Remind the member that although their active policies will remain in effect until its end date, Fractured Atlas will not be able to service their policies if they downgrade or cancel their membership. They will also not have access to request certificates of insurance online if they are not at a dues-paying level.
>_Artful.ly and/or SpaceFinder tab_: Encourage the member to switch to the Community level if they have used these services in the past. Remind them that at least a Community membership is required to use Artful.ly.
**Reactivating** If a member wishes to reactivate their membership, make sure their Membership Type is toggled to Community and click the Save button (if they were not already Community members when they were terminated). Then click the Reactivate Membership link below the membership range date (underneath the different record tabs). Let the member know that they have been reactivated at the free Community level and provide steps for upgrading if they want to do that online in the future.

Membership Refunds

_What's our policy on refunds?_
We can refund any dues transactions that have occurred in the past 90 days (three months). Any transaction beyond that timeframe will have to be coordinated with the Finance team.
If a member successfully and satisfactorily used our programs and services, we would generally not offer to refund the dues charged during that period.
If a member is requesting to downgrade their membership to the Community level or cancel, and you notice that they have been charged recently, it is a good customer service gesture to simply refund that latest dues transaction and let the member know they should be seeing that refund in the next few days.
_What are the steps to conduct a refund?_ You can refund a dues transaction by going to the Transactions tab in their record and clicking Refund button. Let the member know they should be seeing the refunded dues in the next few days. If a transaction has a Void button instead of a Refund button, this means that the transaction has not been settled by us yet. If you click Void, you can let the member know that the charge will not post to their account (if they seeing a pending charge, it should drop off).
If a member is asking to refund dues and also a monthly donation they might have set up for the Fractured Atlas General Fund, please check in with Development Associate (or whoever is handling monthly donations for the FA General Fund) before refunding any charged contributions. If any donations to us are refunded, please let Development team know via email.
NOTE: A member will NOT be sent a notification/email confirmation of the refund.
Resetting Passwords

You can reset a password by going to the member's record and heading to their Membership tab. There is an unlock icon that you can click (located under their username/email address info). Once it has been sent, an alert box will open up to confirm so.
Resetting a password will send a login reminder with the username and temporary password to the member's email address on file. These passwords do expire (typically we say a day), so please communicate to the member that they should be using the most recent temporary password sent to them if they have repeatedly been trying to reset their password. Prompt the member to change their password by going to My Stuff → Change Password. The Old Password field will be the temporary password they just used to log in.
Changing a Member's Credit Card Info

Any authorized user on the account can change their billing information over the phone, but only the Master User can update it online.
**Here are the steps you can send by email: **
1) Log in to [www.fracturedatlas.org](http://www.fracturedatlas.org) 2) Go to "My Stuff" → "Billing Info/History" 3) Update your billing information and click "Update Billing"
** Updating over the phone:**
Make sure you are speaking to an authorized user on file with us. If you are not, provide the steps for the Master User to do so online. You can edit the CC info by going to the Membership tab for the record. If you scroll towards the bottom, you can click "Change Number" link to enter a completely new card on file. Make sure to get all the updated info before clicking the Save button. If dues are owed, you can ask the member if it's okay to go ahead and charge the membership dues on the updated card (otherwise it will go through the next day automatically).
Special Purchases/ Out of Band

For transactions that cannot be captured through the website, you may do so manually as an out-of-band purchase or a special purchase. You may select either option on the Member profile page.
![enter image description here](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=673 "enter image title here")
**Out-of-Band**: This charge is for when a policy is purchased outside of an online application (or for specific endorsements) when we have the information for the carrier and type of insurance in the Helpdesk. It may be split into a binder fee and premium:
![Out-of-Band](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=674 "Out-of-Band")
**Special Purchase**: For insurance, this is for when we do not have the information for the type of insurance in the Helpdesk. It may be paid for by the CC on file, a new CC, or through a fund release if the full amount is available.
PLEASE NOTE: Before charging a Special Purchase, confirm with the Program Director and Controller, as these charges would not be billed in the manner an out-of-band purchase or on-site purchase would be.
![Special Purchase](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=675 "Special Purchase")
Assigning Tickets

Every employee of Fractured Atlas has the ability to assign Helpdesk tickets, but it is normally handled by the program directors who oversee the Helpdesk during the day, who tag and then direct **Unopened Tickets** to the appropriate staff person.
![Unopened tickets](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=668 "Unopened tickets")
**Deleting a ticket**:
A ticket comes into the Helpdesk in the New Tickets quadrant (upper left-hand corner). Occasionally, spam emails appear, which can be deleted.
![Delete a ticket](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=669 "Delete a ticket")
Sometimes, spam looks just like real email and vice versa, so if you are not absolutely certain that it is spam, do NOT delete it. You can always View an email before actually opening or assigning it. Mass emails from members that are not directly for a staff member can also be deleted.
Any tickets that are not spam or should not be deleted should be either Opened or Assigned. We should respond to all inquiries (email or phone) within one business day per our Customer Service Pledge.
**Tagging a ticket**:
![tagging a ticket](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=670 "tagging a ticket")
Every ticket assigned in the Helpdesk must have a tag associated with it; some tickets are automatically tagged when the ticket is created, but others must have a tag (or tags) assigned to them. Only Program Directors have the ability to create new Helpdesk ticket tags, but any employee can tag a Helpdesk ticket as he or she deems appropriate.
**Opening a ticket**:
![Opening a ticket](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=667 "Opening a ticket")
This places you in charge of this Helpdesk ticket: you are now the one handling the issue and you will see it through to its resolution, whatever that might be. Do not open the ticket if it is not for you, or if it is a question that you do not feel comfortable answering.
**Assigning/Re-assigning a ticket**:
![assign tickets](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=671 "assign tickets")
New tickets have a drop-down list of FA employees that you can assign the ticket to. Choose the best employee to handle the question asked.
Sometimes, you assign the ticket to the wrong person. If you've done this, use the "reassign" dropdown menu in the open ticket to select the correct staff member.
If you were assigned a ticket and do not believe you are the best person to answer the inquiry, you can reassign it to another staff member.
**Redirecting a ticket**:
![redirect tickets](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=672 "redirect tickets")
Occasionally an email comes to the Helpdesk that does not belong there; it may be a personal or professional communication that should not be in the Helpdesk or is better handled by the staff member directly (a funder attempting to contact Adam Huttler, for example). Redirecting a Helpdesk ticket completely removes it from the Helpdesk system, leaving no record of it, and so this feature should be used with caution.
Managing Tickets (CC)

**Responding to Tickets**
It is always best to go through your open Helpdesk tickets at least once a week (picking a specific day, like Friday, makes it easier) to close out old tickets and to ensure that you've responded to all emails that need a response. Sometimes, a response can be easily missed, so it's good to look at the most recent email in each Helpdesk ticket chain. To access the tickets assigned to you, select **Working Tickets** under Helpdesk.
![(/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=736 "Selecting "Working Tickets"")](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=736 "enter image title here")
**Closing Tickets**
A Helpdesk ticket should be closed when the issue has been fully resolved. This can be done at your own discretion, but it is usually best to wait for the sender's final email, to confirm that the issue has indeed been resolved. If you feel that the issue has been resolved, but have not received a final email from the sender, you should feel free to close the ticket a few days to a week after your last communication. You can always re-open the ticket if necessary.
![enter image description here](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=737 "enter image title here")
**Creating New Tickets**
Anytime you are working with a member on a specific issue, it is helpful for Fractured Atlas to have a record of it. If it's a phone conversation, note it in the CRM. If it's an email conversation, or something that will eventually involve email communication, create a new Helpdesk ticket by going to the member's file and clicking on **New Helpdesk Ticket**. Keep in mind, your ticket does not have to start out with an email. It will only send an email if "Send Email" is clicked. You can always un-click that and write a message about the issue that can only be viewed internally; notes like this are helpful if you know that further communication with the member on the issue is forthcoming.
![Creating new ticket](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=788 "Creating New Ticket")
**Linking Tickets**
If someone sends an email or Helpdesk ticket that directly relates to a past issue, you should link the new ticket to the existing ticket chain regarding the issue. This way, all communication about that topic is viewable at once, rather than spread across multiple Helpdesk ticket chains. Only link tickets if it's clearly the same issue that is addressed throughout. Do not link a new ticket to an old ticket if it's a new issue, even if it's about an old topic. For example, if the person has an old Helpdesk ticket chain asking about Fiscal Sponsorship, but then sends a new email/ticket about a specific donation, there's no need to link those tickets.
**Recording Information in a Helpdesk Ticket Without Sending an Email**
As stated above, sometimes you want to record something that happened (a call for instance) as a part of the Helpdesk ticket chain, but you don't want to send an email to anyone. You can always unclick **Send by Email** to record a note without it being emailed.
![Deselecting "Send by Email"](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=739 "deselceting Send by Email")
**Importing Emails to the Helpdesk**
If a member has emailed you directly (without going through the Helpdesk) in response to, or about an issue, their email should be linked to their member account so that we have a record of it. To import the email into the Helpdesk, you can either forward the email to support@fracturedatlas.org or, in the reply to the member, BCC: support@fracturedatlas.org. When the email arrives in the Helpdesk, make sure to link it to the appropriate Helpdesk ticket chain (if appropriate) and be sure to assign it to the appropriate member.
**Assigning a Ticket to a Member**
If a ticket is sent through the Helpdesk and it is not already assigned to a member, please be sure to assign it to the appropriate member so that we have it saved in the member's record. If the ticket is assigned to the wrong member, you can always detach it and then reassign it to the appropriate member.
![Assigning a ticket to a member](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=786 "Assigning a ticket to a member")
**Detaching a Ticket**
If you incorrectly attached a Helpdesk ticket to a chain, you can detach the ticket by clicking **Detach from Thread** up by the ticket number. You can then reattach the ticket to a new chain, if appropriate.
![Detach from thread](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=787 "Detach from thread")
**Re-assign Ticket to Another Staff-member**
On occasions where you need to reassign tickets to different Fractured Atlas staff-members, merely select **Re-assign** in the upper righthand corner of the Helpdesk ticket. Once reassigned, the ticket will go into the other staff-member's queue of working tickets.
![Reassign Ticket](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=735 "Reassign Ticket")
**Set a Reminder**
To set a reminder, select the icon in the upper righthand corner of the ticket.
![Set a reminder](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=742 "Set a Reminder")
You will then receive an email reminder to check on the ticket at the time you select from the calendar.
![Set a reminder, Calendar](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=789 "Set a reminder, Calendar")
**Mark a ticket as "Waiting for a Response"**
When you do not need to take action on a ticket but you are waiting for a response, you may select the **Waiting for a Response** icon. The ticket will then drop to the bottom of your queue of Working Tickets.
![Waiting for a Response](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=744 "Waiting for a Response")
**Mark a ticket as "High Priority"**
To mark a ticket as urgent in your queue, you may select the icon in the righthand corner of the ticket. Once marked as High Priority, the ticket will be at the top of your Working Tickets.
![High Priority](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=745 "High Priority")
Your Helpdesk Account (CC)

The Fractured Atlas Helpdesk is the primary tool used to communicate with our members. Below are instructions for some basic functions about your Helpdesk account
### My Out-of-Office
When you are away and not responding to Helpdesk inquiries, remember to set your account to 'Out of Office' - this way customer service can be coordinated as needed.
1. Go to HelpDesk 2. Go to [My Out of Office](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/admin/Helpdesk/ooo_form) 3. Click 'I'm Away" and SAVE 4. You'll notice a cute little "Gone Fishin" sign appear
![Gone Fishin'-Out of Office HelpDesk](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=654 "Gone Fishin'-Out of Office HelpDesk")
*Pro Tip: Schedule a reminder to turn this off on the day you return back to work *
### My Signature Your signature will automatically be added to every Helpdesk ticket you write a response to. Check with your supervisor on what your signature should say.
1. Go to Helpdesk 2. Go to [My Signature](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/admin/Helpdesk/signature_form)
***Pro Tip: Signatures DO NOT allow for formatting or hyperlinks - keep it simple***
### My Auto-Reply
Auto-replies are sent out by email whenever you are assigned a helpdesk ticket (even if you assign it to yourself). Check with your supervisor on best practices for enabling this setting.
1. Go to Helpdesk 2. Go to [My Auto-reply](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/admin/Helpdesk/autoreply_view)
### My BCC Settings
It is common when a new staffer is in training that all their Helpdesk tickets be cc'd to a supervisor for the dual purpose of coaching and quality assurance.
1. Go to Helpdesk 2. Go to [My BCC Settings](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/admin/Helpdesk/bcc_form)
***Pro Tip: To remove BCC settings, delete the BCC email and save the empty form to overwrite***
2009 October Staff Meeting Minutes

### 2009 October Staff Meeting Minutes
9/29/2009 Staff Meeting
**Adam H.:** Adam spoke briefly about the two big ancillary tech projects for 2010, ATHENA and the Bay Area Cultural Asset Mapping project: ATHENA is likely to receive $350K from Mellon, on top of the $100K secured from Doris Duke. However, Mellon is sensitive to Gemini working on it so there will be little to no synergies with anything else, meaning more flexibility with staffing configurations for the project. More details soon! The latest update on the Bay Area Cultural Asset mapping project is that the Hewlett Foundation has invited FA as a finalist! – Both of these tech projects will expand FA’s identity and our organization’s abilities to serve the field in various capacities.
Alfresco snafu was a common complaint from Emily and others, mainly due to lost insurance data. Adam H. suggested we use Alfresco version backups until we figure out how to prevent data loss from permissions issues (and other “weirder” issues). However, opening up all permissions on folders would compromise the standardized maintenance system that has been put in place.
-> Dianne and Emily granted highest permissions in order to better maintain work on Alfresco.
On the topic of sprinting to keep moving over files: there is still work to be done! A sprinting night needs to be scheduled soon to give everyone a chance to finish. Adam H. is going to Budapest (Oct 16-18) for Opera Europa. University of Wisconsin at Madison’s arts admin program also invited him to talk. The emerging leader program is also potentially having a conversation with him, via WNYC, later this month. Adam’s op-ed ran this Sunday, as well.
**Dianne:** Read Zappos article on customer service attitude – which is relevant in light of time recently spent on the phone assuaging an upset member. Are we not fostering an encouraging, positive attitude already? Positively spinning the info that we deliver to our members is always a good strategy that we tend to already practice, but when a member interferes with the staff’s ability to offer good customer service to the rest of the members, a line needs to be drawn. In some cases a member may be better served (emotionally) by a fiscal sponsor that offers more “intimate” and personalized relationships.
To what extent is customer service excellence within FA’s hirees, and to what extent is that a function of the organizational culture? Should star members and difficult members be given special flags viewable by staff? Adam will revisit the idea. Suggestion that Tim Cynova be tasked with delivering cookie cakes *via segway* to very, very special members.
Juliana and Dianne’s absence for fiscal sponsorship work in CA – September 30 through Oct. 13 (for Juliana) and Oct. 19 (for Dianne). Dianne will be online almost every day, and Kara and Rafael have been prepped for coverage for this period.
Emily Bowles complained about the member spotlight section – what are the criteria for selection? Do people read them? Juliana mentioned that some members really value them. Adam H. believes that the profiles are a good thing, and that the links established by profiled members bring in a lot of extra attention, in addition to giving us a human face and the impression of ongoing art production (rather than sterile, abstract service provision). A.H. wants to continue highlighting the diversity and breadth of the FA community. But as for managing the member profile system, Emily Bowles needs to be given more specific direction.
**Adam N.:** Two new Open Arts Network partners! United Arts of Central Florida and Fashion Research Foundation (the latter in Second Life).
Also, traveling from 10/2-10/6 in Atlanta (Foundation Center event, talk with Alternate Roots, talk with Athens and OCAF area arts councils, meetings with local orgs) and 10/7-10/16 in LA (college visits and meetings with those in music, arts ed, and dance).
**Tim: On Philly news:** Lois Welk, Director of Dance/USA Philadelphia, and chair of the Philly council, will be attending the board meeting this Saturday, Oct 3.
**Triathalon follow-up: **in spite of rainy weather there was a definite staff morale boost provided by the triathalon, which is vibrantly apparent in the wild-style video that Emily cobbled together out of sheer love. Some of us have signaled enthusiasm for a repeat occasion down the road (sans crap weather, of course).

**Lessons of Fundraising **
1. Diversify funding sources 1. Diversify funding materials 1. It’s the board of directors, stupid 1. Advice and Money: the relationship – TAKE BOTH 1. Fundraising Anytime, Anywhere, Any Season 1. The Solicitor’s Magic words – always please and thank you 1. The right way to ask – connections – the web of who knows who 1. Shoe leather trumps mail – always go places, walk in the door, face to face 1. No is not an answer – don’t give up, maybe later or another time – keep trying 1. Baseball, not a college exam – work on team 1. Fundraising as an apple pie- it’s easy, giving people opportunity to give 1. Fundraising is a team effort – back to #10 1. Practice, practice 1. Philanthropy is biography – research, do your fucking homework 1. Speed and agility – better to have rough draft faster than a good letter later 1. The Corporate/Nonprofit meeting place – always find connection 1. School of Hard Knots – it takes a long time 1. Early money the best kind – person who give early gives twice 1. Donors crave recognition 1. Merit matters 1. Reputation hard to acquire, easy to squander 1. Communicate early and often 1. Roles that fundraisers play – part detective psychologist 1. Plan and prepare 1. Spread the gospel – tell them to ask everyone they know 1. Fundraising is all about tomorrow –plan plan plan 1. Leaving a legacy – come out better and stronger than you came in

### STAFF MEETING MINUTES
June 8, 2009 (Marie)
**ACTION-ABLES**
- The ongoing social media strategy was created and is accessible on the wiki. Please review and sign up. - FA Triathlon teams (both active and support) are being formed for an event on September 27. Those interested should speak with Tim. - Tim will schedule multiple dates for wiki sprints in June and July. - An RFC for a FA virtual conference will be set up.
**Guest Presentor - Caron Atlas, Place + Displaced**
Caron Atlas—Featured guest speaker presenting information on Place & Displaced. Caron sees herself as an organizer working to connect the arts with other industry sectors around issues of social change. She seeks to raise awareness among artists that the arts cannot self-perpetuate their own marginalization. P&D began with mapping 3 neighborhoods in Brooklyn which included: Williamsburg, Greenpoint, and Bushwick around the interrelated phenomena cultural vitality of a community, gentrification, and displacement. The next area beginning now is Long Island City, with the Chocolate Factory as one of the partners. The philosophy behind the project simply is that information is important to make change. In other words, data and stories are necessary to make compelling arguments: information is power.
The process of mapping the arts in a community began to play around the issue of “visibility,” and hence, inclusion vs exclusion (“Are you on the map or not?” P&D kept hearing from and/or coming across individuals who were not on the map). This brought up the questions around the definition of an “artist” ie., “Are you a baker that bakes and is creative or do you just bake? Where is the line?”
The project also brought to the light the issues around “community building,” as some communities had propensity to be extremely polarized. By contrast, it became apparent that there exists overlaps and alliances among different communities (ie. Manufacturers who are also artists).
The methodology of the project is based upon “participation action research” which involves having key partners well respected in the community to lead the research from within (vs an external organization infringing or encroaching a community). This helps to ease suspicions by the community members. The process is inclusive and slow. It approximately takes about 1 year for each neighborhood. Examples of partners include: El Puente, Arts in Bushwick, Williamsburg Gallery Association, North Brooklyn Development Corporation. The project also involves augmenting any existing available data, (as arts and cultural mapping has become a popular practice) for instance, that of the Americans for the Arts. The information for Brooklyn is currently being massed and organized, while Adam Huttler is working on building the interactive map, with search functionalities. It will include neighborhood tours in video format, (whereby you can see, for instance, hidden sites where art in the community exists, ie. Subterranean site of a brownstone in Brooklyn where teaching artists help children learn how to read).
The survey part of the project includes questions like: “How do you connect to the arts? What’s your deal in the arts?” It also involves questions on social networking like: “Do you feel you are a part of this neighborhood? Are you involved in community activism?”
A number of people have asked whether P&D has a stance or a policy/agenda it supports, but there are none predetermined policies, in order to remain true to the methodology of “participatory action research.” We are aware that displacement is occurring, and hints are provided in the survey results, which can inform policy at a later point.
Many questioned the integrity of the methodology of the project, and much time was devoted in the beginning to heed well the advice of social science research experts. Developing the survey took several months. There is a possibility for the project to be open-sourced at a later point after the 1st curated version. Currently Rockefeller is the biggest funder with a 2 year grant, applicable for 3 sites. There are several other funders as well.
The best attempt of an elevator speech for P&D (as it is a difficult project to describe), includes the following: “Information is part of policy making. It involves making ties within communities and de-marginalizing artists. It’s focused on building healthy communities via basic political literacy in community activism (ie. Learning about what a community board is and how individuals can become a participant in it.” There were high expectations by some that the project would evolve into a separate service organization. However, one key consequence is to result in basic educational workshop on political community organizing. P&D has new logo which is a Venn diagram.
**Featured Presentation**
Kirsten Nordine gave a presentation on Artspace Projects.
**Ask the ED: Adam Huttler**
There are two efforts concentrated in the Philadelphia area which include bringing PA Spaces to Philly and marketing the Aetna health insurance plans.
Also, in the process of identifying candidates to establish a Philly Advisory Council to serve as ambassadors for Fractured Atlas. The idea is for this group to serve as a template model for other cities. Ars Librera has a new name -- ATHENA = Advanced Technology Hub Extensible Network for the Arts. Open source software featuring seamless integration of applications ie. Ticketing and donor relationship management. Two interns will jointly develop a spec figuring out the necessary functional requirements for the 1.0 version (with the on ticketing first).
There will be a cash option for health insurance if an employee is able to obtain comparable or better coverage from another source (ie. Spouse).
Wiki: include one page with all links of frequently recommended outside resources for members (ie. VLA, Actor’s Fund) in one centralized location as well be included within the respective program departments. A wiki sprint was suggested again in order to update it and reorganize as a true functioning wiki as a narrative with an organic interlinked flow. Before a sprint is organized, a tutorial and structure should occur ahead of the wiki renovation.
RFC Re: Social Media It will be an ongoing strategy with a check in every 3 months. The goals and focus can be viewed in the wiki with the central theme of participating in social media beyond just “talking” about FA.
An RFC was suggested in order to discuss the idea of an FA conference to be hosted virtually. May be related to Fractured U can be conceived as interactive webinars.
FA will be conducting a feasibility study on starting a captive insurance company for the liability program (hopefully fully subsidized by MDP). The point in doing so would be to keep the premiums instead of passing it off to external insurance companies. It would also allow for FA to have more control and flexibility in providing insurance orgs or projects that are now deemed as too “risqué” or offensive by traditional insurers.
MDP will still serve as the General Agent under this new model. An update to the liability software is occurring now regarding renewals.
An FA Triathlon Team has been officially started by Adam H., Elizabeth, and Tim. The event is based in NJ on 9/27/09. An additional sprint team will include Emily, Juliana and Avi. Adam has reached out to the Board, and it is likely that we will field another spring team as well. For those not actively participating, cheering groups will be formed for more festive activities on the road. Special cycling jerseys/tees will be made. Conceived as a fundraising event, there are plans to be able to accept pledges. Alex is working on cultivation event opportunities.

**Huttler ** **- Response to 360 Review:** Some people feel I should slow down when making decisions. Don't be afraid to ask questions when I'm doing this. I'll try to improve. In terms of feedback, some people felt that they've received good feedback, whereas others want more. It's never a problem to ask for feedback -- I'll be better about offering it. Program director check-ins... Are these useful? On one level, they are frequent, but we cancel them a lot. Would it be more useful to have a monthly meeting where we try NOT to cancel and that we reschedule if it needs to be postponed. (Response from staff was mixed... We could go either way.) Maybe we can do it on a per-person basis depending on what you want. Staff were sympathetic to the stress I face with web-related stuff, but were very frustrated when things blow up since it creates more work. Staff wants more web stuff delegated to Gemini. Huttler would love to give 80% to Gemini (there is some stuff he likes doing), but the problem is that it's harder than you think to pass it off to other people. Most of the code isn't documented and exists in my head. I'm trying to move in the direction of transferring everything over. It's not a "flip the switch" kind of thing. I'm optimistic that within the next year, we'll have some progress on that front. Comments about me zoning out during conversations. I'm aware this is a problem. Punch me in the nose when you see me doing this. Usually, I'm still taking in information, but sometimes I'm in Neverland thinking about something else that was triggered by your conversation. The other thing people mentioned was that I spend too much time working on Misnomer's Board while at work. I like and believe in their work, but I'm doing Misnomer's Board with my FA hat on because it gives us access and face time that I couldn't get otherwise (Ben Cameron, Rock Fdn, etc). It's the best face time since I'm not asking them for face time for FA. It's great for relationship-building. If I can succeed in getting AEP built on Ars Libera, it will add so much to Ars Libera. There are a lot of deep synergies between Misnomer and my work here. I will continue to do projects like this so that I'm seen as an expert in the field.
- Getting more interesting resumes from the Yale folks for internships. I want to give an intern something real since they aren't paid much, but that requires you provide a lot of supervision. The only way I think we can make it worthwhile is to get great people and give them a project that they can own completely. We just define deliverables. I'm putting two people, at least, on an Ars Libera project. Ticketing and maybe donor management. These interns would put together a needs assessment and functional spec. Talk to fundraising professionals, what they like about Raiser's Edge and Tessitura. The deliverable would be a spec that I can give to developers to build. I interviewed Devon Smith who I liked and I invited her to do this. We will pay about $10/hour. Devon might not be able to do it. I have another interview next week. This project can easily expand to meet the labor capacity available -- I'll take up to three people. I want grad students who are really smart and don't need to be handheld during the process. Need people who know a lot about the field. (Marie: Any way we can have a design intern?) I'm open to it, but my hesitation is that you need to have a long-term design person generally. Do you have someone in mind? (Marie: No, but I know people that can point us in the right direction.) The guy who was doing the Fractured U. work is a really great designer. He worked at an elite branding firm doing design work. His aesthetic is good for us. I'd like to give him one or two assignments. Justin has committed as an intern for 15-20 hours a week for 8 weeks or longer. He'll be working here in the office. Haven't set a start date yet.
**Lowbridge **
- Narrowed Program Associate search down to three candidates, who will meet with Huttler next week. It depends when they will start. Two out of three can't start until mid-May and one can start after giving two weeks notice. We didn't set a deadline -- we wanted to find the best person possible. We interviewed 15+ people out of 150+ submissions. We won't do more interviews. May 15th is the latest -- not ideal, but it is what it is. (Emily and Juliana: We need someone ASAP. We are staying very late, working from home, and not getting everything done. We might need two new people. It seems like something happened this week or last -- maybe NPR -- but the last three weeks have been overwhelming and we're starting to make minor mistakes because we're working so quickly. Call and email volume is huge. Healthcare and grant reviews have gone up. We walked out at 7PM with 17 unanswered voicemails. Checked things on vacation as well. We'll make it to 5/15, but it's hard.) Hiring a second person might be a possibility we can look into. (Huttler: It make might sense to get two people if we can. Let me look at the numbers and see if it's realistic. What percentage of the overwhelm factor falls in the category of admin work vs. content matter expertise/customer service.) (Emily: I have a fair amount of admin work that is admin work, but that takes time.) (Juliana: QB and other logging is a time suck, which I know will end soon since we will only have to log things in one place.) (Huttler: Because of uncertainty with healthcare and with some of the roll-out of automation software, I want to make sure this person would have enough to do.) (Staff: But we're blowing up and we'll need new people soon anyway.) (Emily: I'm under water with Liability Insurance and am caring more about the famous people applying, which isn't good.) (Huttler: Well let's see what we can do about hiring another person.) (Huttler: Alex, we should talk about making Community Members a good individual donor base and work on a campaign for this.) (Alex: Agreed.)
- Adam and I haven't talked about my managing director transition yet, but we will later today. April 16th is Tim's first day. More on this soon.
**Natale ** - Went to APASO. Great conference. Theatre Bay Area wants to do PA Spaces with us and has funders basically lined up for the project. (Staff: This will be great. San Francisco is a great place to start.)
- Talked to students at the School of the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. Small, but good, as expected.
- Want to have a social media marketing strategy. How are we using Facebook, Twitter, etc? Want to make sure we use each in tandem and are sending the same message. (Huttler: Let's have a task force to develop this strategy. Let's leave Emily Bowles out of it for now. Who is interested?) (Marie, Kirsten, and Natale are especially interested. Others are also interested, but we will wait until Tim is here.)
- Went to Arts Advocacy Day. Spoke at an Emerging Leader Symposium at American University, which went well. Spoke to a legislative aide for Rep. Dan Maffei (D - Syracuse, NY) and got to meet the congressman as well. My friend is his chief of staff. Also went to a session on advocacy on healthcare and the arts, but it was mainly about using art in therapy. Very little dedicated to artist healthcare plans. Huttler is on some advisory group for this, which he doesn't like being on.
**Ortiz ** - Ceased enrollment for all NY plans. Those plans are probably going away anyway and we're attracting the wrong crowd (lots of over 50's, which isn't good for these plans). Looking at the healthcare plans on the whole, we want to look at what value we can bring and what niche market we can serve. We want to fill a need and do something no one else is doing. I see it as a way of bringing the HC program in line with everything else with what FA is doing. There are three strategies we are going to try:
---> Although I've never wanted to do this before, we might try doing small group plans in NY for employers. We can't do this in other states, but laws might change. We would serve as the broker for this plan. Smallest group plan would be for two people. (Huttler: I bullied Marie into offering this. We have great brand recognition in NYC, that it would be easy to leverage this to get meetings with Managing Directors and convince them that we could serve them better than their current brokers. There could be synergies with the Liability Insurance program as well. Instead of having Marie talking to some crazy person over 50 for hours, she can spend 30 minutes on the phone with a managing director and they'll stay with us year after year.) (Lowbridge: What about the revenue structure?) (Huttler: The only incentive is that we're Fractured Atlas and it's a free service to help you with your plans.) We wouldn't deal with their employees, just the heads of the organization making the decisions. It's an HR thing for them. It saves us time. (Huttler: You would have to have actual employees to get these plans. If there is credibility to leverage, we can provide them with all of their insurance needs.) I'm worried about tracking renewals, but we can build it into the software spec.
---> The second strategy is broker-service model. Advertising as a free service, but removing basic customer service (very specific questions about the plans). Aetna is willing to cut some of their marketing budget to do an awareness campaign. (Huttler: Aetna wants to do the customer service.) But, Aetna could start poaching our members. There is no way of calling customer service without calling sales first. (Huttler: We need to talk about that.) (Lowbridge: But the whole thing is that members are trained to call us with those questions.) There would be education surrounding the plans that Aetna would provide -- cool, hip, and targeted towards our main segment of members. All we're getting is people in CA who are over 50. I want to target our demographic. Make an education component so that there are no qualms about buying and that it winds up being just transactional. Drill down to the most important things about health insurance. Here are the things you need to know and here's how you can buy it. Building awareness that way so they can easily decipher differences between plans will make the process less time consuming. The people we want on these plans... they don't want to think about getting health insurance. So, we'll make it easy for them. But, Aetna won't be caught up on technology until 2011. So that makes this hard. (Huttler: But, we've gotten some clarity on this recently. Healthcare companies went to Congress and are now willing to do guaranteed issue plans if Congress does a government mandate requiring everyone to have insurance. This would be great for us and Congress was extremely interested, which is surprising, as people think it feels un-American. The healthcare companies proposed a riff on Hillary Clinton's campaign plan. It sort of makes sense.) But, we would need to see what this mandate would look like. The biggest hurdle would be getting over the fact that this is coming from the insurance companies and not from Congress itself.
---> The third model focuses on education and advocacy, with some ad hoc recommendations of certain insurance plans. This would be through eHealthInsurance, which is great and takes like 15 minutes to get insurance through. We could become a part of their referral service and get $40 per app that's submitted through them. They take care of all customer service.
- All three strategies would go together. We would then be planting seeds for if the new administration changes things, we've built brand recognition and trust with our members and then they can come to us. We would be ready when and if we do have a plan again. (Huttler: We can dodge the "why go through FA if they aren't cheaper" by saying "we offer a free service, here's what we do for you." Might not solve everything altogether, but it's a reframing.) I think people still want to know the added, tangible value. (Gray: It's "go try doing this yourself.") We would schedule appointments with people. They fill out an intake form and then I sit down with them for 15 minutes and answer their questions. Program Associates can handle this. (Gray: This model drives home the value and I can get funding for it.) (Huttler: It's a major reframing that I feel really optimistic about.) And people won't call me three times a day. I'll only talk to them during the meeting. All three strategies will be tried in parallel. I like eHealthInsurance the best. These changes will roll out in the next three month.
- We need to meet about NY Health Foundation. We should just pin all of these things on HIP and their restructuring, price increase, and possibly going to drop us. (Gray: They know their shit. We have to make sure we know our message going in.) (Huttler: Have Marie and I on the call with you.)
**Watts ** - ShowBiz Expo was not especially interesting or exciting. Bob, Meghan, Cynthia (E&O attorney who was awesome... she is an artist, too), Alex, and I. Fewer people there this time around. Bob felt good about it. I hated it. We need a new banner -- we don't do marketing or fundraising and that's what everyone asked about. Lots of people have called wanting us to buy ad space. We should only do it once per year, if that. We had three people sign up so far. Lots of annoying phone calls resulted from it. We'll probably do it in the spring. (Arwen: It's not our demographic.) I'll keep an eye on who signs up and if they do anything.

### March 2009
Staff in attendance: Adam H, Alex, Adam N, Arwen, Marie, Emily, Juliana, Kirsten
Alex presented on Christo and Jean Claude and the logistics of large-scale public art.
**Huttler: **
- purchased rugs for the West Wing which should be arriving shortly; - updated us on the status of Ars Libera: the Mellon Foundation has given a soft commitment for funding for the fall, ticketing software will come first - updated us on P&D: he will be going to California to advise on a cultural mapping project in Silicon Valley, East Harlem is still in the running for the third neighborhood of P&D - the move to the document management system is in progress and the final move will happen soon - discussion on the FA healthcare plan, flex spending accounts, possible switch to two plans pending more research, one that we currently have and possibly a high-deductible plan with an HSA
Lowbridge:
- brought up the possible need for a conference room schedule: from here on it will be done through Zimbra's calendar with conference@fracturedatlas.org - we currently have 28 applications for the Program Associate position and will begin calling people the week of March 9 for interviews - attending an event for Yale School of Management to search for an intern and an NYU event to talk about general FA things on Saturday - alerted us that quarterly budget reports will be out the week of March 9 - discussed a "wiki sprint" where we all spend time together updating and standardizing the wiki - facilitated a discussion on the possibility of an "FAQ sprint" as well
**Gray:**
- explained the upcoming cultivation event on March 12, asked that FA staff try to attend and bring friends
**Natale: **
- facilitated a discussion on potential changes to the development grants: final decision appears to be to combine into one program and rename "micro grants" but keep funding options broad. In addition the grants committee may have some changes made to it as well as a discussion to clarify exactly what they are looking to fund - announced new Open Arts Network partners: New York Women in Film and Television, Pittsburgh Arts Council - described his experience attending a Savannah College of Art and Design career fair and commented that career fairs are probably not good uses of staff time but events specifically targeted to giving information to students might be more useful - updated us on the progress of Fractured U: the software development is progressing and Kamal is working with instructors to develop classes - facilitated a discussion with Lowbridge regarding the most recent LA trip to let us know that it was quite successful; the next trip is being planned for April or May to focus on dance and music - provided us with the results of the annual member survey in which many things remained the same, including the tendency to think of us as being smart but slow and too New York-centric. The possibility of including program-specific questions in the survey was discussed and generally agreed upon as well as the potential for deploying uservoice for comments and piloting programs outside of NYC; some edits to the healthcare portion of the website to minimize the focus on New York were discussed.
**Watts: **
- described the two new liability programs that will be launched shortly: fine art coverage and travel accident insurance - discussed the upcoming Showbiz Expo and facilitated a discussion as to whether it is worth our time: the decision was that we will do it again this time with some small changes and see if we can track the efficacy in order to more accurately determine the impact of the event
**Nordine: **
- informed us of the progress of the Musician's Residency competition that is being conducted: a meeting will be held Wednesday to review submissions and select the recipients - NYCPAS will shortly be sending out their annual survey to the spaces included in the database to ensure the accuracy of their information

Indirect calculated based on percentages; we have no direct control over that as it is based on overall average of all of our time. October Board meeting approved this year's budget.

**Alex:** Restricted reflects spent not received; more money coming in from Eugenie and Horace for NYCPAS that will arrive in Q2. Some things are high, some things are low for various reasons.
**Adam Huttler:** whatever he has plus “Ask the ED”. Board meeting Saturday, presenting at APAP Saturday morning, Ian and Huttler meeting with Hewlett in SF for BACAM next week, Missouri State University Public Affairs Conference in a few months, delivering keynote speech. MSU, part of public affairs program. “New models” speech. Meeting with Chair of NEA from Reagan era this afternoon. Adam's chair is slowly but steadily breaking. How to aggregate and present information about US artists performing abroad already and how to increase US cultural diplomacy. May be a technology component to this but Adam will help him see the light. Possible consulting gig for FA?
**Jungle Disk:** we have an open HD ticket with them, Justin has not received an awesome response. He and Huttler have discussed possible other options including windows share instead of jungle disk.

W2s should be coming shortly. 1099 will be done this week (hopefully) and we'll get a PDF of them directly. Monday Marie and Alex leading ice cream social/branding session. There may not actually be ice cream.
Diversity task force being chaired by Alex. If you're interested in participating let her know. Michelle sent comments on our session over to Tim, including recommendations, which he shared with Adam and Alex. Michelle also forwarded two books for our possible use.
**Where have you been, where are you going:** Adam is going to Phoenix next week for emerging leader council; Ian got elected to the council so congrats. Adam renewed for another three years but is only intending to stay on for one year. He considers him to be an emerging rockstar rather than an emerging leader. 17-ish member council. Justin is going to Toronto for Intix supposed to be international ticketing conference but may be more North American. 2010 April Staff Meeting Minutes

### Staff Meeting April 1, 2010
(Pretty much everyone was in attendance and there were no pranks.)
**Quarterly budget reports**
Tim reminded everyone that each quarter carries less weight than the one before it for membership dues. We’re doing well on investment income due to the fact that we budgeted very conservatively. There is a 433% surplus right now (end of Q2).
**Adam Natale:**
Professional Development - Hopefully revenue will increase, we’re sending out more letters to immigration attorneys.
Open Arts Network - No earned revenue for this program, but we did receive $20K from the NEA. Expenses are just travel and payroll.
**Dianne/Fiscal Sponsorship:**
- We’re on target for the money released this quarter. - Slightly behind on direct fees (rush fees, consultations, etc.) - On target for the amount of money that projects are supposed to be earning. - (At this point there was a question about the point of the budget reports. Adam Huttler suggested that we use more of a narrative for the budget reports. What do the numbers mean about the health of the program? The point of the budget reports is for the Program Directors to have greater conceptual responsibility for their own areas and a better understanding of how FA’s finances work as a whole. Justin said it would be helpful to have a breakdown of variable expenses. Tim and Adam said that was doable with advance notice.)
**Emily/Liability Insurance:**
- Number of policies sold is right on track. The money coming in from binder fees is down in Q2; many members buying policies are actually renewing and are paying a lower binder fee. Still ahead of schedule – at 62% right now, expects to come in around 110% overall. - We will be launching 2 or 3 new programs in the next quarter which may impact the numbers (no new programs added in Q2). - Not sure how many more targeted audience groups we’ll find, so growth will probably be about volume and hopefully larger policies (less about adding new programs). - New programs are Instrument Insurance, Craft Artists, and Technicians. - Pocket guide site was launched yesterday: http://www.arts-insurance.info - Not every guide will be printed, we’ll do it on an as-needed basis (half of the dance guides have been given away so far!) - Purpose of pocket guides is two-fold: educational & marketing. - Insurance business cards with the new website have been made.
** Dianne/Fiscal Sponsorship (cont.)**
- We’ve signed an agreement with IndieGoGo to allow our members to raise money for their projects through the site. (Won’t look like our donation page, but the money will come directly to us.) We’re going to test this for a year and see if it brings in any new projects (IndieGoGo currently has 2400 projects on their site. Also talked to Kickstarter but they’re not interesting in partnering with us right now. - We’re about to start allowing projects to accept partially deductible donations by credit card. They’ll actually be able to create giving levels and an entire campaign (we’ll develop more functionality down the road). There has been a huge demand for this. - There will be a webinar info session in a couple of weeks. It will be recorded and maybe posted. The plan is to do two different info sessions – one for projects that are already in the program and one for projects that are interested in joining.
**Justin/ATHENA:**
- We’re hiring 2 ATHENA employees (both Java developers). Gary Moore will start in April and work in Justin’s office (he’s moving here to take the job!). Finn lives in Ireland and will remain there and work as a contractor. (Finn and Justin have worked together before.)
Marie/Health Insurance:
- Income for dues for health insurance went up a little bit. Increased new enrollments since December. More enrollments than we’ve ever had before and not as many terminations (only 1-2/month). - HIP plan went up almost $100 – now our lowest HIP plan is close to $500. Hopefully some of the members will switch to Emblem Health plans (those will go up in September, but hopefully not as much). - Currently we have 193 enrolled in HIP, 198 in Emblem Health, 50 with AETNA.
Ian/BACAM:
- The budget is really dictated by the Hewlett contract. Mostly on target. Lots of travel expenses to go to California. - Next trip in June we’ll be presenting progress report to Hewlett.
**Kirsten/PA Spaces:**
- A lot of what we’re currently working on is actually in the BACAM budget. - “PA Spaces” budget is really only Philadelphia, not much happening. - NYCPAS budget is musicians’ residencies, Mellon Study, a lot of contract labor (David J. and Emily B.), this probably won’t continue into FY11.
**Adam Huttler:**
- Creative Economy Workspace Initiative – it’s a bad budget year but Adam’s optimistic that we’ll get something for this proposal.
**Alex: **
- $50K in senate money, maybe assembly money, DCA money in next Q and the rest of the Mellon money. - Kresge grant contract begins in April? - NEA award letter came today and our amount went up. - Bonus Status Report: Tim reported that our bonus status for the year looks like about 10.5% right now (last year was 8%). Adam H. suggested that we may want to revisit this formula based on some of the new ways we’re tracking things.
**Ask the E.D.:**
- Tomorrow at the Board meeting Adam is presenting his plan for the $750K Kresge grant: - The grant does require us to create two new spaces modules (visual arts and film) plus bring the existing PA Spaces module to 4 new cities. This accounts for roughly $125K - Some of the money will go to an additional hire for ATHENA. This person will focus on user interface and design. - We’re also interviewing PHP programmers now. This person (or maybe we’ll use a few different contractors at first) will address the backlog of work that needs to be done. Adam won’t initially put them on anything that touches money. They’ll be working on the Calendar of Events, “My Stuff”, and the Liability Insurance policy status tracking. - The Development/Marketing Specialist willwork closely with Alex and Tim on development administration, social media management, etc. This will be a full-time position, and they’re open to inside hires. Target is for the person to start in June. - This leaves around $150K, which Adam is viewing as marketing/outreach R & D budget. The idea is to try some experiments – maybe advertising? - Ticketmaster and Livenation merger – the Justice Dept. has been going to the Future of Music Coalition for advice on various aspects of how this merger might affect the field. FMC asked Adam to participate in an educational campaign for the field on their rights re: the consent decree and how to spot violations. Hopefully this will get us on the radars of music people and get us noticed more in DC. -
**New office info/updates:**
- There’s a punch list for all the things that are still not working in the office, let Tim know if you see anything that looks “weird.” - Tim and Justin are working on the 215 ext. problem. - Still trying to figure out what’s happening with the front desk. The doorbell works and Tim and Justin are installing a motion sensor so we can hear when people enter the office. - The 10th floor is a reentry floor and that door will always be unlocked, so make sure you lock the actual doors to the office. - All keycards now work at front and back doors. - Justin asks us to turn our computers off ALL THE WAY. Try plugging your phone into an outlet other than your power strip and turning your power strip off when you leave the office for the evening. - Tim suggested people pay closer attention to their IM statuses so people know where you are. - We’ll start using the 888-692-7878 # as a contact for members. It’s less NYC-centric.

2010 May Staff Meeting Minutes

### 2010 May Staff Meeting Minutes
**Impact Study**
Interested in conducting an impact study as a way of more formally and rigorously measuring what we do. This would include gathering both quantitative and qualitative data on ROI. Most the nonprofit sector, particularly the arts, has not really caught on to it. It’s difficult to measure more intrinsic impact but there are some in the field already paving the way in this respect with success, like Alan Brown in the Bay Area.
An impact study would be much easier for an organization like Fractured Atlas to conduct since we more closely resemble a social service organization.
The Doris Duke Foundation is a good candidate as a source of funding through their Arts Innovation Program. That program focuses on funding half baked ideas that are new, different, and risky, which could have an impact on the organization and the field.
It would be interesting to find out who Fractured Atlas is serving, or not, and what may be the underlying causes. Most organizations would be scared to find out that they are not making as much as an impact they think they are, but Fractured Atlas must be open to that possibility. This, in turn, would inform future program development. It may be interesting to learn of other impacts we make on the field that we may not be aware of and how our work affects the quantity and quality of art in America.
This type of study would be useful in how a service organization thinks about their programs across the board.

### 2010 July Staff Meeting Minutes
July 1 Staff meeting
Lunch: pizza!
**Presentation by Gary on wine.** Unfortunately, there were no samples. Introduction of FA wine tasting club.
**Adam Huttler/Ask the ED July Monthly meeting:** he’ll be somewhat available while he’s on vacation. Program directors will meet with Tim, and Adam can call in on as-needed basis. Adam probably more available in the morning while on vacation.
Gemini SBS Relationship: Outside people have distorted view of what the FA/Gemini relationship is. Here’s the low-down: Gemini was a wholey owned sub of FA in 2003 for being a broker for HC, and to do software devel for other nonprofits and govt orgs. In 2007, FA sold 60% of stake in Gemini, only holds 40% now. Gemini employees hold other 60% now. Mostly software development now. Gemini budget is $500,000 while FA is approaching $7 million. We pay full price for work we contract from them. Gemini is very insignificant source of revenue for FA, maybe $100,000 in revenue. They do not contribute to FA. FA is share holder and nonprofits can legally own stake in for profits. Huttler owns 20%, Shawn and Dan own 20% each as well. Adam may be the only conflict of interest issue, so he runs big projects past board first. Some funders don’t want grant money to go to Gemini since Huttler is part owner, some funders don’t mind. Justin and ATHENA are completely unrelated to Gemini. For RFPs, moving forward Gemini will probably not be allowed to bid, Justin will decide about software development.
Latest on Future of Music: Ticketmaster/LiveNation merger; since Justice Department decided not to sue to block the merger. They made a deal with Ticket/Nation that they agree to 5 conditions to mitigate risk of anticompetitive nature. Future of Music Coalition (FMC) was brought in to provide oversight and enforcement on the 5 conditions. FA brought in by Future of Music because of expertise on ticketing. We are advising Justice Department on ticketing, also creating consumer guide to this merger and what it means. Also working with FMC on healthcare reform (mostly just high level talks) and also cultural policy coalition in DC is being batteded around. Michael Bracey is DC lobbyist and may be hired by us to do federal lobbying. We are kicking Ticketmaster in the chins since Justice Department can’t sue over merger. We are still not announcing this to the general public.
Board Meeting is July 23rd – If you owe Adam H anything for meeting, please get it done by JULY 12. Emily will be asked to present at that board meeting.

Status Reports
*Athena/Artful.ly (Gary, Justin, Natale)-* - weekly meeting reminder-open to everyone - Moving forward w/ Ron Evans partnership, still confidential unless otherwise told by Justin - Athena 1.0 is in final test mode- any minute now - Artful.ly development progress is going well. *Member Interaction (Tara)* - mention poster initiative to members in conversation- refer to blog post from Tara. In short, we are decorating our office walls with member promotional posters. 16x20 thu 24x36 no returns, not taking actual artwork.
*Health Insurance Change (Marie)*
- Pocket Guides have hit membership. People like. - Discussion: Reform changing healthcare landscape- companies have been responding aggressively in response. Resulting premium increases. Emblem Health instituted re-certification process and minimum income requirement. We lost 30 people as a result.Talking about HC program direction in light of the future and reform and FA as a whole as the current Business Model no longer makes sense. - Not enrolling people any more in NY or elsewhere as of May 1. - Next Step- Play and education/advocacy role- don’t know what that looks like yet, entering exploratory phase. - Points- has to be a better use of our resources, and goal to create larger impact instead of focusing on finite number of individuals. - Developing a webinar (eventually maybe a series) jumping of pocket guide info-educational - LINC/FA coalition- RFP for healthcare reform advertising or health insurance in general campaign. No good proposals thus far except for one. - Not Kicking out any member currently enrolled (about 300) - Will be providing widget for auto-quotes via e-healthinsurance.com.
**Thoughts and Questions**
How to present program moving forward?
There will still be a health insurance section. The program will no longer will steer members to specific plans. The site will act as a platform for advocacy and education. Custumer Service will no longer exist in this area outside of this platform besides what we provide to current enrollees.
Ian- Curious to talk further about how we will fit in with other orgs doing education advocacy work in this area.
Tiffany- Statement to membership? Answer: Quietly flip the switch. For folks that see us through the lens of direct link to health insurance, not necessarily concerned. The same for OAN partners. Access to information about plans is still present in-directly. Message to note: Side effects of reform: association plans are fading/retaliating, are they even necessary?

St. Paul Chamber Orchestra- (Huttler) Hunch that conventional advertising was ineffective-as experiment cut advertising to general budget from 500K to 0- result- NO EFFECT!! Presentation Skills with Will Carlin

In March 2014, presentation and speech coach, Will Carlin conducted a workshop with staff in NYC.
It is hard to capture his presentation in an article, but we've distilled some here. His comprehensive handout is in the Resource Folder of the Netdrive.
### Good Presentations
The best presentations use slides that don’t compete with the presenter in any way. These formatting tips can help you build great slides.
- **Make two decks.** Make one deck just for projecting. This allows you to use fewer words per slide because you will be saying them instead. Make a second version of the deck as a handout for the people who are not in the room. - **Plan for one key idea and 15 seconds per slide.** This will keep your audience attentive. You will need to create more slides with less information per slide. For webinars where audience attention is even shorter, you may want to increase the number of slides and decrease time per slide to 7-8 seconds. - **No more than five bullets on a page.** The only exception is if you are conveying a list. - **All main bullet text should stay on a single line.** Sub-bullets also should attempt to stay on a single line. This means you are going to have to be concise with your wording. - **Eliminate select verbs and articles.** The audience doesn’t need these to understand your meaning. For example, “Nonprofits largely focused on helping others” is missing the word “are.” This is preferable in bullet points. - **Help your audience know where they are. **Use chapter headings that correspond to the words you used in the agenda, and consider putting the same chapter headings on each slide in smaller print so that the audience can keep track. - **Font sizes should stay the same on all pages.** There is an automatic setting in PowerPoint that resizes your fonts to fit the window, so that if you type more text, it will always fit. This means that you may inadvertently have a number of different font sizes in your presentation. It is subtle, but it means that your audience must readjust each time a new slide appears. Your fonts and font sizes should be the same on all pages. Turn off this setting if necessary. - **Replace text with images whenever possible. **Whenever you put words on a slide, they involve the language center of the audience’s brain. The problem with that is that the speaker is also involving the same language center. The brain cannot read and listen at the same time. - **Use eight words or fewer.** Many studies have shown that a listener can take in a maximum of eight words at a time, without losing focus on the speaker. Even better: combine one or two with a picture. - **Fill your slide with a single photograph. **Photographs work unbelievably well to convey information, make a point, and engage emotions. And they work much better if you can see the whole thing. Put words over the image rather than putting words on a slide and then fitting the image around it. - **Use a plain background. **A plain background will show your information best. Black or soft, neutral colors are easiest on the eyes. Avoid bright, busy, complicated backgrounds. - **Use a clear typeface. **Use a simple typeface that can be read easily from across the room. It should have clear, basic shapes and little or no detail. San serif fonts are best. - **Choose a basic transition effect and use the same one throughout. ** - **Use animations sparingly, and only use them when you have a reason for the effect. ** - **Use the Fractured Atlas template for title slides. **
Zimbra Tips

Zimbra is our email client and calendar tool. It's sort of open source Outloook. Here are some tips for using it.
### Sharing Your Calendar 1. Log into Zimbra 2. Click on your **Calendar tab** 3. On the left, you'll see a side bar with a list of calendars. Right click the top one that's probably called **Calendar**. This will reveal some options. 4. Select **Share Calendar**. 5. This opens the Share Properties modal. Type the email of the person with whom you want to share your calendar. 6. Configure the other settings as you please. The default settings are usually good for sharing with colleagues. 7. Click **OK**. 8. This will send the individual an email alert that you have shared your calendar with them. Then he or she can choose to accept the calendar.
### Setting Auto-Response If you are planning to be out of the office for a day or more, it's best to turn this on. 1. In Zimbra, click the **Preferences** tab at the top 2. On the left hand menu, select **Mail** 3. Scroll down to the **Receiving Messages** section 4. Check the box next to **Send auto-reply message** 5. Write your message 6. Set the **Start On** and **End On** dates 7. Click the **Save** button on the top left
If you answer customer service tickets, you should also turn on your out-of-office in the helpdesk.
### Importing your Google Calendar If you use a Google Calendar for personal appointments and want to be able to view it in Zimbra alongside your work calendar, follow these instructions: 1. Go to your Google Calendar 2. On the left side, under **My Calendars**, hover over the calendar you want to sync 3. An expansion arrow should appear, click that and select **Share this Calendar** 4. On the top left, click **Calendar Details** 5. Find the **Private Address** section, click **ICAL** button 6. Copy link from modal 7. In Zimbra, open the calendar tab 8. On the top left, click the **Add New Calendar** button 9. In the modal, assign a name to your Google calendar 10. Check the box next to **Synchronize appointments from a remote calendar** 11. Paste the link in the **URL** field 12. Click **OK** to save
Fiscal Sponsorship Theory of Change (CC)

The fiscal sponsorship program aspires to fulfill the Fractured Atlas mission with the following activities, outcomes, and impacts.
### **Activities**
### Provide online fiscal sponsorship services and software - Continually refine and improve software in response to feedback - Ensure compliance with relevant regulations
### Provide technical assistance to fiscal sponsees - Provide educational materials and training for raising money - Provide staff attention and expertise on an individualized basis - Promote best practices
### **Outcomes**
- Fiscal sponsees satisfy their need for a fiscal sponsor fast and easily - Fiscal sponsees save time getting fiscal sponsorship rather than 501(c)(3)status - Fiscal sponsees get more convenient fiscal sponsorship through FA - Fiscal sponsees pay less for nonprofit status than they do through the IRS - Fiscal sponsees have access to tax-deductible donations - Fiscal sponsees have increased access to grant funding - Fiscal sponsees become better grantwriters and fundraisers - Fiscal sponsees save time and money over alternatives - Fiscal sponsees meet legal/contractual requirements for opportunities
### **Impacts** - Fiscal sponsees have more time and resources to do their work - Fiscal sponsees have fewer barriers to doing their work - Fiscal sponsees are able to raise as much money as possible
![Fiscal Sponsorship Theory of Change](http://fracturedatlas.org/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=790 "Fiscal Sponsorship Theory of Change")
SpaceFinder Theory of Change (CC)

### The SpaceFinder program aspires to fulfill the Fractured Atlas mission following the theory of change outlined below.
## Activities
- Provide local/regional online marketplaces for space rental - Educate venues operators about marketing - Educate venues operators about operating their space - Market the service to a wide audience - Ensure a high quality database of cultural facilities - Populate space marketplace with data - Provide quality assurance on space listings
## Outcomes
- Members of the public visit SpaceFinder marketplaces - Artists visit SpaceFinder marketplaces - Rental venue operators visit SpaceFinder marketplaces - SpaceFinder facilitates new rental transactions - SpaceFinder has a comprehensive listing of creative spaces - Cultural sector stakeholders have better info about cultural facilities
## Impacts
- Artists have fewer barriers to doing their work - Artists have more time and resources to do their work - The marketplace for space is rationalized - Local/regional creative economies are strengthened.
![SpaceFinder Theory of Change](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=653 "SpaceFinder Theory of Change")
