DRAFT - Policy on the hybrid addendum

When a project indicates that they have investors in a fiscal sponsorship application, the following steps must be taken:
1. The Board reviews and approves the project 2. The hybrid addendum is sent to the project to be signed 3. Adam or Tim countersign the addendum and then the project is approved 4. The project is marked in the database as having signed the hybrid addendum 5. If we receive an investment or distribution agreement, Adam reviews it and authorizes staff to provide written consent that it's okay. In Adam's absence, Dianne will review and authorize staff to provide written consent with final approval from Adam or Tim. 6. Projects that have been marked as having signed the addendum will be asked a handful of additional questions in the annual report.
SpaceFinder Regional Team Support

Fractured Atlas maintains a separate knowledge base to support regional teams working on SpaceFinder.
*For example: ArtsBuild Ontario is the regional team for SpaceFinder Toronto.*
Support content is provided in the following areas:
- Press - Social Media - Marketing Collateral Examples - Regional Customizations - Data FAQ - Measuring Impact
[**EXPLORE THE SPACEFINDER REGIONAL SUPPORT FORUM HERE**](https://spacefinder.zendesk.com/hc/en-us)
What SpaceFinder info is displayed on membership record?

### In order to create an account on SpaceFinder a person must sign up for a free community membership with Fractured Atlas.
An account is NOT required to search for or request space, but it is required to do things [save a shortlist of searches to your dashboard](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-share-a-shortlist-of-spaces), or to create a listing. For those that sign up for venue accounts in order to create listings, a SpaceFinder tab will display on their Fractured Atlas member record.
![SpaceFinder info on member record](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=655 "SpaceFinder info on member record")
### Important facts about info on the SpaceFinder tab:
- You will only see a SpaceFinder tab if the member has a venue account - This data is pulled from SpaceFinder database when you refresh the member record - 'Instance' tells you which regional SpaceFinder the member uses (i.e. NYC, Austin, D.C. etc.) - The 'Venue Account' active link will take you to SpaceFinder - If 'Venue Account' is empty it means the venue account is pending approval (or was deleted)
### Important info the SpaceFinder tab DOESN'T DISPLAY:
- You won't be able to tell if the member is paying booking fees to Fractured Atlas (i.e. a paying customer of SpaceFinder) - You won't be able to see all of the members associated with that venue account
### Key Take-Aways
- SpaceFinder database is in a separate location (and form) than the Fractured Atlas database. - A member who has a $0 lifetime value and a SpaceFinder tab, could be a paying customer - A member might be using & loving SpaceFinder to rent space, but not have a tab on their record - When in doubt, don't assume just ping one of the SpaceFinder PAs
Checklist when approving new listings on SpaceFinder

### Approving new listings across SpaceFinder websites is a daily administrative task, usually managed by a SpaceFinder Program Associate.
If you are being trained to approve listings, you will be taught in person. This handy checklist below is for reference _after_ training.
Before approving a listing for publish:
- Confirm venue did not create a duplicate account - Edit space name if it has useless "craigs list-like" descriptive key words (i.e. "dance studio downtown CHEAP!" should be edited to be "dance studio") - Check for typos in the organization information and test website link - Check basic description for typos and edit for clarity - Check hourly and long term rates for accuracy - If no photos are added, then visit venue webpage, Facebook, etc. to see if you can include any. - Select a primary photo that will best represent the listing in search results (well lit, or high contract photos are best, do not select logos)
*Note: Certain regional teams (such as Bay Area and certain Canadian instances) prefer to approve their own listings, check with a supervisor for details.*

Questions to ask a prospective OAN partner organization

### For Fractured Atlas staff members speaking to an organization about a specific program, while also having a hunch they might be a good fit for our Open Arts Network.
Below is a list of questions to help identify if the organization is indeed a good match, and also prime the warm hand off to the FA staff member who manages Open Arts Network.
1. Who are your primary constituents for membership? Institutions? Individual artists? 1. How would you describe your organizations relationship with your members? (i.e. high touch vs low touch, incubator vs training, curator/artist vs service provider/client, etc.) 1. How many members do you have? 1. What are your members pressing needs? 1. What professional development/admin infrastructure support do you currently provide in your programming? 1. How might Fractured Atlas's services buttress or optimize your offerings? 1. How do you envision your organization/membership growing? 1. What segments are most likely to grow?
Note: Membership can be interchangeable with Alumni, Students, Resident Artists, etc.
Setting up Electronic Funds Transfer (EFT)

Before a project can release funds from Fractured Atlas, they must first set up Electronic Fund Transfer. Projects can access the EFT Signup Form at My Fiscal Sponsorship --> Fund Releases --> Sign Up for EFT. They can complete the form and return it to our staff along with a voided check. If a project does not have physical checks for their account, they can send the first page of their bank statement or a letter from their bank. It needs to be official bank documentation that confirms the account and routing numbers, account holder name and address.
Once we receive the form, a staff member will manually enter the EFT information (account and routing numbers, and whether the account is personal or business) under the FS Tab in the Helpdesk. The information should be entered first by looking at the check or official documentation, and then checking that against the information provided on the form. If there's any discrepancy, the staff member should reach out to the project to clarify account and routing numbers. With written permission from the project, the staff member can make edits to the EFT form. Once numbers are entered, the staff member will then save the form in the customer record (date.EFT Signup.projectname). The staff member should then e-mail the project to confirm that EFT has been set up, and that the account and routing numbers are accurate - there's boilerplate for this under the tag, f.s. eft.
Annual Reports

* General Info
All fiscally sponsored projects are required to submit an annual report detailing how funds disbursed over the prior calendar year were spent. Projects are sent an automated email on or around January 1st informing them that the report is due by April 1st. They are sent two other reminder emails prior to the deadline.
Only fiscally sponsored projects who have released funds in a given calendar year are required to submit the annual report. Projects who received donations but did not release funds are not required to submit a report.
Projects can access their Annual Report online through our website by logging-in and following My Stuff-->My Fiscal Sponsorship-->Info/Reports. The report is automatically available to projects once they release funds, although they should not submit it until the calendar year ends or they terminate.
If a project does not submit their annual report by April 1st, their fiscal sponsorship will be frozen, meaning that they cannot process new donations or request new fund releases. Their sponsorship will be unfrozen upon receipt of the report. A fiscal sponsorship staff member needs to manually unfreeze the project - this does not happen automatically.
Staff can view a project's annual report on their CRM under the Fiscal Sponsorship tab. There are staff permissions to edit and delete annual reports. It is almost never necessary to delete an annual report, so please consider very carefully before doing so.
*Report Components
** Project Impact
The Project Impact portion consists of a narrative with three prompts: - Please describe the activities of your project in 20XX. Please share any relevant milestones, achievements, or challenges. - Please describe the people that experienced your work. - What are your plans for the project for 20XX? (the following calendar year)
Projects are asked to review the description they submitted when they applied for fiscal sponsorship. If the description no longer accurately reflects the work that they are doing, they have the opportunity let us know so that we can follow up with them about submitting a revised fiscal sponsorship application for re-approval by our Board of Directors.
Finally, under Project Impact, fiscally sponsored projects enter in numbers about who participated in their work. - How many people paid to experience your work? - How many people experienced your work for free? - Artists Served
** Project Spending
Using the same Expense Category budget line items that are used in the Fund Release Request procedure, projects report their expenditures from the previous calendar year.
They are also asked to estimate the percentage of their total project spending that fell into each category. The total must equal 100%. - Fundraising - Management and general - Programs and services
Finally, they are asked to estimate what percentage of their spending went directly toward paying artists.
** Project Revenue
Fiscally sponsored projects are asked to provide a breakdown of their income. Funds processed through their fiscal sponsorship program are pre-populated into the relevant fields (Individual contributions/Grants and corporate contributions).
If, after the project enters their expenses and income, there's a surplus on the report, the project is asked to provide a description of how their surplus will be spent.
** Work Samples & Documentation
Fiscally sponsored projects have the opportunity to send links and/or upload up to 64 MB of files that are work samples. This is an optional portion of the report.
* Review Procedure
The fiscal sponsorship team regularly reviews annual reports in "sprints" during the months of January-April as reports are coming in.
Review consists of reading through the report narrative and reviewing the updated financials.
[edit]Terminated Members
Sometimes the project will terminate before they have filed the annual report. We have a link that they can use to access just the report, without reactivating the membership. The link is www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/report2008 and add '?termed_fs_id=XXX' to the end (where XXX is the id number for the terminated project).
For example, you could send something like: www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/report2007?termed_fs_id=197
That url would invite Tia Shearer or her cohorts to submit an annual report for FY2007. Remember to change the year for the annual report that is due.
[edit]Active Members
For projects who want to have their project returned to active status, have them submit the report through the website, and then a staff person will review the report and reactivate them.
Nonprofit Rate Requests

Sponsored projects are often eligible to receive discounts from vendors who have a policy of offering a "nonprofit rate". For these kinds of requests, we need to have the name and mailing address of the vendor and the purpose of the request on file so we know what kind of letter to give and how best to provide the information.
In order to request a discounted rate, projects should send our Staff the contact person, company name and address so that we can create a letter requesting the rate in their behalf. There is a boilerplate document found here: Q:\Fiscal Sponsorship\Sales Tax Exempt and Nonprofit Rate Docs - this should be used as a template for the request. The document should be created, saved as a pdf within the Member Folder and then sent to the project so they can send it to the vendor directly. If there are supplemental documents needed (IRS Determination Letter, W-9, etc) they should be attached to the letter and sent as one PDF document.
New Application Procedures

**Application Requirements**
[Applications for fiscal sponsorship](/site/fiscal/apply_instructions) are only available online to professional and organizational members of Fractured Atlas. Our fiscal sponsorship application requests the following information:
Name of Legal Entity Responsible (it may be an individual or a company) SSN or EIN (For an individual we need an SSN; for an unincorporated group or corporation we need an EIN) Project Name (It should be the name used for fundraising purposes) Project Discipline (There is a drop down menu of options) Temporary or Ongoing Project description (Note: Any future changes to this section need to be approved by our Board) Public Benefit Online Profile Text (All sponsored projects are profiled on our website. This should be a general description of the artist or group. Projects may update this section anytime through our website) Summary of Artist Qualifications/Group history Budget Fundraising Prospects, if any (foundations, corporations or individual donors) Whether or not any investors who are not also creative participants will be involved in the project
**Application Timeline**
Applications are reviewed monthly. The deadline for application is 11:59PM EST of the last day of each month. The Executive Committee of the Board meets sometime within the first two weeks of the following month (usually the first Tuesday) to review and vote on applications. Once applications have been approved by the Board, the applicants will receive their notice of approval via email with the fiscal sponsorship instruction packet attached as a PDF. Our goal is to get the approval packet to new projects by the 15th of the month.
**Application Approval Procedure**
Every new application for fiscal sponsorship is to be sent an email confirmation from the program staff stating that the application was received and will be reviewed at the next Board meeting. The Executive Committee of the Board of Directors make up the review panel for all sponsorship applications. All applications are marked "Pending" in the fiscal sponsorship admin panel until Board approval.
All pending applications must be reviewed by our staff prior to the Executive Committee's meeting to monitor any red flags that may exist in the application. If any red flags are found, it is best to contact the member, request clarification and explain that this is necessary to help the application receive approval. Staff should grade the projects as the following:
A - The application should be approved. The staff is confident that the project is a good fit for the fiscal sponsorship program and meets all criteria for approval.
B - The application warrants extra scrutiny by the board. While the staff believes the application meets the criteria for approval, there is something in the application that is unusual or a-typical.
C - The application warrants close, skeptical scrutiny by the board. The staff is concerned that the application may not meet the criteria for approval.
N - This application should be denied. The staff is confident that the project is not a good fit for the fiscal sponsorship program and that application does not meet the criteria for approval.
Staff should send their assessment of the current round of applications one week prior to the Executive Director so he may alert the Committee to any applications requiring extra scrutiny.
Once the Board approves a project, the admin panel should be updated to reflect "approved" instead of "pending". This will generate the automatic link we provide on our website for online donations.
Projects that have been approved will be automatically emailed a fiscal sponsorship instruction packet for their review and records. This email consists of a copy of the Pre-Authorized Grant Agreement and the full Instructions.
Staff must track each project that applies (regardless of approval or denial) for the Ex. Director's quarterly report to the Board of Directors. The report can be found in Q:\Board of Directors\Meeting Supplements\FS Supplementals. The report should include the project name, member name, geographic location, a short statement of activities, the staff recommendation and the Executive Committee's decision. The Executive Director can pull an excel spreadsheet after each set of project approvals containing project name, project description, and state that needs to be edited by the program staff. This spreadsheet should be updated each month by program staff.
Materials for the Arts Procedure

If you are receiving an inquiry about access to Materials For The Arts, you should first verify that the project is currently fiscally sponsored by us. If they are, you should direct the sponsored project to visit the Materials for the Arts website ([www.mfta.org](http://www.mfta.org)) to review the program guidelines and determine eligibility. There is an online application for the artist/arts organization can then fill out. Once they have successfully submitted this form, MFTA will ask the sponsored project to submit an official letter of request to Ms. Harriet Taub at MFTA, as well as supporting documentation of ongoing arts or cultural programming in NYC for at least a year (this would be in the form of brochures, flyers, etc.).
Typically, after the project has done these steps, a representative from MFTA would email us requesting a sponsorship letter for a newly registered applicant. The template for this letter can be found in the shared drive → Programs and Services → Fiscal Sponsorship → MFTA → MFTA_Letter_w_Header. If you open up that document, you can replace the two highlighted sections with the name of the fiscally sponsored project. You would then need to save this document on the desktop (or some other folder where you saves documents) as a PDF file formatted as such "YYYY-MM-DD.MFTA Sponsorship Letter.Project Name". An example of the proper format is as follows:
**2015-10-15.MFTA Sponsorship Letter.7 Train Murals.pdf**
You will also want to upload a copy of the PDF sponsorship letter in the member's files (click the folder icon near the top of the member's account, next to the Quick Actions dropdown menu) before sending it to Hallie Bahn at hbahn@mfta.nyc.gov or whoever from MFTA contacted us for the letter.
If the project has already 1)submitted the online MFTA application and 2) sent in their official letter of request and supporting documentation to MFTA, then feel free to send the sponsorship letter to Hallie Bahn at hbahn@mfta.nyc.gov and info@mfta.nyc.gov.
Membership for our projects at MFTA needs to be renewed annually: MFTA will occasionally send FA an email when a project's membership has expired. Sometimes a project will contact us directly for the updated letter. Once again, just check that a project is still actively sponsored before sending out a new letter to MFTA. In the latter case, you will want to check the member's files to see whether an updated sponsorship letter has been submitted recently to MFTA on the project's behalf or not.
Annual Reports

#General Info
All fiscally sponsored projects are required to submit an annual report detailing how funds disbursed over the prior calendar year were spent. Projects are sent an automated email on or around January 1st informing them that the report is due by April 1st. They are sent two other reminder emails prior to the deadline.
Projects are asked to report on all funds handled by their arts practice in a calendar year, even those that were not handled by Fractured Atlas or our fiscal sponsorship program. This helps for our data collection purposes to have an accurate picture of the project's size, scope, and real-world impact in their communities and disciplines. Additional funds included on the annual report are not reported as income to the IRS or charged our 7% administrative fee.
Only fiscally sponsored projects who have released funds in a given calendar year are required to submit the annual report. Projects who received donations but did not release funds are not required to submit a report.
Projects can access their Annual Report online through our website by logging-in and following My Stuff-->My Fiscal Sponsorship-->Info/Reports. The report is automatically available to projects once they release funds, although they should not submit it until the calendar year ends or they terminate.
If a project does not submit their annual report by April 1st, their fiscal sponsorship will be frozen, meaning that they cannot process new donations or request new fund releases. Their sponsorship will be unfrozen upon receipt of the report. A fiscal sponsorship staff member needs to manually unfreeze the project - this does not happen automatically.
Staff can view a project's annual report on their CRM under the Fiscal Sponsorship tab. There are staff permissions to edit and delete annual reports. It is almost never necessary to delete an annual report, so please consider very carefully before doing so.
#Report Components
##Project Impact
The Project Impact portion consists of a narrative with three prompts: - Please describe the activities of your project in 20XX. Please share any relevant milestones, achievements, or challenges. - Please describe the people that experienced your work. - What are your plans for the project for 20XX? (the following calendar year) These prompts have a 100-word limit.
Projects are asked to review the description they submitted when they applied for fiscal sponsorship. If the description no longer accurately reflects the work that they are doing, they have the opportunity let us know so that we can follow up with them about submitting a revised fiscal sponsorship application for re-approval by our Board of Directors.
Finally, under Project Impact, fiscally sponsored projects enter in numbers about who participated in their work. - How many people paid to experience your work? - How many people experienced your work for free? - Artists Served
##Project Spending
Using the same Expense Category budget line items that are used in the Fund Release Request procedure, projects report their expenditures from the previous calendar year.
They are also asked to estimate the percentage of their total project spending that fell into each category. The total must equal 100%. - Fundraising - Management and general - Programs and services
Finally, they are asked to estimate what percentage of their spending went directly toward paying artists.
##Project Revenue
Fiscally sponsored projects are asked to provide a breakdown of their income. Funds processed through their fiscal sponsorship program are pre-populated into the relevant fields (Individual contributions/Grants and corporate contributions).
If, after the project enters their expenses and income, there's a surplus on the report, the project is asked to provide a description of how their surplus will be spent.
##Work Samples & Documentation
Fiscally sponsored projects have the opportunity to send links and/or upload up to 64 MB of files that are work samples. This is an optional portion of the report.
#Review Procedure
The fiscal sponsorship team regularly reviews annual reports in "sprints" during the months of January-April as reports are coming in.
Review consists of reading through the report narrative and reviewing the updated financials. Staff can compare the reported expenses with the project's fund release history, which appear side-by-side during staff review. If the project reported less expenditures in a given Expense Category, the line will appear red in the report. Staff should review the report to confirm that funds were put to different Expense Categories. For example, if our fund release history indicates that a project released $10,000 for *Contract labor: artists* but then only reported $8,000 in *Contract labor: artists* expenditures on the report, we will want to see that the remaining $2000 were used for other expenses.
Staff can either click 'Approve' or 'Place on Hold' upon review. For projects that show a mismatch between the project's fund release history and the reported expenses, it is important to briefly note on the report what changes were made. For example: "Funds released for Contract labor: artists were put toward other expenses, like Production and exhibition or Advertising and marketing."
Reports would be placed on hold if it were unclear how all funds released the previous calendar year were used, if there's a large surplus on the report that's unaccounted for, or if the narrative raises any red flags regarding prohibited activities outlined in our program manual.
Reports where the respondent indicated that their project description had changed can be approved if there are no other questions. Staff need to promptly follow up with these respondents to see if they need to submit a revised application for re-approval by our Board of Directors.
#Terminated Members
Sometimes a project's fiscal sponosrship will terminate before they have filed the annual report. We have a link that they can use to access the report, without reactivating their sponsorship. The link is www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/report20XX?termed_fs_id=YYYY to the end (where XX is the year of the report and YYYY is the ID number for the terminated project).
#Active Members
For projects who want to have their project returned to Active status, have them submit the report through the website, and then a staff person will review the report and reactivate them.
#Historical Info on Annual Reports
The Annual Report requirement has evolved over the years. Here are a few things to keep in mind for context.
Reports submitted in FY11 or prior will appear quite different. The Expense Category budget line items used in the fund release request process were changed to map to data on expenditures collected by the CDP and the annual report changed accordingly.
The narrative portion of the report has also been refined. The three writing prompts did not exist prior to 2014.
We used to require that fiscally sponsored projects base their reports on our fiscal year (September to August). This frequently resulted in confusion from projects that have a different fiscal year or use the calendar year for budgeting and financial reporting purposes. In 2013, it was decided to switch the annual report from our fiscal year to the calendar year. To accommodate this and bridge the gap between reports, we had projects submit a 'Mini Report' for the months of September through December of 2013. The Mini Report was administered through SurveyMonkey and was a condensed version of our annual report.
