Fund Release Procedures

###How a Sponsored Project Can Request Funds
- Login at www.fracturedatlas.org - Go to My Fiscal Sponsorship --> Fund Releases --> Request Funds - Projects will need to select from the drop-down menu of expense categories to indicate how they expect the funds will be spent. They can select multiple expense categories in a single fund release request, and should specify the amount that needs to be released toward each expense. Explanations of these expense categories can be found on the Fund Release Request page. - If the fund release request is $5,000 or more, the project should also upload supporting documentation of those expenses, to be reviewed by our staff prior to release.
###Reviewing Fund Releases
1. An FA staff member will review all fund release requests on a daily basis. Pending fund release requests can be reviewed under Transactions Processing in the Helpdesk (Fiscal Sponsorship --> Pending Fund Releases). This person should check how all fund releases were reported - if any were categorized as "other" in the expense categories, the staff member should follow up with the project to try to determine a more appropriate line item for the fund release. There's boilerplate for this, under f.s. fund releases.
2. All fund releases over $5,000 require documentation of expenses (receipts, contracts, quotes, invoices, etc), but we reserve the right to request documentation at any time. First time fund releases of $3,500+ require documentation as well.
3. For fund releases of $3,500 - $4,999, check to see if the project has previously submitted documentation (will be saved in the customer record). If they have, it’s not necessary to follow up to request further documentation, even if no documentation was included as part of this request. If they have not previously provided documentation, follow up with the project to request it.
4. If a fund release request is $5,000 or more, search the fund release request ID in Zimbra history – an automated e-mail is generated at the time the request is submitted. If documentation was uploaded to the request form, it will be attached to the automated e-mail. Documentation should be saved in the customer record using the following file format: [Date].Fund Release Docs.[Fund Release Request #] Ex. 2015-04-22.Fund Release Docs.53975
5. If documentation is not included as part of the request, contact the project and ask them to provide signed contracts, invoices, receipts, or quotes. There is boilerplate under the f.s. fund release documentation tag. Add a flag to the request by including a note in the fund release notice on the member’s FS page in the HD, using the following format: [Date] Documentation Requested – [initials] Ex. 4/22/15 Documentation Requested – AK
6. Documentation should include the following information: • date (must be after fiscal sponsorship approval) • the contractor/employee/vendor name • the project or company name • the goods exchanged or services provided • the agreed upon compensation/price/fee The documentation should also be signed by both parties whenever possible.
7. In the event that the project does not have documentation for all requested funds but needs the funds in advance of making purchases, the staff member can ask that they send: • any documentation they may already have (quotes, screenshots, invoices), and/or • a budget for anticipated expenses, and/or • a timeline for when they expect the expenses will be incurred If the above can be provided at that time, the staff member may submit the request and follow up with the project according to the agreed upon timeline.
8. There are some projects for whom documentation is required for every request, regardless of the amount requested. Reasons for this include: • a funder requires us to keep full documentation • they have not provided full documentation for a previous release if we required it • we have concerns that they may be operating in a for-profit manner • someone (typically a donor or collaborator) has raised a concern about the way the project handles funds
9. Fund releases are approved on a daily basis by the Program Director or Program Specialist. Once fund releases are approved, it typically takes about 1-3 business days for the funds to transfer to the project's bank account.
###Fund Release via Wire Transfers This is generally discouraged and only done on a case by case basis when a project needs funds sent to a company overseas or in an emergency situation where a delay in releasing funds through a check will be prohibitive to a project's successful completion of their activities. To execute a wire transfer, a project must submit a fund release request as with all other releases. After this is done, they should send all of the information listed below to the program staff (which will be forwarded to the Deputy Director and Controller).
Account Holder Name Account Holder Address Routing Number Bank Name Bank Address Account Number Sort Code (if international)
Fiscal Sponsorship Theory of Change

Activities
- Provide online fiscal sponsorship services and software - Continually refine and improve software in response to feedback - Ensure compliance with relevant regulations - Provide technical assistance to fiscal sponsees - Provide educational materials and training for raising money - Provide staff attention and expertise on an individualized basis - Promote best practices
Outcomes - Fiscal sponsees satisfy their need for a fiscal sponsor fast and easily - Fiscal sponsees save time getting fiscal sponsorship rather than 501(c)(3) status - Fiscal sponsees get more convenient fiscal sponsorship through FA - Fiscal sponsees pay less for nonprofit status than they do through the IRS - Fiscal sponsees have access to tax-deductible donations - Fiscal sponsees have increased access to grant funding - Fiscal sponsees become better grantwriters and fundraisers - Fiscal sponsees save time and money over alternatives - Fiscal sponsees meet legal/contractual requirements for opportunities
Impacts - Fiscal sponsees have more time and resources to do their work - Fiscal sponsees have fewer barriers to doing their work - Fiscal sponsees are able to raise as much money as possible
**Impacts**
Profile Edits

Projects are free to make edits to their online profile at any time. Staff members are to make sure that the update is still in line with the project description from the project's application (viewable in the CRM). If it is, staff will approve the edits within 1-2 business days.
To approve the profile, staff members should click the link in the associated ticket. Please note, staff must be logged into the Fractured Atlas website (www) under their staff profile for the "Approve Edits" button to appear.
If the update(s) indicate a substantial change from the project description, staff will ask the project for clarification about how the proposed edits fit with the current description on file. If these changes are not covered by the current description, staff will ask the project to submit an expansion application.
TDF Costume Collection Procedure

If you are receiving an inquiry about access to TDF Costume Collection, you should first verify that the project is currently fiscally sponsored by us. If they are, you can send the boilerplate steps and two documents: a Blank Letter of Agreement and the CC Authorization form. You will find these documents to attach by going to the shared drive → Programs and Services → Fiscal Sponsorship → COSTUME COLLECTION → "Blank LOA. TDF" and "Credit Card Authorization. TDF Costume Collection"
The boilerplate is asking for the project's production information that we prefer to have in an email reply back. The reason for this is because on our end, we will have to fill out the PDF document of the TDF Costume Collection Letter of Agreement (LoA) with the project's details. This is what is asked for in an email reply back from the member:
Sponsored Project's Name Name of production Size of house Authorized Designer or Contact Person Email for contact person Performance Dates Return Dates (CC policy states they are due 10 days after the final performance)
After the project sends us the production info and the completed CC form, you can find the LoA we need to send to TDF by going to the shared drive → Programs and Services → Fiscal Sponsorship → COSTUME COLLECTION → "Current Letter of Agreement. TDF Costume Collection". Click Tools → Typewriter → Typewriter. Use your cursor and edit the following sections of this LoA (examples of added sections via Typewriter tool are in bold):
Company: Fractured Atlas, Inc. (fiscally sponsoring **PROJECT NAME)** Title of Production: **NAME OF PRODUCTION** Authorized Designer(s): **JANE DOE 555-555-5555** Company Billing Address: **Fractured Atlas, 248 West 35th Street, 10th Floor, New York, NY 10001** Seating Capacity: **NUMBER** or write in **FILM** 1st Preview Date: **2015/10/01** Opening Date: **2015/10/02** Closing Date: **2015/10/13** (on second page of LoA) Date:** September 20, 2015**
After the LoA is completed by you, you will need to combine it with the completed CC form. As with MFTA Sponsorship Letters, you should save a copy of the PDF on your desktop somewhere and upload a copy of it to the member's files. The file should be saved in this format: "YYYY-MM-DD.TDF Costume Collection.Project Name". An example of the proper format is as follows:
**2015-10-15.TDF Costume Collection.Live Source.pdf**
You can then email the PDF document to Craig Steuker at costume@tdf.org and confirm with the project that you have sent it (there is boilerplate text for this).
Processing Stock Donations

**Processing Stock Donation**
To initiate a donation of stock, Fractured Atlas staff must speak with the donor directly. When we have contact with the donor, we should email them the following information about our brokerage account which they should pass on to their broker:
- Charles Schwab - DTC # 0164 - Code 40 - FBO: Fractured Atlas Productions, Inc. - Account number: 2800-1541 - Problems, Charles Schwab Transfer of Assets Team: 877-328-0276
The donor should let us know when they’ve initiated the transfer so we can alert the Controller and the Deputy Director to keep an eye out for the transfer. Once it posts to our account, the Deputy Director will email you a screenshot of the account activity.
When we email the brokerage information to the donor, we should also email them the stock donation letter. This can be found here: Q://Programs and Services/Fiscal Sponsorship/Donor Materials. **Be sure to enter the project’s title before sending the letter to the donor.** This letter states the amount of shares they are giving, the company issuing the stock and the date it was transferred to Fractured Atlas's brokerage account. The donor doesn't need to include the value of the stock, since it's a publicly traded security with an objective market value. This letter will need to be received in our offices before we can process the donation
Donation Receipt: **The donor's receipt should only list the shares, the ticker symbol, and the date of the transfer.** Make sure to enter this information into the "Non-cash/stock description" on the transaction page when processing the donation. Example: 12 Shares of IBM on 12/24/2014.
To Process Stock Donations: When the pending donation is ready to be processed on Fractured Atlas's end, Fractured Atlas staff should process the gift manually. The figure to use is the actual closing value of the donated shares on the date of the transaction. To find this information:
1. Visit www.bigcharts.com 2. Click Historical Quotes 3. Enter the ticker symbol and date of the transfer.
This can only be done after the stock transfer is complete. In addition to including the cash value of the stock in the "Donation Amount" field, the stock donation option should be selected, and then the description of the donation should be entered into the description field. Once the transaction has been processed, email the Controller with the donation ID.
Giving Level Review

Giving levels are available for fiscally-sponsored projects on the Fractured Atlas website so you can offer gifts in exchange for donations. The giving levels live on the project profile. We strongly encourage projects to use giving levels to define standard contribution levels for their donors and offer reward packages in return. These are easy to add and hide from the My Fiscal Sponsorship section of the website.
Once a project submits their giving levels for review, they are unavailable to the project for editing. If the project wishes to make substantial edits before approval, you can suggest deleting the levels and resubmitting - this allows for the project to have greater control of the copy. Once any giving level has been used by a donor, staff should not delete the giving level. This ensures that we have accurate records of donations received should any issues or questions about a donation arise. We frequently have donors reach back out to verify the specifics of a donation. Older giving levels should be made invisible if the project no longer wishes them to be active.
Staff reviews the giving levels for the following:
- The goods or services being offered in exchange for the donation are not prohibited by the terms of fiscal sponsorship. - The "Non-Gift Amount" of any goods or services being offered in exchange for the donation is included in the correct place. - The "Non-Gift Amount" of any goods or services being offered in exchange for the donation is less than the total amount of the donation.
Artful.ly Wordpress Plugin

[Github Repo](https://github.com/fracturedatlas/artfully-wordpress-plugin)
[Wordpress Page](https://wordpress.org/plugins/artfully-widget/)
[Wordpress Admin](https://wordpress.org/plugins/artfully-widget/admin/)
### Creating a Release to Test
* Go to trunk/ * Compress that directory * RENAME the zip file to "artfully-widget.zip" * **Deactivate** and **delete** any old Artful.ly plugins on your Wordpress install * Upload artfully-widget.zip to your installation
### Releasing to WP Plugin Directory
Because we host the code on Github but AP uses SVN, there are some hoops to jump through. If you've never done this before, follow instructions here to clone the git repo in the proper way: https://gist.github.com/gmoore/af4c2abf86d3f646ffff
We use Git SVN
The workflow:
* Do some work * git add * git commit * git svn rebase (This can take a long time, sometimes up to an hour) * git svn dcommit
If your "git svn rebase" fails, check here: http://blog.victorquinn.com/fix-git-svn-in-mountain-lion
Onboarding Regional Teams

When new team members are brought onto a SpaceFinder project (or team members leave and are replaced) there is an opportunity for fresh ideas and renewed energy. Fractured Atlas has created an onboarding process to help new team members get a solid grounding in SpaceFinder and quickly get up to speed within their role on the team.
1. Review partnership agreement/contract * Fractured Atlas will forward the agreement and clarify "who does what?" 2. Schedule SpaceFinder General Overview (15 minutes + time for questions)
This overview will cover best practices for talking about the resource to renters and venues.
During the overview you will learn how to talk about the resource and be given access to: * SpaceFinder Admin account - make sure to click "My Info" at the top of the page and uncheck the box for email notifications * Google Analytics Access & Monthly stats email * Support Center Access to private 'partner-only' content
3. Explore content in [Support Center](/hc/en-us/categories/200047420-Support-for-Regional-Partners) (After Intro) * Data FAQ * Measuring Impact * Marketing Examples
4. Schedule SpaceFinder Communications Overview (15 minutes + time for questions) * User communications * Community directories * Social media * Terms of use for email marketing
Optional specialized training sessions are available for team members as needed. Topics include: * Social Media Strategy for building renter audience * Measuring Impact for funders * Data collections from existing resources
What Local Teams Need to Know

## SpaceFinder App Training - What does it do and how does it do it - The Marketplace vs. Database - Think like a renter: Search Filters - The Backend of the App - Dashboard and notifications - Org and user search - Subscription page and info - Adjusting the slideshow
## What are their responsibilities? - Advertise to renters - Market to venues
**Seed the database** - workflow
**Venue outreach** - measuring
**Connect with other local orgs** - community directories
## What can be customized by the local leaders? - landing page slideshow - hidden landing pages - community directories - logos/links - Approve new listings (some rates, narrative descriptions, rental policy, visuals) - Building the Database
## Goals Increased venue inventory and searches - Outreach methods (email, phone) - Share My Calendar - Why it is a game changer -Time for local team questions.
## Knowledge base - Personal research - Links for CS Tech Support
Making Your Space More Inclusive and Accessible: Resources

Did you know that 20% of the population identifies as having a disability, making disabled people America’s largest minority? According to New York City's Mayor's Office for People with Disabilities, New York City alone is home to more than 800,000. Did you know that disabled people have a reported $220 billion in discretionary income? Yet despite these numbers, disabled people represent a hugely underserved market, and that includes the thousands of disabled artists living and making work throughout the five boroughs. But the opportunity for you to connect with this vibrant and growing community of artists is lost if they can’t get through your doors.
While increasing your customer base may be your primary goal, making your venue accessible is about more than simply complying with legal requirements; it should celebrate the positive benefits of running a universally inclusive space. Improving the accessibility of your space and fostering a more inclusive environment can yield benefits that strengthen the culture of your venue from the top down.
**How can I benefit from making my space more accessible and inclusive?**
- More artists will be able to rent, rehearse and create in your space; - More patrons will be able to attend your productions; - Disabled artists and audience members will recommend your venue to others in the community; and - Your space will be recommended by and recognized among artists as a place where the inclusionary impulse is celebrated and great work is made.
## Where do I begin?
At Fractured Atlas, because our SpaceFinder NYC directory is home to thousands of spaces—some conventional, some not so conventional—we understand that New York City presents both unique opportunities and challenges when it comes to finding places to make compelling work. Whether you’re creating a site-specific piece on a boat or hosting an event in a turn-of-the-century church with no elevator, or even renting a studio in a building that isn’t your own, there are things you can do to improve accessibility While you likely won’t be able to take all of these steps and/or totally renovate your space, understanding how you can accommodate disabled artists and patrons and is a great starting point to move your space toward a more inclusive environment for all artists.
## Evaluate Your Space
Developed by disabled artists exclusively for SpaceFinder NYC, we encourage you to use [this checklist](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=731) as a guide as you walk through your space. While it's not exhaustive and some of the considerations on the list may not apply to your venue, it will help you look at your space with an eye on accessibility and inclusiveness.
There are many accessibility checklists available online. These are a couple of our favorites:
- [Checklist for Existing Facilities, Adaptive Environments, Inc.](http://www.ada.gov/racheck.pdf) - [New Jersey Theatre Alliance’s Self Assessment](https://njtheatrealliance.org/accessibility/self-assessment) - [Web Accessibility Initiative's Guide](https://www.w3.org/WAI/intro/accessibility.php)
## Engaging Disabled Artists and Patrons: Make Accessibility Information Clear
Addressing accessibility features is not just for audience members, but also for renters and artists interested in using your space. By making information about your space’s accessibility clear, you’re helping your organization to reach a wider audience and increasing it’s visibility.
- If it’s not already accessible, take steps to make your website accessible. (See bullet 3 above) - Include as much information as possible about your space’s accessibility features wherever you advertise it: your website, social media, SpaceFinder, etc. - Make accessibility information easy to find on your website. Don’t bury it ‘below the fold’, so to speak. - Familiarize staff with these features so that anyone can have a conversation with a prospective disabled renter or patron.
## From the New Jersey Theatre Alliance: best practices for addressing accessibility
- Address every issue and policy with the question: Does this provide equal access for everyone? - Mandatory nondiscrimination - Consider accessibility in all routine parts of day/operations. - Apply accessibility law to all functions. - Establish an advisory committee or enlist a staff member who can be seen as an expert and can field questions from the disability community. - Barrier removal: Provision of reasonable modifications to achieve a basic standard for architectural access and equal access to employment, programs, services for all visitors. - Budget for accessibility.
To learn more about the above steps, see [these resources provided by the NJTA](https://njtheatrealliance.org/ada-planning) for more in depth details.
### More Organizations and External References:
- [Disability and Dance Task Force Report](http://www.dance.nyc/uploads/DanceNYC-ReportDisability-Final(Linco).pdf): This report presents and analyzes issues facing disabled dance artists in NYC today, and provides resources and explanations of the task force's findings. - [Design for Accessibility (NJTA)](https://njtheatrealliance.org/accessibility/design-accessibility-chapters-facility-access) - [Alliance Inclusion in the Arts](http://inclusioninthearts.org/)
*Thanks to Christine Bruno, actor and Disability Advocate from Inclusion in the Arts, for her assistance with this article.*
Checklist: Assessing Your Space's Accessibility Features

This checklist was created with help from Alliance for Inclusion in the Arts. It is by no means exhaustive, but is meant to act as a starting point for venues looking to learn about their space's accessibility features.
It's also available for download [here.] (/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=731)
## General points to consider:
**What is the experience like for a disabled person creating in your space?**
- Can everyone access the venue easily? - Is your staff knowledgeable of accessibility features? Are they welcoming and accommodating to patrons with multiple needs? - Is your space welcoming to all disability communities? (Consider physical access and overall inclusiveness.) - Which communities do you feel would be best served in your space?
### Venue Entrance
- Is the venue near an accessible public transportation stop? - Is it near a route of travel that does not require stairs? - Is the main entrance wheelchair accessible? If not, is there an alternate entrance, elevator, or ramp? If yes, where is the entrance, elevator or ramp located? (e.g., next to main entrance, in alley, side of building, basement, etc.) (Note: Wheelchair accessible means that the entrance to the building is completely flat. One step up makes the entrance inaccessible to many wheelchair users.) - Can alternate accessible entrance be used independently of venue staff?
**Exterior Route Checklists**
Writing a Great Space Recommendation

Thank you for your interest in writing a recommendation for a space listed on SpaceFinder. SpaceFinder has repurposed our reviews feature so disabled artists can recommend spaces that are best practice examples of accessibility and inclusiveness. Any SpaceFinder user looking for space will be able to see recommendations. Recommendations are also how spaces get added to the Disability and Dance Workspace Directory being piloted in New York City. Where do you enjoy making work or performing? Help make SpaceFinder as useful as possible to other artists by writing a recommendation for it! **Recommendations on SpaceFinder:** - Give details from a personal perspective that help identify positive factors for working with the space. - Help others to understand how the space helped meet your needs. - Provide peer disabled artists with accessibility information that might not otherwise be on the venue's listing or website. - Include details regarding which communities will be best served by working in the space. ## How to Write a Recommendation **To write a recommendation, you must either log into your SpaceFinder account, or [create a free membership.](https://cas.fracturedatlas.org/signups/new?service=http://nyc.spacefinder.org/dashboard)** 1. Visit the venue's listing. 2. On the righthand side of the page, under **Options**, select **Read/Submit Reviews**. ![Submit Review Button on Listing](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=690 "Submit Review Button on Listing") 3. Then, select **Write a Review**. 4. Next, log in if you have an existing SpaceFinder account, or create a free account to write your recommendation. 5. Once you've written your review, be sure to check the recommendation box if you think you'd recommend the space to other disabled artists. ## Tips For Writing A Helpful Recommendation For others to get the most out of your recommendation, be as thorough as possible about your experience with the venue. **Some general questions to consider:** - What made working in the space a positive experience? Be specific. - Can everyone access the venue easily? - Is staff knowledgeable about accessibility features? - Is the space welcoming to all disability communities? (Consider physical access and overall inclusiveness.) - Which communities do you feel would be best served in the space? Before reviewing a space, keep in mind that the most effective recommendations will provide helpful information for patrons from all disability communities. To get an idea of various features to consider, take a look at [this checklist](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=730) -- or even better, print it out and take it with you! That being said, **a simple 'thumbs up' recommendation, is better than nothing!** Of course, a recommendation with lots of detail is best, but even a simple recommendation helps make SpaceFinder a more useful tool for other artists. ### Need some examples? Check out this excerpt from a recommendation: "Though the theater is not wheelchair accessible, being downstairs, once inside the space is very negotiable and manageable for blind and low-vision patrons. In particular, access to the stage from the tiny green room is level, which provides great comfort! The same can be said about the level stage—the spectators being raised above in tiered seating. For a small theater, they have a great sound system and very nice lighting. Another benefit to producing here is the proximity of the stage to the sound/lighting booth making communication easy." **Click on these links for more full reviews:** - [Mark Morris Dance Group](http://nyc.spacefinder.org/spaces/4682/reviews) - [The Secret Theatre](http://nyc.spacefinder.org/spaces/5330/reviews?from_search=1) **Thanks again for your interest in recommending a space! If you have questions or need assistance, email us at: [spacefinder@fracturedatlas.org](mailto:spacefinder@fracturedatlas.org).**
How CAS authenticates users when they sign into our products.

When someone logs in to anything Fractured Atlas, be it fracturedatlas.org Artful.ly, SpaceFinder, or any other future program they log in through CAS (Central Authentication Server).
Then say that customer goes to Artful.ly.
Artful.ly asks CAS for info on this user.
In this case, CAS says “Here’s the User ID (40) and here’s the email (“jim@example.com”).
Artful.ly then looks up a user with fa_user_id=40 and then changes that record’s email to “jim@example.com."
That's the ideal scenario.
But if there’s already a record with “jim@example.com" Artful.ly doesn’t know what to do and says “Whoa” etc... Then the email address will need to be changed on Fracturedatlas.org because it's associated with two accounts. Once the two are
Deleting Ticket Types

If you haven't sold any of a certain type of ticket for a show, you can delete the ticket type.
1. From the **Event Overview** page, view the **Shows** section. 2. Click on **List** and select the show date. 3. Under **Ticket Types**, click the asterisks next to the type you'd like to remove and select **Delete.**
This will delete the ticket type from that show completely. This will not delete the ticket type for other shows.
If you've already sold a ticket type and can't delete it, but want to take it off sale, check out [this article](site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-take-tickets-off-sale).
### Related Articles - [Editing Ticket Information For Existing Shows](/site/knowledgebase/editing-ticket-information-for-existing-shows)
Should I invite or subscribe a fan to my MailChimp list?

There are a couple different ways that you can ensure a fan ends up on your MailChimp list from Artful.ly. Before you choose a method, it's important to understand the difference between subscribing someone and inviting them to join your mailing list.
## Subscribing a Fan to Your Mailing List
If a fan has given you the okay to add their email to your mailing list, you can subscribe them immediately from Artful.ly. Anti-spam laws require subscribers to opt-into or request to join your mailing list, so make sure that this process is clear to your patrons. To learn more about MailChimp's guidelines and review their definition of permission, read their article [here](http://kb.mailchimp.com/accounts/compliance-tips/guidelines-for-list-compliance?&_ga=1.215225951.913571212.1401485725).
Subscribing can be done either in bulk from a list segment, or by viewing an individual record in your database. This article provides detailed instructions on the various methods: [Adding People to MailChimp Lists or Groups](/site/knowledgebase/adding-people-to-mailchimp-lists-or-groups)
*Note: This method does **not** send an email confirmation to the individual, since they've already given you permission. If they haven't yet given you permission, see below for details on sending an invitation.*
## Inviting a Fan to Your Mailing List
Have new people interested in your work, and want to tell them how they can keep up-to-date with your organization? Send them an invitation to join your mailing list. MailChimp recommends a [double opt-in process](http://kb.mailchimp.com/lists/signup-forms/the-double-opt-in-process) to avoid any compliance issues. Just like subscribing your fans, sending them an invitation to subscribe to your mailing list can be done either in bulk from a list segment, or by viewing individual records in your Artful.ly database.
*Note: This will send each person an email asking whether or not they'd like to join your mailing list. They will not be subscribed until the invitation has been accepted.*
![Confirm method for adding individual to mailing list](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=637 "Confirm method for adding individual to mailing list")
### Related Articles - [How do I update my MailChimp lists and groups in Artful.ly?](/site/knowledgebase/how-do-i-update-my-mailchimp-lists-and-groups-in-artful-ly) - [Connecting Your MailChimp and Artful.ly Accounts](/site/knowledgebase/connecting-your-artful-ly-mailchimp-accounts)
Merging Feature Requests

If you find two similar feature requests, you should merge them. This consolidates the votes and communication about this request.
1. Figure out which request should be the winner and which should be the loser. The comments, votes, and subscribers from the loser request will be added to the winner request. The title and status of the winner request will remain unchanged. 2. From HD admin, go to the **Feature Request list**. 3. Find and open the request that should win. (Usually this is the older request.) 4. The the Merge section of the page, start typing the title of the other request. 5. Select this loser request and hit **Merge** button.
NOTE: Merges cannot be undone.
Beta: How do I designate a primary contact for a company?

With the Relationships kit activated, you can now indicate which individuals in your database are employed by which companies. To further clarify who to contact for your staff, there is a "Primary Contact" relationship type. This only works between an individual and a company record in your database. For example, if you're working with a grants officer at a foundation, it's a good idea to list them as your primary contact there. That way, when someone views their record, they'll know who to to reach out to.
## From an individual's record 1. Visit the person's record and select the **Work with...** button to edit their information. 2. Select the **Relationships** tab on the left. 3. Click on the drop down menu and select the **Primary contact for** relationship type. 4. Start typing the name of the company. Artful.ly will suggest companies in your database, select the correct one and save your changes.
## From a company's record 1. Visit the company's record and select the **Work with...** button to edit their information. 2. Select the **Relationships** tab on the left. 3. Click on the drop down menu and select the **Primary contact for** relationship type. 4. Start typing the name of an individual in your database. Artful.ly will suggest names, select the correct one and save your changes.
These changes will now be saved both on the individual's record, as well as the company record. To further highlight this relationship, you can **Star** it.
![Primary Contact on Record](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=700 "Primary Contact on Record")
### Related Articles - [Tracking Relationships Between Patrons](/site/knowledgebase/beta-tracking-relationships-between-patrons)
Fundraising Campaigns Overview

*This kit is currently only available to beta testers. If you would like to beta test these features, please have your Organization Administrator email us at support@artful.ly and we will reach out to you about activating the kit.*
Whether you are planning a campaign to raise funds for your organization's upcoming project, you're getting ready for your organization's end-of-year ask, or you want to past log donations, campaigns, and pledges, the Campaigns Kit in Artful.ly will allow you to keep track of all of your organization's fundraising efforts. The kit can be activated from your **Account Administration** page.
## With the Campaigns kit activated, you can...
1. Create a New Campaign
- Set a goal, add information about when it starts and ends, and add details - Create appeals to track your correspondence with potential donors - Log individual donations, pledges, and apply them to appeals or campaigns to keep track of the campaign's progress - View and download a report of campaign donation activity
2. Add individual appeals
- Specify the engagement method - Upload related documents and materials - Select a segment of your database that was contacted/will be contacted about the appeal - Add notes to include details that your staff needs to know
3. Log donations and pledges
- Log donations and identify which appeal they are for - Apply soft credits to donations - Log pledges and identify a corresponding record in your database - Track outstanding pledges
4. Log Matching Gifts - Add match eligible gifts - Apply matching gifts to specific campaigns or appeals - Track outstanding matching gifts
### Related Articles - Creating Campaigns - Creating Appeals - Logging Donations & Pledges - Pledges & Scheduling Pledge Payments - Logging Matching Gifts - Acknowledging Gifts
Creating a Campaign

*If you don't yet have the Campaigns kit, please have your organization administrator contact us at support@artful.ly if you're interested in this beta kit for your organization.*
1. Click on the **Fundraising** menu in the top navigation bar and select **Campaigns.** 2. Select **Create a new campaign**
![Create a New Campaign Button](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=701 "Create a New Campaign Button")
3. Under the **Basics** section, enter the details about your campaign. - **Name** your campaign. - Identify when it will **Start** and **End**. - Indicate whether the campaign is **Active** or **Inactive** - Enter any remaining **Notes** that your staff should be aware of.
![Basics Section on campaign creation page](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=702 "Basics Section on campaign creation page")
4. In the **Financial** section: - Define a **Goal** for your campaign's budget - Set a **Restriction** if applicable. If you haven't yet added restrictions to your account, you can add these on your Account Administration page.
![Financial section on campaign creation page](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=703 "Financial section on campaign creation page")
5. **Save** your campaign and you're ready to go!
![Finished campaign](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=704 "Finished campaign")
Next Steps:
- Add new Appeals - Log donations - Keep track of your progress with Reports
Creating Appeals

To create an appeal for a campaign, visit the campaign overview page.
1. Select "Create Appeal". 2. Choose a **Name** for the appeal. 3. Select the **Start** and **End** dates 4. Choose a **Method**: This is how you will announce the appeal (Or how you announced the appeal, if you are logging a past appeal.) 5. If you have any appeal materials, add up to three in the **Attached Materials** section. 6. Select a **Prospect List Segment** to identify who will or did receive the appeal. If you haven't yet created a list segment for the appeal in Artful.ly, you can leave this section blank and return to it once you've done so. 7. Define whether or not the appeal is **Active.** 8. Lastly, add any pertinent **Notes.**
![Add new appeal details](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=705 "Add new appeal details")
**Save** your results and you're all set!
## Next Steps: - Log donations or pledges
###Related Articles:
Logging Donations & Pledges

A **donation** is a one-time contribution to your organization, whereas a **pledge** is a commitment to contribute a certain amount during a timeframe specified by the donor. There are a few different places that you can log donations and pledges in Artful.ly.
## From an individual's record: 1. View an individual's record. 2. Next to their **Action Feed**, **Add** a new action. 3. Select a **Gave** action type to log a new donation or pledge in that individual's name.
![New Contribution Contact Information](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=706 "New Contribution Contact Information")
## Add new individual and donation 1. Go to the **Fundraising** section of the top navigation bar. 2. Select **Log Donation/Pledge**. 3. In the **People Search** section, enter the name of a new individual, or start typing the name of an individual in your database, and Artful.ly will suggest existing records. 4. In the **Basics** section: - Choose whether you're logging a **Donation** or a **Pledge**. - If you'd like to attribute it to an existing **Campaign**, select which one from the drop down menu. - Select the **Donation Type**. - Enter the **Donation Date**. - Select the **Payment Method**, **Total Gift Amount**, and enter a **Nondeductible amount** if applicable. - If you've already acknowledged the patron's donation, enter a **Date** next. - To apply the donation or pledge to a specific **Fiscal Year**, select one from the drop down menu. - Add any **Notes**.
![Contribution Information Fields](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=707 "Contribution Information Fields")
**Adding a Matching Organization** In the righthand column of the donation/pledge creation page, you can specify a matcher, if applicable. 1. Enter the name of an existing contact to **Match** this individual's donation. 2. Choose a **Ratio**. 3. Enter the match **Amount**.
![Matcher Information Section](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=708 "Matcher Information Section")
**Adding Soft Credits** If you're logging a group or institutional donation that needs a soft credit, do so here. 1. Enter the name of the person to Soft Credit 2. Enter the amount that they should be credited for. 3. It's possible to add as many individual soft credits on a single donation/pledge as you'd like.
![Add soft credits here](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=709 "Add soft credits here")
## Related Articles -
Pledges and Scheduling Pledge Payments

A **pledge** is a promise to contribute a certain amount to your organization over a set period of time. For example, a donor might pledge to give your organization $200.00, in payments of $20.00 per month for 10 consecutive months. This is different than a **recurring donation**, when a donor gives a certain amount repeatedly on an open ended schedule, with no particular set final contribution amount. (Currently, Artful.ly cannot process recurring donations of this nature, if this feature is important to you, vote for it [here.](/site/knowledgebase/feature_request_view?id=270))
## Log a New Pledge
1. Click on the **Fundraising** tab in the top navigation bar and select **Log Donation/Pledge**. 2. in the **People Search** section, enter the name of an existing contact in your database and select the correct person from the suggested menu, or enter a new person's information.
![Add donor name and contact information](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=713 "Add donor name and contact information")
3. In the **Basics** section: - Next to **Donation/Pledge**, choose **Pledge** from the dropdown menu. - If applicable, select which **Appeal** this Pledge applies to. - Enter the **Total Gift Amount** - If applicable, add a **Nondeductible amount**. - Enter the **Commitment Date**. - If you've acknowledged the pledge, add ann **Acknowledgement Sent Date**. - Choose a **Fiscal Year** and finally, enter any **Notes**.
![Add donation information](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=714 "Add donation information")
6. Next, enter the **Pledge Payment Schedule** on the right side of the screen. Enter a **Date**, **Amount**, and select the "+" button to add more dates.
![Add pledge donation schedule](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=715 "Add pledge donation schedule")
Pledges can be logged in Artful.ly and attributed to a specific campaign goal.
## Log a New Pledge for a Campaign 1. Click on the **Fundraising** tab in the top navigation bar and select **Campaigns**. 2. Select the campaign you'd like to add the pledge to. 3. From there, scroll down and select **Add Pledge**. 4. in the **People Search** section, enter the name of an existing contact in your database and select the correct person from the suggested menu, or enter a new person's information. 5. In the **Basics** section: - Next to **Donation/Pledge**, choose **Pledge** from the dropdown menu. - If applicable, select which **Appeal** this Pledge applies to. - Enter the **Total Gift Amount** - If applicable, add a **Nondeductible amount**. - Enter the **Commitment Date**. - If you've acknowledged the pledge, add ann **Acknowledgement Sent Date**. - Choose a **Fiscal Year** and finally, enter any **Notes**. 6. Next, enter the **Pledge Payment Schedule** on the right side of the screen. Enter a **Date**, **Amount**, and select the "+" button to add more dates. 7. **Save** the pledge!
Note: Adding a pledge from either location will add a **Pledge** tag to the patrons' record. Their pledge will also be added to the campaign's progress bar in the campaign overview page.
### Related Articles
Logging Soft Credits

Soft credits enable you to give credit for a donation to one or more people who are not the actual donor themselves. This is a way of giving recognition to an individual or organization who might have been involved in the donation in some way. For example, if a business has a donation match program, when you log their donation in your Artful.ly database, you can add a soft credit to the employee who works there.
## Donations can be soft credited... - From a newly logged donation on a campaign. - By adding a "Gave" action, or a manually logged donation on an individual's record. - From an existing donation in your database.
![Add soft credits to donation](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=710 "Add soft credits to donation")
## Adding a Soft Credit to a Campaign Donation/Pledge 1. From the **Fundraising** menu in the top navigation bar, select **Campaigns.** 2. Choose the campaign you'd like to add the donation to. 3. Select **Add Donation** or **Add Pledge** and fill out the donor and amount information. 4. Then, select **Soft Credits** and enter the person's name and amount. You can add as many soft credits per donation/pledge as you'd like. 5. **Save** it and you're all set!
## Adding a Soft Credit to a Donation on an Individual's Record 1. Visit the individual's record. Next to **Action Feed**, select **Add**. 2. Choose **Gave** from the list of action types. 3. Repeat steps 4 and 5 from the above instructions.
##Adding a Soft Credit to an Existing Donation 1. Locate the donation from either the individual's record or from the **Orders** menu. 2. Click on the donation and select **Edit** 3. Click on **Soft Credits** to add individuals and the corresponding soft credit amounts. 4. **Save**.
This will credit the entire amount on the donor's record, noting the people who were soft credited.
![Soft credit on actual donor's record](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=711 "Soft credit on actual donor's record")
... And will add another Gave action on the person's record who was soft credited.
![Soft credit on creditee's record](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=712 "Soft credit on creditee's record")
### Related Articles
Reviewing Fundraising Materials - Individual Donors

Fiscally sponsored projects are required to submit their fundraising materials for review by Fractured Atlas staff before they get sent out to potential donors.
This includes, but is not limited to: - individual appeal letters - crowdfunding campaigns - newsletters - e-blasts - web copy - event programs
A good rule of thumb is that any document that mentions the name "Fractured Atlas" or offers tax-deductibility should be reviewed a member of the fiscal sponsorship team.
First, we will be looking to see that the standard text from pages 11-12 of the fiscal sponsorship program manual is included somewhere, even if it's just in fine print at the bottom of the document.
*[PROJECT NAME] is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of [PROJECT NAME] must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.*
Letters are frequently sent with the standard text edited by the project. We discourage projects from doing this as much as possible. There might be situations where it's appropriate for the first sentence and the second sentence of the standard text to be separated or for slight modifications to be accommodated, but the text needs to remain largely intact in order for staff to approve the document.
Fiscally sponsored projects, even those that include the standard text, often include statements that depict the fiscal sponsorship arrangement incorrectly. A common mistake is for projects to say that Fractured Atlas has granted them 501(c)(3) status. Please consult [this Internal Knowledge Base article](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/admin/Knowledgebase/view_article?id=673) for a list of no-no words to keep an eye out for.
We are also looking to see if the project is incentivizing donors with any rewards. This has the potential to make donations partially tax-deductible. If projects offer donors an incentive that qualifies as advertising, we will point out that this is a prohibited activity and will need to be revised. There is separate standard text for partially-deductible donations.
*[PROJECT NAME] is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of [PROJECT NAME] must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. The value of [GOODS OR SERVICES RECEIVED BY DONOR] is $[XX]. Any contribution above that amount is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.*
There may be some situations where the partially-deductible text would be unwieldy, for example, if the project is offering multiple giving levels. In such case, we would have the project include the fully-deductible text and add a note next to each giving level stating "(the amount over $XX)," where $XX is the non-deductible value of the giving level. This is how partial-deductibility is expressed on Indiegogo and RocketHub campaigns.
Beyond that, the staff reviewer is looking to see if he or she can provide feedback to help maximize the effectiveness of the document. Some things to think about: - Length: For an individual appeal letter, is it longer than 1-2 pages? - Typos/Formatting: Are there suggestions you have for making it more aesthetically pleasing? If it's a letter, it should be a "business-style letter" with a date and an address for both the sender and recipient. - Clarity: Does the project explicitly ask for a "donation" as opposed to "support" and do they make the ask early in the letter? - Tone: Is the ask worded in a defeatist, subservient, or otherwise strange way? The material should be inviting and exciting! - Donor-centric: Could the letter focus more on how the donor is involved and what impact they can make? The letter should use plenty of second person: how *you* can help, *your* donation, etc. The letter should also be as personalized as possible. - Fundraising Goal/Specific Ask Amount: Could the project benefit from communicating their fundraising goal and making a specific ask amount that's tailored to each donor? - Urgency: Does the project state a timeframe and make it clear that a donation is needed *now*? - Instructions: Does the material provide clear next steps for donors to take in order to make a contribution?
Please see these articles with more info about reviewing Indiegogo and RocketHub campaigns.
Fundraising Events

Fractured Atlas fiscally sponsored projects conduct fundraising events throughout their sponsorship with us. In anticipation of these events, we often encourage projects to reach out to us to go over their plans for the event, particularly with regard to selling tickets and/or receiving donations at the event itself. A few questions projects typically need to cover with us prior to the event:
#How should I sell tickets to my event?
There are a few options for fiscally sponsored projects to do this: - If the project wants tickets to be tax-deductible or partially tax-deductible, they can set up giving levels via the Online Profile. - If the project wants to sell fully non-deductible tickets, we typically encourage them to ticket through Arful.ly. This way, attendees can have the option to donate above the cost of admission.
#How can I receive donations at the event?
We encourage projects to set up a laptop at the event, so that donors can contribute by credit card then and there. We provide a special link for event tabling, that turns off fraud protection for their Online Profile. This allows many donations to come through one IP address in a short span of time, without flagging the computer as potentially fraudulent. The event tabling link can be found if the project logs in then goes to My Fiscal Sponsorship --> Donations --> Donation Link for Event Tables.
Projects can also receive donations by check at the event, then report them online and send them to us for processing. Cash donations cannot be considered tax-deductible.
Note: Projects should not collect credit card pledges from their donors at the event. It is prohibited for our projects to collect credit card information from their donors, as it creates a major liability for Fractured Atlas.
#How do I conduct an auction at my event?
Fractured Atlas projects frequently run silent auctions as part of their fundraising events. It's possible for silent auction bids to partially tax-deductible, if the winning bid is above the value of the item won by the donor. For example, if a donor bids $80 on an item valued at $50, $30 of that bid can be considered tax-deductible. We encourage projects to list the values of the items at the silent auction table, so donors are aware of the value when making bids. If the winning bid is greater than the value of the item, the donor can make payment by check, which can then be reported and sent to Fractured Atlas for processing. There's no simple way to conduct a silent auction by credit card, so we discourage our projects from trying to do so. If they like, they can receive payment directly by credit card for silent auction items, but it won't be considered tax-deductible.
#How do I receive noncash donations for my event?
Projects often solicit local businesses, particularly wineries, breweries, groceries, and venues, for donations of noncash goods/services for their events. Policies and procedures surrounding noncash donation processing hold true for this - in short, donations of goods can be considered tax-deductible while donations of services/space cannot. Projects can feel free to solicit businesses for donations of any kind, but it's important to point out to them what could be processed by Fractured Atlas vs. what cannot.
Most local businesses ask for 6-8 weeks to process requests of noncash donations, so it's important to encourage projects to factor that timeline into their event planning.
#Can I conduct a raffle at my event?
Raffles are governed and regulated by each State. Due to these regulations, Fractured Atlas is not able to accept money raised through a raffle or assist projects in conducting a raffle. Projects can conduct a raffle if they like, but funds should be received by them directly and would not be considered tax-deductible.
A couple helpful resources on the blog:
[Tips & Tools: Planning Your Next Event](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/blog/2015/09/23/tips-tools-planning-your-next-event/) [5 Tips for Running a Fundraising Event](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/blog/2013/03/29/5-tips-for-running-a-fundraising-event/)
Fiscal Sponsorship Program Fees

### **Fiscal Sponsorship Program Fees**
1. **Administrative Fee:** There is a base **7%** administrative fee on all donations, with no additional fees for processing credit cards. As a project raises more funds over the lifetime of your project, the fee is reduced. These lower fees apply to grants and donations by check, but not to donations by credit card: $0-$150K: **7%** $150K-$500K: **6%** $500K-$1M: **5%** $1M+: **4%**
2. **Hourly Grant administration fee:** All fiscally sponsored projects are allotted 1 hour of grant administration per grant opportunity. After the first hour, projects will be charged a **$50/hr** fee for grant administration.
3. **Rush Fee for grant reviews:** We charge **$75** to rush review any grant application. Paying a rush fee ensures that a Fractured Atlas staff person will perform a preliminary review within 1 business day of receiving the completed grant application materials. Charging the fee is up to the discretion of the staff member reviewing the application.
4. **Fund Release Check Fee: $15**. All funds are released by EFT, but if there is an emergency and the project needs a check, we will charge a $15 processing fee to cut the check.
5. **Stop-payment/Re-issue fee for fund release checks:** If a project opts to have a fund release check cut, there is a **$50** stop-payment and re-issue fee if the check is lost.
6. **Outgoing Wire Transfer Fee:** - We can initiate a fund release request by wire transfer for a **$25** fee. The transfer can take up to 5 business days to post to the recipient's account.
7. **EFT Reject Fees:** If an EFT attempt fails, we charge a **$10** fee unless the failure was due to staff error.
8. **FedEx/USPS Express Fee:** If a project requires expedited shipping, we charge **$15** for staff time **plus the cost of the shipping**.
Fiscal Sponsorship No-No Words

This article is a running list of words/phrases mostly drawn from *Fiscal Sponsorship: 6 Ways to Do It Right* by Gregory L. Colvin and are red flags when reviewing fundraising material submitted by fiscally sponsored projects.
- Fiscal agency/fiscal agent (Sometimes grantmakers will use this phrase to refer to Fractured Atlas. Projects are not allowed to describe their relationship with us in this way.) - Earmarked for the X project - Acting as a conduit - Pass-through - Funnel - Intermediary - Partnership/joint venture - Cooperative - Shell - Autonomous - Laundering - Go-between - Parent company - Curiously, Colvin believes that "umbrella" is an acceptable term, but we disagree and would not allow sponsored projects to describe the fiscal sponsorship arrangement in that way.
Special Funding Cases

NYSCA
1. Send an email to all potential fiscally sponsored applicants to NYSCA a few months before the registration process begins. Send it to projects that have received funding the previous year or expressed interest. The email alerts them that they must wait to hear from FA before they can register and that FA must actually register each project. The email also provides them with a timeline of the registration process. And it prevents the projects from accidentally trying to create a profile on their own.
2. Once FA has updated our organizational information, another email is sent after the registration process opens. Once we have the word document registrations, save each one and enter it into the NYSCA website. Create an excel spreadsheet each year that documents each project's name, contact person, program applied to, deadline and the username and password.
4. Send each project copies of the final registration, application and final report (which you'll need to copy from the NYSCA website and paste into a word document.) Try to encourage projects to save all grant applications. Even if they don't save these copies, we have them on file for each year and can always re-send any copies they need.
CITY COUNCIL
The easiest agency to deal with as far as city council funding is the DCA. IN ORDER TO BE ELIGIBLE FOR MEMBER ITEMS AS PART OF THE FISCAL YEAR BUDGET ADOPTION PROCESS, GROUPS MUST SUBMIT A FISCAL YEAR DCA APPLICATION.
The City Council offers:
1) Capital Funding (for building costs/ bricks & mortar)
2) Expense Funding (for project/ program costs)
Expense funding can come from one of three sources:
1) Discretionary member item (from individual Council Members - typically no more than $5k per group per year.)
2) Delegation Fund (from all the council members in a particular borough - projects must submit a form to the Manhattan Delegation, which used to require testimony from all applicants but starting in 2008 applicants will be selected to testify.)
3) Speaker's Fund (from the entire City Council as a whole - biggest pot of money.) As part of 2007's reforms, all the Speaker money allocated to cultural activities was handed over to the DCA to distribute through their competitive process.
The Manhattan Delegation funding must pass through a city agency (DCA, DYCD, DFTA).
Department of Youth and Community Development - DYCD
Fractured Atlas does not accept funding through the DYCD. The DYCD contracts are huge and not possible for Fractured Atlas to manage or handle in behalf of a project.
Department of Cultural Affairs - DCA
IN ORDER TO BE ELIGIBLE FOR MEMBER ITEMS AS PART OF THE FISCAL YEAR BUDGET ADOPTION PROCESS, GROUPS MUST SUBMIT A FISCAL YEAR DCA APPLICATION.
Eligibility:
- Projects must be incorporated in the state of NY in order to apply.
- The fundamental requirement for all proposals is that they represent a cultural activity of recognized quality accessible to the public.
- The services must occur with the City's Fiscal Year (July 1st - June 30th).
- Projects must have been in existence and have provided public services for no less than two years before applying for DCA funding.
- Projects must have either have filed a 990 with the IRS or an Audited Statement. If unavailable, the project must submit their balance sheet.
Deadlines and application procedures
- Seminars explaining the application process typically start in November.
- The application must be submitted by paper, although the DCA is hoping to have on-line application by 2010. The application is available to download at www.nyc.gov/culture.
- The application deadline is early February.
- The DCA will accept up to a maximum of five projects for support per applicant.
- $5k is the minimum award so the ask for each project needs to be at least that much. Each project needs to have a total budget of at least $10k. Organizations with project budgets less than $10K should be encouraged to apply directly to their local arts council re-grant program.
- The DCA will not fund more than 50% of a project budget and usually does not approach that level of support.
- Fractured Atlas sets an internal deadline for all applications to be at the Fractured Atlas office. Typically, this is three weeks before the official DCA deadline. This allows time for the review of the application, edits, and for FA to get the necessary paperwork together. Projects that applied the previous year should be sent an email reminder in December.
State Officials Discretionary Funding - (NY State Dept. for the Aging, Dept. of Parks and Rec, etc.)
There is no way for Fractured Atlas to accept discretionary awards from most state officials. In case anyone asks, you can tell them we did everything we could to try and work it out, but it is due to contractual restrictions within all of the state agencies and there is nothing the electeds can do to change it. Unless an organization is a fully vested exempt organization, there is not anyway around contract or agency based policy and procedures.
The Dept. for the Aging requires that we certify the project as an employee or independent contractor of Fractured Atlas, which is not possible given that it is an inaccurate and incorrect representation of the relationship we have with our fiscally sponsored projects.
Rockethub

#What is Rockethub?
RocketHub is a crowdfunding campaign that offers an innovative way to raise money (crowdfunding) and tangible opportunities to take creative products and endeavors to next level (LaunchPad Opportunities). RocketHub is a destination for emerging artists and entrepreneurs, and those who wish to discover and support innovative work.
#Step-by-step instructions for projects to set up a Rockethub campaign
1. Start at the My Fiscal Sponsorship page. 2. Click the link to “Accessorize!” and “RocketHub”. 3. Click on the link on the bottom of the webpage to connect your fiscally sponsored project to RocketHub. 4. You will be brought to the RocketHub website where you can set up a RocketHub account and campaign. 5. You must use the button from the Fractured Atlas website in order for it to be connected to Fractured Atlas. 6. Remember, if you offer your donors a reward in exchange for their contribution, please make sure to list the partially deductible value when setting up the reward. 7. After you launch the campaign, Fractured Atlas will review it and make it live on the RocketHub website.
Timeline: Once you click LAUNCH, it can take up to five (5) business days for our staff to review and approve it. You will receive an email once it has been approved. Please plan accordingly.
#Credit Card Contributions
Donations to Rockethub campaigns can be made by credit or debit card. All funds raised for projects via Rockethub go directly to Fractured Atlas and are subject to the same 7% fee as all other credit card donations. Fractured Atlas cannot accept checks for Rockethub campaigns, and checks processed by Fractured Atlas cannot appear on the Rockethub campaign.
#How to review Rockethub campaigns
When projects create Rockethub campaigns, they can submit the campaign to us for approval. We then receive an automated e-mail from Rockethub, letting us know that the campaign is ready for review. When reviewing a Rockethub campaign, Fractured Atlas staff should look for the following:
- There is a leading video or image that is viewable to the public and properly functioning. - The goods or services being offered in exchange for the donation are not prohibited by the terms of fiscal sponsorship. - The "Non Tax-Deductible Amount" of any goods or services being offered in exchange for the donation is included in the correct place. - The "Non Tax-Deductible Amount" of any goods or services being offered in exchange for the donation is less than the total amount of the donation. - The campaign includes the standard text.
If the campaign is ready to go live, click "Approve" at the bottom of the campaign page.
Unlike Indiegogo, Fractured Atlas staff has no editing capabilities with individual Rockethub campaigns, and we have limited access to donor/campaign information via the Rockethub site. Rockethub's staff is quite responsive, though, and can be reached at support@rockethub.com.
Searching for Accessible Space

**For folks looking for inclusive and accessible space in NYC, check out our [Disability & Dance Directory of Workspaces](http://nyc.spacefinder.org/communities/DisabilityNYCDance)**
If you're looking for more information about what a space has to offer in terms of accessibility, click on the **Accessibility** search filter.
![A view of the accessibility menu on a SpaceFinder website](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=716 "Accessibility menu")
This will expand and show you all of the accessibility search filters.
![An expanded view of SpaceFinder's Accessibility Search Filters](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=717 "accessibility search filter detail")
- **Recommended** by a disabled artists. Spaces that have written recommendations by disabled artists will appear here. - **Virtual Tour Provided** Checking this box will show all of the spaces that have provided a link to a virtual tour. This tour could be a 360 view from Google StreetView, a YouTube video, or something else entirely. - **ADA or AODA compliant** - **Accessible without stairs** - **Elevator** - **Infrared System/Assistive Listening**
Once you click into a listing, you'll find the accessibility information listed directly above *Rates* on the bottom of the listing.
**Note:** Venues self-report information on their SpaceFinder listings. If you have questions about a space's accessibility features, contact the venue to make sure.
Are you a disabled artist with recommendations you'd like to share? Find out more about how to submit your own recommendations here: [Writing a Space Recommendation as a Disabled Artist for Disabled Artists](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/writing-a-space-recommendation-as-a-disabled-artist-for-disabled-artists).
Indiegogo

###What is Indiegogo? How do projects set it up?
Indiegogo is a collaborative way to fund ideas. Fiscally sponsored project can use Indiegogo's tools and process to enhance their fundraising and complement the tax-deductions made possible by Fractured Atlas. To connect their projects to Indiegogo, fiscally-sponsored projects should follow the below steps, which are detailed in [the Program Manual](/site/fiscal/Instructions.pdf):
1. Start at the My Fiscal Sponsorship page. 2. Click the link to "Accessorize!" and "Indiegogo". 3. Click on either of the options on the bottom of the webpage to connect the fiscally sponsored project to Indiegogo. 4. Check their inbox (this must be the email address they use for Fractured Atlas) for instructions from Indiegogo. 5. Follow the instructions in the email from Indiegogo to login to their website. 6. Once logged in using the Indiegogo emailed instructions, they can build their campaign on the Indiegogo website. 7. If they offer their donors a perk in exchange for their contribution, please make sure to list the partially deductible value when setting up the perk. 8. After the launch of the campaign, Fractured Atlas will review it and make it live on the Indiegogo website.
If a campaign is properly connected, an email notification will added to the helpdesk stating that "New campaign connected to Fractured Atlas." You can then begin review at that point.
###Manually Connecting A Campaign
Sometimes, projects have begun campaigns before properly connecting to their fiscal sponsorship, so Fractured Atlas staff has to contact Indiegogo to get it manually connected. To do so, follow the below steps:
- Have the project email you their campaign's preview link. (Instructions for the project below.)
1. Log in to your Indiegogo campaign dashboard. 2. Go to option number 6 - "Extras" 3. Select "Generate Link" under "Share Your Draft Campaign."
- Once you receive the preview link, email the link to "partnersupport@indiegogo.com."
- In the email, ask IGG to connect the campaign to the project's Fractured Atlas project ID.
- Inform the project that you've contacted IGG and remind them *not* to hit launch until the connect has been confirmed.
*Live campaigns cannot be retroactively connected to fiscal sponsorship.*
- Once IGG let's you know that the campaign is connected, proceed with the normal review procedure.
###Reviewing a Campaign
Once a campaign is connected, a Fractured Atlas staff member receives the helpdesk notification and can begin the review. Staff should be looking for the following conditions:
- There is a leading video or image that is viewable to the public and properly functioning. - The goods or services being offered in exchange for the donation are not prohibited by the terms of fiscal sponsorship. - The "Non Tax-Deductible Amount" of any goods or services being offered in exchange for the donation is included in the correct place. - The "Non Tax-Deductible Amount" of any goods or services being offered in exchange for the donation is less than the total amount of the donation. - The campaign includes the standard text. - All perks require a shipping address. - The campaign *has not* opted into InDemand.
If all of those conditions are met, the campaign can be approved. It is advisable to check with the project to confirm a launch date and time, if need be. If a project wishes to launch without perks, it is also advisable to let them know that they cannot add perks after the campaign is live - only Fractured Atlas staff can do so. This information needed to add a perk is below:
- Contribution Amount *(whole dollars only)* - Perk Name *(limit 30 characters)* - Nondeductible Amount *(whole dollars only)* - Perk Description *(exactly as the project would like it to appear on the campaign. limit 500 characters.)* - Number Available *(optional)* - Estimated Delivery Date *(optional)*
Publicize Your Venue's Accessibility Features

Finding space poses additional challenges for disabled artists, but if you have an accessible space, you can help make it easier by noting your accessibility features your SpaceFinder listing.
This can be done in the Accessibility section of your listing.
![a screenshot showing the accessibility menu when a venue manager edits a listing](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=719 "accessibility menu location")
## Accessibility
![Accessibility features on a SpaceFinder Listing](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=718 "Accessibility Features in Detail")
If your space is ADA or AODA compliant, you can check the corresponding box. - For more information on the ADA, see [ADA.gov](http://www.ada.gov/ada_intro.htm)
- And for more information on the AODA, see [Ontario.ca's website on Accessibility laws](https://www.ontario.ca/page/accessibility-laws).
You can also indicate whether or not your space has an elevator, freight elevator, is accessible without stairs, and other search filters, but we've also added a few more unique options to make your space more visible.
## Virtual Tours If you have a virtual tour of the space, be it a Youtube video, a Google 360 Degree virtual tour on Google StreetView, or something else entirely, you can add a link to this field. Listings that have a virtual tour will appear in search results when someone uses the "virtual tour provided" search filter, the tour will be linked on your listing.
You can see some examples of spaces listings with virtual tours here:
- [The Fox Theatre](http://atlanta.spacefinder.org/spaces/12038?from_search=1) - [The Abbey Pub](http://chicagospaces.fracturedatlas.org/spaces/11797) - [Alliance of Resident Theatres](http://nyc.spacefinder.org/spaces/5397?from_search=1) - [Lucid Body House](http://nyc.spacefinder.org/spaces/8279?from_search=1)
This is a great way to help give all perspective renters a better idea of your space, and it gives disabled artists a lot of helpful information on whether or not your space will work for them.
If you're interested in having a 360 Degree virtual tour of your space created, more information can be found in this article: [Marketing Your Venue's Accessibility Features with Virtual Tours](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/marketing-your-venue-s-accessibility-features-with-virtual- tours-).
## Accessibility Details Link
Some spaces have a page on their website dedicated to detailing their accessibility features. If you have such a page on your site you can add it here. Like the virtual tour, this will link out from your listing. Here are some examples of listings with links to their website's accessibility details.
- [Double Door](http://chicago.spacefinder.org/spaces/11972?from_search=1) - [Terminal West](http://atlanta.spacefinder.org/spaces/11865?from_search=1)
