Logging Matching Gifts

*This feature is available with the Campaigns Kit, which is currently in Beta. If you are interested in turning this kit on for your organization, have your Organization Administrator contact us at support@artful.ly*
A **matching gift** is a charitable gift made to an organization by a matching organization (usually an employer) once an original donor has made a gift to that specific organization. For example, some employers have matching gift programs which state that they will match any donation made by their employees do charitable organizations. (Or, in this case, Fiscally Sponsored Projects or 501(c)(3) nonprofits.)
## To log a matching gift in Artful.ly:
1. Go to the **Fundraising** menu in the top navigation bar, and select **Log Donation/Pledge** from the drop down menu. 2. Enter the information about the donor and donation amount. 3. On the right hand side of the page, select **Match Eligible.** 4. Enter the **Name** of an existing contact in your database. 5. Enter a **Ratio**. (Most of the time, this is just 1 to 1.) 6. Enter an **Amount**.
![Add matching organization information](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=721 "Add matching organization information")
Once you've saved the donation, this will be logged as a match eligible donation on the donors record, as well as on the matching organization's record.
##Track Outstanding Match Eligible Donations 1. Go to the **Fundraising** menu in the top navigation bar, and select **Outstanding Pledges**. 2. Here, you will see the list of any pledges or match eligible gifts that have not yet been received. 3. Click on the order for the matching organization's outstanding gift. 4. From the **Work with...** menu, select **Receive Pledge Payment** to confirm that your organization has the funds and log a donation on the organization's record. 5. From there, you can also schedule the payment for a future date. 6. This will mark the payment as **Paid in Full.**
![List of outstanding pledges and donations](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=722 "List of outstanding pledges and donations")
### Related Articles
Acknowledging Gifts

Donors and their gifts help keep your organization alive and thriving. When you get a new donation, you make sure to log it on the individual or organization's record in your Artful.ly database. What's the next best thing to do once you've done that? Thank the donor! It's a best practice to keep track of gifts that you've acknowledged and those that you have yet to acknowledge. That way, your staff can be up to date on who needs to be thanked for their generosity. It's possible to track acknowledgements for gifts in Artful.ly in a few different ways.
1. When adding a new donation, you can set a date that the acknowledgement was sent in the **Acknowledgement Date Sent** section, and add a **Method** for the acknowledgement. 2. For previously logged donations, find the order to **Edit** it. From there, you can set the date that the acknowledgement was sent, and add a method.
![Add acknowledgement sent date and method](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=724 "Add acknowledgement sent date and method")
## Find Unacknowledged Gifts 1. Click on the **Fundraising** menu in the top navigation bar and select **Unacknowledged Gifts**. 2. From here, you can specify a **Date** range, **Gift Type**, gifts from a certain **Campaign** or **Appeal**, or search for a specific person or company record. 3. Once you've found the gifts you're looking for, you can bulk add an acknowledged action from the **Work with...** menu, or export the list as a CSV.
![Unacknowledged gifts list](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=725 "Unacknowledged gifts list") 4. To bulk-add an acknowledgement date, click the **Work with...** button and select **Set Acknowledgement Date**. Then, enter the date and method to add a **Heard** action on each donor's record.
![Set acknowledgement date](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=726 "Set acknowledgement date")
### Related Articles - [Donations & Donation Reports](/site/knowledgebase/donations-donation-reports) - Logging Donations & Pledges - [Artful.ly Donation Management Tips](/site/knowledgebase/artful-ly-donation-management-tips)
Your Mac Computer

### Your Mac Computer
**Big Picture **
The reason Fractured Atlas is making the transition to laptops is to give more flexibility in how and where we work. Want to collaborate with someone on the other side of the office? Just move on over to sit with them. Have a video conference meeting but it’s noisy by your desk? Now you can move somewhere quieter. The HVAC unit in part of the floor doesn’t work? Now you can move to somewhere cooler (although let’s cross our fingers that this will not be an issue).
**Security Checks**
Since it’s relatively easy for laptops to grow legs and walk away, we are instituting a few new security checks to insure that all of our machines are protected and can be remotely wiped in the unfortunate event of a theft. We will hold quarterly one-on-one security checks where each of us will demonstrate that all of the mandatory security precautions are installed and activated on our laptop. Don’t fret, these security checks aren’t opportunities for someone else to read our emails, look through our browser history, or sift through files. They’re merely a time for you to quickly show that the five or so items on our security list are in place—password, check; back-up turned on, check; etc.
**Taking them on a field trip**
Like many of us, laptops love to travel. For now though, all laptops should stay in the Fractured Atlas office. After we get everyone up-and-running, we’ll move to evaluating what’s needed for laptops to leave the office.
**Can I use this laptop for personal things?**
These are work computers, so treat them as such. This shouldn’t change all that much from your current workflow.
**Oops!**
If your laptop is acting up or if it was dropped (or spilled on), contact itadmin@fracturedatlas.org so that a plan can be worked out to get any repairs done.
**Lost or Stolen?**
If you suspect your laptop is lost or has been stolen, email itadmin@fracturedatlas.org as soon as possible. This notifies Nicola and Shawn so they can start the process of tracking it down or remotely wiping the machine.
**Are you my laptop?**
We recognize that working in an office where everyone is using exactly the same laptop might lead to confusion about whose machine is whose. All the laptops will have a label with an ID number. If you can’t tell if a laptop is yours, either take a look at that number or open it up to see if the sign in is for your name. The mice and keyboards given to you will also have labels with this ID.
**But I want that case with the fun bedazzlement!**
We’ll be providing simple cases that do the job. If you want something extra you are totally free to buy something as long as it sufficiently protects the machine.
Advanced Search Conditions Glossary

There's a lot of advanced search conditions, so feel free to use this list as crib notes to get you started.
| Condition | Searches | |--------------------- |------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | | Action | Allows you to search for heard, said, went, helped, gave, and bought actions. You can also narrow this to a particular date range. | | Birthday | Searches for birthdays by month, day, and year. | | Email | Limits your search for people who either have or do not have an email address. | | Donation | Searches for contributions. You can define a minimum and maximum contribution amount, as well as a date range. | | Events | Searches for people who have bought tickets. You can limit this search to specific events and date ranges. | | Keyword | Looks for keywords that you define. You have the option to search the action feed, or in notes you've made on people records. | | Location | Find people by their addresses. You can search by city, state, zip code, and country. | | Mailchimp List | Finds particular people subscribed to one of your MailChimp lists. The MailChimp Kit must be activated. | | Mailchimp Group | Looks for people based on the MailChimp group you've added them to. The MailChimp Kit must be activated. | | Membership Start Date | Search for people by when their memberships began. You can define a date range here. The Memberships Kit must be activated. | | Membership End Date | The same as above, but instead you're searching for when someone's membership ends. The Memberships Kit must be activated. | | Membership Status | Find members who are current members, lapsed, past or expired. The Memberships Kit must be activated. | | Orders: Discounts | Look for orders where a particular discount code was or wasn't used. | | Orders | Search for orders within a date range. | | Passes: Type | Find everyone who holds a pass type. The Passes Kit must be activated. | | Record Type | Limit your search to individuals, all company types (business, foundation, government, nonprofit, or other) | | Relationships | Find people who have a specific type of relationship (parent, board, representative, etc.). The Relationships Kit must be activated. | | Segment | Search within your list segments. Searching within your searches. | | Tags | Only surface the records that have a particular tag. | | Total Revenue Value | This condition combines all of the revenue categories, rather than searching by donations and other orders separately. |

Recipe for new SpaceFinder instance

This internal support article outlines the coordinated steps between the programs team and the development team to get a new regionally instance live on the SpaceFinder network.
SpaceFinder program team create/collect and provide:
1. Create header logo image (use Illustrator source file and customize region) for the new Instance and add this file to the pivotal story. The logo should be in png format, transparent background, and at lease 200px in height.
2. Create new reports in Restful Metircs, and provide keys for the following reports: “[InstanceName]_Accounts”, “[InstanceName]_DataCollection”, “[InstanceName]_SearchTrends”
3. Create new property under Fractured Atlas Google Analytics account, and provide google analytics tracking code for: “google_analytics”, “google_verification”
4. Determine primary domain and any vanity redirects (example: mass.spacefinder.org is primary, while SpaceFinderMass.com and SpaceFinderBoston.org redirect)
5. Research location customization and provide excel spreadsheet of zipcodes [example here](https://spacefinder.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/200229429-Location-Search-by-Neighborhood)
Developer needs to:
In an image editing program (I use Sketch), you’ll need to create two images for the new instance (use the images for the existing instances in assets/images/themes/ as a guide.
logo.png (transparent background, height: 98px, you will likely need to add additional transparent space around the logo to make it match the others) email_header.gif (white background, dimensions: 550px by 91px, use other images as a guide for the amount of whitespace around the logo)
These should go inside a folder named for the instance in ‘themes/‘
SpaceFinder Code Changes
- add new instance specifications to config.yml (you can use the standard domain structure for the ‘restful_metrics_domain’ unless the stakeholder specifies otherwise) - the secure domain deviates from the pattern of most preferred domains. It will likely be something like: 'spacefindernashville.fracturedatlas.org'. - add new instance to copycoptor.yml - create migration for new instance - create migration for new domain - create stylesheets/instances/application_[instance_name].sass
Checklist Canadian Instances: - in config.yml, currency should be 'cad' - look up the timezone and use the province abbreviation for the 'state' attribute - set config.ml, metric_system should be true
White Label: add '@import whitelabel_sso' to the stylesheet for the instance
Coming Soon: If you set this to true, when the user selects the instance from the search dropdown, they will be re-directed to the home page (rather than a search of the spaces in the instance)

Processing donation and grant payments to the Fractured Atlas General Fund

The following instruction outline how to process various types of donations for the Fractured Atlas general fund.
- **Check:** Checks should be made payable to Fractured Atlas and mailed to our New York City office. Typically, they will come from institutional funders as well as individual donors. To process a check, head to the *Donors* tab and click *Record Donation*. Most likely, the donor will exist in the database, but can be added then, if necessary, using the processing form. Fill out all of the contact info (if it does not auto-populate) and donation details, and make sure that a project is NOT selected for the fiscal sponsorship field. If there is an associated grant in the tracker, make sure to select it, and add any necessary soft credits. Also, make sure you add information in the memo as to the reason for the gift (for example: "stARTup Party 2015" or "2014 End of Year Appeal"). You can leave *Send Receipt* checked, since that only sends a receipt to staff. Hit *Record Donation* when you're done.
- **ACH:** Payments from governmental and institutional funders will often arrive via ACH (Automated Clearing House). Sometimes, they are referred to as electronic funds transfers or wire transfers. The finance team will alert development and fiscal sponsorship to the arrival of an ACH transfer, and ask that it be identified and processed. They will send the amount and name of the transferring entity, and it's up to fiscal sponsorship and development to determine who the funds are for (a project or the general fund) and which grant in the tracker should be associated with the funds. Once it is determined what the funds are, it should be processed in the same manner as a check, with the exception of a check number. After an ACH transfer is processed, the finance team needs to be altered with the donation ID so that they can manually deposit it into Quickbooks.
- **Stock:** For a stock donation, the donor will need to get in touch directly with the development staff to request brokerage information.
Employer Match Employer matches help you give even more to Fractured Atlas. Click here and select the company match option when you fill out your contribution details.
Honorary or Memorial Gift Contact the Development Department at support@fracturedatlas.org or (888) 692-7878 to discuss your gift and provide instructions for notifying the honoree or their family.
Planned Gift Consider including Fractured Atlas in your estate plans. Contact Director of Development Marie-Louise Stegall at support@fracturedatlas.org or (888) 692-7878.

Donation Reports 2.0

This article covers how you retrieve donor information once it's in Artful.ly. For information on how your audience can make online donations, and how you can bring your donation history into Artful.ly check out these support articles:
- [How can my fans make online donations?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/how-can-my-fans-make-online-donations) - [Donation Imports](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/importing-donations) (For 501(c)(3) organizations) - [Converting a Ticket to a Donation](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/converting-a-ticket-order-into-a-donation) (For 501(c)(3) organizations) - [Donations to Fiscally Sponsored Projects](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/donations-to-fiscally-sponsored-projects)
Once you have donations in your Artful.ly there are a number of ways you can find your donations, gain new insights about your donor base, and work with that information.
## Donation Alerts
There are a couple ways that you can ensure you and your colleagues are notified when your organization receives a donation via Artful.ly.
- [Daily Sales Reports](/site/knowledgebase/daily-sales-report) are sent to the Organization Administrator and whomever else is listed as a recipient. This is a summary of all orders and donations made to your organization for the day. - Email alerts when a donation is made. From your **Account Administration** page under **Users**, the Organization Administrator can select who should receive an email notification when a patron donates to your organization. Read [Adding Users & Managing User Permissions](/site/knowledgebase/adding-users-managing-user-permissions-) for more detailed instructions.
## Advanced Search Searching for your donors through Advanced Search lets you looking for donors in combination with other useful information, like actions, ticket purchases, membership status, tags, and a whole lot more. Here's where you'll find out a lot more about your audience.
Advanced search is found in the people menu.
![A close up view of the people menu with an arrow pointing to Advanced Search](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=767 "advanced search")
From there you can build an advanced search for your desired donor search. ![An example of an advanced search for donations between 26 and 78 dollars](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=765 "Advanced Search for Donations") For more information on building your advanced searches check out these articles:
- [Advanced Search]() - [Advanced Search glossary of terms]()
## Donation Reports Donation reports can get you a list of anyone who has donated during a certain time period, along with their order numbers and links to their order details.
This is often more convenient than an advanced search for when you just need everyone who's donated you in a certain time period. For example, order reports are very useful when you want to pull all donations from the last month so you can send out acknowledgment letters and tax receipts.
Donation reports can be found in the orders menu at the top of Artful.ly. Date ranges can be specified, and by using the work with button, you can export your report as a CSV to work with in another application.
![The donation reports page with an arrow pointing to where to find donation reports in the Orders menu](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=764 "donation reports")
## Exporting All Donations Sometimes you just need everything all at once. That's what exporting your donation list is for. Exporting all donations gives you essentially the same information as a donations report, but instead of a specific time period, you get every donation logged in your Artful.ly account.
![Export all donations option](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=766 "export donations")

Using Multiple Passes on an Order

Article content should be added to "How Fans Buy and Apply Passes"
Events are social experiences, and it's likely the majority of your tickets are purchased in at least sets of two. So, if a fan buys two passes, she can use both passes in the same order when buying tickets.
![An example of an order confirmation with two pass codes]( "two passcode confirmation email")
All she has to do is add tickets to the cart and each pass code in the pass or discount code individually. Each code will appear as a line item in the left hand side.
![An example of two pass codes applied to an order]("multiple pass codes on an order")
**Note: Multiple pass codes may be applied to an order, but only one discount code per order is allowed.**
Pass codes may also be applied in the widget, but the passes must be sold through the passes storefront, first.
![Pass codes being applied in the widget]( "pass codes in widget")
Company Holidays

![Out Of Office written in the beach sand](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=781 "Out of Office")
### Fractured Atlas staff are eligible for 11 paid company holidays each year in which the office is closed for business (all federal holidays plus the day after Thanksgiving).
If a company holiday falls on a Saturday, the preceding Friday will be observed as the holiday. If a company holiday falls on a Sunday, the following Monday will be observed as the holiday.
### The 11 holidays are as follows:
* New Year's Day (January 1) * Martin Luther King, Jr's Birthday * Presidents' Day * Memorial Day * Independence Day (July 4th) * Labor Day * Columbus Day * Veterans Day * Thanksgiving Day * The day after Thanksgiving * Christmas Day (December 25)
### The following days are 1/2 days:
* Thanksgiving Day Eve * Christmas Eve * New Year's Eve
In addition to these days, the office will close on **Federal Election Days** so you can take time to get to the voting polls.
## Company Holiday Tips
- Remember to [update your Help Desk status](/admin/Knowledgebase/view_article?id=537) as "out of office/gone fishin" - Remember to update your voicemail with an away message - Zimbra calendar does not include company holidays as default, add these dates to your calendar as 'out of office' as needed

As a venue, should I be requiring liability insurance from my renters?

Renting out your venue space carries unique, associated risks and exposures. To limit these risks, you may consider requiring your renters to carry insurance:
**General liability insurance** covers damage to locations and injury to bystanders. This coverage is available on an annual and short-term basis, to fit your renters' needs.
**Why do certain venues require it from renters?**
Venues will often require proof of insurance from renters to confirm that they have coverage in place. You may also consider asking to be listed as an Additional Insured entity for the risks and exposures related to a renter’s operations; this means that their insurance comes into play before any your venue carries.
**Why do some venues offer a master plan for their renters?**
Venues can offer a TULIP (Tenant/Users Liability Insurance Protection) plan, which allows all renters to be covered under the venue's insurance policy. This type of policy can keep renter claims separate from the venue's, while making sure that everyone can be covered. Venues can offer to include the renter as insured under a TULIP policy for an additional fee or include the cost in the rental charges.
**What exactly does a Certificate of Insurance (COI) from a renter cover?**
A Certificate of Insurance is the document that provides proof of insurance, listing the venue as either Certificate Holder or Additional Insured (if this was requested).
**Additional insurance help:**
[Fractured Atlas](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/about/): Fractured Atlas, the non-profit technology company that powers SpaceFinder, also helps the creative sector by offering affordable business insurance for the arts. In addition to being brokers for insurance, our friendly staff also come from artistic backgrounds, so they get both sides. Fractured Atlas has helped over 15,000 creative projects secure insurance. Depending on what else is involved in renting out your venue space, you may consider requiring other insurance types, which we can also help out with. For more info please visit our main [Insurance Program page](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/liability/).
**Note:**
Fractured Atlas can only secure insurance for groups based in the US with US tax IDs.
**Canadian-based insurance help:**
Many Canadian venues who require liability insurance work with their own preferred insurance providers, so start by asking a venue directly about options. Otherwise the Insurance Bureau of Canada is a general resource.
Processing Matching Gifts

### Processing Matching Gifts
Usually a matching gift requires the donor and Fractured Atlas staff to fill out the same form to process a gift but the procedure is always dictated by the corporation that operates the program. Employees always have to initiate the gift. FA must receive a donation from the donor prior to completing any matching gift forms. Once the donor has reported a donation to their company, a Fractured Atlas staff member will: 1. Complete any paperwork required by the company to confirm the donation or confirm the donation online 2. Set up a grant in the grant tracker 3. Save Paperwork in the grant tracker
**Entering the match into the grant tracker** 1. Find the corporation providing the match in the admin panel. If one doesn't exist, create a New Prospect (under the "Donors" tab) 2. Navigate to the corporation's "Donations" tab 3. Click "Log new grant application" 4. Title the grant application "Match for [DONOR NAME], [DONATION DATE] 5. In the "Fiscal Sponsee" field, select the project that the original application was intended for 6. Complete the rest of the form with relevant information 7. The "Ask Amount" will be the donation amount confirmed (tax-deductible portion of any partially-deductible gifts) 8. Select "Matched Original Confirmed" from the Status dropdown menu
**Processing the matching gift payment** When matching donation checks arrive at our office, they must be manually processed through the record donation page.
To process the transaction: 1. Find the grant application in the grant tracker that correlates with this matching gift and enter the amount of the donation in the "Award Amount" field 2. Navigate to the Record Donations page under the "Donors" heading in the admin panel 3. In the "Existing Donor" field, type the name of the company that is providing the match (i.e., Microsoft, Google, etc.), the company's contact information should auto-populate 4. In the "Optional Soft Credit" field, select the donor who gave the original donation 5. Enter the match amount 6. Enter the name of the fiscally sponsored project that received the original donation and is listed in the grant tracker 7. Make sure "Check" is selected as the type of donation 8. Enter the check number (if this is an ACH transfer, enter "ACH transfer" in the check number field) 9. Select the grant application from the grant application dropdown menu 10. Enter "Matching gift from [DONOR NAME] on [DONATION DATE]" in the memo field 11. Unclick, "Send Receipt?" We do not issue receipts for matching gifts 12. Click "Record Donation"
**Now what? Send an email!** We'll need to notify the member about the donation. Send an email to the member alerting them to the gift: there is boilerplate email text for this connected to the F.S. Matching Gift tag.
**There's more?** Sometimes a company will send multiple gift matches for multiple projects in one check. The processing procedure is the same, but run each contribution as a separate one for each match amount. Scan check and save to donor folder noting each project donated to. Put a note on the check with donation IDs for each match amount to alert whoever is doing a QB deposit that the check was run as multiple transactions.
Donor-Advised Fund Procedure

### Donor-Advised Fund Procedure
A donor advised fund gift is unique because we are legally barred from issuing a receipt for the gift - this is because donor-advised funds get one receipt for the total amount granted out each year by the organization that manages the fund. Donations of this kind are usually sent directly to FA with a letter designating the gift for a specific project. Therefore, the project does not need to report the donation before it arrives in our office.
The project name on this letter must match the project name in our database. If the project name does not match, alert the project and ask them to contact the donor to request the donor advised fund send a corrected letter.
**To process the transaction:** 1. Navigate to the Record Donations page under the "Donors" heading in the admin panel 2. In the "Existing Donor" field, type the name of the company that is providing the match (i.e., Fidelity, Schwab etc.), the company's contact information should auto-populate 3. In the "Optional Soft Credit" field, enter the individual or fund that gave the original donation (if a donor record does not exist for this donor, create a New Prospect under "Donors" for the individual/fund giving the donation 4. Enter the donation amount 5. Enter the name of the fiscally sponsored project that is listed on the gift letter 6. Make sure "Check" is selected as the type of donation 7. Upload the gift letter send with the check as the "Major Gift Letter" 8. Enter the check number (if this is an ACH transfer, enter "ACH transfer" in the check number field) 9. Enter "Donor-advised fund from [DONOR NAME]" in the memo field 10. Unclick, "Send Receipt?" We do not issue receipts for donor-advised funds 11. Click "Record Donation"
Email the member once the donation has been processed alerting them to the gift. There is boilerplate email text for this attached to the f.s. donor advised fund tag.
**What if the letter does not indicate a specific project?** It is possible that this donation is for Fractured Atlas, but also very likely that the donor did not list the intended project on the letter. In these cases, look in the admin panel to see if the donor exists and has given previously. If we have contact information for the donor, call them to determine if the donation was to be recommended for a specific project. If we do not have contact information for the donor, Google them to see if you can find a phone number for them. If we can find contact information doing a web search, call the donor. If you have searched and searched, but still cannot find contact information for the donor, give the check to the Development Associate.
Tips When Moving from Paper Calendar to Digital Calendar

Moving from paper calendar to a digital calendar is certainly a shift, yet one with many benefits. We recommend using [Google calendar](https://www.google.com/calendar ) as it is free, and integrates with everything from smart phones to SpaceFinder! Some of the largest and most grand venues use Google calendar to manage rentals, so don't feel pressured to build a custom software solution for calendar.
## Here are a few things to keep in mind when preparing to make the switch:
### Start with an open discussion among your staff, ask yourselves:
- How often do we have to tell someone a space is not available? - How much email goes back and forth over availability? - How much of our space goes unrented? - Do we have staff that need to collaborate on managing rentals? - Do we have high turnover in the position that manages rentals? - Do we have staff that feel confidant about working with a digital calendar? - Do we often have double booking or confusion around rental times? - What is our marketing budget to bring new renters in? - How can being transparent about availability externally help us attract renters? - How can being transparent about availability internally help us coordinate?
### Create Google Calendar account and keep in mind:
- Create a calendar for each unique space within your venue that you would like to rent - Title each calendar clearly (no abbreviations, it will help you keep track) - Consider how color coding of events on the calendar will be most useful to you - Create test events on your calendar, play and learn BEFORE migrating all of your paper calendar bookings into Google. - Consider who should have edit permissions to the calendar, and who should only be able to view, share accordingly
Some final words of encouragement...Youtube is filled with helpful tutorials on getting started with Google Calendar, so we won't repeat any of that here. Fractured Atlas's SpaceFinder program has worked with hundreds of venues on marketing their rentals. We've even helped church groups move from paper calendar to Google calendar, and it increased their bookings on SpaceFinder by 50%. We won't say it's easy, no change is completely friction free, but we can say it is a game-changer and we encourage you to take that step. Good luck!
### Leave Behind Paper Calendar Chaos & Embrace Calendar Transparency
![ECalendarChaos](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=797 "CalendarChaos")
### Related Articles - [Share My Calendar Features & Benefits](/site/knowledgebase/share-my-calendar-features-and-benefits) - [3 Steps to Uploading Your Calendar](/site/knowledgebase/3-steps-to-uploading-your-calendar) - [Google: Finding Your Calendar Feed](/site/knowledgebase/google-finding-your-calendar-feed-)
Adding Images to Records

It's possible to add images to records in your database either by uploading an image, or using the Gravatar associated with the person or company's email address. If the person has not established Gravatar image with their email address, it's easy to add a new image.
1. View the record and select the **Work with...** button to **Edit** the record's info. 2. View the **Image** section and click on **Choose File** to upload a new photograph.
![Upload an image to a record modal](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=801 "Upload an image to a record modal")
**Images should be:** - No larger than 1 MB - Of equal height and width - At least 200 pixels x 200 pixels - .jpg, .jpeg, .gif, or .png

Intercom Formatting Guidelines and Best Practices

### Formating
**Header:**
SpaceFinder header logo is regionally branded, left aligned, and linked (but not campaign coded)
**Links:**
Use toronto.spacefinder.org as linking convention (rather than spacefindertoronto.org). This makes it easier to duplicate a message and customize for regional branding)
Always default to sending users to directory landing page, i.e. toronto.spacefinder.org/spaces rather than just toronto.spacefinder.org which is a welcome page
**Coded links: ** Only campaign code 'calls to action' (usually created as buttons) to measure click thrus on messages.
**Campaign code convention: ** Keep the source and medium consistent, and update the name as needed:
&utm_source=Intercom&utm_medium=Email&utm_campaign=RenterEdu1
&utm_source=Intercom&utm_medium=Email&utm_campaign=RenterEdu2
&utm_source=Intercom&utm_medium=Email&utm_campaign=RenterEdu3
**Images:**
In general, do not link images that are not calls to action, instead use the button convention. Use fun images, make sure we have proper usage rights and credit the image.
**Signature:**
Do not sign intercom message as personal messages, i.e. "Sincerely, SpaceFinder team"
**Footer: ** "SpaceFinder is a program of Fractured Atlas" (link to spacefinder.org and fracturedatlas.org/site/about)
**Regional Partner Credits (optional): ** Option 1: "SpaceFinder X is made possible by X, and X" (link to individual websites) Option 2: 1 image made from all partner logos (link to Community Partnerships page)
### Approval
Send a test email to someone other than yourself before setting live.
When working with regional partners, sending them a 'last looks' email is not required but is an appreciated courtesy (especially in Canada when there might be a better way to word something with such a different audience).

Deceased Patrons

When one of your supporters passes away, it's important to note it in your database so that you no longer send them mail and emails.
## To mark an individual as deceased:
1. View their record and select **Work with...** 2. Click on **Edit** to view their information and go to the **Attributes** section. 3. Check the box next to **Deceased**.
![Check deceased box to mark patron as deceased](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=811 "Check deceased box to mark patron as deceased")
## When a patron is marked as deceased: - The front page of her record will be prominently marked "Deceased" - The Do Not Call and Do Not Email checkboxes will automatically be checked. (You can uncheck them if you wish.) - If the individual was a member of a household, she will be marked as deceased in the household view too. - When you export any list of people, her record will be marked in the deceased column. (You can also import records and mark individuals as deceased.) - When you use Advanced Search, you can choose to include or exclude deceased patrons in your search.
At this time, marking a patron deceased does NOT unsubscribe them from any MailChimp lists. You can do this manually for now and we'll work on including that automation in our next MailChimp upgrade.
Completing a Feature Request

### Delivering Initial Requirements 1. Work with stakeholder(s) to come to an understanding of the story requirements 2. Estimate the story 3. Click "Start" on the story 4. When you are ready to have your changes reviewed by the stakeholder(s) create a pull request 5. Complete code review process 6. Go to Heroku and create a review app ([See Heroku docs](https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/github-integration-review-apps)) 7. Remove the Heroku Postgres add-on 8. Add ClearDB add-on, if you need a DB bigger than 5MB ask an FA admin to upgrade the DB 9. Confirm that that your changes are all working as expected 10. Deliver the story, provide a link to the review app in the comments 11. Work with stakeholder(s) to complete any required modifications until the story is accepted
**Do not close your pull request, doing so will destroy your review app**
### Deploying to Production 1. If necessary, complete another code review 2. Work with stakeholder(s) to schedule the deployment 3. As you approach the scheduled deployment date/time merge your pull request 4. Monitor the build and confirm that your changes have been deployed to staging 5. Click through staging, confirm that the application is functioning properly 6. Promote to production from the Heroku Pipeline Dashboard
Logging onto Medium

Signing into Medium with an email requires a [two-step verification system](https://help.medium.com/hc/en-us/articles/213531928-Sign-in-by-email)—meaning that once you enter your email address, Medium sends a link to that address in order to sign-in. This should not be a problem for your individual @fracturedatlas.org accounts.
Here is how you can sign-in to the main Fractured Atlas Medium account:
- Enter this email address: **media@fracturedatlas.org**. - This email address is a distribution list. Ask one of these staff members to forward you the verification link: - Adam Huttler - Jason Tseng - Juliana Steele - Do not log out unless you need to use your personal Medium account (which you would only use to write a Thought Piece, for instance). Medium will keep you logged in, so you will not have to use the two-step process every time you go onto the site.
Writing and Formatting Blogs Posts on Medium

### Content
- **Updates.** For quick posts about upcoming deadlines, webinars, job openings, or announcements. These articles do not include an author’s name, but are published under the Fractured Atlas header. Examples include: - Upcoming Grant Deadlines. - Upcoming Webinars. - Job Postings. - Events. - Open Calls. - Any other announcements. - **Information/Educational Resources.** These articles range from general tips and tools for the field to our GIF-laced lists to project round-ups. Author's name is included in these articles. The content focuses on sharing resources or tools, like in these examples: - Tips and Tools. - Fractured Atlas Book Club. - Meet the Project/Meet the Member. - Techtool Tuesday. - Listicals. - **Big Idea/Thought Pieces.** Adam’s forte. These longer articles provide food for thought, personal opinion, analysis of pressing issues in the field. Content can be one-off essays or a series of essays. Bid Idea essays are published under the individual's Medium account. These articles can be written by any staff member, and many are provided by the Executive Director, Deputy Director, and the Arts & Technology Policy Fellow. Some past examples: - Copyright with Courtney. - Fractured Atlas as a Learning Organization. - New Models Redux.
### Format & Templates
To keep the content types clear on the Fractured Atlas Medium pag, there are recommended templates for each type of post. Sample templates are provided below, explaining authorship and layout:
- **Updates.** Check out the [Updates and Announcements Style Template](https://medium.com/@fracturedatlas/fractured-atlas-updates-and-announcement-style-guide-12a78b4739c8#.wtud1qlt6) on Medium. - No author information (published by Fractured Atlas). - Bold titles of webinars, grants, events, etc. - **Information/Educational Resources.** Check out the [Informational/Educational Post Style Template](https://medium.com/@fracturedatlas/fractured-atlas-informational-educational-posts-style-guide-4f2e0dad87bb#.wg2q0lp60) on Medium. - Include author information (still published by Fractured Atlas). - Use headers (instead of bolding). - Embed picture or videos (don't forget to credit!). - Highlight quotes (hit " once). - Add pull quotes (hit " twice). - **Big Idea/Thought Pieces.** Also check out the [Thought Piece Style Template](https://medium.com/@fracturedatlas/fractured-atlas-thought-piece-style-guide-230e60c2579b#.rtyocqgrt) on Medium. - Publish on your own Medium account, and Fractured Atlas will share it. - Open with a big, beautiful picture (and credit it). - Use headers (instead of bolding). - Embed pictures or videos. - Highlight quotes (hit " once). - Add pull quotes (hit " twice).
Medium also has a useful [knowledge base](https://help.medium.com/hc/en-us) to help guide you through their interface.
### Tags
Tags are a way of organizing and discovering content on Medium. When a post is published, you can add up to three tags to help categorize your content (Medium will also try to suggest relevant tags). Read more about it on [Medium](https://help.medium.com/hc/en-us/articles/215252438-Tags), or review sample tags based on content:
- **Updates.** - Crowdfunding. - Event. - Fiscal Sponsorship. - Grants. - Webinar. - **Information/Educational Resources.** - Book Review. - Fundraising. - Nonprofit. - Resources. - Startup. - Tech. - Tips and Tools. - **Big Idea/Thought Pieces.** - Advocacy. - Big Idea. - Copyright. - Creativity. - Entrepreneurship. - Innovation. - Technology.
How to submit your post to the Fractured Atlas publication

Once you have written a final draft your post on Medium (either on the @FracturedAtlas handle or on your own handle, depending on the content type) and are ready to submit it for review, you'll need to add it to the Fractured Atlas publication on medium.
To do this, simply click on the "..." button in the top nav bar of your post while in draft mode and select "Add to publication." (_Note: if you are writing from your own handle and do not see this option, it might be because you have not been added as a writer to the Fractured Atlas publication. Ask an editor to add you as a writer_)
Select the "Fractured Atlas Blog" option and select "Submit Draft for Review."
The editors of the Fractured Atlas publication will be notified that you have submitted an article for review and they will schedule it for publishing according to when it has been scheduled on the Communications Calendar.
See this post by Medium for more info about [Submitting and Requesting Stories for a Publication](https://medium.com/the-story/submitting-a-story-to-a-publication-d234638b3577#.adqg03q14).
How to request to add a Medium post to the Fractured Atlas publication

Simply navigate to the published story you would like to request and click the "..." button in the lower right corner of the post.
Choose "Request a Story." This will bring up an e-mail form that will be automatically sent to the author. You can edit the copy of the body of the message and include your e-mail address if you desire.
Read more about [submitting and requesting stories to a publication](https://medium.com/the-story/submitting-a-story-to-a-publication-d234638b3577#.adqg03q14).
How to include a story in the Fractured Atlas publication as an editor

If you are an editor of the Fractured Atlas publication, go to the publication page and click on the drop down arrow at the top of the page, and select "Submissions."
Here you will see all the stories that have been submitted to the Fractured Atlas publication. If you want to publish a draft or story that has been submitted to you, simply click on the story and select the edit button at the top of the story. Then scroll to the bottom of the page and select the "..." button, and then select the "Add to Publication" option, and choose the Fractured Atlas publication.
If you would like to schedule this draft to publish on the Fractured Atlas blog at a future date you can do so by clicking the "Publish" button while in edit mode at the top of the story, and selecting the "Schedule to Publish" option. This will open up a dialog box that will allow you to select a date and time for the story to be published on your publication. More on that [HERE](https://help.medium.com/hc/en-us/articles/216650227-Schedule-to-publish).
Is someone wants to submit a story to Fractured Atlas but they have not been made a "writer" on the Fractured Atlas publication, you can find more info on how to add them as a writer [HERE](https://help.medium.com/hc/en-us/articles/214878078-Manage-editors-and-writers). See this [Medium post](https://help.medium.com/hc/en-us/articles/213796358-How-do-I-include-a-story-in-a-publication-).
Sponsorship Confirmation Letters

The fiscal sponsorship team frequently receives requests to send letters of confirmation on behalf of fiscally sponsored project. These letters confirm that a project is fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas. Most often, these are requested by funders, or sometimes by vendors or service providers that seek to confirm that an organization is operating under a non-profit fiscal sponsor.
When the request is received, it's first important to confirm the following with the project (if they don't do so in their initial e-mail):
1. The name of the person or organization requesting the letter 2. Their mailing address 3. If it's a business, the contact person there (if there is one) 4. Any additional information the requester might need (Fractured Atlas's EIN, IRS Determination Letter, etc) 5. Why this information is being requested at this time
It's especially important to clarify this last point, so we can be sure to only issue letters like this in instances where it's appropriate to do so, and so we can tailor any language to the needs of the request.
Once the above is confirmed, you can put together a letter using the template in the Shared Drive (Fiscal Sponsorship > Sponsorship Letters). Complete the letter and PDF it, and then you can send it to the project to pass along to the person or business requesting the information.
Donation Receipts

### Donation Receipts Fractured Atlas issues tax receipt for all donations processed for the purposes of our fiscally sponsored projects, unless they are [donor-advised](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/admin/Knowledgebase/view_article?id=695) or [matching gifts](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/admin/Knowledgebase/view_article?id=694). **Check or Wire Donations** 1. We will email a receipt to the project for which the gift was recommended. 2. If the check is $1,000 or more, we will mail a paper copy. Development takes care of mailing these receipts along with a thank you note. 3. If the check is $250 or more, the Membership Associate will mail a paper copy. We do not share this information with our projects. 4. If the check is $75 or more and is partially tax-deductible, the Membership Associate will mail a paper receipt. We do not share this information with our projects. **Online Donations** 1. We will email a receipt to every donor who contributes online. They will be required to provide their email addresses at the time the donation is made. 2. We will email a receipt to every project when they receive online donations. 3. Development will mail a paper receipt for all online contributions of $1,000 or more. All donation receipts can be downloaded from a project's Donation History on their My Fiscal Sponsorship page. _Note:_ We always recommend that projects forward receipts on to their donors. If a project calls asking about a receipt, please suggest that they download it from their Donation History and send it along to their donors directly.
Staff Donation Allowance

At the start of each fiscal year, Fractured Atlas staff members are allocated an allowance to donate to fiscally sponsored projects. The amount may vary from year to year and will be announced at the beginning of each fiscal year. If you do not use the allowance by the end of the fiscal year, you lose it.
**Instructions on making a donation to a project**
1. Search for the project you would like to give to in the Fractured Atlas database. You can use this [link](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/admin/Fiscal/project_tracker?prompt=id-autocomplete). 2. On the fiscal sponsorship tab of the project you would like to give to, click on the yellow star icon next to the project name at the top of the page. 3. Enter in the amount of the donation you would like to make and click donate. (This will both trigger an email notification to the project and add your name to their Supporters list on their fiscal sponsorship page - see examples below) 4. Email the project and let them know you made a donation. 5. Share your donation on social media and tag the project or member.
**Guidelines for making donations**
- Fractured Atlas requests you do not publicly share that these are funds from Fractured Atlas, but rather from you. - Each donation will be made under your name and Fractured Atlas may promote your donations. - Please do not donate to a project that you lead. - Please give at least $5 each time you give. - You can also choose to give your entire allowance to one project. - Your "donations" tab on your staff member record in the Fractured Atlas database should be marked as "no" next to the question "Anonymous".
**Tips for finding projects to donate to**
- Read the project of the month blog on Fractured Atlas's website. - Search for projects in your geographic area. You can search on our website by state and discipline [here](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/browse_projects). Or you can search in our database [here](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/admin/Fiscal/project_tracker?prompt=id-autocomplete) by metro area, discipline and a number of other filters. - Make notes at the staff meetings about projects that are shared each month. - Ask fiscal sponsorship staff members if they know of any projects that are doing something really interesting, have an active crowdfunding campaign, or the members are people that are really nice to work with. - Look at who other staff members are giving to. - Look at the "[Meet our Sponsored Projects](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/meet_projects)" page - it changes everyday.

Fractured Atlas 401K Plan

### 401(k) Retirement Plan
**Welcome to the wonderful world of long-term financial planning!**
Fractured Atlas employees are eligible to participate in the company's 401(k) plan upon hire. The 401(k) plan is administered by BPAS in partnership with Ritholtz Financial Management. The plan is fully vested immediately - there is no waiting period.
### Traditional vs. Roth
You may contribute to either a Traditional 401(k) (pre-tax, but taxed upon withdrawal) or a Roth 401(k) (post-tax, but tax-free upon withdrawal) or both. Fractured Atlas sets no limits on the amount you may contribute, but the IRS does set a maximum annual amount.
### Matching
Fractured Atlas provides limited matching for your contribution. **The first 4% that you contribute each pay period is matched 1:1.** To receive the maximum matching contribution you must contribute at least 4%. Note that the employee match will always go into the traditional 401(k); contributions to the Roth 401(k) must come from the employee.
### Getting Started and Making Changes
**Enrollment happens online.** After you're first payroll is processed (the 15th or last day of the month) you will receive a letter in the mail from BPAS, our Plan Administrators. Use the credentials you receive in this letter to log in to your "Participant Account" at **[bpas.com](http://www.bpas.com)** and fill out the online enrollment form. BPAS says it should take about 10 minutes to sign up (it's helpful if you know the details of the person you'd like to be your beneficiary, but not mandatory). Once you submit your form, your contribution and employer match will be applied to the next payroll we process.
Upon Request, the People team can mail you a Ritholtz/BPAS 401K informational package. This will have the details of our plan, all the funds/portfolios available and has some tools and templates to help with determining how much to contribute and target fund totals for people who are new to the 401K game.
There will be an annual overview presentation for staff at the beginning of each fiscal year to answer general questions and give updates on the plan.
1 to 1 meetings with our Ritholtz Financial Advisor will occur annually following the overview presentation.
Writing Feature Stories

Ideally, when a stakeholder writes a story in Tracker, it should follow this anatomy:
### Title
One sentence that describing the story. > As a [role], I want [feature], so that [benefit].
### Description
Give a little more context and definite the Acceptance Criteria.
### Acceptance Criteria
This defines exactly what should happen. Use this format: > Scenario 1: Title
> Given [context]
> And [more context]
> When [event]
> Then [outcome]
> And [another outcome]
A helpful way to think about this is
> CONTEXT + ACTION + OUTCOME = GIVEN + WHEN + THEN.

Transferring Members Between Programs

For transferring calls between programs, we provide what is called a "consultative" rather than a blind transfer. Staff members should answer as many questions as they can and then find the appropriate person to transfer the member to if it is beyond the scope of your specific expertise. You should check with the appropriate staff member before completing the transfer. If they don't answer or are unavailable, you can let the member know you are transferring them to voicemail or, if urgent, try to get another staffer to help.

**Artful.ly:**
• General Demo & Questions - Marcus & Alessandra • Selling Memberships & Passes - Marcus • Chargebacks - Alessandra • EFT Sign Up Form - Marcus and Alessandra (may alternate monthly) • Everything Else - Marcus & Alessandra
**SpaceFinder:**
• Questions from renters- Sabrina (Further breakdown to come after program transition)
**Insurance:**
• Claims - Holly • Everything else - Any available rep.
**Fiscal Sponsorship:**
• EFT sign up forms - Aisha & Courtney • Fund release documents - Amanda • Duplicate donations - Aisha • Everything else - Any available Program Associate

![How to mute a call in Spacephone](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=845 "How to mute a call in Spacephone")
- Once confirmed, let the member know you're transferring them. With the caller on the phone, press the **transfer** button.
![How to transfer in Spacephone](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=843 "How to transfer in Spacephone")
- Select the staff member's name in the Spacephone **directory**.
![Selecting another staff member in Spacephone](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=844 "Selecting another staff member in Spacephone")
Kits

Have you ever felt overwhelmed by a pice of software that was full of features you never use? We feel you. That's why Artful.ly is built to be modular, so outside of the basic CRM and Free ticketing features, you choose which features to add. We call those sets of features *kits*, and they're activated from the Account Administration page.
![A view of all of the available kits](/site/Knowledgebase/view_image?id=848 "all available kits")
## What kits are available? - **Paid Event Ticketing** Want to add prices to your tickets? Start here. To activate the kit we need a completed [EFT form and a copy of a voided check](https://www.artful.ly/forms/artfully_etf_sign_up.pdf). - **Fiscally Sponsored Donations** Fiscally sponsored projects can link their Artful.ly account with their fiscal sponsorship, which synchronizes donor contact information and donation records into the Artful.ly CRM. Once the accounts are linked, ticket buyers also have the opportunity to add a donation at checkout. Steps to link the two accounts are in this support article: [Connect Your Sponsored Project & Artful.ly Account](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/connect-your-sponsored-project-artful-ly-account) - **501(c)(3) Donations** Organizations with their own 501(c)(3) may activate a donations kit that allows ticket buyers to add a donation at checkout, as well as set up a storefront specifically for accepting donations. This kit requires the EFT form and a copy of your IRS Determination letter. Detailed instructions are here: [Enabling Donations for 501(c)(3) Nonprofits](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/enabling-donations-for-501-c-3-nonprofits) - **MailChimp** We have an integration with MailChimp that will sync your MailChimp lists with Artful.ly and record when you send email marketing campaigns to your supporters. Plus on the MailChimp side you get access to their excellent email analytics tools. More information on MailChimp can be found in [What is MailChimp and why should I use it?](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/what-is-mailchimp-and-why-should-i-use-it) Already have a MailChimp account? Instructions to connect it to Artful.ly are here: [Connecting Your Artful.ly & MailChimp Accounts](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/connecting-your-artful-ly-mailchimp-accounts). - **Print at Home Scannable Tickets** With this kit, your ticket buyers receive a PDF with QR coded tickets whenever they make a purchase. You can scan those tickets, either printed or on customer phones using the Artful.ly check in app for iPhones and iPod touches. The app also doubles as a mobile door list. More on the kit here: [Print at Home Scannable Tickets Kit](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/print-at-home-scannable-tickets-kit) - **Passes** (in beta testing) This kit allows organizations to set up flex and season passes. Details are in the [Passes Overview](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/beta-passes-overview-activation-) - **Memberships** (in beta testing)Organizations with the Memberships kit can set up member only ticket prices and create events exclusive to members. Read more here: [Memberships Overview](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/beta-memberships-overview) - **Relationships & Households** (in beta testing) Knowing who knows who within your network is a powerful way to understand the connections between your supporters. That's where the Relationships and Households kit comes in. Learn more in: [Tracking Relationships Between Patrons](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/beta-tracking-relationships-between-patrons). - **Campaigns** (Coming Soon) When it releases, the Campaigns Kit will help with running fundraising campaigns and tracking appeals. If you're interested in beta testing the kit, add a vote to the [Campaigns Feature Request](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/feature_request_view?id=190). - **Assigned Seating** (Coming Soon) Features to sell assigned seats and hold seats. Interested in being a beta tester? Add a vote to the [Assigned Seating Feature Request](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/feature_request_view?id=311)
## What do you mean by beta? Artful.ly is in a constant state of development, and producer feedback is one of the biggest influences on how new features get made. A big part of that is our [Feature Request Forum](https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/knowledgebase/feature_request_list?topic=Artful.ly), where producers can vote on requests and suggest new ones. We do our best to take producer voters into account as much as possible when developing new features.
Before a new kit gets turned loose so anyone can turn it on, we put features through a closed beta period. Interested organizations can chat with us about whether or not the kit will meet their needs, sometimes we'll train them on how to use the features, and if it's a good fit we'll turn the kit on for them.
When a kit is in beta we consider it to be in a state where an organization can use it in their day to day, but there's the possibility that small issues can come up. When that happens, we ask beta testing organizations to reach out to us so we can confirm, and then if it's an issue, get it fixed.
Organizations that beta test help shape how kits get refined. We ask for feedback on the kits, and use it to further iterate on the new features. If you're interested in beta testing any of our kits currently in beta, let us know. We're happy to talk with you about it.

Fractured Atlas DUNS for Grant Applications
Our DUNS is 041299061.
NYSCA Application Process for Fiscally Sponsored Projects

1. Send questionnaire if project has reached eligibility requirement 2. Review Questionnaire 3. Send Registration Form 4. Add Project Contact on NYSCA.org 5. Register Project Take note of Application ID assigned to project once registered. 6. Create Grant Application in Tracker 6. Save PDF of Registration in Grant Tracker
